HEADLINE: A Rising Argument That Teaching Values Should Rank With Lessons

BYLINE: By ERIC N. BERG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BIRMINGHAM, Ala.

 BODY:
Kevin Walsh, an education professor at the University of Alabama, says that what is wrong with America's schools is not that Johnny can't do math. Johnny can do math. And he can read and write.
The problem, Professor Walsh says, is that Johnny does not write neatly or take time to punctuate properly. When Johnny works through math problems, he often races to find a solution, seizing shortcuts and bypassing critical steps that prevent errors. 
 Nor does the trouble end there, Professor Walsh says. When Johnny is asked to care for the classroom rabbit, he is delighted to play with the pet but avoids the unpleasant task of cleaning the cage. When it is time to paint, Johnny produces beautiful artwork but does not rinse his brushes and put away his paints. Hand out milk? No problem, but Johnny will not return to the cafeteria and get more milk for classmates who did not get a container.
 
Plan for Building Character
 In short, Professor Walsh says, most American schools, while working at teaching basic skills, fail to instill in children the values, morals and other positive attributes that contribute to the development of good character. Long on facts but short on the qualities that so often produce success in life, including dependability, honesty and perseverance, many children do not realize their potential, Professor Walsh says.
In extreme cases, he adds, the absence in schools of an emphasis on a child's character contributes to classroom discipline problems, truancy and juvenile delinquency.
"Our society is certainly not deteriorating because of lack of knowledge," Professor Walsh said in an interview at the School of Education here. "While we are not going to make everyone a brain surgeon, we can develop people who have positive characters and who are, therefore, valuable members of society."
Among others, who, like Professor Walsh, are talking about the importance of developing character in children are Philip Jackson, a psychology professor at the University of Chicago, William Damon, chairman of the department of education at Brown University, and Penelope Leach, who writes children's textbooks.
Character education, which some educators call "values clarification," is not new. More than a half-century ago, the educator John Dewey wrote about the importance of using schools to impart values to children. Nor is character education without risk.
"You can have disciplined slaves, but is that really what you want?" asked Mihaly Csikszentmihalyi, a professor of developmental psychology at the University of Chicago. "Discipline is not always internalized and actually can breed resentment among children."
 
View Attracts Attention
 But at a time when parents, teachers and politicians are trying to understand why the quality of the schools has slipped and are debating solutions, Professor Walsh's contention that building character may be as important as reading, writing and arithmetic is injecting a fresh note into the discussion.
"To limit education only to what is relevant is to reduce it," he said. "The purpose of education is to prepare the next generation to inherit society."
Professor Walsh's views, particularly as they relate to expecting children to behave in a respectable and responsible manner, are attracting widespread interest. Here at the University of Alabama, which has named him teacher of the year 12 times, his courses are always fully subscribed, and often oversubscribed. And nationwide scores of educational organizations have asked him to speak.
At the heart of Professor Walsh's theories is the idea that if children are equipped to exercise self-discipline, they will be well on their way to developing a strong positive character and self-esteem. The object, he says, is not to turn public schools into military academies. Rather, he advocates schools in which children respect the teacher and one another, and in which the curriculum has character development at its core.
It is not enough, for example, that a student in a large group can give the right answer to a math problem, Professor Walsh says. That student must also know to wait to be recognized before giving the answer.
Some educators and child psychologists find this emphasis on character education superficial and misplaced. A preoccupation with self-discipline, they argue, ignores the horrors of some children's homes -- divorce, sexual abuse, drug use, violence -- and the importance of attending to their emotional needs.
 
'Those Other Qualities'
 "If someone is not listening to that child's emotional concerns, the child cannot possibly begin to concentrate on developing those other qualities you call 'character,' " said Patricia Sherman, a psychologist and professor of child development at New York's Bank Street College of Education.
Ms. Sherman also said that emphasizing decorum in the classroom can stifle creativity. "Children need to be moving and exploring their world," she said. "Professor Walsh is not taking the psychological and cognitive development of children into account."
Professor Walsh responds that by developing character, children build the self-esteem that often suffers at home. "Children experience joy in finding and fulfilling responsibility," he said.
With so many single-parent homes and households with both parents working, Professor Walsh says it has fallen to schools to take on some of the responsibility of building character through discipline.
Every elementary-school classroom, he says, should have a "rules chart" and every rule should have a purpose. For example, a rule requiring students to ask the teacher's permission to leave the classroom shows students how to respect authority and how to practice patience, and a rule forbidding speaking while other students are speaking demonstrates the rules of courtesy.
He says that he also believes in posting responsibility charts to make clear to children their assigned tasks, like handing out books, feeding the fish and watering the plants.
 
Preparing for Work
 These are precisely the qualities, Professor Walsh said, that lead to success in jobs.
"The development of character is the backbone of the economic system," Professor Walsh said. "It is the fiber by which the work ethic develops."
A postal worker's son who earned his Ph.D. at the University of Pittsburgh and who served as a principal of a rural Pennsylvania school for two years, Professor Walsh has become something of a hit in his own community, Trussville, the Birmingham suburb to which he and his wife, Donna, an elementary school teacher, moved 12 years ago.
Soon after arriving, Professor Walsh was elected to the Jefferson County Board of Education, which oversees public schools in Trussville and nearby Hewitt. He has used these schools as laboratories for his ideas.
At the Hewitt-Trussville Middle School, he met with teachers and encouraged them to praise students' good behavior and to quickly and unambiguously scold their displays of bad behavior.
In an effort to teach older students that they must bear the consequences of their misdeeds, Professor Walsh introduced a rule at the Hewitt-Trusville High School that required students who were caught spray-painting graffiti on the school's exterior walls not only to pay fines but to clean up their mess. To develop students' work ethic and sense of community, he had them weed and groom a derelict baseball field.
All this character building, says Connie Williams, the high school's principal, has instilled in students a desire to do the best they can.
As a result, she said, the high school, which used to have only two sections of chemistry, now has enough students enrolled to fill 12 sections. There are two sections of honors chemistry and one advanced placement course. The foreign language department, which included instruction in French and Spanish, has been expanded to include Latin.
Nowadays, she said, "It's hard for me to imagine teaching children reading and writing without also attempting to build their character."

He is shown with pupils at the Hewitt-Trussville Elementary School, where he has introduced programs intended to build character. (Alan S. Weiner for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Accord Reached to Halt Civil War in El Salvador

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Wednesday, Jan. 1

 BODY:
The Government of El Salvador and the leftist guerrillas who have fought to overthrow it for more than a decade announced in the first minutes of the new year a comprehensive plan to end their civil war.
Their accord capped an extraordinary day and night of talks that saw the departing Secretary General of the United Nations, Javier Perez de Cuellar, postpone his retirement hour after hour to continue prodding the negotiators to settle their differences before the year ended. 
 The new year "will be the year of peace and harmony for a country very dear to you," Mr. Perez de Cuellar told the negotiators as they waited to sign the agreement in his office. Reading from its text, he said its execution would "bring a definitive end the Salvadoran armed conflict."
 
Cease-Fire on Feb. 1
 Negotiators said the summary accord they signed a few minutes after the deadline they had pledged to observe was based on a 75-page document that fell just short of the final peace treaty that they had hoped to conclude.
But leaders of both the conservative Government of President Alfredo Cristiani and the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front said that with their pledge to negotiate a schedule for the implementation of their accords by Jan. 10, they were certain that the guns of Central America's most violent conflict would finally fall silent.
They said a cease-fire would begin on Feb. 1 and continue until Oct. 31.
Thus would end a conflict that has ravaged a tiny country that has become known to world for the disparities in its distribution of wealth and the intensity with which its people have gone about killing one another.
 
75,000 Killed in Fighting
 Since the fighting began, set off by the rightist backlash to the overthrow of a military dictator by reformist officers in October 1979, it has left more than 75,000 people dead. Most of them have been civilians.
From a population that was slightly more than 5 million when the war began, more than 1 million people have been displaced from their homes or have left the country. The fighting has also battered the economy and institutions of El Salvador without respite, frustrating a $4 billion effort by the United States to defeat the rebels, revive the country and implant democracy there under strong civilian control.
 
Negotiators Embrace
 The rebel and Government negotiators, who embraced each other warmly after the signing, said that their agreements would bring about a sweeping tranformation of Salvadoran society.
"Our ten years of struggle are expressed in these accords," said Salvador Sanchez Ceren, a former teachers' union leader who commands one of the two largest rebel armies. "These are fundamental changes that are going to take place."
Mr. Sanchez and other negotiators that the agreement would sharply reduce the size of the military, purge them of abusive officers, change their military doctrine, and turn over control of public order to a new National Civil Police.
The agreement will also provide full political freedoms for former guerrilla combatants after they lay down their arms and land for peasants in rebel-held zones, the negotiators said.
 
U.N. to Verify Accords
 The terms of agreement are to be verified by the United Nations, through a contingent of special representatives in El Salvador.
The excruciating difficulty of the negotiations stemmed in large part from the fact that they became a forum in which the rebels sought many of the political and economic changes that they had failed to win on the battlefield.
In negotiating an end to the war that they had fought in the name of political and economic justice, guerrilla leaders pressed for an agreement that might recoup some of the support they lost as Salvadorans tired of the fighting. The Government, which had long sought to undercut the guerrillas' appeal with limited democratic reforms, made significant concessions to the rebels last fall but then stiffened its positions as it came under sharp criticism from conservative military officers, politicians and businessmen.
The head of Mr. Cristiani's Nationalist Republican Alliance Party, Armando Calderon Sol, agreed that the agreement would dramatically change El Salvador. But he denied that it represented a rebel victory.
"It is the Salvadoran people who are the great victors of the end to this tragic chapter in our history," he said.
Through much of the 1980's, analysts on both sides of the conflict blamed much of the bloodshed on those who helped make El Salvador a scene of superpower conflict. But it was a further reminder of the depth of the hatred and mistrust among the Salvadorans themselves that as the night dragged on, they managed to resist intense pressures for peace from a grouping of nations that would have been almost unthinkable before the end of the cold war.
 
Pressure From U.S.
 At the request of Mr. Perez de Cuellar, diplomats said, United States officials including the Assistant Secretary of State of for Inter-American Affairs, Bernard W. Aronson, spent hours at the United Nations headquarters coaxing and cajoling officials of a Government they had steadfastly supported in the war.
And for days, officials of Colombia, Venezuela, Mexico and Spain -- all countries that had criticized the United States in years past for opposing diplomatic solutions in Central America -- worked in concert in trying to soften the positions on both Salvadoran sides.
Throughout the day, United Nations officials had insisted that Mr. Perez de Cuellar would leave his offices without fail by 4:15 P.M. to catch a plane that would take him out of the city on vacation. Shortly thereafter, his wife, Marcela, arrived at United Nations headquarters, got out of a car and was overheard saying that she was going upstairs to get her husband. Instead, Mr. Perez de Cuellar came down to tell a crowd of reporters and United Nations officials who had gathered to say goodbye that he would continue his mediation for two or three hours more. And more than six hours later, he was still at work.
Diplomats involved in the talks said they had reached a deadlock in the final hours with a dispute over the terms economic and social measures in the agreement, including the terms under which the Government would distribute land to peasants in rebel-held zones.
 
Agreement on Sept. 25
 In the preliminary accords that Mr. Cristiani and the rebels signed at the United Nations on Sept. 25, they had committed themselves to broad terms under which the guerrillas would lay down their arms and return to legal politics.
The powerful armed forces were to be reduced sharply in size, purged of abusive officers and stripped of the virtual impunity that the officer corps has enjoyed throughout the war. Military doctrine was to be rewritten, military education changed, and responsibility for public order was to fall to a new civilian police force in which former rebel combatants would be allowed to serve. It was also agreed that social programs would be put into place to ease the effects of economic austerity policies imposed by Mr. Cristiani.
But with a vast amount of detail to work out, positions hardened on both sides. Three rounds of talks in Mexico made only limited progress.
 
U.N. Chief Preoccupied
 After the talks moved to New York, Mr. Perez de Cuellar, overwhelmed with the details of leaving the United Nations after ten years' leadership and hobbled by a bout of sciatica, was available to join them only intermittently.
Frustrated by the stubbornness that seemed to well up in negotiators each time sat down across from enemy representatives, Mr. Perez de Cuellar's representative to the talks, Alvaro de Soto, tried to move them along with indirect meetings. But he had little succcess, and the day before Christmas Government officials spoke of giving up for the time being and going home.
"There is a fundamental problem of trust," one Latin diplomat said on Christmas Eve.
Shortly thereafter, over what diplomats said were the objections of some senior military officers and extreme conservatives in his own Government, Mr. Cristiani finally agreed to Mr. Perez de Cuellar's requests that he take charge of the Government delegation. He decided to come after encouragement from several quarters, diplomats said, including President Carlos Andres Perez of Venezuela, President Carlos Salinas de Gortari of Mexico.

HEADLINE: SOVIET BRAIN DRAIN POSES ATOMIC RISK, U.S. REPORT WARNS

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31

 BODY:
Bush Administration officials are expressing apprehension that the economic deterioration of the former Soviet Union, the demoralization of its military forces and an expected high rate of unemployment may prompt some of its top experts with the know-how for making nuclear weapons to sell their services abroad.
A classified report prepared by the Central Intelligence Agency and other intelligence bureaus and agencies on weapons proliferation in the former Soviet Union warns that the potential for nuclear mercenaries is more worrisome than the danger of nuclear-related materials going astray because they are easier to control, said officials familiar with the report. 
 Other nuclear weapons experts both inside and outside the Administration said they believed the danger of the Soviet brain drain could be overstated. They argue that even with the know-how, the crucial ingredient in making a nuclear bomb is sufficient quantities of plutonium or highly enriched weapons-grade uranium, which are subject to strict international controls and extremely difficult to acquire.
 
A Worst-Case Scenario
 The intelligence report, one of about a dozen brief analyses on the breakup of the Soviet Union ordered by Robert M. Gates, the Director of Central Intelligence, estimates that 900,000 military officials and civilians work in the nuclear weapons community -- from blue-collar workers running lathes for nuclear weapons and academicians with theoretical knowledge about the state of nuclear materials to military personnel responsible for deploying and maintaining nuclear weapons.
Of that number, some senior Administration officials estimate, as many as 2,000 people in the former Soviet Union have an intimate knowledge of nuclear weapons design, and 3,000 to 5,000 people have worked in uranium enrichment or plutonium production.
"A large percentage of these people could be of value to foreign buyers," said one non-proliferation expert in the Bush Administration.
The intelligence report, a National Intelligence Estimate that has been circulated to President Bush and other senior policy makers, paints a worst-case scenario of what is likely to happen when unemployed scientists, military officers and academicians who have made their livelihoods in the huge nuclear weapons industry meet up with buyers who are already wandering around the former republics.
The potential problem is so serious that the Administration's goal will be to slow down, not eliminate, the seepage of materials and expertise, the intelligence analysis says.
 
'More Concern About Experts'
 "The paper discusses the enormous potential for draining away technologies and experts as people are looking to make a fast buck," said one intelligence official familiar with the report. "In the end, there is more concern about the experts. It's the people who really count."
In a news conference on Dec. 19 after his trip to the Soviet Union, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said that both authorities in the republics and the union gave him assurances that they would impose stringent export controls on weapons and technology. But even the strictest controls cannot stop the flow of expertise, said one nuclear non-proliferation official, who added, "There is no expectation they will have much success in stopping the movement of people."
American intelligence has not uncovered conclusive evidence that rogue nations have begun to recruit nuclear experts, although officials have received intelligence reports that wealthy individuals and groups are traveling in the former republics seeking both technology and expertise.
In testimony before Congress earlier this month, Mr. Gates speculated that among the tens of thousands of scientists and engineers emigrating annually from the Soviet Union, some may find a market for their expertise in countries in the developing world that are striving to acquire new weaponry. In a subsequent interview with The Los Angeles Times, Mr. Gates said unemployment and food shortages may compel Soviet nuclear, chemical and biological weapons experts to market their expertise abroad.
 
Concern in Former Republics
 Concerns by Bush Administration officials is echoed by officials in the various former republics, who have stressed the danger of widespread unemployment of nuclear experts in urging the rest of the world to pour in huge amounts of aid.
"You have to discount some of the rumors, because the scientists themselves have a vested interest making it appear like a big problem," said one Administration official involved in non-proliferation issues.
But the concern is reflected in the American academic community as well. A recent Harvard University report on control of the Soviet nuclear arsenal concluded: "Bomb designers, builders of assemblies for testing, custodians of the Soviet Union's excess supply of special nuclear materials, manufacturers of sensitive components and employees of final weapons assembly facilities all have some sort of access to nuclear materials and even to finished bombs. They also possess knowledge of the deployed weapons and have personal contacts among the custodians and the military. In this period of drastic cuts in military purchases, managers of these facilities may find themselves with large numbers of disgruntled workers seeking to use their special access and knowledge for political or economic gain."
As an example of the potential seepage of nuclear materials, the Administration's intelligence analysis cites a report on Moscow television last July about a roadblock set up to uncover drugs. Instead, officers conducting a search seized platinum and other materials used in nuclear weapons development that the television report asserted had been stolen from Chelyabinsk-70, one of the former Soviet Union's two main nuclear weapons design laboratories, which is in the Urals in Russia.
Bush Administration officials said they could not confirm reports that 65 pounds of low-enriched uranium seized in northern Italy last month and a tiny amount of plutonium seized from a businessman in Switzerland in October originated in the former Soviet Union.
On Monday, Romano Dolce, assistant public prosecutor in the northern Italian town of Como, said on Italian television that American experts had examined the nuclear material and concluded that they were of Soviet origin. But American intelligence officials said the United States had not inspected the material.
"We have seen various reports in recent months of attempts by entities in the former Soviet Union to sell nuclear and other materials," said Richard A. Boucher, a State Department spokesman. "We cannot confirm any of these reports at this time but are checking into the latest reports from Italy. In view of the uncertain conditions in the republics of the former Soviet Union we are concerned that illicit sales could take place by entities or individuals seeking hard currency."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY
The Global Lab -- A special report inside: Industry by industry, pages 48-49.;
Technology Without Borders Raises Big Questions for U.S.

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK

 BODY:
Just as they once moved manufacturing plants overseas, American companies are now spreading their research and product development around the world, helping to turn the creation of technology into an activity that transcends national borders.
The trend raises tough new issues for policy makers intent on preserving jobs for Americans and keeping the nation competitive in high-technology industries like aerospace, pharmaceuticals and information processing. But many business leaders say the march toward technology with no national allegiances -- the march toward the borderless lab -- is as inevitable as it is irrevocable. Government policies that do not adapt to this fundamental industrial shift, many executives contend, are bound to fail. 
 "Policy has to deal with these global realities," said John A. Armstrong, vice president for science and technology at the International Business Machines Corporation.
But not all policy makers and strategists agree how to proceed. Some would seek to stem the international flow to safeguard America's braintrust. Others insist that the best Government response is to accept the inevitable, while insuring that the United States offers a supportive economic environment for research and development work by foreign and domestic companies alike.
Most executives tend to be pragmatists who say that innovation recognizes no borders. "We want to be able to tap into technology wherever it is developed," said Geoffrey C. Nicholson, staff vice president for international technical operations at the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company. "It would be naive to think the U.S. is Mecca for all technologies." The St. Paul company, which makes everything from Post-it notes to optical data disks, now has 2,500 technical people stationed abroad, three times as many as in 1980.
Overseas laboratories are not the only mechanism for the globalization of technology development. In the last month alone, other examples have included the acquisition of a majority stake in a promising American pharmaceutical biotechnology start-up, Systemix Inc., by a leading Swiss drug maker, Sandoz Ltd. From across the Atlantic came word that I.B.M. and Siemens A.G. of Germany had jointly developed the prototype for a new generation of computer memory chip. A few days later, across the Pacific, I.B.M. said it would produce a Japanese-English notebook computer for one of its computer rivals, Tokyo-based Hitachi Ltd.
Since the mid-1980's, there have been more than 900 transnational alliances by United States businesses or investments by foreign companies in American technology start-ups, and those deals do not include countless other joint marketing agreements or outright acquisitions.
With more and more products assembled from components made around the world, notions like "made in the U.S.A." and "American know-how" may be destined to take their place alongside such relics as the "space race" and war bonds in the history of American industrial policy. Apple Computer Inc., which a decade ago was considered the epitome of renegade American entrepreneurial verve, is now working to combine its software expertise with the Sony Corporation's ability in miniaturization to develop consumer electronics devices that neither company could produce as well on its own.
 
Big Risks for U.S. Companies
 The advent of the borderless lab raises big risks for American companies and for the United States economy. Since, as is widely acknowledged, American industry often lags behind foreign companies in manufacturing, the nation's competitive edge now depends on being able to create new technologies faster than overseas rivals. But the rapid spread of technological expertise around the globe could dull this edge in the future.
Globalization also makes it more difficult for policy makers to determine how best to serve the nation's interests, or even to define what those interests are. The conundrum is likely to color the industrial policy debate that is starting to revive in this Presidential election year -- and cannot help but provide a subtext next week when President Bush visits Japan with 21 American executives in tow.
Among the policy issues is whether the Government should try to stem the overseas migration of American technology by such measures as blocking acquisitions of key American technology companies by foreign corporations.
Other questions: Does it makes sense for Washington to spend money on research and development, or on competitiveness programs like the Sematech semiconductor consortium, if the technological fruits are going to be immediately enjoyed overseas? If the Government does finance such programs, should they include only American-owned companies, or also foreign companies operating in the United States?
 
Technology at Fire-Sale Prices?
 "You don't want a situation in which very significant technology is being bought at fire-sale prices in the United States and commercialized overseas," said Clyde Prestowitz, president of the Economic Strategy Institute in Washington.
Mr. Prestowitz is in the camp of strategists and policy makers who argue that the globalization of technology can still be, and should be, held in check. Access to technology, like access to markets, they say, is not equal around the world. It is far more difficult, for instance, for an American company to buy a Japanese one than vice versa, they note, arguing that the United States would be naive not to look out for its own interests.
"We're the only country in the world that thinks nationality doesn't matter," said Pat Choate, an economist who is a leading critic of foreign investment in the United States.
But another school of thought -- whose adherents include many business people -- contends that globalization is inevitable and that the best policy is to make sure the United States reaps its share of benefits from the trend.
 
'A Very Hazardous Exercise'
 "The policies that won't work are those that assume the technology base is national," said Proctor P. Reid, who is a senior program officer at the National Academy of Engineering, which advises the Government on technical matters, and is co-editor of "National Interests in an Age of Global Technology," a book recently published by the academy.
"These global networks are already well developed," he said. "To try to tear the fabric to advantage your companies, or companies resident in the U.S., seems to me a very hazardous exercise."
Just how hazardous was shown in the recent controversy over display screens for notebook computers. To help American manufacturers of these flat panel displays, the Government levied tariffs on screens imported from Japan. But American computer companies, led by Apple and I.B.M., said the tariffs hurt them as well as the Japanese because they needed the screens to stay competitive. To avoid the tariffs, Apple and some other companies have already begun moving production of their portable machines outside the United States.
Those who share Mr. Reid's outlook say that as companies become even more globalized, the companies' nationalities will matter less and less. If I.B.M. and Fujitsu Ltd., the Japanese computer giant, were to spread their jobs, profits and expertise equally around the world, the United States might have little interest in which company triumphed in computer sales.
But, according to this line of thought, the United States would have a vital interest in securing the best jobs for its citizens by making this nation an attractive place for both Fujitsu and I.B.M. to conduct their research, development and manufacturing.
 
Seeking Improvements
 Therefore, those who see globalization as inevitable are calling for Washington to improve domestic education, modernize American factories and create advanced telecommunications networks within the United States. Such improvements, they say, cannot migrate across borders as easily as research discoveries.
"The goal is to have a flourishing climate in the United States for the creation of wealth and added value," Dr. Armstrong of I.B.M. said.
Those who think the nation should go with the technology flow also say that rather than worrying about the nation's best ideas being smuggled away, American companies and the Government should concentrate on acquiring more foreign technology and putting it to use in this country -- an effort that the United States did not have to make during the decades of American technological hegemony.
Nowadays, parties on both side of the issue acknowledge, the United States no longer holds a near monopoly on technical advances. Indeed, while the earlier movement of American manufacturing abroad was aimed largely at taking advantage of low-cost foreign labor, the movement of research and development is intended to tap foreign knowledge.
 
Isolation Can Hurt
 "If you isolate yourself to the United States you can hurt yourself and your ability to be competitive," said Alexander MacLachlan, senior vice president of research and development at E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, the American chemicals giant.
Only 10 percent of Du Pont's current research and development is conducted overseas, Dr. MacLachlan said, and "we recognize that it is not a satisfactory situation." The company is gradually increasing its level of overseas research, he said.
At Motorola Inc., the Schaumburg, Ill., maker of semiconductors and communications equipment, researchers are quick to point out that the Europeans have pioneered many developments in telecommunications, including alternatives to cellular telephones. "We ignore that at our peril," said Dick Heimlich, corporate vice president for international strategy at Motorola, which established a telecommunications research laboratory in England in 1991.
Another motive in conducting research and product development abroad is to increase overseas sales, which already account for more than half the revenues of many technology companies. Companies are also trying to achieve closer cooperation between their research-and-development activities and manufacturing, to speed the introduction of new products.
 
Products From Singapore
 That sometimes means putting research and development near manufacturing plants that moved abroad years ago. The Hewlett-Packard Company, for example, began a few yars ago to move some product development activities to a plant in Singapore that in the past simply manufactured products designed in the United States. Recently, an engineer in Singapore developed a key component that will become the basis of an entirely new line of Hewlett-Packard printers.
Sometimes, of course, political factors play a role. Hewlett-Packard's president and chief executive, John A. Young, said some foreign governments let it be known, however subtly, that they considered it good corporate citizenship to place research, development and manufacturing activities within their borders, rather than merely selling products there. The United States has also encouraged foreign companies, particularly Japanese auto makers, to set up plants and design centers in this country.
Despite the various transnational forces, technology development by American companies remains far less internationalized than manufacturing and sales. On the whole, only 10 percent of American corporate research and development funds is spent abroad. Basic research is even more likely than product development to be kept close to headquarters -- in large part because the creation of wholly new technology is so close to the heart of a company's business.
Motorola, for instance, gets half its revenues from international sales, and 40 percent of its work force is stationed abroad. But officials estimate that only 20 to 25 percent of product development is conducted overseas and only about 5 percent of pure research. Even I.B.M, whose European researchers have won two Nobel prizes, conducts less than 25 percent of its research and development outside the United States, Dr. Armstrong said.
 
Where the Benefits Go
 Armed with such evidence, some policy analysts argue that globalization is still relatively limited. There is an enduring national component to technology development, the argue, that continues to justify policies favoring American companies. "The primary benefits will always go to the host country," said Dr. Choate, the economist.
Dr. Choate and some other analysts fear that the transfer of high-paying research and development jobs could hurt the American economy by exporting prime cuts of personal income. But on this point, as in the other issues emanating from the borderless lab, corporate executives say that if they fail to direct their energies offshore when appropriate, their companies would be less competitive -- and the American economy would suffer even more.
At Hewlett-Packard, one of the nation's largest exporters, Mr. Young said the company had no choice but to continue expanding its overseas research and development. Otherwise, he said, "we wouldn't have a thriving business and we wouldn't be able to do these exports."

HEADLINE: U.S. Official Calls Muslim Militants a Threat to Africa

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31

 BODY:
A few weeks before the Islamic Salvation Front swept to victory in the first round of national legislative elections in Algeria, a senior Bush Administration official was analyzing the many faces of political ferment in Africa in the 1990's: the drift to anarchy in Somalia, the move to democracy in Zambia, unrest in Zaire and the promise of peaceful change in South Africa.
At the end, he paused to reflect on the single most worrisome trend for policy makers. "The march of Islamic fundamentalism," he said. 
 In government and the research organizations, the Algerian election results last week were a reaffirmation of the potential power of Islam in African politics. Moreover, experts believe that the trend is not confined to North Africa, historically part of the Islamic world, but that it could affect the political stability of countries from the Horn of Africa south to Kenya and Tanzania and west to Nigeria and Senegal.
The result would be the establishment of governments antithetical to secular politics and Western cultures, posing a new challenge to Western policy makers after the collapse of Communism. The Senate Foreign Relations African Affairs subcommittee is to hold hearings on this issue early in 1992.
 
Networks Are Growing
 The test case, Bush Administration officials and independent experts say, is the Sudan. If the Sudan, where a military Government under the influence of a zealous Muslim party, the National Islamic Front, is able to enforce its austere vision of society on a country where various ethnic and religious groups have lived in uneasy coexistence for generations, then other nations historically more African than Arabic in culture and religion, are vulnerable to similar movements. Diverse Islamic movements are already building networks.
Some Muslims are tempted to see in the resurgence of religious fervor a renewal of the triumphant sweep of Islam across North Africa and into the Iberian peninsula from the seventh to the ninth centuries. Ijaz Gilani, an Islamic scholar and adviser to Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif of Pakistan, cautions against jumping to such conclusions.
"The feeling I have is that these societies where there is an Islamic resurgence are fairly weak societies not making great strides in science, art, economy or social organization as classical Islam did," he said in a telephone interview from Islamabad. "So this is more of a defensive step against Western society, which is still a dynamic force."
With the worldwide decline of Communism, always a foe of Islamic radicalism, or earlier suppression of leftist movements, as in the Sudan, well-educated Islamic leaders have begun to play on a search for roots and "to use the tools of modern society to reinforce an Islamic agenda," said Francis Deng, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution and a former Sudanese Ambassador to the United States. "It is a politicized Islam to be used for political control."
 
Assisted by Iranians
 Mr. Deng said in an interview that Islamic radicalism is coming down from the north and gaining strength in the Sudan, which is becoming a base for a wider Islamic campaign, assisted by Iranians.
"The Sudanese National Islamic Front, under its very bright leader, Hassan el-Turabi, is now recognized as a force across the continent," Mr. Deng said. "Sudan could become a bridge for Islam into Africa."
He added, however, that the strongly Christian southern Sudan would have to be put down by force first, along with areas in the west and north where Islam has been tempered by African religions and Sufi mysticism.
David Chand, a Sudanese political scientist living in the United States, said the military Government now in power, backed by the National Islamic Front, is already showing that it is capable of "genocide" in southern Sudan.
 
Training Camps Set Up
 In the western part of the country, he said in an interview, there are "systematic human rights violations against ethnic African Muslims." Training camps are being set up in the Sudan to train Islamic warriors from Egypt, Tunisia, Algeria, the Persian Gulf nations and Saudi Arabia, he said.
Islamic groups are also active in Chad, Niger and Mali. Mali's President, Amadou Toumani Toure, began negotiations this month with four Muslim rebel groups made up of Taureg people from the Sahara region whose clashes with Malian troops have killed several hundred people in recent months.
Envoys from Algeria, Libya, Burkina Faso and Mauritania were observers at the talks. All are reported concerned at the links being built among Muslim movements.
According to a Congressional aide who has been researching the Muslim movements, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi is apparently among those feeling threatened by Islamic radicals. The Libyan leader recently made a speech against fundamentalism in the Sudan.
 
Comes From Many Sources
 Experts say the rise of Islamic fundamentalism or radicalism comes from many sources, mostly drawn from within the diverse African societies themselves. The Iranians are now reported to be taking advantage of these to foster their vision of an absolutist Islamic state that is neither African nor Arab. Iran, a largely Shiite Muslim nation, is a fierce rival of predominantly Sunni Saudi Arabia for dominance in the Islamic world from Central Asia to Southeast Asia.
A Bush Administration official who spoke on condition of anonymity said that Islamic fundamentalists, whose goal is to end a separation of religion from politics just as democratization is spreading in Africa, have devised different formulas to suit local conditions, supporting Muslim parties where there are religious divisions and backing the least "Africanized" Muslims where Islam predominates.
Moderates in Iran, this official believes, are encouraging militants to "do their thing" in Africa, far away from Teheran, which is now thought to be eager to rebuild bridges with the West.

HEADLINE: Business Digest

 BODY:

The Global Lab
U.S. companies are spreading their research and product development around the world, helping to turn the creation of technology into an activity that transcends national borders. The trend raises tough new issues for policy makers intent on preserving jobs for Americans and keeping the nation competitive in high technology. Business Technology: A special report. [Page 1.] 
 In agricultural biotechnology, the contrast between the American style of creating new businesses and the approach in Europe and Japan is especially stark. [48.] The idea of an all-American semiconductor is fast becoming a historical artifact. No industry has seen a bigger blitz of international alliances. [48.]
An expanding international network of computer links is spurring a remarkable transformation in virtually every scientific discipline. [49.] Every new airliner is the product of international cooperation. [49.] Drug research has become as international as medicine itself, and pharmaceuticals are among the few products in which the U.S. has a surplus of exports over imports. [49.]
 
Markets
A year ago, few on Wall Street would have predicted the year-long bull market to come. War gave prices the initial lift, and the year was capped by a record December, sparked by lower interest rates. The Dow ended with a gain of 4.92, to 3,168.83, its fourth straight record. Small stocks did even better in 1991. [1.]
Stock mutual funds apparently had their best year ever, and bond funds seem to have turned in their best sales figures since 1986. [45.]
Treasury bond prices moved higher and long-term interest rates fell again in light pre-holiday trading. [55.]
The dollar settled mostly lower in extremely light dealings, but it was mixed compared with its levels a year ago. [56.]
Wheat and soybean futures prices recovered from their recent sell-off to close higher, while crude oil prices jumped. [56.]
 
Companies
The F.A.A. selected Harris Corp. to produce a $1.7 billion air traffic control system to be installed nationwide over the next 14 years. [45.]
Ikea said it would buy Stor, a West Coast competitor, for about $20 million. [47.]
 
The Economy
The Index of Leading Indicators fell 0.3 percent in November, the fourth straight month without a significant advance. And a gauge of current economic conditions dropped 0.8 percent, suggesting that the economy may have contracted slightly. [45.]
Prices farmers get for raw products declined 0.7 percent in December from the previous month and were 3.5 percent less than a year ago, the Agriculture Department said. [46.]
New-home purchases held steady in November despite the lowest mortgage rates in nearly two decades, as strong sales in the South and West offset a huge decline in the Northeast. [46.]
Marshalltown, Iowa, was one of dozens of municipalities that found their investment funds frozen when their investment manager, Steven D. Wymer, was accused of fraud. [45.]
 
International
The fight for control of Maxwell Communication neared a resolution, and it seemed that the company's directors would be the losers. [45.]
 
Today's Column
Do Israel's capitalist policymakers sincerely wish to live by the rules of free markets? Conservative critics contend that big government is an addiction. But others disagree. Peter Passell: Economic Scene. [46.]

HEADLINE: Indicators Dropped 0.3% In November

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31

 BODY:
The Government index meant to predict the economy fell three-tenths of 1 percent in November, the fourth straight month without a significant advance.
At the same time, a companion gauge of current economic conditions issued by the Commerce Department dropped eight-tenths of 1 percent, suggesting that the economy may have contracted slightly in the final quarter of the year after modest gains in the spring and summer. 
 "The economy truly is weak," said Daniel Laufenberg, an economist at I.D.S. Financial Services in Minneapolis. Whether this period is ultimately recorded as a drawn-out early stage of recovery or a latter stage of protracted recession is merely academic, he added.
Daniel Friel, an economist at Nationsbank Corporation in Charlotte, N.C., said: "We're really sort of dead in the water. Any growth is so slow you can't tell there's growth at all."
In a separate report, sales of new one-family houses were at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 520,000 for November, the same as the revised pace for October, according to estimates by the Commerce Department and the Housing and Urban Development Department. [Page 46.]
Since most of the 11 components of the index of leading indicators have previously been published, today's negative figure was widely anticipated and did little to change views of 1992. To hasten an economic revival, the Federal Reserve already moved to slash interest rates, with steep cuts announced on Dec. 20.
As a rule of thumb, it takes three straight months of increases to signal recovery and there has been no solid gain since July's jump of 1.2 percent. October's gain was a negligible one-tenth of 1 percent and there was a two-tenths of 1 percent decline in September. In August, the index was flat.
While not large, the three-tenths of 1 percent decline in the leading index was the biggest since January, when the index fell six-tenths of 1 percent. Sizable gains began the following month and continued until an abrupt end in August.
Of the seven components that contributed to the November decline, the most important by far was the drop in consumer expectations as measured by the University of Michigan. If expectations were excluded, the leading index would have been unchanged for the month. Since November, consumer sentiment has steadied and is unlikely to prove a significant drag on the December index, analysts said.
Other November negatives were a rise in first-time claims for unemployment insurance, a decline in building permits, lower factory backlogs, a decline in new factory orders for consumer goods and materials, and declines in the money supply and stock prices. During December, the money supply and stock prices surged, perhaps enough to push the index ahead, analysts said.
 
Some Positive Factors
 The positive factors for November were a rise in contracts and orders for new plant and equipment, higher prices for materials particularly sensitive to the business cycle and a rise in the proportion of companies experiencing slowing deliveries from suppliers.
The 11th component, the length of the average workweek, was unchanged.
The decline for the coincident indicators, also the biggest since January, included falling personal income and shrunken company payrolls. Industrial production also fell while the fourth component, manufacturing and trade sales, was not yet available.
The index of lagging indicators, those that move after the economy and tend to confirm the coincident index, fell five-tenths of 1 percent in November, the 10th straight decline. The seven lagging items are average duration of unemployment, the inventory-sales ratio, change in unit labor costs, the prime rate, bank loans, installment credit related to incomes and the change in the services portion of the Consumer Price Index.
 
Another Index in Decline
 An alternative predictor -- the ratio of the coincident index to the lagging index -- fell in November after rising slightly in October, the report also showed.
In the private sector, a forecasting index compiled by Safian Investment Research in White Plains fell four-tenths of 1 percent for November, with 10 components up, 12 down and one unchanged.
But one designed by David B. Bostian of Josephthal, Lyon & Ross, a Wall Street investment firm, rose two points, to positive 85, a small increase but from a point that was already bullish. "The recovery is on course," said Mr. Bostian, who is among the most optimistic forecasters for 1992, predicting that gross domestic product will climb 4 percent. His index rose to positive 50, which he regards as signaling a business upturn, in July.

HEADLINE: Tsongas Pitches Economic Austerity, Mixed With Patriotism

SERIES: Last of six articles on the Democratic Presidential candidates.

BYLINE: By KAREN DE WITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NASHUA, N.H.

 BODY:
Anyone looking for a slick political campaign won't find it on the hustings with Paul E. Tsongas.
Mr. Tsongas, a former Senator and Representative from Massachusetts, runs a dogged, bottom-up campaign that works voter to voter, town to town, and captures space in the news seemingly newspaper by newspaper and sound bite by sound bite. 
 His is a Spartan campaign with a hair-shirt message: America must wake up to its economic peril or slide into a third-world posture of chronic unemployment and lowered living standards. His solution: an economic pragmatism, mixed with patriotism, sacrifice and responsibility, intended to recapture America's manufacturing pre-eminence.
This is not a message geared to win the hearts and minds of voters who ditched the Democrats and Jimmy Carter's "malaise" for Ronald Reagan's "Morning in America" and George Bush's "No new taxes."
But given the economic downturn, a certain disillusionment with shop-till-you-drop materialism, and a natural American altruism that has not been tapped in several elections, it could be a stirring message.
The problem is that Mr. Tsongas does not stir.
He is less the rousing Paul Revere that he would like voters to think him than the somber St. Paul his critics once dubbed him. Whether he is speaking to a group of international executives in Washington or unemployed blue-collar workers in New Hampshire, Mr. Tsongas delivers his message of economic bootstrapping not with the bravado of a candidate intent on victory but with soporific sincerity. The 50-year-old Mr. Tsongas can occasionally be peevish in his presentations, warning his listeners that if they reject him and his message, "I'll go home to Lowell, make money and take care of my family."
Then there is the cancer that led Mr. Tsongas to retire from the Senate in 1984. Though he has overcome the disease -- he consulted with his doctors before announcing his Presidential campaign -- its specter rises each time Mr. Tsongas looks the least bit tired.
Mr. Tsongas is also a Greek-American Democrat from Massachusetts, which leads to unflattering comparisons to Michael S. Dukakis, another Greek-American from Massachusetts, who in 1988 failed to wrest the White House from Republicans.
Some political analysts think that what Mr. Tsongas really wants more than the party's nomination is the opportunity to influence the political debate and help to define the party's platform.
"He might provide the message for some other messenger," said Robert Squier, a Democratic consultant who is not advising any of this election year's contenders. "That's not fair but that's politics.
"Voters get down to does this person act, sound, look like a president?" he added. "His problem is he doesn't."
 
Tough Odds
Swimming Against the Tide
 What political professionals see as liabilities, Mr. Tsongas tries to present as assets. He is the dark horse that no one has ever taken seriously, the man who beat cancer and the odds in his political races.
It is the tack taken in his television advertisement in New Hampshire. Called "Swim," it is a 30-second spot of Mr. Tsongas doing the strenuous butterfly stroke the length of a pool while a narrator talks about his history of surprising the political oddsmakers and overcoming cancer, and ends with "Paul Tsongas has never been afraid to swim against the current."
Mr. Tsongas makes the advertisement itself a kind of courageous march against the odds.
"The nuclear weapon in this business is 30-second TV ads, O.K.?" he told an audience of teachers at the National Education Association in Washington in early December. "Now, we've already run our first ad. The ad which we've run in New Hampshire, which is the first primary state where we're putting a lot of effort in, is an ad of me swimming the butterfly. Very intellectual. I wanted to demonstrate courage. And I am 50 years old. And I was photographed in a Speedo bathing suit. I challenge you to do the same thing."
For seven months, he was the lone Democrat to challenge Mr. Bush, a straw in the wind of the President's overwhelming popularity in the wake of the Persian Gulf war. "Spring and summer was like going through a swamp," he said. Now he jokingly tells audiences his candidacy is responsible for the decline in Mr. Bush's ratings.
"He started out at 91 percent and now he's at 69. Not bad, huh?" he asked a group of unemployed workers, some of whom were studying for General Equivalency Diplomas they hoped would lead to jobs, at an adult learning center here. Not belly-laugh funny, but it elicits chuckles from audiences.
The party analysts do not openly ridicule Mr. Tsongas's campaign, but neither is he considered a serious contender.
"Paul Tsongas is a good guy who was an effective Senator who has absolutely no chance of winning," says Ted Van Dyk, a Democratic consultant, in a comment typical of those heard inside the Washington Beltway.
But Mr. Tsongas said he is not intimidated by the other Democratic contenders and conceded stature only to Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York. Without Mr. Cuomo, "we don't have any 1,000-pound gorillas" in the contest, Mr. Tsongas said.
Mr. Tsongas argues that the Democratic Party has an inferiority complex that prevents it from seeing that it can recapture the Presidency with the economic issue. And on that issue, Mr. Tsongas maintains, it is answers, not pretty-boy looks and scintillating rhetoric, that voters want.
 
Tough Message
Giving Priority To the Economy
 In New Hampshire, which has been hard-hit economically, Mr. Tsongas frequently emphasizes how far removed the Republicans are from the lives of ordinary Americans. He tells audiences there that the only unemployed person from New Hampshire that President Bush knows is John H. Sununu. It gets appreciative applause.
And though Democrats -- and now Republicans -- talk about America's economic woes, Mr. Tsongas notes that he began developing his ideas on the economy over a decade ago, starting in a 1980 speech in which he said that the Democratic Party was out of touch with a changing economic world.
For the campaign, he has honed this argument into an 85-page booklet, "A Call to Economic Arms," that trounces both parties for allegiance to partisan politics and ideologies that he maintains have sapped the country.
His solution is pro-business, but he touts his liberalism on social issues, citing his experience as a teacher for the Peace Corp in Ethiopia. He favors abortion rights, civil rights and gay rights. But first and foremost comes the economy. Without a vibrant economy, Mr. Tsongas says, the social services the Democrats have brought to the country cannot be maintained.
"No goose, no golden eggs," he told his audiences, noting that he serves on a dozen corporate boards and knows the business arena firsthand.
He wants the country to embark on an industrial policy that would rejuvenate industry from the ground up. He would encourage American technological progress with governmental investment in specific emerging technologies, better funding for science and research at the National Science Foundation, the National Institutes of Health, NASA, and the Departments of Energy and Agriculture. He contends that many German and Japanese industries captured markets from their American competitors because of support by their governments. Currently, most Federal research and development money goes to weapons development.
Mr. Tsongas would also change antitrust laws so that American companies no longer face barriers to joint ventures in research and development and marketing that now hinder their competing in the international market. He wants to reduce the capital gains tax for investments in certain securities held over long periods. He would also provide a tax credit to companies that do research and development.
Mr. Tsongas is opposed to the middle-class tax cut favored by other Democratic candidates, which he argues will be so small that it will neither benefit consumers nor solve the root problems in the economy.
When it comes to these issues, Mr. Tsongas is unapologetically tedious. The campaign has printed 100,000 copies of his economic booklet and Mr. Tsongas dispenses them at campaign stops like other candidates distribute buttons. And he expects his audiences to read that booklet.
"There will be a test afterwards," he quipped, as the small gray books were being distributed to an audience at Plymouth State Community College in Plymouth, N.H. He then went on to batter the audience with his call for a national economic policy as he fiddled with the lectern's microphones and drew charts and graphs on a large flip chart.
"I need to make people understand that this is a long tough haul," he said. "I've dropped a pebble -- maybe it's the wrong pebble -- but over time, people will talk about it. It is not unlike having cancer. You accept what's there. You deal with it. At some point there is generational responsibility, there is generational morality."
 
Tough Campaign
Trading Slogans For Sincerity
 Mr. Tsongas's campaign manager, Dennis Kanin, a veteran of many Democratic races, said his candidate's unorthodox strategy is based on Mr. Tsongas's belief that Americans are fed up with slickness, shaped campaigns and sound-bite sloganeering. "Paul has his own style and people find him genuine. People know Paul's not talking rhetoric, not making statements based on polling data," he said.
So far, Mr. Tsongas has focused his anti-glitz crusade on New Hampshire, with frequent sorties into Maryland, Florida, Washington state, and other states that hold early primaries or caucuses. He has 42 full-time paid campaign workers and he has been relying on a number of Boston-based advisers for advice, including Lester Thurow, the economist; Daniel Yergin, oil historian and president of Cambridge Energy Research Associates; Kelly McClintock, executive director of the Conservation Law Foundation on environmental issues, and Al Carnaschale at Harvard University's John F. Kennedy School of Government and Ruth Morganthau at Brandeis University on foreign policy.
Mr. Tsongas's fund raising has been slowed by his seven-year absence from Congress and his low name recognition outside New England. He has managed to raise just over $1 million in campaign contributions through a combination of events, direct mail and one-on-one phone calls by Mr. Tsongas. Mr. Tsongas's fund-raising events are decidely downscale.
"We've had a lot of low-ticket events, in the $10 and $25 range," Mr. Kanin said. "Most of the high-ticket events have been in the $250-$500 range. Often we'll have a two-tier event, say, a $250 dinner and a $100-a-person reception and rally. Everybody has to rely more on organizational support because funds are much tighter than they were."
A good portion of the money has been spent on travel. Since his announcement in April, Mr. Tsongas has traveled to 30 states. In addition, nearly $100,000 was spent on Mr. Tsongas's television campaign advertisement that aired for two weeks in New Hampshire.
Mr. Tsongas thinks he will fare well in New Hampshire -- and he is considered by many political organizers to be the candidate to beat here -- not because he is from a neighboring state but because of his message of economic renewal.
"When the poll was done in New Hampshire in September, I had a lead, the others had not yet made any moves, and so the collective wisdom was that this was a sort of local favorite, but that it would dissipate," said Mr. Tsongas. "That lead is still there and something has to account for that. I'd say my message is getting through. What I generally hear back from people is that what I say makes sense.
"My strategy has always been to be the last person standing and to try to end up as the person who can steer the country away from economic disaster," said Mr. Tsongas.
"As long as people can believe that this is a temporary economic setback, that life is a beer commercial, a candidate like me has no relevance," he said. "But my message truly resonates in the business community because they're really scared. That I'm not a dominant orator is irrelevant because they want to get out of this dilemma.
"But there will come a point of scrutiny on specifics and that's the point where I'll shine. The media finds the economic downturn uncomfortable and inconvenient, so they're far more likely to be attracted to people who do better on television."
"You take something as simple as the capital gains tax issue," he added, underlining his status as the only Democrat who agrees even in part with Mr. Bush on this issue. "The other candidates have been out for months and yet who knows where they stand? What exactly is the blueprint the other candidates have to bring back the economy? We're going to do something to force the issue, make the other candidates respond. One thing I've done during the campaign is I still attend board meetings, partly for the income but also to keep myself in that mindset. Because on those boards they see what's coming. And at some point, when the nation sees that, they're going to want to know someone who can fly and that's me.
"I'm fully aware of all the disadvantages I bring," Mr. Tsongas said. "But because of the circumstances of my life, and the last seven years, I feel I'm prepared for that challenge.
"I know I'm the best candidate. Now if I could just convince God to make me a movie star."

HEADLINE: U.S. Orders Assessment of Harm Caused by Dams

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31

 BODY:
A Federal energy agency is undertaking a long review of scores of hydroelectric dams, and promises a new era in which such dams will be operated in ways aimed at reducing or eliminating damage to the environment.
Over the next two years, the agency, the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, will review applications from utilities, paper mills that run dams for their own power and other industries to relicense 237 of the country's oldest hydroelectric dams and generating stations. That is the most hydroelectric projects to come up for relicensing at any one time in the agency's 71-year history. 
 Most of the dams were built in the early decades of the century and have been operating under licenses that in some cases were granted half a century ago, well before builders seriously considered the harm a dam could do to fish, other wildlife, river beds and stream banks.
 
A Rare Opportunity
 Fred E. Springer, the director of the agency's Office of Hydropower Licensing, has joined American Rivers, an environmental group, in calling the relicensing project a unique opportunity to repair ecological problems caused by obsolete designs and outdated management practices.
Among the new structures the agency could require at old dams, Mr. Springer said in an interview, are devices called fish ladders that would allow salmon and other species to spawn upstream. Some dams will be required to install barriers to protect fish from being chopped up by turbines. In addition, Mr. Springer said, dam owners could be called on to build boat ramps and other provisions for recreational river users.
The agency could also require utilities to more carefully regulate the flow of water through dams. That wouldeliminate the sudden turbulent rush of water during periods of peak electricity demand, followed by a trickle as utilities store water in reservoirs to gain energy. The irregular flows, environmental scientists say, cause erosion of stream banks, ruin fish breeding grounds and make it dangerous to go canoeing or kayaking.
In rare instances, the agency may even require owners to remove a dam because the amount of electricity it generates is far outweighed by the environmental harm it is causing.
 
No Large Expenses Expected
 "Virtually every project we are reviewing will require changes to reduce their effect on the environment," Mr. Springer said. "Environmental standards are much different now than they were when these projects were first licensed."
Utility executives said today that in most cases new construction and changes in the way the plants are managed were unlikely to be excessively expensive. The Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation, which is seeking to relicense 30 of its 74 hydroelectric projects in New York, more than any other utility in the nation, said it planned to spend $100 million over the next eight years on improvements including new equipment to increase the amount of power generated by 8 percent.
"We've already been working with canoeing groups, fishermen and cities where we operate hydroelectric power projects to prepare our application," said James M. Cosgrove, a spokesman for Niagara Mohawk Power in Syracuse. "We're trying to meet the concerns of the environmental people at the same time we're also meeting the demands of our customers."
When they were built decades ago, virtually all the 237 dams that are coming up for review by the Government were seen as vibrant emblems of American industrial ingenuity and engineering prowess. Some were magnificent, like the Cushman Dam, built in 1924 by Tacoma City Light in Washington State. It snaked across the Skokomish River, a concrete drapery unfurled in a snow-peaked wilderness.
More recently the reputation of the country's roughly 2,000 hydroelectric dams -- 1,400 are privately owned and 600 were built by the Federal Government -- has grown considerably more complex. Studies by the Department of Energy and other Federal agencies say hydroelectric power is cleaner, safer and less expensive than almost any other form of energy now available. About 10 percent of the country's electricity is generated by hydroelectric projects, the Energy Department says.
 
Criticism From Ecologists
 In addition, Mr. Springer noted that in many regions old dams were holding back lakes that are the centerpieces of regional economies reliant on fishing, hunting and other tourist activities.
But aquatic scientists and ecologists say that flooding vast areas to establish reservoirs, block rivers and artificially manage the flow of water to gain peak amounts of power is destructive to wildlife, fish and habitat.
The answer to these problems is not to destroy dams but to change how they are operated, said Matthew H. Huntington, director of the hydropower programs for American Rivers, the country's principal river conservation group.
But Mr. Huntington said environmental groups and state environmental agencies did not believe that the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission would go far enough in ordering changes that will make any difference.
"Given their track record, we have no confidence in FERC's commitment to bring about any kind of environmental repair," Mr. Huntington said. "They have been challenged too many times to count in court by state agencies and environmental groups in previous licensing decisions because they tell everybody they are protecting the environment and they don't."
Mr. Springer today defended his agency's record in licensing dams. "The commission independently reviews applications with a look toward balancing all the issues," he said. "In the last 10 years, 85 to 90 percent of the changes recommended by state agencies or the United States Fish and Widlife Service were put in licenses. But not all the wishes of every private environmental group or resource agency can be accommodated in a balanced decision. You have to weigh all the factors."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY -- The Global Lab: Aerospace;
International Flights, Indeed

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA

 BODY:
Every new airliner is the product of international cooperation. In the new Boeing 777 program, for example, the Boeing Company is manufacturing only the wings, nose structure and engine nacelles. The rest of the wide-body airplane will come from hundreds of subcontractors in North America, Japan and Europe. The main fuselage sections, for example, will be fabricated in Japan; the wing flaps come from Italy.
The McDonnell Douglas Corporation, Boeing's only domestic rival in the airliner business, wants to go even further. It is seeking to sell 40 percent of its civil airliner business to the Taiwan Aerospace Corporation, a newly formed entity that has the backing of the Taiwan Government. Because no military technology is involved, the deal requires no approval from the United States Government. 
 But the arrangement could have far-reaching policy implications for the $30-billion-a-year airliner industry, in which the United States has long been the world leader, with more than 75 percent of the market.
 
A Widespread Practice
 International cooperation in aircraft development and manufacturing is a fact of life for several reasons.
For one thing, the other guys do it. To preserve their aircraft industries, the Governments of Britain, France, Germany and Spain have collectively poured an estimated $25 billion into Airbus Industrie, the Paris-based consortium that has developed into a big force.
Officials of Airbus say they are interested in taking on Japanese companies, like Mitsubishi Heavy Industries, Fuji Heavy Industries and Kawasaki Heavy Industries, as limited partners if the consortium proceeds with plans to build a 600-seat jet transport some airlines say they might need. (A Boeing 747 seats between 385 and 400; the new Boeing 777, which will seat up to 375, is designed for service requiring a twin-engine plane.)
In the case of McDonnell, the aircraft builder needs the capital from a Taiwan deal to stay in the game. McDonnell is hoping to develop an all-new airplane, the MD-12, to challenge the Boeing 747 and Airbus A340 in the long-haul market. The company's current models, the MD-11 and MD-80, are updated versions of older designs, and do not compete directly with the 747 because of size and range limitations.
But even Boeing, which has produced a majority of the world's airliners flying today, cannot go it alone. Aircraft purchases are political as well as economic decisions, particularly in parts of the globe where governments either own or heavily influence the national airlines.
Boeing officials say that to sell in some Asian and European markets, they have to include local manufacturers in aircraft programs. And by subcontracting parts of the planes to low-cost manufacturing areas, the company helps hold down overall expenses.
Boeing executives say they are acutely conscious that jetliners are among the few complex manufactured goods that American companies can still sell to the world, and the company knows that the Japanese Government has repeatedly focused on commercial aviation as an industry to conquer.
The strategy for keeping control of the business, Boeing executives say, is to contract out some parts, but to keep wing manufacturing, final assembly and integration of the electronic, hydraulic and mechanical systems firmly in-house. Uniting several million parts into an airplane that flies reliably and at low cost is not a skill that can be easily learned from the outside, they assert.
But some in the industry fear that McDonnell, which has nowhere near the bulging, $100 billion order book of Boeing, may have to trade key technology for the financing it needs to build the MD-12. That could be the first step toward true Asian competition for the American airliner industry, critics say.
There are other concerns, too. The next generation of airliners may have to be supersonic to shrink the vast distances between North America and the Pacific Rim. Some American aerospace executives say such a project may be too big and risky for even Boeing to tackle alone, especially in a future in which Pentagon spending is unlikely to subsidize aerospace research to the extent it has in the past half-century.
