LENGTH: 1354 words

HEADLINE: Long Viewed as Safe From Slumps, Las Vegas Finally Feels the Recession

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Dec. 29

 BODY:
For some time Las Vegas has purveyed an escapist world of fantasy and gambling and a view of itself as largely resistant to national recessions.
Now, the recession has finally hit the Strip, just as it has Atlantic City in New Jersey. There are more visitors than ever under the neon glare, but they are gambling less and spending less. The casinos' take has dropped substantially in recent months, local home sales are down from the torrid 1990 pace, and unemployment is up. Even the high rollers are lying low; baccarat play is down by a third. 
 "It is pretty clear the recession is finally catching up with Las Vegas," said Alan Feldman, spokesman for the new Mirage Hotel, one of the few hotel-casinos that have thus far weathered the downturn well. "Whether it will be a serious or mild effect, the jury is still out."
Casino operators fret over visitors like John Liemert, an administrator with an aerospace company from Torrance, Calif., who took a $42 room at a small hotel and then spent his Saturday afternoon sipping beer and flirting with the cocktail waitresses at Caesars Palace rather than playing the nearby blackjack tables and slot machines. "It's recession, fear, uncertainty," he said of his hard-hit industry in California. "It's scary. People are cutting their entertainment funds."
To be sure, the slowdown is mild compared with the recession in the Northeast and nearby Southern California. But the fact that Las Vegas has slowed at all is remarkable.
 
End of Increases
 "Nevada has a long history of virtually unbroken year-to-year increases," said William R. Eadington, an economist who is director of the Institute for the Study of Gambling and Commercial Gaming at the University of Nevada in Reno. "For many years, there was a perception that the gaming industry was recession-proof. But as the industry has matured and the supply increased, it has become more susceptible to changes in the national economy. There's been a very noticeable shift in attitude, toward pessimism."
During the 1981-82 recession, Professor Eadington said, "there was a slowdown in growth rates, but at no time was there a decline." He added that there could be "significant layoffs" by hotels and casinos this time.
The recession comes to Las Vegas well after Atlantic City, which has apparently begun to recover. The amount of money won by the city's 12 casinos before expenses was up 1.7 percent for the first 11 months of this year, although the results varied considerably from casino to casino. This followed a poor year in 1990, when the gaming win fell from 1989 for the 11 casinos that predated the opening of the Trump Taj Mahal. Direct comparisons to Las Vegas are difficult because there are far fewer casinos in Atlantic City, and the addition of the Taj Mahal has skewed the data.
Other experts are less bearish on Las Vegas than Professor Eadington is, but signs of trouble abound:
*The Nevada Gaming Control Board reported Dec. 11 that the gambling industry suffered the steepest one-month drop in winnings in the state's 60 years of legalized gambling in October, the latest month for which figures are available. The casinos' gaming win fell by 6 percent statewide and 12 percent in Las Vegas, compared with October 1990.
*The state government, which depends on gambling taxes for 40 percent of its revenue, finds its current $2.2 billion budget in trouble because it assumed a 7.5 percent increase in gambling taxes.
*In the week before Christmas, two Las Vegas casinos -- Main Street Station and the Riviera -- declared bankruptcy.
*The unemployment rate for Clark County, which includes Las Vegas, rose to 6.0 percent in November from 5.5 percent in November 1990. The number of new jobs in the county in the 1990-91 fiscal year totaled a negligible 100, compared with 36,600 in 1989-90, according to the Nevada Employment Security Department.
*Sales of new homes are running 10 percent behind last year's pace in Las Vegas, and resales are behind by 18 percent, said Dennis L. Smith, president of Home Builders Research here. Mr. Smith said the 1990 level was so overheated, however, that the market remained comparatively healthy. "We have gone back into the reality world from the fantasy world," he said.
Though Nevada is expected to continue to grow in population substantially, economists now doubt that the state will continue to lead the nation. According to the 1990 census, Las Vegas was the fastest-growing major American city in the 80's.
 
Crowds Are Up
 From the crowds here this holiday weekend, it was hard to tell that anything was amiss. Long lines formed at the restaurants at the Mirage, the Excalibur, Bally's and other major hotels, all of which were fully booked through New Year's Day. Liza Minelli's four shows at Caesars Palace sold out at $72 a head, not including drinks and tips. And there were still regulars like Cecil Payne, a petroleum engineer from Houston, who visits two or three times a year and says, "I gamble till I leave."
Indeed, according to the Las Vegas Convention and Visitors Authority, the number of visitors to Las Vegas was up by 1.7 percent during the first nine months of this year over last, to 15.9 million.
But appearances are deceiving. "The consensus is that we are getting a decent number of visitors, but they are spending somewhat less," said Phil Hevner, a casino industry columnist for The Las Vegas Sun and editor of International Gaming and Wagering Business, a trade journal.
He added that economic difficulties in Japan and other parts of Asia had deterred many of the high-rolling Asian players who have become a mainstay here in recent years. For the four months ended Oct. 31, the baccarat take was down 27.5 percent, 33.1 percent in October alone, compared with the same periods last year. Figures show that table games like baccarat and blackjack have slumped much more sharply than slot machines.
Prof. William N. Thompson of the College of Business Administration at the University of Nevada at Las Vegas said October's slump was not so severe as it seemed. This October had the Comdex computer convention, whose 120,000 participants are notorious non-gamblers, and there was a heavyweight prize fight last October, making that month a record for profits.
 
'Business Is Awful'
 Even so, "clearly business is awful," said Paul W. Lowden, president of Sahara Resorts, which has three hotels in Las Vegas and one in Laughlin, a new gambling resort development on the Colorado River 100 miles south of Las Vegas that is bucking the recessionary trend. He added that he and other operators were having to work harder than ever to attract business and capture a special niche for each hotel.
The recession appears to be accelerating a significant shakeout in Las Vegas that has been building with the opening of major theme hotels like the upscale 3,049-room Mirage and the downscale 4,032-room Excalibur in the last two years. Moreover, three huge new projects on the drawing boards will add 10,000 rooms to the Strip by 1994, meaning more competition than ever for the gambling dollar.
"The win is off, and the pie is sliced up more," said Mr. Lowden, who said he was reaching out to potential new business in foreign countries.
A key indicator of troubles in Las Vegas is room rates, which drop substantially in slack periods. Earlier this year, for example, the Las Vegas Hilton was offering rooms at $20 a night, double occupancy, including buffet dinner and a show. In holiday periods like this, the room rate runs about $85 a night for two people.
The recent discounts meant the hotel was essentially giving away the rooms to entice gamblers; the casinos' win typically runs about $16 for every $100 played.
But if the gaming win is down, too, the hotels are put in a tough squeeze. In recent years, they have depended more than ever on turning profits from rooms and food. "The question now is how much are you going to have to give away to maintain the gaming room," said Mr. Feldman of the Mirage. "Most casinos rely on getting something from the hotels to turn a profit."

HEADLINE: India Seems Adrift in Changed World

BYLINE: By EDWARD A. GARGAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW DELHI, Dec. 30

 BODY:
Last August, when most of the world's leaders were rushing to denounce the hard-liners' coup in the Soviet Union, India's Prime Minister, P. V. Narasimha Rao, declared that the coup was an instructive example of what happens to "over-enthusiastic reformers."
Unfortunately for the Prime Minister, and India's foreign policy as a whole, Boris N. Yeltsin crushed the plotters, resurrected Mikhail S. Gorbachev and began the final disassembling of the Soviet Union. Since then, India has struggled to cope with the new landscape in the old Soviet Union and has begun to search for its own place in a world that is changing rapidly, in ways that have upset India's traditional assumptions. 
 Yet, it is not only in regard to the Soviet Union that India is feeling its way forward, but on a range of international issues, whether with its neighbors, with its near-neighbors in Southeast Asia or with the United States. India's decades-long reliance on the Soviet Union as its ally, an ideological preoccupation with third world solidarity and a stubborn faith in socialism has, in the minds of many diplomats and Indians, hindered fresh thinking on foreign policy issues.
 
'Trying to Adjust'
 "India has been slow to grasp the change in the world and is hobbled by inertia," said a senior Western diplomat here. "But they are trying to adjust."
India's foremost news magazine, India Today, which is critical of the Government, is even harsher in its judgments. "Having been cussedly Indo-centric for so long," the magazine said in a editorial in its last issue, "with foreign policy conforming to ideology rather than reality, the politicians and bureaucrats running the country seem incapable of learning to think globally -- of tailoring international changes to fit the country's vital interests."
Many Indian professionals as well as foreign diplomats are expressing increasing concern about the Government's perceived missteps and gaffs in foreign policy, behavior that has done much to convey an impression of amateurishness in foreign affairs. Critics of India's performance point to a series of actions that have betrayed its uncertainties about the newly emerging world, including these:
*India's announcement that it would not recognize the three Baltic republics after they declared their independence from the Soviet Union. Three weeks later, it reversed its position. For their part, the Baltic states have largely ignored India.
*The failure of India's Embassy in Moscow to anticipate the events of August and to provide any effective analysis of the events in the wake of the coup's collapse.
*New Delhi's effort to pursue relations with the Soviet Union even as it was dissolving.
*The slowness with which India responded to Pakistan's proposal for the establishment of a nuclear-free zone in South Asia, a proposal endorsed by the Soviet Union, much to India's shock, and China.
*India's scuttling of a summit conference of regional countries last month and its apparent unwillingness to move decisively to resolve its decades-long disputes with its most powerful neighbor, Pakistan.
Emerging as a central target of criticism over the country's international performance is the Foreign Minister, Madhavsingh Solanki, an affable Congress Party politician who has publicly said he did not want the job, who is increasingly seen as unable to understand the world around him and incapable of providing leadership in formulating new foreign policy initiatives. India Today tersely labeled him as "a square peg in a round hole," who was "ineffective and inarticulate."
Indeed, at a meeting last month between Mr. Solanki and Reginald Bartholomew, the United States Under Secretary of State for international security, the Indian Foreign Minister simply sat in silence after Mr. Bartholomew gave a brief report on American concerns in the region.
Mr. Solanki, in recent conversations, has reiterated many of the policies of earlier governments, stressing the importance of such organizations as the nonaligned movement, a group of mostly third world countries known for hostility to the United States and a less-than-critical attitude toward authoritarian dictatorships and human rights violations among members.
Nowhere has India's lack of surefootedness in international affairs been more apparent than in its relations with the Soviet Union and the emerging republics. "They're still looking at the Soviet Union in a freeze-frame manner," said Shekar Gupta, a senior editor at India Today. "They still look at the Soviet Union as the same as before the coup. They have a nostalgia for the past and an affection for Communism."
Only belatedly did India recognize the importance of Mr. Yeltsin and only with difficulty was Mr. Solanki able to meet the Russian President during his visit to the republic in November. India's trade relations with the old Soviet Union, largely the product of sweeping treaties, have disintegrated as the union fragmented, but in New Delhi there is still talk in the halls of the Ministry of External Affairs about preserving treaties of friendship and of India's special relationship with Moscow.
 
Relations With the West
 But some Western diplomats here are more charitable in their assessments. "I see the Indians casting about," said a senior Western envoy. "That's not the same as floundering. There have been efforts to smooth relations with the United States, with the European Community, with Japan, the I.M.F. and the World Bank. That's been a solid decision."
Perhaps the most significant act by India, from the perspective of Western diplomats, was its decision to vote to repeal the United Nations resolution equating Zionism with racism, a measure India sponsored when it was adopted in 1975. The United States as well as dozens of Western countries bombarded the Ministry for External Affairs with official and bluntly worded messages urging that India join them in the vote to repeal.
As India pursues a program of internal economic liberalization, and necessarily a more relaxed approach to foreign investment, there is a growing view here that India's foreign policy is being orchestrated less and less by the views of the Foreign Ministry officials and more by the consequences of decisions made by the Finance Minister, Manmohan Singh. Since his appointment in June, Mr. Singh has recharted India's economic course by encouraging foreign investment, closer links with the International Monetary Fund, devaluation of the country's overvalued currency and encouragement of private enterprise.

SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 3; Financial Desk

HEADLINE: DISSONANT MESSAGES: Market Place;
Can the Rally Endure Without a Recovery?

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS

 BODY:
Rarely in the history of Wall Street has a year ended with such opposing messages coming from the stock market and the economy.
The stock market story of 1991 was one of prices that soared early in the year and again at the end, producing an excellent year for large stocks, and a phenomenal one for small stocks. The Nasdaq composite index had its best year ever, rising 57 percent. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 20 percent. 
 But the economy barely limped along, with the weakness returning during the summer, and consumer confidence plunging to its lowest level in a decade, reversing a brief recovery that followed the liberation of Kuwait. Corporate profits are weak, and layoffs are rising.
 
Something Has to Give
 Such a divergence suggests that something has to give, that either the economy should pick up soon, or the stock market may have to surrender. Some market bears even suggest that both could happen.
Wall Street has long been a place where conventional wisdom can change almost overnight, far faster than most economists or politicians can appreciate. Such a change took place in the final three weeks of 1991, when a mood of despondency about the fate of the economy was replaced by renewed confidence in the ability of the Federal Reserve to spur business activity with lower interest rates. The Fed's sixth discount-rate reduction played an important role in igniting that resurgence. The Dow Jones industrial average leaped 10.7 percent in 15 trading days.
It was the most explosive move for stocks since early January, when pessimism over the possibility of war with Iraq was replaced by exultation at how weak a foe the Iraqis proved to be. That rally, as it continued, convinced many analysts that the recession that had begun the previous October would soon end. There was a brief economic recovery, but it soon faded.
The period of dismay, which began in November amid signs of the weak economy, brought stock prices to their lowest levels since March.
The problem, said one economist who remained confident of economic recovery, was too short a time frame. "On average, a change in short-term interest rates takes nearly 18 months to reach its maximum effect on the economy," said R. David Ranson of H. C. Wainwright & Company in Boston. "The short-run impact is negative." Mr. Ranson predicts that a period of strong growth, lasting at least two years, is likely to begin in 1992.
That level of optimism is rare, but many economists expect to see real growth by the second half of this year, and that expectation is embodied in most bullish forecasts.
"I think 1992 is going to be a good year," said Abby Joseph Cohen, the co-chairman of the investment policy committee at Goldman, Sachs & Company. "It will be the first year in three in which we have had any kind of improvement in profits." She forecasts that stock prices will advance as the profit outlook becomes clearer.
But many people, including Ms. Cohen, suggest the riskiest time of the year may be early in it. Carmine Grigoli, the chief equity portfolio strategist at the First Boston Corporation, predicts that by the end of 1992 the Dow is likely to reach 3,400. In the meantime, he says, it could drop to 2,750.
"Taken together, a weakening economy, falling profits, earnings disappointments and high valuations suggest that the early months of 1992 will be a vulnerable period for the stock market," Mr. Grigoli wrote late in December. He said the earnings improvement needed to justify current prices was unlikely before late 1992.
Such forecasts should, of course, be taken with a grain of salt. As Mr. Grigoli also wrote, "For many forecasters, 1991 was a humbling experience."
While there undoubtedly was a crystal ball somewhere in which both the economy and the stock market were in focus, it was not easy to find. In general, a year ago forecasters thought that both the stock market and the economy would revive in 1991, or that neither would.
It is common for stocks to begin rising before the end of a recession, but in this case the lead time was far greater than normal -- assuming that the recession has yet to end. One explanation for that move, beloved among bears, is that traders simply put too much trust in the Fed, and have yet to recognize that this recession reflects structural problems brought on by the huge debt of the 1980's hanging over the economy, problems that cannot easily be offset by lower interest rates.
Many bulls offer an explanation of the stock market's explosive performance in 1991 that suggests it will be a precursor of things to come. They argue that the prolonged period of low short-term interest rates is leading to a fundamental shift in Americans' investment preferences, away from short-term, risk-free investments and toward long-term stocks and bonds.
"At some point, household investors will say: 'I am investing for the long term. I want to be investing in an asset category that offers a better long-term return,' " said Ms. Cohen of Goldman, Sachs.
Another explanation, which could suggest a less-long-lasting bull market, is that the Fed's attempt to spur growth for most of 1991 simply provided money that the "real" economy did not need, because businesses did not want to build new plants or install new machines. That money had to go somewhere, and much of it went into financial assets, pushing up prices of stocks and bonds.
"What we are seeing is that there can be a paper asset inflation in the face of a slow economy," said Charles Clough, the chief strategist at Merrill Lynch.
To Michael Murphy, the editor of Overpriced Stock Service, a newsletter that reports on stocks he expects to decline, the flip side could come this year. He forecasts that if the economy does revive, it could absorb money that is now in financial assets, and send stock prices lower. Or, he argues, stock prices could fall if the economy stays weak.
If 1991 taught that the stock market can become decoupled from the economy, it also retaught some old lessons: for example, that the best buys may be found among the most hated stocks, or that it is possible to find a great performer in a bad industry, or vice versa.
Evidence of the first point could be found in the performance of Goodyear, which in 1990 ranked as the worst performer in the Dow Jones industrial average, losing 56.6 percent of its value. So what happened in 1991? Goodyear's prospects turned out to be not so bad as had been expected, and its stock made up all of that loss and more. It rose 183.4 percent, making it the best performer among the Dow stocks.
The worst Dow stock in 1991 was Westinghouse, down 36.8 percent as huge losses from its financial services subsidiary were disclosed. But as the year ended, it appeared that investors were hoping for another revival. From the time the market bottomed, on Dec. 10, to the end of the year, Westinghouse was up 22 percent, making it one of the best performers for the period.
If there was one industry to avoid in 1991, it was oil. At the beginning of the year there was talk of soaring prices brought on by the gulf war. Instead, Saudi Arabia stepped up production, demand fell as economies weakened, and the price fell. Many oil stocks were down, and Standard & Poor's ranked oil and gas as the worst performing group.
Don't tell that to holders of Triton Energy. Its shares rose a stunning 434 percent. Triton had the good fortune to make what its backers hope is a huge discovery in Colombia.
On the other side, there was no stronger group than biotechnology, which produced no fewer than 24 initial public offerings. Biotech stocks dominate the list of best-performing stocks both on the American Stock Exchange and in the Nasdaq over-the-counter market. But Granada Biosciences saw a planned sale of part of its business fall through, and the stock price went with it, dropping 96 percent.
Speaking of going in different ways, consider two companies controlled by media moguls: Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation and Robert Maxwell's Maxwell Communication. When the year began, it was News Corporation that had widely publicized debt problems and was scaring investors, while Mr. Maxwell's company seemed far more secure. By the end of the year, News Corporation shares had nearly tripled, while Maxwell Communication shares may be worthless when the investigations of the late Mr. Maxwell's actions are completed.

HEADLINE: Banking Crisis Still Grips Rhode Island

DATELINE: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Jan. 1

 BODY:
On New Year's Day 1991, Bruce Sundlun was inaugurated as the new Governor of Rhode Island. Less than an hour after the ceremony, he announced that 45 banks and credit unions would be closed indefinitely because of the collapse of the Rhode Island Share and Deposit Indemnity Corporation, the private fund that insured them.
More than $1 billion, belonging to more than 150,000 depositors, was frozen. A year later, many of those people still have not been paid, and state regulators are still ironing out how to do so. 
 The state has blamed poor record-keeping by the banks and credit unions for the delay. Although Governor Sundlun, a Democrat, has proposed and won approval of a plan to pay the depositors, payoffs have been repeatedly stalled while the state waits for private investors to acquire the closed institutions.
Although 36 of the 45 closed institutions have been reopened, depositors with accounts in the remaining nine institutions have received payouts equaling about 10 percent of their accounts' values. Smaller depositors with accounts of $2,500 or less have been paid in full.
 
A Statehouse Demonstration
 Tonight hundreds of depositors still waiting for their money held a candlelight vigil outside the Statehouse here to mark the anniversary of the crisis.
With their arms around each other, depositors lined the steps of the marble-domed Capitol and waved signs demanding, "We Want Our Money Back Now."
Sam Masnuppelli, a 71-year-old depositor, rode a Honda motorcycle with a trailer that held a sign decorated in Christmas lights that said, "Governor, It's Our Money, Not Yours."
For many, last year was one of frustration and anger. Some depositors have been consumed by the daily developments of the credit union crisis, partly because they believed that their money would have been returned by now.
 
'Faith Has Been Shattered'
 "Nineteen ninety-one will be written off as the year Rhode Island lost its hope," said Terrence McKenna, who has led numerous rallies on behalf of depositors in Woonsocket, an old mill town 13 miles northwest of here. "That faith has been shattered by the inaction of legislators and their absolute inability to handle this problem in a quick and efficient manner."
Last August, in a protest with symbolic links to the Boston Tea Party in 1773, depositors dropped 3,000 teabags in front of the Governor's office. "We wanted the Governor to know how close we have come to a citizens' revolt," Mr. McKenna said.
Mr. McKenna, who owns a tire and auto parts business in Woonsocket, said he spent last year trying to keep his cash-strapped business afloat. With $90,000 frozen in an account in the Marquette Credit Union, one that is not expected to reopen, Mr. McKenna said he had to lay off some employees.
Many other businesses in this state did not survive 1991. Bankruptcy filings increased 62 percent in Rhode Island last year, a development that many residents attribute to the trickle-down effect of the credit union crisis. The size of the increase was second only to that in New Hampshire, where bankruptcy filings rose by 69 percent, according to a report released by the American Bankruptcy Institute this week.
All the money that was tied up in closed credit unions and banks is money that could have been spent or invested, depositors point out.
Waiting for Her Money
Jane Tinberg of Warwick, a 50-year-old native of Rhode Island and former McDonald's franchise owner, said she had more than $300,000 tied up in four of the closed institutions.
"I used to go shopping all the time, travel, go to the movies at least once a week," she said. "In 1991 I did not buy one article of clothing; I did not go to the movies once. My life has changed dramatically."
Before last Jan. 1, Ms. Tinberg said, she lived off the interest from those accounts.
She said she did not receive a single penny of her money until June. Since then she has received payouts totaling $29,500, she said, adding, "But I want to know when I am going to get the rest of my money back."
 
Some Have No Guarantees
 Under Mr. Sundlun's payout plan, depositors with up to $100,000 in frozen accounts are supposed to get back all their money. But those with more than $100,000 have been given no guarantees that all their money will be returned.
"The Governor has not ruled out payouts over $100,000," said Barbara Cottam, Mr. Sundlun's spokeswoman. But she said the credit unions that are in the worst shape -- Rhode Island Central, Central and Marquette -- will have to wait until acquisitions of the remaining institutions are completed.
"Once those are set we will be able to determine the payout schedule," she said. The state hopes to recover some of the money from pending lawsuits against the private insurer.
The insurer, Rhode Island Share and Deposit Indemnity, failed when it bailed out one of its institutions, Heritage Loan and Investment, after $13 million disappeared from Heritage Loan in late 1990.
 
Heavy Toll on Depositors
 The Governor has said depositors with accounts in credit unions that will not be acquired by other institutions should be paid in full by next June.
Ms. Cottam said 65 percent of the depositors in these institutions had been paid in full.
Meanwhile, depositors say the credit union crisis continues to take its toll on Rhode Islanders.
'You can't imagine the number of strokes, heart attacks and even suicides that this has caused," said Stephen Altieri, a leader of the depositors' protest.
"The sad thing is," he added, many depositors "are in the same situation they were a year ago."

Many of those people have still not been paid, and state regulators are ironing out how to pay them. Depositors rallied in Providence at a candlelight vigil on the anniversary of the crisis. (Bill Powers for The New York Times)

SECTION: Section A; Page 4; Column 3; Foreign Desk

HEADLINE: U.S.-Moscow Pact on Kabul Clears Way for Transitional Rule

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 1

 BODY:
An era ended in Afghanistan today, 12 years after a Soviet intervention that drew Washington into a proxy war with Moscow over a poor crossroads country that for centuries had been the focus of big-power rivalry.
Under an agreement announced on Sept. 13, Kabul's former backers in Moscow and the United States pledged to end all military assistance to their respective allies -- the leftist Government of President Najibullah in Afghanistan and a loose alliance of Islamic rebel groups based in Pakistan -- by the first of this year. 
 Officials on both sides say that the pledge had been met before the deadline, clearing the way for the formation of a transitional government under the sponsorship of the United Nations.
But Afghans and independent analysts say that the story of Afghanistan's most recent civil strife is far from over, and that the nation of 15 million, where more than a million people died in war and 5 million fled into exile, faces more instability within its borders that could affect the formerly Soviet Central Asian republics.
 
Excluding Najibullah
 "The military era is over for us," said Hamed Karzai, foreign policy adviser to the president of a fractious Afghan rebel coalition supported by the United States, Pakistan and Saudi Arabia. "Now we have to concentrate on how to solve the bigger problems of Afghanistan."
"Afghanistan is so divided and there are still so many hands in the Afghan issue that the country may lose itself to its divisions," said Mr. Karzai, who is in Washington on what he described as "a strictly private visit."
Afghan rebels, quarreling among themselves, are united in their unwillingness to include President Najibullah, a ruthless head of the Afghan secret police who rode to power on a Soviet tank, in talks about a future government.
Among the Afghan rebels, there is a fear that the Najibullah Government, having lost Russian aid, will be supported by governments in neighboring Tajikistan and Uzbekistan, where secular leftist leaders would be concerned that Islamic rule in Kabul would encourage Muslim fundamentalist movements within their borders.
 
Threat to the Secular
 "They would support Kabul not out of love for Najib," Mr. Karzai said, "but because a resistance government in Afghanistan would be seen as a threat to their secular social structure."
He said such considerations could outweigh the common ethnicity of Tajiks or other groups whose culture links Afghanistan to Central Asia.
Barnett G. Rubin of Columbia University, writing in a memorandum to be delivered at the Carter Center for policy studies at Emory University this month, said: "Today the war in Afghanistan is not solely or even mainly about who is to govern Kabul and under what rules of the game. It is about the nature of the state of Afghanistan itself."
"As much as, if not more than, the former Soviet Union, Afghanistan is threatened with economic collapse and ethnic and sectarian conflict," Mr. Rubin said. "Combined with the coming crisis of the international state system in Central Asia and the escalation of tensions between nuclear-armed adversaries on the Indian Subcontinent, Afghanistan threatens to become part of a regionwide challenge to world peace."
On Tuesday, Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif of Pakistan told reporters in Islamabad that his Government was not bound by the Washington-Moscow agreement. The Pakistani military and its Inter-services Intelligence agency are known to have a continuing interest in Afghanistan, which many consider a jumping-off place for influence in Central Asia.
A Bush Administration official said that it is not likely that Pakistan can do much on its own to continue a war in Afghanistan so long as it has to devote most of its resources to defense against India. In addition, the United States cut off all military aid to Pakistan in the fall of 1990. The official discounted reports that American weapons were being delivered to the Afghan rebels via Saudi Arabia.
Administration officials also do not believe that India, which has been a strong supporter of President Najibullah, would be willing to back him militarily at a time when New Delhi, having lost its Soviet alliance, is seeking friends in the West.

HEADLINE: ROSLYN HARBOR JOURNAL;
Spy's Library Holds Many Volumes but No Secrets

BYLINE: By JOHN T. McQUISTON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ROSLYN HARBOR, L.I.

 BODY:
"WHAT secrets have you learned?" is usually the first question Henry L. Grant is asked when he is introduced as curator of the personal library of William J. Casey, the former Director of Central Intelligence.
"But I have to tell them there aren't any juicy documents lying around," Mr. Grant said. "The C.I.A. made sure of that long ago." 
 The library is part of the late Mr. Casey's 133-year-old Victorian estate, Mayknoll, overlooking Roslyn Harbor on the North Shore of Long Island. Its 10,000 volumes include a vast collection of books on espionage, a subject that seems to emerge from every nook and cranny.
"These are not the kind of books you would pick up and read lightly," said Mr. Grant, a 72-year-old former member of the Central Intelligence Agency and a specialist in library and information sciences. "This is all heavyweight stuff. There's very little gumshoe or other fiction here."
"Mr. Casey was very interested in the history of subversion, terrorism, abduction and economic warfare," Mr. Grant said. "In addition to espionage and war, there are also the special areas of Judaica, Christianity, archeology and biography."
Mr. Grant said he had spent the last three and a half years sorting and cataloguing the collection and entering the data into a computer catalogue program, making it available for the first time to the public for scholarly research. He said that the Hoover Institute of War and Peace at Stanford University was seeking to add the Casey library to its collection, but that Mr. Casey's widow, Sophia, was holding on to it.
Mrs. Casey, carrying a silver tray with a crystal decanter and glasses, welcomed visitors with a warm smile. "Have some sherry," she said. "It's cold outside."
"We get a strong wind off the bay, winter and summer," she said, glancing out one of the many windows that surround the library, once a porch extending across the back of the house, which she said was built in 1858.
Mrs. Casey said that both she and her husband had grown up on Long Island, married in 1941 and lived in the house for 40 years.
"This was Tory country, an old English area," she said. She recalled that her husband had written an extensive history of the Revolutionary War. "There once were many spies in this area who would make runs back and forth to Brooklyn," she said.
"George Washington was his own intelligencer," Mr. Grant added. "He was the guy who masterminded the intelligence system that we had then. But it wasn't until Franklin Roosevelt and Bill Donovan during World War II that the United States really got interested in a formal intelligence network."
Mr. Casey was sent by Mr. Donovan, a former Roosevelt aide in Albany, to England to start an intelligence office in London. Mr. Casey, a graduate of Fordham University and St. John's University Law School, was successful at a variety of business ventures. He contributed heavily to the Republican Party and was rewarded by President Richard M. Nixon with appointments as chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, Under Secretary of State for Economic Affairs and president of the Export-Import Bank.
After serving as campaign manager for Ronald Reagan, Mr. Casey headed the Central Intelligence Agency for six years.
His C.I.A. tenure ranged through the United States aid program to the Mujahedin resistance in Afghanistan, the Solidarity movement in Poland and the Iran-contra affair. The affair raised the key question of whether a White House aide, Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North of the Marine Corps, acted alone or with Mr. Casey's implied or direct consent in financing covert operations in Central America through the sale of arms to Iran. Mr. Casey's death at the height of the controversy in 1986 left the question unanswered.
Mrs. Casey, who is 78, sat in her husband's Cabinet chair from the White House, ran her fingers over its brown leather. "If you've lived history, you're very alert to history," she said. "Bill loved history as much as he loved coordinating intelligence, especially the analytical side of it."

HEADLINE: 2 Charities for Poor Children Battle Over a Name

BYLINE: By ANDREW L. YARROW, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WESTPORT, Conn.

 BODY:
Usually occupied with helping the world's poorest children, a Connecticut-based charity has recently become embroiled in a nettlesome legal and public-relations battle over its own name.
Save the Children, a 60-year-old nonprofit organization with headquarters here, has become more than a little upset over a newer, increasingly well-financed group also dedicated to aiding impoverished children. To defend its trademarked name and stave off what some organization officials say is an intentional effort to create public confusion about the two groups, Save the Children has sued the newer charity, Feed the Children, which is based in Oklahoma City, charging trademark infringement. 
 "We have objected to their use of 'Feed the Children' as confusing because we have gotten calls and letters about 'our TV ads' that weren't ours," said James Bausch, the president of Save the Children. "People said that they didn't look like the old Save the Children ads, suggesting that they were more exploitative and wondering why they were very religiously oriented."
But the Rev. Larry Jones, who founded Feed the Children in 1979 as part of the Larry Jones International Ministries, said that words like "feed" and "children" cannot be trademarked, and his organization's name merely states the obvious.
"We started by bringing surplus American grain to Haiti and then Africa, where we saw tremendous poverty and children suffering," said the 51-year-old minister, whose televised sermons are nationally broadcast. "As people called, wanting to give us food for children, we gave what we were doing a name."
Although each organization professes admiration for the other's work, the battle has cultural and economic undertones. Save the Children embodies a New Deal-era philosophy of secular charity, while Feed the Children is very much a part of the upsurge in Christian fundamentalism of the 1970's and 1980's.
In addition, at a time when philanthropic dollars have been declining, Feed the Children has attracted financial support that might otherwise have gone to Save the Children, its organizers say.
Feed the Children began to attract the attention of Save the Children several years ago. Responding to the older organization's objections, Mr. Jones applied in 1987 to the United States Patent and Trademark Office for legal registration of his charity's name. In the fall of 1990, the agency's Trademark Trial and Appeal Board denied the trademark, but Mr. Jones's group continued to call itself Feed the Children in its ads and other fund-raising appeals.
Save the Children filed a trademark lawsuit last summer and a motion for summary judgment in late December, said Matthew A. Landy, the organization's corporate secretary and an executive vice president. The suit demands that Feed the Children change its name and destroy all ads and printed material using the name.
Mr. Landy noted that Feed the Children has not only been using "remarkably similar" television ads and a similar logo -- of a child with outstretched arms -- but also showed up in nearby Bridgeport several weeks ago with 80,000 pounds of food to be distributed and an ample supply of press releases.
"At the same time that Larry Jones's attorneys were directed by the court to meet with our attorneys, he was holding a press conference beside two of his tractor-trailers," Mr. Landy said. "He claims that the timing and the selection of Bridgeport -- on our back door -- were coincidental."
In a Nov. 13 letter to Mr. Landy that was distributed at the news conference, Mr. Jones said: "It is extremely disappointing and frustrating that you and Mr. Bausch approach this matter as though it is McDonald's versus Hardee's rather than two organizations seeking to help needy children. To look at Feed the Children as 'competition' for the charity dollar rather than as an ally in an extraordinarily important and difficult battle is both cynical and callous." The letter also said both groups "should get back to serving children rather than paying lawyers."
Mr. Landy characterized the letter as "self-serving." He added, "We don't want to spend money on lawyers, and we don't have public relations firms working for us," referring to the fact that Mr. Jones has retained a former Congressman, Toby Moffett, who now works for the public relations firm of Hill & Knowlton.
Mr. Landry said that in November, during their only face-to-face meeting, Mr. Jones refused to consider using another name that his ministry employs -- "Touch a Child" -- or even "Feed a Child."
 
New Group Grows Faster
 Feed the Children has been growing far more rapidly than Save the Children in recent years. In 1990, The Nonprofit Times, a monthly trade journal, ranked Save the Children as America's 34th largest charity and Feed the Children as the 41st. Although its 1991 rankings have not yet been compiled, information provided by the two charities indicates that Feed the Children surpassed the older charity in 1991.
In the 1991 fiscal year, which ended Sept. 30, Save the Children had a budget of $97.5 million, Mr. Bausch said. Feed the Children, which has the same fiscal year, received $86.3 million worth of food and other gifts in kind and $25.7 million in cash, Mr. Jones said.
The charities differ considerably in their missions. Save the Children combines long-term community assistance and child-sponsorship with immediate relief, with programs in 20 states and 37 other countries. Feed the Children principally provides short-term food assistance, particularly after disasters, operating throughout the United States and about 30 other countries.
Save the Children spends 84.1 percent on direct relief, while Feed the Children devotes 79.1 percent to direct relief and 12.1 percent to "ministry and education." For both, the remaining money goes for administration and fund-raising.
Both sides say their main concern is helping children.
"We don't want to do anything to harm Feed the Children, and we don't want it to look like a fight when we should be concentrating on children," Mr. Bausch said. "There's unfortunately more than enough need out there to go around."
 
Do TV Ads Aid Both?
 Mr. Jones also said that he has been "very complimentary of Save the Children's work," but added: "You would think that our television programs would elevate support for all children's causes."
Asserting that he remains baffled by Save the Children's lawsuit, Mr. Jones nonetheless speculated that "there could be some animosity since I'm from the Midwest, I'm a Christian minister and we're one of the fastest-growing charities in the country."
Save the Children officials dispute Mr. Jones's suggestions that they are rivals and that the Connecticut charity is having trouble raising money, but Mr. Landy said that "the confusion absolutely has siphoned money away from us."
Mr. Bausch added: "Over the years other organizations with names like Help Our Children or Feed Our Children have agreed to change their names, but Larry Jones has been unwilling to work things out. It's not a semantic issue. People should be clear what organization they are giving to."
With the courts thus far siding with Save the Children, Mr. Jones grudgingly recognizes that his charity may have to relinquish its name.
"Either way we go -- to find another name they would agree with, or a court battle -- we're in a no-win situation," he said. "I've spent 12 years getting people familiar with our name, and with a change we'd lose that name recognition. People would ask why we did it, and it would cost hundreds of thousands of dollars."

HEADLINE: DISSONANT MESSAGES;
An Uncertain Outlook For Dollar's Rebound

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
As the new year begins, the dollar is falling, just like last year. But analysts are not soon expecting a sudden and sharp rebound of the sort that occurred at the beginning of 1991. In fact, some forecasts show the dollar falling to record lows against the German mark before it makes a modest recovery late in the year.
The latest jolt to the sagging dollar came the week before Christmas, when the Bundesbank raised German interest rates sharply and the Federal Reserve cut American interest rates sharply a day later. By the end of the year, the dollar had lost almost all the ground it had gained against the mark and other European currencies in 1991 and had fallen against the yen as well. 
 The chance of new lows combined with the possibility of a subsequent rally could make the year difficult for American business, especially exporters or companies that have significant operations abroad. As long as the dollar is falling or remains low, they are in great shape, because their foreign profits are worth more in dollars. But they will have to scramble to protect profits from abroad by hedging if the dollar suddenly turns higher. And a turn in the dollar may not be nearly as easy to read this year as it was last year.
 
Layers of Protection
 "We are looking at the effects if the dollar were to turn around," said Peter M. Donahower, assistant treasurer at Tandem Computers Inc. in Cupertino, Calif. "We are laying in levels of protection using options in case the general market expectation is wrong."
He said that regardless of his view, which is that the dollar will continue to be weak until there is a clear sign of an American economic recovery, "We will take hedging action.
"The view would determine how much and how far we would go out on the economic horizon," he said, "and how closely we would watch it."
Last year analysts pinpointed the turn in the dollar fairly quickly, though the reverse last February probably came a lot sooner than many had expected. But they were generally fooled by the sharpness and speed of the dollar's increase -- up 23 percent against the German mark by July 2. They were a little less stunned by its sudden plunge at year-end, when the hope for economic recovery in the United States evaporated. The dollar ended 1991 at 1.5170 marks, up only 1.68 percent and showed similar increases against other European currencies.
Against the Japanese yen, the story was the reverse. In all the flurry of the dollar rally and the dust following its sudden fall, the yen quietly gained on the American currency. The dollar ended the year at its low of 124.78 yen, down 7.84 percent, even after the Japanese cut their discount rate on Monday.
 
Two Big Factors
 This year, two main forces will tug at the dollar, the same two as last year. Economic recovery, which would help the dollar, has yet to materialize. Nor is there any potential spark, like the victory in the Persian Gulf war last year, to set off the rally.
The sighting of a sure recovery should give the dollar some strength. A recovery would mean an end to falling interest rates. And it would attract foreign investment in the stock market and elsewhere to take advantage of the rebound, also giving the dollar a boost. Of course, to the extent that the economy of Japan strengthens, that would support the yen.
The force working against the dollar is the higher interest rates in other countries. That favors European currencies now and gives a smaller edge to the yen. Short-term interest rates in Germany are currently 538 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, higher than in the United States. In Japan, the differential is 138 basis points. These differentials drain money out of the dollar into these higher-earning currencies.
"The interest rate argument favors the European currencies," said Neal M. Soss, chief economist at the First Boston Corporation in New York. "The United States will ease more, and so will the Japanese. But in Europe, they cannot ease until the Germans are ready. But the economic-performance arguments tilt either in favor of the United States or Japan. These variables frame the values next year."
Mr. Soss said the increase in interest rates by the Bundesbank and the cut by the Fed had just strengthened the two forces pulling on the dollar, leaving its fate still unresolved.
"It re-emphasizes the themes," Mr. Soss said. "The American economy is more likely to pick up sooner, and the interest-rate differential is even more favorable to the European currencies than it was before."
John Lipsky, director of international bond research at Salomon Brothers in London, said the key for dollar forecasters is to decide "whether the United States economy faces some serious structural problems that will push it into a new decline or whether the traditional tools of monetary and fiscal policy will ultimately restore growth in the relatively near future, albeit it at a modest pace."
Salomon's position, he said, is that the traditional tools will work and that there will be a moderate recovery that will give the dollar a lift, possibly pushing it back into the 1.60 range against the mark by the end of the year.

HEADLINE: DISSONANT MESSAGES;
Investors' Hopes Overseas Shaded by Doubt

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The professionals who spend their time pondering foreign stock markets say that on balance they are optimistic about 1992.
But their optimism, bolstered by an end-of-the-year rally, is tempered by the underlying economic outlook, especially uncertainity about a global recovery. This makes 1992 harder to call than 1991, despite the threat of the war at the beginning of last year. 
 Some analysts predict returns on equities this year of 20 to 25 percent worldwide, better than 1991, when the gain was 16.53 percent in dollar terms after a sharp decline in 1990. But the 1991 performance was achieved only with a surge in the final week and a record-setting rally in the United States. As a whole, the Financial Times index for all world markets ended at its high for the year because of the American rally. But many leading markets still finished below their 1991 highs. Without the rally, the year would have been little more than half as good.
 
A Rally Late in the Year
 The fourth quarter began with a sharp decline. But the year-end rally turned that into a 3.72 percent rise in the index, in dollar terms. But much of this gain was from a slumping dollar. In local currencies, the index was virtually unchanged. In 1990, the index fell by more than 19 percent.
The reasons for optimism in 1992 include expectations of falling interest rates, a continuing decline in inflation and relatively attractive values in many stock markets, in part because of projections of higher earnings. But these forecasts all include ifs. The economic recovery in the United States, which is important for stock markets worldwide, is in doubt, despite the sharp interest rate cut by the Federal Reserve on Dec. 20. So is the recovery in Britain.
Economies elsewhere are slowing. While short-term interest rates have fallen sharply in the United States, Britain and Japan, which cut its discount rate on Monday, the Bundesbank raised German interest rates another half a percentage point the day before the Fed acted, confirming that rates in Europe will not soon fall. France, Spain and Italy have all followed with interest rate increases, and Britain may have to follow, too, despite an approaching election. Earnings estimates are falling rapidly. And the remaking of what was the Soviet Union offers plenty of opportunities for developments that may disturb world markets.
This uncertainty behind the optimistic forecasts is leading some brokerage firms and money managers to hedge or even trim their bets on equities by putting more money into bonds, especially in Europe, where there is the best chance for a bond rally next year.
For Americans there is another possible negative: the dollar. It fell sharply at the end of the year and could rally this year if the positive forecasts are right and the American economy rebounds. But a rally would cut into capital gains from abroad when they are translated back into dollars.
Guy Rigden of UBS Phillips & Drew in London has a well-hedged, optimistic view for 1992. When told that his optimism sounded a little pessimistic, he turned to Charles Dickens's "Tale of Two Cities" to underline his sentiment. "It was the spring of hope; it was the winter of despair," he read.
He then expressed his view in his own words. "You have to have a central case of assumptions, but that central case is more uncertain than it is normally," he said.
Because of the uncertainty, Mr. Rigden has just revised his recommendations for client portfolios, shifting money from equities to bonds. He has moved to a 50 percent investment in equities, below his normal or neutral level, from 65 percent. And he has jumped to an aggressive 40 percent in bonds, from 25 percent, with the remaining 10 percent in cash.
"I would rather get, with a pretty high degree of confidence, the 15 percent in bonds than the 20 to 25 percent in equities, with all the uncertainty," he said.
One of the uncertainties, he said, is corporate profits. While he expects them to grow this year, he acknowledges that forecasters have gotten profit forecasts wrong the last two years.
Lawrence W. Harris 3d, a director of Lombard Odier International, a fund manager in London, said declining inflation and falling interest rates would give equities a lift this year. He also argued that falling short-term and long-term interest rates would provide stock markets a sort of safety net, because there would be fewer attractive alternatives for investors as the return on fixed-income investments continues to drop.
 
Views Expected to Change
 "Sometime during the year people are going to think that things are good rather than bad," he said. "And then, at some point, stocks should kick in because there is so little competition to stocks these days, especially as long-term interest rates begin to fall."
But Mr. Harris is still placing his biggest bets in bonds; his funds are aggressively buying long-term bonds outside the United States. "I think in most cases that the long bond will do better than the stock market in whatever country you are talking about," he said.
The December rise in German interest rates makes this forecast even more likely. The rate increase should signal that rates have reached their peak and also further curb inflation in Europe by slowing growth. Both factors are good for bond markets.
Richard H. King, the manager of Counsellors International Equity Fund in New York, holds another view. This is the time for investors to switch from bonds to equities, he said, but he adds a note of caution. "Because we are coming from a recession, I think that 1992 is going to be a better year," he said. "But it is going to be a bumpy year."
Once one decides to invest in stocks abroad, the question is what country and stocks to choose, a matter of much debate and uncertainty. In Europe, the biggest question is whether to buy German stocks.
Mr. Rigden says yes, arguing that the German market is a good two-way bet. The stock market should rise, he said, if economic growth is slow next year, because interest rates will finally be cut and inflation will fall. But if growth continues, stocks should be helped by rising earnings and dividends.
 
Doubts About the Germans
 But Goldman, Sachs expects the German market to be a below-average performer in Europe because its stocks are still overpriced and because inflation will be high this year, with growth slowing.
The Japanese market is another tough question. Many firms take a neutral or negative view. Michael Howell, chief strategist for Salomon Brothers in London, said a recent survey indicated that equity managers in Tokyo did not expect the stock market to be higher a year from now. But Mr. King said that the decline in the market since 1990 had made it more attractive and that it should get some impetus from Japanese interest-rate cuts, like the one announced this week, that are expected as the economy slows.
As for the year that just ended, it began well for stock markets, soured in the fall and then ended with a rally. The United States and Hong Kong ended at new highs. But other record-breakers, like Britain, did not regain their lofty peaks by the end of the year. The threat of the Persian Gulf war, which drove markets down at the end of 1990 and the first two weeks of 1991, was turned to the impetus for a rally at the beginning of the year when the United States and its allies swept the Iraqi forces aside.
 
Exchange Rate Gains
 But markets slumped when the economic recovery in the United States fizzled and interest rates remained high in Europe. Without a 6.91 percent rise in dollar terms in December -- with half of that rally in the United States -- world markets would have been down for the last three months of the year.
For all of 1991, Mexico led the Financial Times index of 24 markets for the fourth consecutive year, as the Mexican market continued to ride the crest of the country's economic reforms. In dollar terms, the market was up 138.03 percent.
Hong Kong was No. 2, rising 44.79 percent on real estate gains and better relations with China. The worst performers were Finland, down 24.35 percent after being shaken by the loss of business with the Soviet Union; Austria, down 15.31 percent, and Norway, down 12.47 percent. The Norwegian market was hit by a banking crisis.
 
Where the U.S. Is Tops
 Among the large markets, the United States was tops, rising 27.44 percent. Japan was almost unchanged in 1991 in terms of the yen, but grew 8.86 percent in dollar terms, because of the decline of the dollar against the yen.
In Europe, the sharp dollar rally early in the year cut deeply into returns. But the fall at year-end eased that pain, more than doubling some of the gains in dollar terms in the last two weeks of the year. France, the second-best performer of the leading markets, was up 14.81 percent in dollars at year-end, compared with a rise of 5.3 percent on Dec. 13. Germany, the third-worst performer of the major markets, was up 4.84 percent in dollars, compared with a slight fall of 0.77 percent on Dec. 13.
Of the large markets, the Italians brought up the rear. Plagued by strikes that temporarily closed the Milan market, financial scandals, delays in settling trades, and the drag of a weak economy and faltering earnings, the market fell 3.72 percent in dollar terms and 1.97 percent in lire.

HEADLINE: Hollywood Delighted At Holiday Success. But Relaxed? No.

BYLINE: By BERNARD WEINRAUB, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOLLYWOOD, Jan. 1

 BODY:
The movie world opened the new year in a giddy but nervous mood.
After a tepid economic year in Hollywood, such films as "Hook," "Beauty and the Beast" and "Father of the Bride" did strong business over the holidays in a time of recession. And many movie executives, vacationing in such places as Aspen, Colo.; Sun Valley, Idaho, and Maui, Hawaii, read their daily faxes of box office returns and proclaimed business better than ever. 
 But other film makers were less sanguine. "I don't see many blessings here," said Lili Fini Zanuck, director of the new film "Rush," about two undercover narcotics agents who turn into lawbreakers, and best known for producing the movie "Driving Miss Daisy" with her husband, Richard D. Zanuck.
Ms. Zanuck, speaking from her home in Sun Valley, said: "The real family-oriented pictures are doing incredible business, but the adult films, "Bugsy" and "J. F. K.," are not doing that kind of business. So there'll be pressure now on those of us who make adult films to come up with these same kinds of family movies. Including animated movies. Frankly, it's very difficult to make certain kinds of adult movies now, movies that were successful in the past, movies like 'Midnight Cowboy,' 'Serpico.' "
Even a traditionally optimistic executive like Mark Canton, head of Columbia Pictures, expressed some uncertainty about the box office over the holidays, one of the year's busiest times for moviegoing. "We're ending the year on an upbeat note," he said in an interview from Maui. "But I think the big news of last year is that the realities of the recession have begun to sink in and are still sinking in."
 
Finding Reasons
 The relatively poor year at the box office, he said, resulted from many factors, including the nation's weak economy, news events, including the Persian Gulf war, the collapse of the Soviet system and the Clarence Thomas hearings, all of which tended to keep people at home watching television, as well as the impoverished state of movies. "Maybe there just weren't enough good movies to attract people," Mr. Canton said. His comment was echoed by other executives.
It is still too early to predict the financial success or failure of any of the films that opened over the last two weeks. The producers of some smaller films took major risks in opening their movies amid powerful competition, risks that were made in order to qualify the movies for this year's Academy Awards. These smaller films include "Rush"; "Fried Green Tomatoes," a comedy-drama about a group of Southern women with Kathy Bates and Jessica Tandy; "The Inner Circle," partly based on a true story about Stalin's loyal film projectionist, portrayed by Tom Hulce; Lawrence Kasdan's drama "Grand Canyon," about race relations, midlife crisis and the randomness of life in Los Angeles, and David Cronenberg's "Naked Lunch," based on the novel about drugs, creativity and hallucination by William S. Burroughs.
It is, however, the expensive and lavishly publicized movies that have drawn the most attention and uncertainty. The Steven Spielberg extravaganza about Peter Pan, "Hook," which opened to mixed reviews, held the No. 1 position for the third week and has been performing with resilience at the box office. To executives at Sony Pictures, the parent company of Tri-Star, which produced "Hook," the box office results have been welcome, especially after the expensive movie proved disappointing at the box office when it opened.
 
The Palliative Effect
 "Look, this business depends on people picking themselves up out of their couch, putting fuel in their tanks, loading up the vehicle, parking and putting themselves in seats with 600 other people to share a communal experience," said Peter Guber, chairman of Sony Pictures Entertainment, speaking from his home in Aspen. "Movies basically have an allure that staying at home with a frozen chicken dinner and a video can't achieve. While entertainment isn't a panacea for problems, it certainly has a palliative effect. And this holiday season shows that."
A bleaker view was expressed by Marshall Brickman, a well-known screenwriter whose most recent credit was "For the Boys." Mr. Brickman, still upset about the failure of this holiday movie, said with a laugh that he was planning to write a prequel to it starring Macaulay Culkin and Anna Chlumsky and to call it "For the Goys."
"Why are people going to the movies?" he said. "It's probably the pre-crash panic. The kids are home. It's the holidays. I don't know many families who like to sit at home and discuss philosophy and art with their children. And if they can afford it, most American parents would prefer to take kids to a hypnotic experience based on the regurgitation of television."
Over the weekend, "Hook" took in $15.2 million, and its total gross earnings as of Tuesday were a formidable $65 million, Sony executives say. But whether the film will earn enough to repay the studio is another matter. Although the movie cost $60 million to $80 million, large percentages of the grosses go to Mr. Spielberg as well as to the three stars, Robin Williams, Dustin Hoffman and Julia Roberts.
 
The Biggest Success
 Perhaps the biggest success of the holiday season is the Walt Disney Company's musical animated film "Beauty and the Beast," which has grossed about $69 million as of Tuesday, film industry executives say. Because of holiday vacations, the movie had a striking leap in business last week, 119 percent over the previous week. Another Disney film, the remake of the M-G-M classic "Father of the Bride," was the third-highest grossing film for the weekend, earning $10.5 million over weekend and bringing its gross after less than two weeks to about $29.5 million. This is a surprisingly strong showing for the frothy comedy, which stars Steve Martin and Diane Keaton, because it got uneven if respectable reviews.
"You have a movie here where people walk out and feel everything's all right with the world, at least for the moment," said Howard Rosenman, co-president of Sandollar Motion Pictures and one of the producers of "Father of the Bride." He added: "The economy isn't good, the world is changing, there's AIDS, the homeless, terrible problems -- and you give the audience something reassuring and funny about a neurotic but not dysfunctional family. It'll work."
Others films that seem to be performing strongly are Barbra Streisand's "Prince of Tides," about a Southern teacher (Nick Nolte) who goes to New York to help his sister after she tries to kill herself, which came in No. 4 at the box office; "The Last Boy Scout," a Bruce Willis shoot-'em-up, which was No. 5, and "Star Trek VI," which came in seventh, after Oliver Stone's "J. F. K.," said Exhibitor Relations Inc., which monitors film releases for theater chains.
 
Some Disappointment
 What has surprised some film executives is that the extraordinarily publicized and controversial "J. F. K.," a revisionist version of President John F. Kennedy's assassination, is so far not doing quite the blockbuster business that the studio, Warner Brothers, expected. Industry executives said the movie had grossed about $21 million.
And the same mild if early disappointment is true to a degree for Barry Levinson's "Bugsy," starring Warren Beatty as the offbeat gangster who dreamed of turning Las Vegas into a mecca of gambling and entertainment. "Bugsy" has received some of the best newspaper and magazine reviews of the year, has already picked up several awards and is a probable prime contender for several major Academy Awards. Executives expect the film to start pulling in business over the next few weeks, especially after positive word-of-mouth reaction from audiences. "Bugsy" had grossed about $17.5 million as of Tuesday.
Mr. Guber said, "You can't attack every picture like 'Hook.' 'Bugsy' is a mature-audience film. It requires strong critical acclaim. This is a real film, not a movie. It requires audiences to become aware of its value and importance. That's what's happening."

HEADLINE: Kurt Masur in Leipzig: A Favorite Son at Home

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LEIPZIG, Germany, Dec. 28

 BODY:
His towering frame draped in baggy brown slacks and a gray shirt opened at the collar and not tucked in, Kurt Masur raised his arms and the Gewandhaus Orchestra stirred to life as though its genial music director had never been away.
It was his third visit to Leipzig, where he remains Kapellmeister, since assuming the directorship of the New York Philharmonic in September. At the end of his 10 days here, he will have conducted Beethoven's Ninth Symphony three times, including on New Year's Eve, extending a tradition begun in December 1918 by a predecessor here, Arthur Nikisch, in the dark aftermath of World War I. 
 "Grossartig" -- "Great" -- he murmured, flashing a thumbs-up sign as the music faded.
Leipzig is proud of the son who made it to the new world. For his part, Mr. Masur is still the same, kibitzing with soloists, harrumphing at the choir, throwing himself into the orchestra work as though he had never left.
Since he left Leipzig in the summer a lot has changed. Leipzig is afflicted with a million problems: crushing unemployment; wrenching debate about just who did and who did not collaborate with the old communist secret police, the Stasi, youthful disaffection. While he rehearsed in the empty craggy auditorium, knots of students huddled about campfires by the Gewandhaus, protesting the closure of a radio station for young people. But the musicians who rose to welcome him appeared glad to have him back if even for only a fleeting visit.
More than anything, Mr. Masur's return to conduct Beethoven's Ninth Symphony with its triumphal "Ode to Joy" climax seemed nothing if not an act of solidarity by a local son returning home with a much-needed message of hope.
"People are behaving maturely; hope is rising," he said, wiping his brow during a pause in the rehearsal. "Some, especially the unemployed, are in a bad situation." Those over 50, he said, were particularly hard hit, because in the primitive economy of what was East Germany, they had grown "unable to come into the computer age."
With Mr. Masur was his wife, the soprano Tomoko Sakurai; their 12-year-old son, Ken David, and a daughter, Carolin, from a previous marriage. Mr. Masur announced proudly that the family had just found quarters in Westchester County. "From February on we will have a home in New York," he said. But Christmas Eve, as in years past, was spent with family at the conductor's comfortable home on the edge of Leipzig, with its large garden and swimming pool, now covered for the winter.
Christmas Day the family went to hear Carolin, a singer with the Leipzig Opera, perform Hansel in Humperdinck's "Hansel und Gretel."
At the Gewandhaus, the conductor interrupted the musicians again and again, fine-tuning difficult transitions. The orchestra was breaking in new flute and bassoon soloists, he explained, but more importantly, "All the well-known pieces are in danger, if you don't work at them."
 
Source of Pride: No Defectors
 The 64-year-old conductor said he found his musicians in good spirits despite Leipzig's travails. None have defected to more lucrative jobs in western Germany, he said proudly, despite wage scales limiting earnings to about two-thirds of those in western German cities like Munich and Hamburg. His goal, he said, is to obtain equal pay and working conditions by 1993, in time to celebrate the Gewandhaus's 250th anniversary a year later.
Leading a visitor to his spacious office, Mr. Masur indicated the deep emotional links that tie him to the orchestra, which he has led since 1970. The walls of a foyer are hung with portraits of distinguished predecessors like Felix Mendelssohn and Wilhelm Furtwangler. He attributed the orchestra's "steadiness" to Mendelssohn, who founded the Leipzig Conservatory about 150 years ago, thereby creating the school that still supplies roughly 85 percent of the Gewandhaus musicians.
"That is not to say there is no competition," he said. "But what matters is that here, the principal goal of the students is simply to play in the Gewandhaus Orchestra." This was different in New York, he said, where, "normally, every musician's ambition is to be a new Isaac Stern."
The portrait of Vaclav Neumann, the Czechoslovak conductor who was Mr. Masur's immediate predecessor, seemed to bear witness to recent troubled times. In 1968, when East German troops joined Soviet units in crushing Czechoslovakia's brief Prague Spring, Mr. Neumann refused to conduct any more concerts in Leipzig and was replaced by Mr. Masur. In 1989, when protesters toppled the Communist regimes in both countries, the two men played key roles in the push for democracy.
In Leipzig, the revolution has been followed by bitter debate about those who collaborated with the old Communist secret police, the Stasi. The issue threatens to divide eastern Germans anew in January, when all citizens will obtain the right to examine their old Stasi files. Already, one orchestra member has resigned after confessing to being a Stasi agent, Mr. Masur said.
Chiding East Germans for their sluggishness in coming to terms with the past, Mr. Masur said that while West Germans generally overdid their discussions of East Germany's past crimes, "people here are in danger of not doing enough." He said the process was complicated by the spreading of scandals.
This was a reference to the newspaper reports that circulated here last year reviving discussion of a 1972 automobile accident in which three people, including Mr. Masur's former wife, lost their lives. The Communist authorities intervened to prevent an investigation of Mr. Masur's responsibility. But Leipzigers, recalling the conductor's leading role in the uprising that overthrew the Communists, appear to have laid the reports to rest.
 
Donations Instead of Subsidies
 The orchestra's most pressing problem, he said, is not political but financial, because of a collapsing economy. To offset cuts in state subsidies, he added, the orchestra would have to learn the unaccustomed American art of aggressively seeking private donors and commercial sponsors.
"We have to be careful and face the fact that the new provinces of Germany will not be able to pay for the upkeep of leading orchestras like the Gewandhaus or the Staatskapelle in Dresden," he said.
Even so, he added, he found "no disturbed mood" among the musicians, who he said were in "very good spirits, unchanged, doing what we have always done, trying to achieve artistic excellence."
