HEADLINE: SALVADOR ACCORD AIMS AT QUICK END TO LONG CIVIL WAR

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Jan. 1

 BODY:
The peace agreement reached early this morning by the Government of El Salvador and its guerrilla enemies will bring an almost immediate halt to their fighting and a final end to the 12 years of civil war there by autumn, rebel and Government officials said.
Diplomats said that the accord, wrapped up by Javier Perez de Cuellar in the final moments of his term as Secretary General of the United Nations, contains a number of points that have yet to be resolved, including details of the dismantling of the rebels' military structure and a comprehensive schedule for putting its various provisions into effect.
 
Signing Set for Jan. 16
 Although the two sides have negotiated other incomplete agreements in the past, this time they devised a guarantee to back their categorical promise that a formal cease-fire would go into effect on Feb. 1. The guarantee provides that if they fail to settle their remaining differences by Jan. 10, the United Nations would have the power to decide them. In either case, they said, "final agreements of peace" will be signed in Mexico City on Jan. 16. 
 "This signing constitutes the beginning of a new era of rebuilding toward democracy and freedom," President Alfredo Cristiani said after his negotiators put their signatures to the two-page preamble summarizing the treaty. "Thanks to God, everything has come out well."
One of the five top rebel commanders, Salvador Sanchez Ceren, added, "The war in El Salvador is over."
 
Resistance From the Right?
 It would be typical of this conflict, which has claimed more than 75,000 lives, if such optimism is soon met by the outrage of militant rightists who have little interest in the sweeping political changes that the agreement would bring about.
On the left, there appeared to be little room to criticize the rebels' gains. In return, essentially, for laying down their arms without a claim to power, they won agreement to changes that will reduce the size and political role of the armed forces, alter the Government's conservative social and economic policies and provide the rebels with full political freedoms after a cease-fire.
But even in the final weeks of contentious haggling over details, these peace talks have been sustained by a strong conviction on both sides that the militants have been isolated as never before.
Under intense international pressure, the two sides continued working on the details of the treaty until the year-end deadline they had set was virtually upon them. But following an emotional signing ceremony that began just after midnight, they sought only to make the point that it had been the suffering of ordinary Salvadorans that forced them to an end.
Tuesday afternoon, diplomats involved in the talks said they nearly foundered once again in a dispute over land redistribution. With Mr. Perez de Cuellar minutes away from his scheduled departure for the Bahamas on his first vacation as former Secretary General, Mr. Cristiani also threatened to leave if no progress was made, the diplomats said.
In the end, Mr. Perez de Cuellar stayed, urging diplomats from Spain, Colombia, Venezuela and Mexico to put pressure on some of the chief rebel negotiators. The United States Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, Bernard W. Aronson, and the chief American representative to the United Nations, Thomas R. Pickering, made similar efforts with delegates of the Government. Officials said the rebel position softened and a compromise was worked out to have a special commission review contested land claims in rebel-held zones on a case-by-case basis.
But around the same time of the day, an even more extraordinary meeting took place, diplomats said. For the first time, Mr. Ceren and Joaquin Villalobos, the two most powerful guerrilla commanders, sat down with a third commander to chat with El Salvador's Defense Minister, Gen. Rene Emilio Ponce.
 
Killing of Six Priests
 Like Mr. Villalobos, General Ponce has been the unchallenged leader of his comrades in arms and their most effective strategist. He has been vilified by his enemies as a ruthless killer. Representative Joe Moakley, Democrat of Massachusetts, who led a special House panel investigating the killing of six Jesuit priests at San Salvador's Central American University in November 1989, recently accused General Ponce of being present when the slayings were ordered. It was an accusation that General Ponce denied.
Yesterday, however, the commanders spoke not of their pasts but of the future. And they agreed that they should keep in touch when the rebels return to San Salvador, in case problems arise.
It is expected that problems will arise. It is not yet clear how quickly the insurgents will return to political roles, but in an interview this afternoon, one of the five senior guerrilla commanders, Roberto Roca, said that members of the rebel front would try to establish a legal political presence in Salvadoran cities before the demobilization of the rebels is to be completed on Oct. 31.
 
'Open Politics' in 1980
 "We will have to be cautious," he said. "But we did a lot of open politics in 1980, when the situation wasn't anything like it is now. Then, the death squads were in full operation."
It was that bloody response to the liberal junta set up after a coup by reformist officers in October 1979 that drove the left fully underground by late 1980.
In the early 1980's it appeared that a man identified by United States and Salvadoran officials as a leader of the assassination squads, a former National Guard major named Roberto d'Aubuisson, would consolidate a position as the country's most powerful politician. At one point, United States officials said, he hatched an assassination plot against Mr. Pickering, who was then America's Ambassador in San Salvador.
But in 1984, in the second in a series of national elections with which the Reagan Administration tried to create the foundations of democratic institutions, Mr. d'Aubuisson was defeated for the presidency by the Christian Democratic leader, Jose Napoleon Duarte.
Soon after his inauguration, Mr. Duarte announced his intention to meet the rebels for peace talks. The talks quickly foundered, however, as the armed forces came to dominate Mr. Duarte's Government.
As Mr. Duarte's Government became more and more ineffectual, however, the Reagan Administration turned its attentions to the Nationalist Republican Alliance, which Mr. d'Aubuisson had founded as the vehicle for his ambitions.
A year after his 1984 election defeat, Mr. d'Aubuisson sponsored Mr. Cristiani, then a 37-year-old coffee producer who had been one of his proteges, to take leadership, saying the party needed a new image.
 
Rebel Attitude on Election
 For all practical purposes, the rebels backed Mr. Cristiani's successful candidacy for the presidency in 1989 against the Christian Democrats. More hard-line insurgent commanders believed that his election would polarize the country, allowing the rebel front to move into at least part of the political void that Mr. Duarte had left. Rebel moderates argued that if a negotiated settlement was going to be possible, only a rightist Government would have the power to make it.
Even before Mr. Cristiani began pulling his party back from the extreme right and offered to meet the guerrillas for talks, the idea that he could be El Salvador's peacemaker was being widely advanced from a seemingly unlikely source.
At San Salvador's Central American University, a Jesuit institution that educated many of the children of El Salvador's elite but also maintained a dialogue with rebel leaders, the rector, Ignacio Ellacuria, insisted to the guerrilla commanders that they should take Mr. Cristiani seriously.
Like so many other Salvadorans, Father Ellacuria did not live to hear the war silenced. He was one the six priests killed by soldiers as the rebels launched their strongest offensive of the war in November 1989.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Nuns attending to Archbishop Oscar A. Romero moments after he was shot while saying Mass in San Salvador in March 1980. (pg. A12)
 
Chart: "Main Points Of the Agreement"
 
Military and Security
Beginning Feb. 1, the warring forces are supposed to begin entering isolation zones, 50 for the 6,000 to 7,000 rebels and 100 for the Salvador Army. The process is to conclude on Oct. 31 with the complete dismantling of the rebels' military apparatus.
 The Government's armed forces are to be cut to less than half its current size, estimated at 53,000. Officers found to have been corrupt or abusive of human rights are to be purged. Military doctrine is to be rewritten and military education and training restructured.
 Rapid-reaction infantry battalions and the National Intelligence Directorate are to be disbanded, along with the Treasury Police, the National Guard and the National Police. A new National Civil Police force is to be created under the control of a public security ministry controlled by civilians. Former guerrillas as well as former members of the National Police will be eligible to serve.
 
Economic and Social Issues
The Government pledged to give away land it owns or purchase land it does not for peasants who now occupy land in rebel-held areas of the country. It will carry out land-reform laws that now provide for the forcible redistribution of holdings in excess of about 600 acres. Social programs will be created to alleviate the effects of economic austerity policies. (pg. A12)

Oct. 15, 1979 -- Coup by army officers overthrows far-right dictatorship of Gen. Carlos Romero. Junta of officers and civilians promises free elections, but hard-line officers take over and moderate civilians resign. Right-wing death squads step up killings, reaching 800 a month in early 1980's.

HEADLINE: Overhauling Services: The Long, Painful Process -- A Special Report;
Employment in Service Industry, Impetus to Boom in 80's, Falters

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
For decades, banks, fast-food restaurants, hospitals, law firms, retail chains and governments -- the so-called service sector -- have been the engine that powered the great American job machine. In the 1980's, when services added a stunning 21 million jobs and employed almost four out of five workers, Americans debated whether service jobs were good jobs or bad jobs, but basically took the steady growth of services for granted.
No more. Except for health care, the services are in the throes of a pervasive shake-up very much like the one that racked smokestack manufacturing a decade ago. The concerted drive to squeeze costs and improve profits has resulted in extensive cost-cutting, job freezes, layoffs, consolidations and takeovers. The storm threatens to last much longer than the recession -- prolonged, very likely, by the wave of white-collar layoffs and the unusual reluctance among service companies to hire. 
 Indeed, most economists expect the great American job machine, even after it gets going again, to run at just half speed through much of the 1990's.
The consequences are likely to be felt by many, if not most, Americans for a long time, labor experts say. They expect job growth in the 90's to be the slowest since the 1950's. Pay, including benefits, is expected to rise more sluggishly. Unemployment, now 6.8 percent, is expected to hover above 6 percent for years.
And they predict that job security -- the comfortable expectation of being able to settle down somewhere for life, at least by middle age -- may be gone for good.
 
Lost Security at T.V.A.
 "If you got a job here it was probably one of the highest paid in the valley, it was secure and you could stay until you retired," said Robert M. Nimetz, a tough-minded 50-year-old former draftsman at the Tennessee Valley Authority, the Government-owned utility that has cut staff drastically to try to do more with less. "A lot of us whose jobs were contracted out were close to retirement," said Mr. Nimetz, whose last day there was the Friday after Thansgiving.
Yet economists say that what is a traumatic episode for individuals may prove to be the painful but necessary cure for the nation's top economic problems: woeful productivity growth and stagnating living standards. Those problems, economists agree, are firmly rooted in the sprawling service sector and not in manufacturing, where productivity has been growing faster in recent years than in the 1960's. By contrast, output per hour in services has barely grown in 20 years.
Economists say the slump in services productivity (which they concede may be somewhat exaggerated by inadequate statistics) is partly a result of the huge influx of inexperienced workers in the 1970's and 80's. They also say service companies failed to use computers effectively. And finally, they say, the service sector has simply had just too much capacity. If less-efficient companies are forced out of business and more-efficient ones handle growth in volume without adding lots of new hands, productivity could pick up.
If restructuring does manage to kick back into gear the growth of efficiency in services, the way it did in manufacturing, real wages after inflation could eventually rise faster in the second half of the 90's than they have since the late 60's, economists say. If it does not -- and, after all, many corporate turnaround attempts fail -- real per capita incomes would grow even more slowly than in the 80's.
For now, what is clear is that the services are struggling to adapt to an unforgiving economic environment of slower growth and lower inflation. It is a rough process, built on cost-cutting and consolidations, and studded with layoffs and bankruptcies.
"Despite the mildness of the downturn for the overall economy," said Allen Sinai, president of the Boston Company Economic Advisors, "most service industries suffered more than in previous recessions with regard to hours worked, jobs lost and the duration of the recession for that industry."
 
Professionals Join Unemployed Ranks
 Placement experts who try to match executives with job openings have remarked on the breadth of the cutbacks. "Unlike the early 80's, we're seeing accountants, engineers, lawyers, financial types, people from all across the spectrum," said Charles Albrecht, executive vice president at Drake Beam Morin, describing some of the unemployed people passing through the nation's largest outplacement firm.
Though service company sales have recovered a bit since last spring, hiring has not. And while service payrolls swelled 4.4 percent in the first 12 months of the early 80's recovery, they have barely budged since April. Many industries are, in fact, still trimming. Retailers, for example, are now in their 22d month of job cuts.
What's behind the belt-tightening? The four basic forces, economists and executives say, are:
OVEREXPANSION: In the 80's, the services added a stunning 19 million new jobs, $800 billion worth of new technology, 16,000 new shopping malls and three billion square feet of new office space (nearly as much again as existed in 1980). For Wall Street, retailers, fast-food restaurants and financial services, that added up to too much capacity, much of it in the wrong places.
"Large banks went into every town they wanted to be in," said James J. Preble who recently retired as vice chairman of the Fleet/Norstar Financial Group. "We wound up with a branch for every 2,500 customers. The norm is one branch for every 7,500 customers." Fleet/Norstar, which is based in Providence, R.I., acquired the failed Bank of New England last year. "We'll wind up with fewer banks," Mr. Preble predicted.
RUNAWAY COSTS: Wages and other costs in services, which grew no faster than manufacturing costs in the 60's and 70's, shot to the moon in the 80's. But service companies found they could not absorb these costs through higher productivity, nor could they recoup the higher costs through higher prices. "Service companies were unprepared for the arrival of an environment in which costs could not easily be passed along to consumers," said a commentary by economists at J. P. Morgan & Company.
TECHNOLOGY: From computers to specialized shipping containers, innovation has created opportunities to increase sales without adding labor. But it is only now, when companies are under the gun, that they are really exploiting technology. While much of the hardware did not pay off in the past, managers are now learning to use it. Michael R. Zucchini, executive vice president of Fleet/Norstar, says the potential for consolidating back-office bank operations has barely been tapped.
In retailing, the same headquarters staff can service nearly twice as many stores as a decade ago, in part thanks to point-of-sale computer systems that let marketing managers stay on top of far-flung sales and inventory trends.
Despite their financial squeeze, service company executives hope to take advantage of better technology to get them out of their current bind. The latest Commerce Department survey of capital spending plans shows that service companies, which barely cut back on spending on computers and the like during the recession, plan to increase outlays.
INCREASED COMPETITION: Challenges have come in many guises. Deregulation of airlines, financial services, telecommunications and cable television have opened the door to price cutting, invading of neighbors' markets and wiry new entrants. "Restructuring is largely due to increased competition," said James Brian Quinn, a professor of management at Dartmouth College.
Waiting to take advantage of these circumstances was a horde of hungry low-cost, high-quality, customer-friendly powerhouses like American Airlines, Wal-Mart, State Farm, CNN and Taco Bell. "The big are definitely getting bigger," said Randall E. Gebhardt, a Columbus, Ohio, retail consultant.
Foreign competition has also surged, with strong new global competitors arising in construction, shipping, travel and half a dozen other services. While foreign competition in service industries seems less apparent than in autos and steel and other manufacturing fields, it is there nonetheless.
Some of the competitive pressure from abroad is indirect. It comes via cost-conscious American manufacturers, who spend more on services than they do on labor these days and have to match foreign rivals on price. Many are pressing their suppliers, from ad agencies to electric utilities, to lower their prices and keep a lid on rates.
 
No End in Sight For Retrenchments
 The bind that service companies find themselves in -- and the radical surgery many are undertaking -- is evident at the Tennessee Valley Authority, which one executive called "a bankruptcy waiting to happen." By 1988, after 20 years of rate increases, large customers, including the city of Memphis, were threatening to defect.
T.V.A.'s chairman, Marvin Runyon, a former auto executive who came on the scene in 1988, spent his first three months on the job talking to customers. "They said to me, 'Look, you've got to stop raising the rates. That's going to drive industry and jobs out of the valley. We can't afford that.' " The T.V.A. has since cut 11,000 engineers, construction workers and clerks from its payroll, but it has not raised rates once.
A majority of executives expect the overhaul to continue indefinitely, according to a survey by Wyatt management consultants. One clear spot for cutbacks yet to come is in state and local governments -- public services that account for one-quarter of the service sector. State and local governments actually expanded their payrolls during the recession. But falling revenues will force extensive cuts next year and in 1993.
And even though airlines, retailing and other industries have been cutting for several years already, executives say they still have too much capacity.
"It's clear there will be more and more consolidation," said Stephen E. Watson, president of the Dayton Hudson Corporation, which added Marshall Field's, a Chicago-based department store chain, to its store chains in 1990.
The services shake-up is exacting a harsh toll. All the layoffs, hiring freezes and cost-cutting in services may be tipping the struggling economy back into recession by squeezing incomes and, more important, unnerving consumers.
"Hiring usually picks up five or six months into a recovery," said Stephen S. Roach, an economist at Morgan Stanley & Company. "October came and went, the hiring pickup was nowhere in sight, so consumers were hit with the cold reality that the dynamics of past recoveries weren't operative."
 
Slower Job Growth Through the Decade
 Job growth -- even after the economy gets moving again -- could be the slowest since the 50's, according to the latest long-term projection of the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Although services are still expected to create nearly all the new jobs in the 90's, forecasts call for job growth to be at less than half of the rate of the 80's. That would not reduce unemployment quickly.
"Long term, the changes will be healthy," said Jerry Cosley, a 56-year-old unemployed public relations executive in Overland Park, Kan. "But in the next 10 years, or however long this takes, all of our expectations will be subject to rude shocks. In no way did I expect to be without a job in my mid-50's."
With labor markets looser than in the late 80's, employers are likely to be stingier with pay, said Anthony J. Vignola, chief economist at Kidder, Peabody & Company. Raises for service employees have already slowed, on average, to 4 percent in 1991 from 5 percent in 1989. Pay increases have slowed more sharply for civil servants than for white-collar workers as a whole, to 4 percent from 7 percent.
If service companies succeed in becoming leaner and fitter -- and that is a big if -- productivity could rebound, economists say. That would be golden for profits, inflation and, most important, living standards.
If there is little or no improvement, however, the economy would suffer. "Unless service industries perform in a way that adds output without adding workers," said Bruce Steinberg, an economist at Merrill Lynch, "real pay will continue to stagnate."
To be sure, many attempts by companies to streamline their operations do not work, often because the companies are in worse shape than anyone realized. Restructuring is also particularly risky in service enterprises where customer satisfaction and sales depend heavily on employee morale. Then, too, competitive pricing is a necessary, but hardly sufficient, condition for success. "Our industry can't make money by holding sales 365 days a year," Mr. Gebhardt, the consultant, said.
Nonetheless, some economists already detect hopeful glimmers. Efficient competitors like Wal-Mart and the Gap are doing well, even in this tough economy. Profit margins for service industries in the aggregate began to improve before the end of recession, something that J.P. Morgan economists say has not happened before. Some companies, even industries, are seeing the benefit of earlier restructuring. Wall Street, which was in the red at the beginning of the year, enjoyed a near record year.
And after two years of declining efficiency, productivity outside manufacturing rose smartly last summer. "The improvement in productivity growth could continue for years," said Mr. Vignola of Kidder, Peabody.
 
The Lowest Paid Are Hardest Hit
 For now, the pain is being felt most by those who are losing their jobs or who are working harder because their fellow workers were dismissed. Hardest hit by restructuring are the young, the low paid, the least educated: clerks, office workers, cleaning, security and food workers.
"This new wave of cost-cutting has had the greatest impact on workers who function in a back-office capacity," Mr. Roach of Morgan Stanley said. "That's the assembly line of the American information-based service economy."
While the number of professional and managerial jobs actually rose in the recession, the number of clerical and sales jobs declined by several hundreds of thousands. Unemployment rates among various categories of clerical and sales workers currently range from 5 percent to more than 10 percent, while they tend to be less than 3 percent for managers and professionals.
More important, workers who lose jobs with good pay and benefits may find it impossible to find another job that pays as well.
"At my age, with a daughter in college, it's very frightening," said Clara Lay, a 46-year-old data base librarian for the T.V.A. "When you get over 40, especially if you don't have all the education, it's very hard. I could hope for a job in retail. The very best I could pull down is $5 an hour. I'd be part-time so I couldn't get benefits."
Most displaced workers are blue-collar or clerical employees, said Ronald E. Kutscher, associate commissioner at the Bureau of Labor Statistics. "The dividing line is education," he said. "People who have less than high school education are in a difficult position whether they're blue collar or white collar. They have higher unemployment rates and they have more trouble finding a new job."
 
Upheaval Hurts Higher Paid, Too
 But for many highly educated, highly paid professionals or managers who have also been laid off, the shock is nearly as painful. "A lesson in humility," as one such person put it.
For some, the upheaval can last for years. Take Sally Chin McElwreath. She was laid off from her public relations job at Trans World Airlines in 1985, spent three years freelancing and then landed a job at Maxwell MacMillan, where she is vice president of corporate communications. Now she is facing another crisis as the Maxwell empire crumbles, even though the individual companies she represents are making money.
"I was so involved in my job," Ms. McElwreath said. "I didn't have lunch. I didn't join professional organizations. I didn't socialize. I'm determined to do things for myself now instead of just staying in the office and finishing that last memo."
Still, despite the latest crisis, Ms. McElwreath said she was doing better in publishing than she would have had she remained in the airline industry. "I make more money, and I am in a more senior position," she said.
In contrast to the least educated service workers, the more educated ones at least have the possibility of recapturing what they have lost. "The more resources one brings to the job market, the greater one's ability to rebound," Mr. Kutscher, the Labor Department official, said. "Education is one of those resources."

GRAPHIC: Photo: "If you got a job here it was probably one of the highest paid in the valley, it was secure and you could stay until you retired," said Robert M. Nimetz, a former draftsman at the Tennessee Valley Authority, the Government-owned utility that has now cut its staff. (Rip Noel for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: In New Hampshire, Needy Schools Test a Tradition: Little State Aid

BYLINE: By FOX BUTTERFIELD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALLENSTOWN, N.H., Jan. 1

 BODY:
When a ceiling collapsed in the elementary school here, officials were so strapped for money that they had to take proceeds from a candy sale by parents that had been intended for a new playground.
Similar shortages in poorer towns around New Hampshire have prompted five school districts to sue Gov. Judd Gregg and other officials, challenging the state's system of paying for public education and, by extension, its most cherished political policy: the refusal to adopt a state income tax or sales tax. 
 Lacking revenue from such taxes, the state provides only 7 percent of its public schools' budgets, compared with a national average of 50 percent, according to documents filed in the lawsuit. That ranks New Hampshire last in the country in the state's share of public education spending.
 
An Awkward Spot
 The state's policy and the lawsuit challenging it place Governor Gregg, a Republican and a leading opponent of a state income or sales tax, in an awkward position. He is the chairman of President Bush's re-election campaign in New Hampshire's primary next month and therefore is the chief representative here of the man who has claimed the mantle of "education President." Also, as critics like to point out, the Governor has placed his own three children in private schools.
Mr. Gregg and those opposed to state taxes point out that New Hampshire has the lowest overall state and local tax burden in the nation, which has made it an attractive place to live and do business. The longtime no-tax policy has become synonymous with the motto on state license plates, "Live Free or Die." Alaska is the only other state with no income tax or sales tax.
Lawsuits charging unfair disparities in the way school financing is determined, including suits in Kentucky, New Jersey and Texas, have been successful in recent years. Similar suits are pending in 22 states.
But the effect of the lawsuit here would be the most far-reaching because, if successful, it would force a revolution of New Hampshire's tax system. According to figures in the suit, New Hampshire's 7 percent share of spending is not even close to that of the state that ranks just ahead of it, Nebraska. That state provides 24 percent of its schools' budgets.
"If we tripled our state appropriation for education, we would still be less than the 49th state," said John Garvey, a lawyer representing the five towns that brought the suit. It has been joined by 23 other towns.
The system makes some towns almost totally dependent on personal property taxes to support their schools. In some wealthier towns, which, in addition, have factories, shopping malls or ski resorts to tax, families may actually pay less in taxes and get more money for their schools than is the case with families in poorer communities with little or no commercial property.
 
Disparity in Rates
 In Allenstown, a small aging mill town where the last factory closed in 1991, residents were taxed at $17.24 for every thousand dollars of valuation on their homes in 1989, a rate that was almost twice the state average. Yet the town raised only $3,473 for each pupil for its schools, and that was more than $1,000 below the average for the state, the suit said.
By contrast, the suit notes that families in Rye, a wealthier town of similar size, paid taxes at the rate of $4.68 and raised $6,037, from all sources, in spending for each pupil.
"It's very nice not to pay income or sales taxes," said Ann Viar, an Allenstown resident whose 7-year-old son, Michael, is a plaintiff in the lawsuit. "But since property taxes are so high, I'd like a little more for my dollar."
Mrs. Viar, who has three other children in the town's public schools, complains that the junior high school can no longer afford a foreign-language program, courses for gifted students or a computer room. The school system has had to lay off its librarians and art teachers, and last spring it ran out of paper for students. Pupils in the sixth, seventh and eighth grades must share textbooks, so that, Mrs. Viar said, "if you have a test on Monday and it isn't your weekend to have the book, you are out of luck."
"At least we have running water," she said, referring to the plight of another town in the suit, Lisbon, where the junior and senior high schools are housed in a 19th century wooden building with antique heating and wiring systems. One classroom in Lisbon is in a converted chicken coop.
The suit is being fought vigorously by Mr. Gregg. Publicly, he argues that "the quality of education is not defined so much by dollars as by involvement of parents, involvement of teachers and involvement of principals."
 
Is Education a Right?
 Privately, colleagues say, the Governor is counting on the vague wording of New Hampshire's Constitution, which is less clear than those of many other states about whether education is a fundamental right. The suit, which was filed in State Superior Court last June, could be thrown out of court if a judge finds that education is not a constitutional right.
But some state residents find Mr. Gregg's stance hypocritical. "I have to laugh when the Governor speaks about the public schools, given the fact that his kids go to prep school," said Randy Perkins, the chairman of the school board in Franklin, another old mill town that is participating in the suit.
Apart from the lawsuit, Mr. Gregg has also come under pressure to deal with two years of plummeting state revenues as the state has slipped into the worst recession since the Great Depression. Last month the state struggled to close a $200 million deficit in its $3.9 billion budget for 1991-1993 and this was adding to the pressure for an income tax, until the White House said it would release $234 million in Medicaid reimbursements for New Hampshire.
Mr. Gregg's critics and supporters of Patrick J. Buchanan, the conservative columnist who is challenging Mr. Bush in the New Hampshire Republican primary, have asserted that the money was a partisan windfall intended to help the President's campaign. The Governor has said the timing of the announcement of the reimbursement, came at the same time as his opening of Mr. Bush's campaign headquarters here, was coincidental.
Even some Republicans say they worry that the Medicaid money will lull New Hampshire into a false sense of contentment with its tax system and prevent the kind of changes that are needed to improve the state's schools.
"The Medicaid bailout is the worst thing that has ever happened to New Hampshire," said Bert Teague, a 74-year-old Republican State Representative who was chairman of the New Hampshire Republican Party in 1952 when Dwight D. Eisenhower began his campaign for the Presidency with a victory in the state's primary.
"The property tax has really become a terrible burden," Mr. Teague said. He noted that while the absence of state income and sales taxes might appear attractive, excessive reliance on property taxes had driven up the tax bills on many families' homes to the point where they defaulted on their mortgage payments.
Forty years ago, he said, the property tax made sense, because the wealth of New Hampshire was still in its land. "But now everything is reversed, wealth is in wages and salaries and dividends and investments, not in land," he said.
"We've bragged for years, come up here and live free, pay the lowest taxes," Mr. Teague added.
"So now they've come by the thousands, and they all vote against taxes," he said, referring to the large number of newcomers who moved to New Hampshire during its rapid growth in the 1980's. "Of course, we have an alternative, it's there on our license plate -- die," he said.

School shortages in towns around New Hampshire have prompted five school districts to sue the state, challenging the system of paying for public education and, by extention, the refusal to adopt a state income or sales tax. PUB-DATE: January 2, 1992

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 5; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 2041 words

HEADLINE: For Many in the New York Region, The City Is Ignored and Irrelevant

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GLABERSON

 BODY:
Without quite noticing it, the New York area, home of the ultimate American city, has transformed itself into a sprawling, dispersed region that more than ever resembles Los Angeles, where a movie at the multiplex or a trip to Bridgewater Commons has become as much a day out as a journey to Lincoln Center or Herald Square.
In place of a "the-subway-can-get-me-there" attitude that survived the first moves to the suburbs from places like the Grand Concourse in the Bronx or Flatbush in Brooklyn, a new culture has taken hold. Many residents in the ring of communities around the city never lived in the five boroughs, hardly ever visit the city and do not care much about what happens there. 
 A recent New York Times poll reflects the weakening ties between New York City and the region around it. The poll found that many residents in the communities that surround the city work near where they live, shop and entertain themselves outside New York City more than ever before and feel that the city is unimportant to them.
 
Paramus Is Preferred
 "The city has moved out here," said Russell J. Hogdahl, who is raising his family in Riverdale Borough, N.J., and commutes to his chemical engineering job in Edgewater, N.J. "There's no need to go across the bridge," He said he would rather go to the Meadowlands than to Madison Square Garden, and he prefers the Macy's in Paramus to the one in Herald Square. Mr. Hogdahl was one of those surveyed for the poll who agreed to a follow-up interview.
The Times's poll, some details of which were reported on Dec. 1, confirmed trends of decentralization and increasing disaffection with cities that have been transforming other areas across the country. But the findings, urban policy experts said, challenge New Yorkers' chauvinistic view that their region is different from other places that have spawned strip malls and suburban sprawl and that have left their metropolitan centers weakened.
"In the 50's and 60's, people moved to the suburbs and they cut the first tie to the city," said Norman J. Glickman, the director of the Rutgers University Center for Urban Policy Research. "In the 60's and 70's, retail stores moved and people severed the second tie. Now the jobs have moved. So people no longer need to go to the city to live, to work, to shop or to play."
In The Times's poll, conducted in November, 51 percent of those who live in the New York area outside the five boroughs said events in the city have "hardly any impact" on their daily lives. That was a sharp increase from 1978, when only 39 percent gave that answer to the same question.
The Times poll found that 51 percent of those who live outside the city say they spend a day or an evening in New York less often than they did five years ago, that more than two-thirds rarely or never shop in the city and that about 6 in 10 principal wage earners work in their own counties, not in the city.
More than three-quarters of the people surveyed said they would not need to go into New York City to see doctors, lawyers or accountants and, in a continuing sign of a shifting way of life, more than 4 in 10 said that, even to see a concert or a play, they could find what they like nearer home than in the city that offers Broadway and Carnegie Hall.
The telephone poll was conducted Nov. 2-12, with 1,726 adults in the 14 counties immediately surrounding the city in New York State, New Jersey and Connecticut. It has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.
Mr. Glickman of Rutgers said the New York area is now "L.A. East," a spread-out, automobile-reliant community in which suburban residents find it hard to understand what the problems of the urban world have to do with them.
 
Multiplex Society With Its Back to City
 Mitchell L. Moss, the director of the New York University Urban Research Center, said, "We have seen the creation of a suburban culture in New York." It is marked, he said, by a dispersion of population across a broad area, a homogenization of cultural offerings through such ubiquitous institutions as mulitplex movie theaters and shopping options that rival or duplicate those available in the city.
In New York, as elsewhere in the country, Mr. Moss said, Caldor and places like Bridgewater Commons in New Jersey are the places for shopping, and El Torito and the Ground Round provide the identical dinner out from Hartford to Trenton and virtually everywhere in between.
Some of those who participated in the follow-up interviews acknowledged that there is a blandness in a regional life that is increasingly divorced from the city. "You do miss something," said Howard J. Feinstein, who lives and owns an interior landscaping business in Fairfield County, Conn. "You don't have the ideas, the vitality. New York is New York."
But like many of those interviewed, Mr. Feinstein, who said he considers himself a New Yorker, provided a litany of reasons not to go into the city, ranging from fear of crime to the irritation and expense of everything from doing business to going on a night out.
Growing up on Long Island in a different time, he said, life was focused on the city: the men went there every day, and everyone else went whenever they could.
As a young adult, Mr. Feinstein, who is 40, worked in the city, too, as his father always had. Then, he said, he and the city changed. He gave up the chance to take over his father's window-cleaning business, then gave up on working in the city altogether.
And in recent years, he said, he has found that he uses the city more like a tourist than a resident, visiting it only four or five times a year.
In the Times poll, 59 percent of the residents in the 14-county area surrounding the city said they had never lived in the five boroughs. In northern New Jersey 71 percent said they had never lived in the city and in Fairfield County, fully three-quarters of those interviewed for the poll gave that response.
 
No Nostalgia For New York
 Young adults who have never lived in any city are part of what Sylvia F. Fava, a senior researcher at the Graduate Center of the City University of New York, calls "the suburban generation." Like their counterparts across the country, she said, they are in the first wave of Americans raised in the vast suburban developments that grew up after World War II.
They are, she said, used to the security offered by suburbs. They have no history and no interest in the city, and what they perceive to be problems there that have little to do with their lives. "Your protection," she said, "is you are surrounded by people who are like you in places you know."
The suburban generation's principal source of information about the city, she said, is the "crime, doom and horror" reports they receive from television and radio broadcasts that she said often specialize in caricature and can subtly perpetuate negative views of New York City.
In the poll, only 35 percent of suburban residents said they read a New York City newspaper almost every weekday, down from 40 percent in 1978, while those who listen to radio stations based in New York increased to 72 percent from 63 percent in 1978. Most of the region's powerful radio stations are based in New York City.
David P. Shields, 27, who sells information services to professionals, is one Westchester resident who says he canceled a New York City newspaper in favor of a local newspaper that provides information more relevant to his life, like classified advertisements and notices of local hearings. He gets other news mostly by listening to the radio while at work, he said.
Born and raised in Mamaroneck, where he lives with his wife, Mr. Shields said events in New York City "really don't affect me here in Westchester." And the delights of New York that he has sometimes heard about, he said, seem little more than bits of nostalgia.
He has heard, for example, that the Grand Concourse in the Bronx once offered a graceful way of life. "You speak to anyone who is 40 or 50," he said, "they tell you it was the place to be. On Sunday, everyone was out pushing their baby carriages. I go there now, I can't imagine it ever being like that."
 
Lifelong Residents Of Suburbia
 The Times poll also found that the sterotype of the suburban couple raising their children, then abandoning their bedroom communities to return to New York City is less true than it used to be. In 1978, 26 percent of suburban respondents said they had lived in their current community for 20 years or more. In the recent poll, 37 percent said they had lived there that long.
Even boosters of New York City say recent trends worry them. Mr. Moss noted that research at the Robert F. Wagner Graduate School of Public Service at New York University showed that, despite the flight from the city in recent decades, Manhattan still has a concentration of more than a quarter of all the jobs in the 31-county region around the city.
But, Mr. Moss said, the erosion of loyalty to the city illustrated by the poll reinforced his conclusion in a November study that it is necessary to "reinvent New York," not only economically but in the image it presents to the region. That study cited such statistics as those in a Port Authority survey showing that the rate of job growth grew faster far from the city than close to the city during the 1980's.
Some of the reinvention of New York, managers of the city's cultural institutions said, would involve an aggressive effort to change both the realities and the perceptions that "citizens of the region" have developed about a dangerous and costly city. "There is not nearly enough effort to make it easier and safer and more pleasant for people to come to the city of New York," said William H. Luers, president of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
New York's municipal government has traditionally looked to the business community for help in improving the city's image. But some experts say the pressure on business is enormous, even in good economic times, to find out what the customer wants and provide it. And if the customer wants a suburban shopping mall with free parking and a Haagen-Dazs ice cream outlet nearby, the customer, as the saying goes, is always right.
A case in point might be Macy's, which is as closely identified with New York City as its Thanksgiving Day parade. A New York City attitude was once so pervasive at the department store that its early expansion efforts in the 1950's were governed by one rule: Macy's would build a new store in the New York area only if potential customers could get there on foot.
That notion is now quaint, said Edward S. Finkelstein, the chain's chairman and chief executive, and Macy's is the anchor store in malls across the region. The main store at Herald Square still claims to be the biggest in the world, producing, Mr. Finkelstein said, seven times the gross receipts of a typical suburban Macy's in such park-and-drive locations as Danbury or Stamford, Conn.
Macy's, Mr. Finkelstein said, is committed to New York. But it is also committed to selling. And that means that, like most businesses, it appears to be watching as the people of the region redefine their way of life. "We are positioned," Mr. Finkelstein said, "to be where the customers choose to be. If they decide they are disaffected with New York, we are in the suburbs."
An effort to change attitudes about shopping and everthing else in the city might be aimed at people like Lynn Vigilante, a 58-year-old retired real-estate broker who lives in Glen Head, near Roslyn, L.I. Her fondest memories, she said, include Italian feasts at Mamma Leone's and dinners at the old Luchow's on 14th Street.
Now, like many of those interviewed, she said the cost of parking in the city would pay for dinner at a pleasant place nearer home. When she thinks of the city now, she said, it tends to be of episodes like the killing of Brian Watkins, the Utah tourist who came to see the United States Open tennis tournament and lost his life in a New York subway.
"Now, it's a whole new era," Mrs. Vigilante said. "It's expensive. They're robbing you. Look at that couple that came from Utah with their son. I'd be afraid to go in."

HEADLINE: For President, Help in Tokyo;
Intent of the Japanese Is to Bolster a Friend

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Jan. 1

 BODY:
President Bush's trip to Japan next week has turned into a messy confrontation over trade and a major test for Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa. But Japanese leaders also hope to make the trip at least look like a success for an American President viewed as a friend.
Aides to Mr. Miyazawa were dismayed when domestic problems forced Mr. Bush first to postpone his visit, originally scheduled for November, and then to take along 21 executives of the American automobile and other industries to demand greater access to Japanese markets. 
 But the Japanese have now apparently decided to try to salvage the trip as a gesture of friendship to Mr. Bush and a reflection of concern over a Presidential race that has already featured calls for trade retaliation against Tokyo.
 
'Bush Is Better for Us'
 "Let's face it, Bush is better for us than any alternatives we see right now," a Japanese official said. "He's the key person standing against protectionism and isolationism in the United States. So to the extent that Bush gains, Japan gains and Miyazawa gains."
But some American officials say Mr. Miyazawa may not have the political latitude to make any major promises. Successful Japanese prime ministers must be perceived to have a good relationship with Washington, but not a subordinate one.
Mr. Miyazawa's predecessor, Toshiki Kaifu, was done in because of a widespread impression that he did Mr. Bush's bidding. And like Mr. Kaifu, Mr. Miyazawa is surrounded by rival kingpins in the governing Liberal Democratic Party who do not necessarily want him to succeed. Their passive support of Mr. Miyazawa has led to a series of disastrous legislative defeats in his first two months in office.
Among them was the embarrassing failure of a bill to enlist Japanese troops in United Nations peacekeeping forces. Also defeated were measures to apologize to the United States for World War II, enact a series of political changes and raise taxes to increase Japanese foreign aid.
"As the year-end approaches, expectations for Miyazawa are failing," a respected political columnist, Kenji Kiatahara, wrote this week. "A feeling of disappointment and helplessness is endemic. Miyazawa has failed to provide anything resembling his promised leadership on any issue."
Some analysts say that if Mr. Bush's visit is perceived as a failure, Mr. Miyazawa could be ousted before the end of 1992.
Faced with American anger and impatience over the trade imbalance, particularly the fact that Japanese cars are wiping out the American competition, Japan is planning a set of initiatives that could have a marginal effect on the $41 billion imbalance.
Under consideration are some easing of environmental and safety regulations for imported automobiles that have been tough for American car-makers to meet if they want to sell their products in Japan. Japanese car producers and retailers are also being pressed to buy more American auto parts and open their dealerships to American cars.
Such steps are likely to have a small long-term effect. But Americans are unlikely to be comforted by the spirit in which these concessions are offered. Mr. Miyazawa, for instance, appealed for voluntary efforts out of compassion, not out of a sense that the current system is unfair, as Americans contend.
"I am asking industry leaders to take more seriously and compassionately the U.S. situation," Mr. Miyazawa said, mentioning what he said was the "considerable shock" felt by Americans at seeing their automobile industry wiped out by Japanese competition. "G.M. is like the Stars and Stripes for the American people," he said.
It remains to be seen whether voluntary purchases by Japanese industries will be satisfying to an American delegation that wants a more systemic change in Japan to make it more open to imports in general.
Many analysts in Japan think that President Bush will be happy to accept the Japanese steps, if only because he has raised expectations to such a degree that he cannot afford to act like he has been spurned.
As for Mr. Miyazawa, aides say that he needs what Japanese leaders always seem to need -- reassurance that Japan is an equal partner with the United States in tackling global problems. The format is to be a "Tokyo Declaration" of the two nations' "global partnership."
When Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d visited Japan in the fall, however, he made headlines when he said Japan must abandon its practice of "checkbook diplomacy" and wade more into the thick of the world's problems. Many Japanese resented what they felt was his condescending tone.
In fact, Japan wants to become a permanent member of the United Nations Security Council. It wants more voting rights at the International Monetary Fund. It wants the United Nations to expunge references in its charter to its status as a former "enemy" state. American response to these requests has been lukewarm at best.
 
How Japan Disappoints
 Now Japan will be watching to see how much Mr. Bush papers over American disappointment that it did not send personnel to the Persian Gulf, but only money, and that its steps on the environment, aid to poor countries and aid to the Soviet Union have fallen short of expectations.
In the end, the biggest favor Mr. Miyazawa, a former Finance Minister, can do for President Bush is to help the United States by helping itself. Accordingly, Mr. Miyazawa is presiding over steps to stimulate the Japanese economy and let the yen rise in value against the dollar.
This week, he said Japan must be the "locomotive" that pulls the whole world out of its economic slump. Such steps as lowering interest rates in Japan and letting the yen rise are viewed by many economists as more likely to spur American imports into Japan than any specific steps in industries.
The problem is that Mr. Bush seems to want something more dramatic. The question now is what Japan can produce within its and Mr. Miyazawa's limitations. "There are things we can do and cannot do," said a senior Japanese official. "Let's see what we come up with in the next week."

SECTION: Section A; Page 20; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 636 words

HEADLINE: Editorial Notebook;
Faces of Japan

BYLINE: By DAVID C. UNGER

DATELINE: KYOTO, Japan

 BODY:
After just a week in Japan, some familiar American stereotypes about this country and its people seem shockingly superficial and dangerously out-of-date. Japanese society differs from America's in important ways. But like American society, Japanese society is neither monolithic nor static.
Today's Japan is one of the world's most modern, most affluent societies, plugged into every trend in international pop culture and a powerful creator of new trends for others. Its young people are highly educated, fashion-conscious and remarkably well traveled. Its face is far more diverse, and youthful, than would ever be guessed from the cautious politicians and corporate tycoons who dominate the news. 
 Americans can usefully debate the nature of Japanese society and how America can best respond to Japan's competitive success. But for too many Americans, Japan's image is a crude caricature, drawn from half-digested sound bites and painted in racist hues.
The Japanese are portrayed as faceless and conformist, their real feelings impenetrable to non-Japanese. This supposedly monolithic society is explained in terms of Japan's militarist traditions, its consensus style of politics and a shared national anxiety over scarce resources. These are said to produce people committed to work unceasingly so that Japan can dominate the world economically, and perhaps militarily too.
There are Japanese who think like that, but fewer than there used to be. Meanwhile a newer, youth-oriented leisure culture is emerging everywhere, from the nightclubs of Tokyo's Ginza and Roppongi districts to Kyoto's Kawaramachi Street.
Most of Japan's 123 million people have been born since 1960. Most adults have no personal memories of World War II or the U.S. occupation. Most Japanese today are children of affluence, not scarcity.
Older people still remember the hard times and hesitate to relax. The middle-aged worry more narrowly about astronomical housing costs and their children's increasingly expensive tastes. And for many school-aged children, the affluence achieved by past generations is there to be enjoyed now and the future can take care of itself. These younger Japanese pleasure-seekers are, their elders say, "nibbling on their parents' shins."
If this generational breakdown sounds familiar to Americans, there's good reason. An internationalized market and culture has homogenized experience to a remarkable extent, particularly in societies at comparable economic levels.
Japan is different from America, but also surprisingly familiar. There are unreconstructed militarists and nationalists who acknowledge no Japanese wrongdoing before or during World War II, but there are also potent pacifist and environmental movements. Traditional values are revered, but a growing feminist movement is challenging patriarchal traditions. Japanese culture values harmony and pleasing words, but some Japanese are bluntly outspoken, even to foreigners.
Why then do so many Americans see the Japanese as an army of ants? One reason may be unfamiliarity. Few Americans have spent much time in Japan. And the faces Japan turns to the outside world are usually those of its mumbling politicians and corporate samurai. It's also more comforting for Americans to explain embarrassing competitive setbacks by conspiracy theories rather than by poor American business practices.
The United States and Japan now have the world's two biggest economies. Their relationship is too important to fall victim to oversimplification and ignorance. Both societies have learned valuable and different lessons from history, lessons they might usefully share with each other. By better appreciating what we have in common with the Japanese, Americans might even discover how to benefit from Japanese successes.

HEADLINE: Essay;
No 'Horror Show'

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Put yourself in the shoes of an assignment editor for any of the news media today, as shoppers in Russia return to stores closed for the New Year's holiday.
You dispatch reporters to cover an inflationary horror show. What Gorbachev had long flinched from doing, Boris Yeltsin has just dared to do: ended the state subsidies for most goods, removed the corrupt bureaucracy from the marketplace and opened the economy to the law of supply and demand. 
 You send one camera crew to a food market to take pictures of the price signs, and ask for interviews with enraged shoppers who cannot afford the food in the stores.
You send another foreign correspondent to a Russian economist raised in the Communist system, who deplores the "shock therapy" of the elected leadership and predicts the inflation that led to the collapse of Germany's Weimar Republic, followed by food riots in Moscow and an authoritarian coup.
For the reaction of the American intelligentsia, you get a sound bite from a think-tanker with C.I.A. ties or a Gorbaphile in a Princeton tie: "didn't work in Poland, won't work in Russia" is bitten off, or "the Russian people are not culturally prepared for self-rule, and yearn for the stability of central command."
That's the obvious "story": anger and worry in the faces of women wearing babushkas, learned predictions of doom by the acolytes of proponents of failed half-measures, and a satisfying exaggeration of the pace of inflation and degree of collapse by statisticians long fooled by the phony high figures of Kremlin economists.
That's the story because it is (a) easy to cover, (b) gratifying to panicmongers and (c) safe -- what everybody else is saying the story is. And nobody ever gets burned for predicting doom; it can be explained later as just a proper show of concern.
But let us not confuse the conventional coverage with reality. The tectonic news, as distinct from the troubling human-reaction story on the surface, is that Russia and its neighboring republics are at last accepting the law of supply and demand.
That is revolutionary change, and decidedly for the better. But instead of cheering, our bargaineering liberals (who were prepared to pay $30 billion to induce free markets and defense cuts) are moaning about safety nets while our supply-siders led by Jack Kemp are bewailing the bold floating of the ruble.
Face it: The Yeltsin men may be making some mistakes of their own, but they are not making the huge mistake of the long Gorbachev nose dive. They are not trying to salvage the Communist system. On the contrary, they are taking the plunge into the icy waters of free enterprise.
But why, some tidy minds demand, can't the old command economy be replaced gradually and painlessly and tidily?
Because turmoil does not give you time. Politicians new to office have only a certain grace period -- a few quarters, a year or two at most, to inflict the pain of necessary change. Our own politicians, safely espousing free-market principles, tend to forget that risking political capital is the highest form of capitalism.
A couple of years ago, a Leningrad student told me: "We are now free to call for change, and we do, all the time -- but nothing changes."
A month ago, the new Russian Foreign Minister, Andrei Kozyrev, responded: "Our people will tolerate hardship if they see real change. If you want to help the Russian people, you should assist the forces of change."
How can we help? By joint-venturing with Russians in getting oil out of the ground and into pipelines and ships; by sending practical experts to show Ukraine's farmers and transporters how to keep harvests from rotting; by re-thinking Cocom regulations that prevent new telephonic communication technology from pulling the Russians out of their business morass; by organizing a private Capitalist Corps to compete with our Peace Corps in showing the former Soviets how to manage and how to enforce contracts.
What is "horror show" to us, as the novelist Anthony Burgess pointed out, is also the Russian word khorosho -- "okay." Through the trials of transition to supply and demand, the historic story of 1992 will be how the enduring Russians turned out khorosho.

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
He Let In The Light

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
Mikhail Gorbachev went out like the old year, unmourned. There was a grudging quality to much of the comment when he resigned. He was not a true democrat, the critics said. He fumbled economic change. He temporized, he wavered, he failed.
The criticism was even harsher at home. Roy Medvedev, the anti-Stalinist Communist historian, said: "The country that was the Soviet Union in 1985 when Mikhail Gorbachev came to power was incomparably better, given all its deficiencies, than it is today." 
 Was it? In 1985 thousands of political prisoners suffered in the gulag, and anyone who said a critical word about the system was likely to join them. In 1985 Andrei Sakharov was held in Gorky, harassed by the K.G.B., force-fed when he went on a hunger strike. In 1985 there was no independent newspaper or broadcast station in the whole vast country.
In 1985 East Germans who tried to cross to the West were machine-gunned on the Berlin Wall. Czechs and Slovaks lived in a grim silence, held in an alien empire along with Poles and Hungarians and Bulgarians.
All that Gorbachev ended. He let the light of free speech and a free press in on his country, ending 70 years of totalitarian darkness. He sent no armies when the Berlin Wall was breached, when Czechs and Poles and the others formed governments of their own choice; he invited the process.
In 1985 no one dreamt that freedom could come so far, so fast -- that the enormous mechanism of tyranny would be dismantled in less than seven years. Or that it could happen quite peacefully, despite the armies of bureaucrats and secret police and soldiers at the regime's command.
It happened that way only because someone who knew the system intimately, who knew the psychology of its legions, took it apart. Only Gorbachev the ultimate insider could do it. Andrei Sakharov was the voice of truth, the inspirer, the saint. But the Communist structure would not have dissolved itself at his command.
Melor Sturua, an Izvestia columnist visiting at the University of Minnesota, writes in Foreign Policy magazine that the fall of Communism was inevitable anyway. Yes it was, some day. So, too, could one predict that white supremacy could not go on forever in South Africa. But that does not lessen the achievement of President F. W. de Klerk in undoing it now.
Gorbachev was really interested in power, Mr. Sturua writes. If that were so, he could easily have blocked change, kept the lid of tyranny on and enjoyed the life of an old-style Soviet leader. If a dodderer like Leonid Brezhnev could hold the system together for years, he surely could. And it was expectable that Gorbachev would: A man who came up through the system, playing the servile games, enjoying the power and privileges.
But he did the opposite. He brought Sakharov back from Gorky. He opened the way for a critical press. He ended the Communist Party's historic monopoly of political power, allowing others to speak and organize.
Then, in 1988, he made the crucial move of creating a parliament that would actually be elected by the people. It was an imperfect election, but it was free enough to register popular disaffection from Communism, and to make the idea of democracy take hold.
He made great mistakes. He freed Sakharov but would not heed Sakharov's warnings. His unwillingness to put himself to the test of popular election cost him legitimacy. He made more and more concessions to the conservatives, failing to see their threat until they moved against him in the August coup.
The coup was his undoing when it aroused public resistance and then revulsion against the whole Communist idea. But there was irony in that. For without the experience of increasing freedom under Gorbachev, it is doubtful that editors and broadcasters and ordinary people would have had the courage to resist the coup as they did.
The world owes him as much as his own people. He ended the cold war, the greatest menace to freedom everywhere -- and to life. He turned back the hands of the nuclear clock.
The correct judgment, I think, is the one made by David Remnick of The Washington Post, writing just before the fall in The New York Review of Books: "Despite the twilight aura gathering around him now, Gorbachev will surely be counted as the dominant politician of the second half of the Twentieth Century."

HEADLINE: Time for Government to Start Spending Again

 BODY:
To the Editor:
While spending by individuals and businesses is an important component of the United States economy, it is a mistake to underestimate the role that Government spending plays in driving the economic engine. 
 From my vantage point as a university-based teacher and scientist, I can see that the recession in universities, and in scientific research, is largely tied to cutbacks in Government programs. People are being laid off, new hiring is frozen, and scholarship programs are threatened.
If Government spending in our sector were restored to former levels we could reinstitute construction and renovation programs, furnishing jobs to the construction industry and increasing our capacity for teaching and research. Students with scholarships would again have money with which to buy what they need, adding to economic activity.
We could afford to hire personnel in scientific research and to purchase supplies, which would again further not only our scientific efforts but also the economy.
I am sure that other Americans can see many examples in their own areas in which cutbacks in Government programs have directly led to our economic downturn. The Government need not sit helpless, watching the economy slide. Government is a key part of the economy, and its overfrugal policies have helped land us in this mess.
If the cutbacks we have had were quickly reversed, this might be just the pump priming needed to get us going again.
 
RONALD BRESLOW
New York, Dec. 18, 1991
 
The writer is a professor of chemistry at Columbia University, and a recent winner of the United States National Medal of Science.

HEADLINE: DISSONANT MESSAGES;
Low Rates Expected to Continue for Bonds

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Credit market analysts and economists say the precipitous decline in short-term interest rates engineered by the Federal Reserve Board over the last 18 months should begin to pay some dividends for the economy in the second half of this year.
Few of them, however, expect much more than a tepid rebound. If they are right, short-term rates will stay low, and bond yields, which remained stubbornly high through much of 1991, will probably fall. 
 But economic recovery, these people acknowledge, has been widely seen as being just six months away for the last three years. And there are enough uncertainties to jeopardize even a modest improvement.
Nevertheless, guarded optimism prevails.
"The prospects for the economy are much better, because rates are down and we have already been through a lot," said Edward J. Hyman, president of International Strategy and Investment, a New York investment advisory firm.
Inflation, the scourge of the fixed-income market, has fallen nicely over the last year and is showing few signs of reviving. And while the worry of rising unemployment continues, the pall of an impending war does not.
Since July 1990, the Fed has lowered its target for the overnight rate on bank loans in the Federal funds market by 4.25 percentage points, to 4 percent. In response, other short-term rates have fallen and now stand at levels not seen since the late 1960's, when inflation was tame and Federal budget deficits were not a problem.
That short-term rates have fallen so far has been a big surprise to many analysts. So, too, is the fact that the rate moves have not yet rekindled economic growth.
But given the problems in the nation's financial system -- difficulties that have transformed what might otherwise have been a traditional recession into something altogether different -- economists shudder to think what might have happened had short-term rates not come down.
The efforts to work off the excessive debt incurred during the 1980's are only one year old. Many economists now say that short-term rates may need to fall a bit further during 1992 and remain at the new levels for the rest of the year if balance sheets are to be further repaired.
"We added up about $2 trillion in floating-rate debt" during the 1980's, said Neal M. Soss, chief economist at the First Boston Corporation, adding: "Every percentage point drop in short rates frees up $20 billion in cash flow to households and businesses. This economy would have collapsed without that sort of support."
Compared with the drop that has already taken place, further declines in short-term rates will be minimal, analysts agreed.
Still, if the economy performs as poorly as is currently expected in the first quarter, the Fed is likely to feel compelled to cut the Federal funds rate by at least another quarter of a point, and possibly more, between now and midyear.
 
Bullish on Bonds
 The analysts expect big things from the bond market this year, because inflation, currently around 3 percent, seems unlikely to move higher in response to a very modest recovery.
"Bond yields at 7 percent could be possible any time during the first half of the year, even in the first quarter," said Edward Yardeni, chief economist at C. J. Lawrence Inc. "Inflation over the next year should be between 2 percent and 3 percent, which makes bonds look very attractive."
David H. Resler, chief economist at Nomura Securities International, said: "We are still bullish on the fixed-income market, particularly for intermediate to long-term securities. A half-point drop in bond yields, which I think is very possible, would produce the double-digit return that Treasuries have provided this year."
Bond yields have fallen sharply since the Federal Reserve lowered its discount rate by a full percentage point last month, and now stand at just under 7.50 percent.
But analysts fear the rally will end, and the recovery will be delayed if not derailed, should Congress or the Administration concoct a wildly stimulative package of tax cuts by spring.
"There is a risk that the bond market may be recalcitrant and refuse to rally further," Mr. Soss said. "That would delay financial restructuring."
 
Among the Risks
 Other risks to the recovery, analysts said, include the possibility of a protracted economic downturn in Europe, especially Germany, and a failure by Japan to stimulate its economy. If one or both occur, American exporters will suffer.
For the bond market, however, the biggest risk is that the widely held view of a tepid recovery is dead wrong.
"The risk is that the traditional business cycle is not dead," Mr. Yardeni said, "and that even as economists conclude that rates will stay low for quite some time, a major turnaround in the economy occurs, causing rates to come roaring back."
 
Outlook for Junk Bonds
 It is hard to imagine how a resumption of strong economic growth could do much more for the high-yield junk bond market, even though its spectacular rise during the year just past reflected sharply rising stock prices, which in the past have been a harbinger of better times.
The combination of better stock prices and falling interest rates acted as a tonic for high-yield issues last year, and pushed up the Salomon Brothers high-yield index of 700 issues by a staggering 40 percent from the end of 1990.
Joseph Bencivenga, a managing director and co-head of equity and high-yield research at Salomon, is not expecting similar performance this year. But he does look for good things.
"With short rates falling dramatically, interest burdens on these companies are falling every day," he said. "All the indicators we look at point to a rate of return of between 12 percent and 15 percent," for 1992.
 
Municipal Bonds
 The big drop in interest rates was also a boon for issuers and investors in the tax-exempt municipal bond market.
Spurred by the decline in rates, new-issue volume was up 30 percent from 1990, to around $165 billion, said George Friendlander, a managing director at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company.
States and municipalities were able to sell that much debt because the drop in yields on taxable securities made tax-exempt bonds look increasingly attractive.
"It was a superb year for the muni market," Mr. Friedlander said.
In large part, the prospects for the coming year hinge on what happens to rates on Treasury securities, the benchmark against which all other fixed-income securities are priced.
"Unless the Treasury market really gets beat up, municipal bond rates will stay low," Mr. Friendlander added.
And, with rates at or near current levels, states and localities are almost certain to continue to call outstanding securities issued with higher coupons.
Similarly, if taxable rates stay low, demand from individual investors for tax-free notes and bonds figures to remain strong.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Italians Polish Their Wine Image

BYLINE: By STUART ELLIOTT

 BODY:
SEEKING to increase "share of mouth" among American oenophiles, the Italian Trade Commission is beginning a multimillion-dollar campaign for fine Italian wines, its first in four years.
The advertising links Italy's premium wines with art, fashion, food and opera, under a "quality of life" theme. 
 "The job isn't to sell Italian wine," William McCaffery, president and creative director of McCaffery & Ratner Inc., the agency for the wines of Italy account, said during a recent interview at the commission's office in midtown Manhattan. "The job is to sell Italy in a bigger, broader sense, as a world leader in quality of life."
That selling job, however, will be difficult. Apart from the sour economy, changing attitudes toward drinking and symbols of conspicuous consumption pose serious obstacles to image-building ads.
Atop that, "the Italians have a lot of problems" of their own, said Frank C. Walters, vice president and research director of M. Shanken Communications Inc. in New York, which follows wine- and liquor-industry trends. Primary among them, he added, is a belief by American consumers that "higher-priced wines traditionally come from France."
Alfonso Barbera, the commission's executive director for the United States, Canada and Mexico, agreed.
"France began to export the best wine, and the image of French wine was built on the basis of their best wine," he said. "Italy began to export the wines the Italian immigrants drank, and the image of Italian wine was built on this wine."
As a result, he added, "it's very, very difficult to promote Italian wine in America."
So for the next two years, the commission will spend on the campaign what for the premium wine market is a large sum, $10 million. Eight print advertisements will begin appearing in January issues of magazines including Bon Appetit, Conde Nast Traveler, Food & Wine, Gourmet, The New York Times Magazine and Vogue.
The two-page spreads feature striking photographs of Italian sights like trattorias, museums and opera houses on the left, and Italian meals, complemented with wine, on the right.
Come spring, the commission will be the sole sponsor of a weekly, hourlong syndicated program of Italian music to be heard on classical radio stations in metropolitan markets. Augmenting the media advertising will be integrated marketing efforts like wine tastings and promotions at Italian restaurants.
The campaign is intended to reach a target market defined by David Hooper, McCaffery's executive vice president and marketing director, as "an influential group" that already regularly drinks wine -- 57 million mostly urban consumers, 35 to 54 years old, who have annual incomes in excess of $40,000.
Since Americans "are ignorant, period," about wine, said Mr. Walters of Shanken Communications, it would make sense to focus on those who already buy it, rather than recruiting converts to the cause.
Shanken's most recent full-year data show that in 1990, 9.25 million 9-liter cases of Italian wine were shipped to this country, down 9 percent from 10.17 million in 1989. Of the 20 best-selling fine wines, the highest an Italian brand ranked was ninth; Santa Margherita, from Palermo Imports Ltd., sold 190,000 9-liter cases at an average price of $14.50 for a 750-milliliter bottle.
The campaign is the commission's first since 1987, when its account was at Ketchum/Hicks & Greist, now known as Ketchum Advertising New York. McCaffery won the account in September, after a review that included two other New York agencies, Della Femina, McNamee Inc. and Geer, DuBois Inc., and the Armando Testa Group Worldwide of Milan.
