HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

COMPANIES
The results of the holiday selling season began trickling out, with most results in line with analysts' expectations. But Toys "R" Us reported better-than-expected sales gains, causing a stampede among investors to buy its stock, which gained $2. Venture Stores and Caldor reported sales results that were more in line with expectations. [Page D1.]
United Telecom plans to buy the 19.9 percent of U S Sprint it does not own from GTE for $530 million. [D3.] 
 Hertz said it would impose surcharges of $15 to $56 a day on residents of Queens, Brooklyn and the Bronx who rent cars anywhere in the New York area. [A1.]
 
THE ECONOMY
The nation's industrial economy contracted in December to its lowest level in 8 months, the nation's purchasing managers said, stalled by declining orders and lower production. The report was the first significant indication of the state of the economy last month. [D1.]
Sales of U.S.-built cars and light trucks remained weak in mid-December, a historically slow period. Auto makers posted a 0.4 percent gain over last year, but the seasonally adjusted annual selling rate was the lowest since last year. [D1.]
The U.S. sale of S.& L. properties to Patriot American was wasteful, uncompetitive and plagued by financial uncertainties, a Congressional report said. The Bush Administration had touted the deal as a model for bulk disposal of properties. [D1.]
Spending on construction projects declined in November for the first time in five months as outlays for new office buildings and other commercial structures fell sharply. [D2.]
The number of Americans filing new jobless claims fell by 29,000 in the third week of December, erasing part of an earlier surge, the Government said. [D3.]
 
INTERNATIONAL
For all the Japanese fears that the executives joining Bush on his Asian trip are coming to protest their trade policies, many will probably bear a friendlier message. Many have already prospered from contracts with Japanese companies and see the trip as a chance to drum up business. [D1.]
 
MARKETS
Stocks edged further upward, as widespread selling was overwhelmed by a last-minute buying surge. The Dow rose 3.58, to 3,172.41, its fifth straight record. [D6.]
In the credit markets, the year began on a somewhat sour note, as prices of longer-dated notes and bonds fell fairly sharply, and interest rates rose. [D11.]
The dollar rose against key European currencies despite new evidence of economic weakness in the U.S. [D12.]
Silver prices rebounded smartly on a wave of speculative buying, and oil prices rose after a long downtrend. [D12.]
 
TODAY'S COLUMNS
For dividend actions, the year just ended was in some ways the worst on record, with fewer companies providing good news for shareholders than at any time since compiling began. Still, the year ended with some limited signs of revival, as more companies announced dividend increases than in December 1990. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [D1.]
How much can the U.S. really help Russia and the other republics? With the shortage of public funds, political pressures have been building on the Government to scale back its global commitments. Leonard Silk: Economic Scene. [D2.]
Upjohn is planning an aggressive campaign to market Rogaine, its hair-loss treatment, to women in the same direct, assertive tones that have infused the ads aimed at men. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D4.]

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
A Specialist in Cutting Costs Is the New President of PNC

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
The PNC Financial Corporation, the prosperous Pittsburgh banking company, which grew rapidly in the 1980's to become the 16th largest in the country, yesterday named a new president, James E. Rohr.
Mr. Rohr, 43, started at the Pittsburgh National Bank in 1972 and spent most of his career in corporate banking. In his new position, he will be the No. 2 PNC executive after Thomas H. O'Brien, who gave up the president's title but remains chairman and chief executive. 
 Although Mr. Rohr said PNC's problems with bad loans were mostly past -- the company's holdings of badly troubled loans and foreclosed real estate more than doubled in 1990 but declined last year -- he expected the weak economy to continue to dampen prospects for the banking industry. "Loan growth," he said, "is not going to be the fuel to profits that it was during the 1980's."
He said banks needed to work harder to keep costs low. Although PNC is already an industry leader in controlling costs, Mr. Rohr recently completed a six-month study of PNC's six banks in Pennsylvania that found ways to improve the quality of service and cut costs by $25 million to $35 million a year, beginning in 1994.
Many improvements, which were culled from about 500 suggestions made by 175 company officials, call for more uniformity among the subsidiary banks. While PNC's 11 banks in Pennsylvania, Kentucky, Ohio, New Jersey and Delaware already share computer systems and similar standards for loans and business practices, "we found incremental savings by adopting identical systems," Mr. Rohr said.
The move to uniformity could go so far as to include name changes for subsidiary banks. But even if the names remain the same, Mr. Rohr noted that the company expected to save more thanr $3 million a year by consolidating its six Pennsylvania banks under one charter, thereby eliminating some costs and making it easier to deal with regulators.
Mr. Rohr is a graduate of Notre Dame and has a master's degree in business administration from Ohio State University.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Yields of Money Funds Post A Mixed Showing for Week

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields of money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were mixed for the week ended Tuesday. Assets of taxable funds declined sharply in the same period, as investors sought higher interest elsewhere.
Tax-exempt money fund yields moved up smartly in the latest week. The rise in yields was attributed to a combination of seasonal factors and, to some extent, a dwindling demand for money market funds. 
 The seven-day compounded average yield for a tax-exempt fund rose 40 basis points, to 4.41 percent, with the simple yield up 39 basis points, to 4.32 percent. During the same period, the 30-day compounded yield rose 16 basis points, to 3.99 percent, and the simple yield was up 15 basis points, to 3.91 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
Donoghue's said the average number of days to maturity of securities held in portfolios fell by 2, to 56. Donoghue's analysts said the shortening of days did not necessarily indicate that managers were expecting an increase in interest rates, but might be pulling back in length of maturity to be in a better position to take advantage of rate changes that are tied to seasonal factors.
 
Tax-Exempt Assets Down
 Donoghue's said total assets of tax-exempt funds for the week were down by $531 million, to $91 billion. This compares with the $1.2 billion decline in assets the previous week, as investors disappointed by the rate of return moved toward equities and a surging stock market.
For investors in the 28 percent tax bracket the taxable equivalent of the current seven-day compounded yield is 6.12 percent, while the equivalent in the 31 percent tax bracket is 6.39 percent.
Of the funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's with assets larger than $100 million, Calvert Tax Free Reserves, was the best performer. The fund, which is distributed by the Calvert Group of Washington, D.C., had a return of 5.49 percent, or 50 basis points higher than the best performer the previous week.
Assets of taxable funds fell by a hefty $12.5 billion, to $456.3 billion, as institutional investors were caught up in seasonal factors and window dressing, and small investors scurried for higher yields in other interest-rate- oriented investments like short-term bond funds, corporate bond funds and the stock market.
The average seven-day compounded taxable yield fell by 3 basis points, to 4.61 percent, with the simple yield at 4.51 percent. The 30-day compounded yield was down 5 basis points, to 4.66 percent, as the simple yield fell to 4.56 percent.
The taxable fund with the best return was Merrill Lynch Ready Assets, with a performance of 6.78 percent.

HEADLINE: Sparing a Dime, Whether They Agree or Not

BYLINE: By LYNDA RICHARDSON

 BODY:
During the morning rush hour yesterday at the Borough Hall subway station in Brooklyn, flames leaped from a trash bin fire that the station manager said probably was set by someone with a ravaged mind. But to a grumbling commuter, John Beranbaum, a civil rights lawyer, the fire looked like a "subterranean protest" of the new $1.25 fare.
Already pinched for money from the holidays and the recession, New Yorkers returned to the subways and buses yesterday to encounter a fare increase that had them waiting in longer-than-usual lines and digging into pockets for an extra dime. The fare increase provoked a range of emotions, from indifference to peevish resignation. 
 Thomas Jones said he was so annoyed about the increase that he could barely read the religious pamphlet that he brought for his commute from the Bronx to his minimum-wage messenger's job in Manhattan. As the Lexington Avenue Express rumbled along, the 43-year-old Mr. Jones finally gave up his search for spiritual solace in the book, "What We Can Learn From the Angels."
"What I've learned from the angels is that M.T.A. comes in the night and sticks 10 cents down your throat," he said.
Mr. Jones said he was reeling from the recession and the expenses of the holidays for his wife and three children. Every day, he counts his pennies carefully to survive on a $4.35-an-hour salary. He called the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's fare increase, the fifth since 1981, "a lousy idea."
"You put your hand in your pocket and your money is gone," he said.
As of midmorning, the Borough Hall subway station manager, Debra Jean-Louis, said proudly that no one had cursed her out or given her a dirty look -- omissions she attributed to relief that the Transit Authority had not increased fares to $1.40, as first discussed, and to leftover goodwill from the holiday season.
Like a number of other commuters, Joe Finegan, a lawyer, had anticipated long lines yesterday and had hoarded tokens in the days preceding the increase. New tokens will take their place, but because of the last-minute nature of Tuesday's vote to raise the fare, the old tokens are valid until a date yet to be set.
As he moved through the turnstiles, Mr. Finegan said he thought the fare increase was reasonable, the opinion of a minuscule minority.
Paul Gee, a retired banker, fumbled impatiently for change as he complained not about the amount of the increase but about what he considered the sneakiness of the M.T.A. in first saying that an increase from $1.15 to $1.40 would be needed to close a projected deficit of $263 million in the Transit Authority's 1992 budget.
"The dime is not the problem; the problem is the way it was done," Mr. Gee said.
In the Times Square station, Kathy Darcy, a bank data processor from Sunnyside, Queens, said she thought the increase unjustified because the trains she rides were often crowded and delayed, with public address systems that were inaudible.
"They should pay me to ride the trains because my life feels in danger," she said.
For Charles Gayle, also at the Times Square station, the fare increase meant a day of blues. Mr. Gayle, a musician, blew hard on his trumpet as the straphangers spilled out. His battered tweed cap lay nearly empty of coins at his feet -- an indicator, he felt, that commuters had a new use for their change.
"Nothing is happening this morning," said Mr. Gayle. "This is the slowest day I've ever had."
But Mr. Gayle, a subway rider for 20 years, said he understood.
"People need their money," he said.

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

NEW EFFORTS TO COLLECT CHILD SUPPORT
One of the chief barriers to collecting child support is the unwillingness of many unwed mothers to identify their children's fathers for months or even years. Increasingly, policymakers in the region and across the nation are trying to get around this problem by establishing paternity early on. A1.
 
HERTZ IMPOSES NEW FEES ON NEW YORKERS
The Hertz Corporation effectively withdrew from a large part of the New York City car-rental market, announcing that it would impose surcharges of $15 to $56 a day on residents of Queens, Brooklyn and the Bronx who rent cars anywhere in the metropolitan region. A1.
 

NEW YORK CITY
 
THE STATE OF THE CITY
In a hopeful speech intended to build confidence in his ability to lead the city through hard economic times, Mayor David N. Dinkins announced measures to stimulate the city's sagging economy. His second State of the City address, at the midpoint of his term, was larded with a mixture of ambitious ideas and simple gestures, some of which have been previously proposed. A1.
 
PUBLIC REPORT CARD, PRIVATE ACCOUNTING
Mayor Dinkins's speech was not so much a summary of the present as a political summons to the future, less a public report card than a private accounting. News analysis, B2.
 
CITY MAY NOT SET A NEW MURDER RECORD
New York City may have fewer homicides in 1991 than in 1990, according to preliminary figures gathered by the Police Department. It would be the first decline in the city in six years. The police said that between 2,180 and 2,225 murders occurred in 1991 -- down from the record of 2,245 set in 1990. B3.
 
NEW FARE CAUSES ANGER AND INDIFFERENCE
New Yorkers returned to the subways and buses to encounter the new $1.25 fare. While for some the fare increase merely meant longer-than-usual lines and digging into pockets for an extra dime, it meant more suffering for those people already reeling from the recession and the expenses of the holidays. B3.
 
CITY COLLEGE LEADERSHIP UNDER REVIEW
Officials and trustees of the City University of New York are reviewing the leadership of City College after an extraordinarily troubled year that was marred by a three-week student strike and a widespread storm over racially charged remarks by two professors before it ended in the deaths of nine young people at a charity basketball game on Saturday. B4.
 
REGION
 
NEW LAW AGAINST INSURANCE LIES
New Yorkers and other out-of-staters who try to beat high automobile-insurance rates by falsely registering their cars in New Jersey will face stiff fines -- up to $15,000 -- under a bill signed into law by Gov. Jim Florio. B5.
 
DISPUTE OVER ABORTION IN NASSAU COUNTY
Advocates of abortion rights are accusing Nassau County officials of carrying out a cynical, ideological vendetta against abortions, as the Nassau County Medical Center has begun to close its abortion and family-planning clinics in a cost-cutting move. B5.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Toys 'R' Us Christmas Sales Jump

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM

 BODY:
As the nation's retailers began reporting the results of the holiday selling season yesterday, Toys "R" Us stood out with better-than-expected sales gains that caused a stampede among investors to buy its stock.
Results of two regional discount chains were more in line with analysts' expectations. 
 Toys "R" Us said sales for the eight weeks ended Dec. 28 were up 16.4 percent, to $2.5 billion, compared with $2.1 billion in the corresponding period last year. Sales in stores open at least one year, which is considered a better indicator of performance, were up 7.9 percent for the Christmas season.
Analysts said Toys "R" Us's way of keeping mum during the normal holiday hype typically made investors jittery, and the better-than-expected sales made its stock the volume leader for the day. The stock closed up 2 points yesterday at 34 3/4.
 
Effect of Grim Forecasts
 On Nov. 6, when gloomy prognostications for the Christmas season were beginning to show up in newspapers and on television, Toys "R" Us shares traded at 26 5/8.
Venture Stores Inc., a discount chain with stores primarily in the Midwest, and the Caldor Corporation, a discount retailer in the Northeast reported sales results that were more in line with analysts' expectations.
Sales at Venture grew 9.3 percent for the four-week period that ended Dec. 28 to $254.9 million, from $233.3 million during the corresponding weeks last year. Sales in stores open at least one year increased 3.7 percent.
Caldor reported a 5 percent sales gain, to $321 million for the period from $306 million in the comparable 1990 period, but its same-store sales decreased 1 percent.
 
Question of Profits
 The two chains are likely to pay for their sales increases with some share of profits, said Robert F. Buchanan, an analyst with Alex. Brown & Sons.
Analysts said Toys "R" Us's good fortune during the holiday selling season was not likely to be matched by many other retailers reporting results today.
"We're not going to get much in the way of positive surprises," Mr. Buchanan said. He added that his company's index of retail sales would probably show a 2.5 percent increase in December.
Four to six weeks before the critical Christmas retail period began, Toys "R" Us executives were predicting that sales in comparable stores would increase only in the low- to mid-single digits.
Retail consultants and analysts had estimated that sales during the holiday sales period would grow between 2 percent and 3 percent, while some retailers had anticipated sales increases of 5 percent and more.
Richard N. Baum, an analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein & Company, said a sales surge late in the season also helped Toys "R" Us clean out its warehouses, which means the company will be able to focus on testing new toys in the new year instead of digging out from under old inventory.
He also warned that some of the sales gains might have come at the expense of profit margins, since Toys "R" Us earlier this year instituted a low-price program for some of its key merchandise.
Similarly, Venture and Caldor reported strong consumer interest in their promotional merchandise, which carries lower profit margins.
Mr. Buchanan of Alex. Brown said Venture's sales were slightly below the company's plans in December, but the decline was balanced by unexpectedly good sales in November. He said Venture had done a good job of stocking the right merchandise in the right quantity.
"They've been keeping their powder dry by managing inventory extremely well," Mr. Buchanan said. He said the primary reason that Venture posted better sales results than Caldor was the Midwestern location of its stores. Caldor's 128 stores are in the Northeast, where the recession has been more severe.
While some stores are likely to report big sales gains today, analysts cautioned that those gains might look stronger than they actually were because the numbers were being compared with weak 1990 results.

HEADLINE: Vehicle Sales Weak Again In Midmonth

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Jan. 2

 BODY:
Sales of cars and light trucks built in the United States remained weak in mid-December, a historically slow period in the automobile industry. Although auto makers said today that they had posted a slight gain of four-tenths of a percent over last year, the seasonally adjusted annual selling rate of 5.2 million cars was the lowest since the comparable period last year.
"With few exceptions, this was a poor showing," said Tom Webb, the chief economist of the National Automobile Dealers Association, a leading industry group.
 
Underreporting Results
 But Ronald A. Glantz, an analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. in San Francisco, said the sales figures were artificially low in mid-December because Chevrolet and Ford underreported sales of pickup trucks. He said they were likely to bunch sales in the final 10 days of December as a competitive move. Those results are to be announced on Monday. 
 Both auto makers hope an end-of-the-year surge will help them beat out each other for bragging rights as the best-selling pickup truck of 1991. A similar sales pattern occurred in December 1990.
Ford and Chevrolet have been offering heavy incentives on their trucks. Ford's dealer and customer incentives have ranged up to $1,500, while Chevrolet's have been up to $2,000, dealers said.
Even with the expected higher sales for the end of December, Mr. Glantz anticipates that December over all will show a drop from November. "Sales absolutely are bad," he said.
For the Dec. 11-20 period, which contained nine selling days this year and last, the domestic manufacturers said they had sold 124,312 cars, a decrease of 2.8 percent. Sales of light trucks rose by 5.6 percent, to 83,718 pickups, mini-vans and sport-utility vehicles.
Several dealers said their mid-December sales were not much lower than expected. Jonathan R. Bishop, the sales manager for Bishop Motors in Barberton, Ohio, called the car market "stable, albeit down."
 
Some Improvement
 Some even saw signs of improvement. Herb Gordon, who owns several foreign and domestic dealerships in Silver Spring, Md., said business in his service departments had improved in recent weeks, an indication that drivers were starting to loosen their wallets and pocketbooks. Other dealers also reported an increase in service business, but suggested that many car owners could simply no longer delay needed repairs.
Joseph Medwin, the general manager of Konner Chevrolet Geo in West Caldwell, N.J., about 25 miles from New York City, said his showroom traffic was up, although his dealership sold 10 percent fewer cars in recent weeks than the previous year.
"There seems to be buyers out there, but people just seem a little hesitant," Mr. Medwin said. "They're at least looking for cars."
The General Motors Corporation sold 56,872 cars in mid-December, down by 5.2 percent over last year. But one G.M. division posted a gain in car sales in the period, Buick, on the strength of sales of its redesigned LeSabre model. G.M. sold 31,626 light trucks, a decline of 7.3 percent.
 
Ford Car Sales Off 5.9%
 The Ford Motor Company posted a 5.9 percent drop in car sales, to 30,447. Its light-truck sales rose by 17.6 percent, to 30,091.
The Chrysler Corporation's car sales dropped by 17.7 percent, to 13,400, based on estimates by Ward's Automotive Reports. Chrysler does not report its 10-day sales figures.
Chrysler's light-truck sales, including mini-vans and Jeeps, rose by 15.6 percent, to 18,500, Ward's estimated.
The Honda Motor Company sold 9,473 domestically produced cars in the middle of last month, a gain of 48.4 percent. But Honda's figures were soft for the December 1990 period because a special incentive had expired at the end of November.
The Toyota Motor Corporation sold 7,604 American-built cars in the period, an increase of 21.3 percent.

HEADLINE: Auto Plants to Shut

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: DETROIT, Jan. 2

 BODY:
Chrysler, Ford Motor and General Motors will close 29 of their North American assembly plants next week -- temporarily laying off nearly 74,500 hourly auto workers -- because of slow dealer orders, the companies said today. In addition, five other plants will be closed because of retooling or material shortages. Auto makers routinely shut assembly plants to bring production into line with sales. But the automobile industry was particularly wounded in 1991 by the national recession, which sharply eroded demand for new cars, and the cutbacks announced today reflected those problems. The number of layoffs during the first full week of the new year will be about 12,500 more than during the corresponding week in 1991.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Rises Despite Signs Recession Continues in U.S.

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar rose against key European currencies yesterday in post-holiday trading despite new evidence of economic weakness in the United States.
Currency traders attributed the dollar's strength to short-term demand after the closing of financial markets on New Year's Day. Some said there was a feeling in the foreign exchange market that the dollar might have been oversold recently, which prompted some traders to buy the currency. 
 Others said speculation was growing that United States interest rates, which have declined significantly as a result of the recession, are not likely to drop further, which would at least be a reason not to sell the dollar. Cheaper interest rates make dollar-denominated investments worth less.
"People think this is a bottom for us," said Ziggy Zborowski, a foreign-exchange trader at the New York branch of Bank Leumi Trust Co.
Mr. Zborowski also said a rumor circulated that German monetary officials, who last month increased interest rates unexpectedly, were not likely to raise them again. He said that also helped the dollar, which gained more than a pfennig against the German mark.
But others said most of the dollar's strength yesterday was from short-covering, in which traders who had sold borrowed dollars bought them back to repay lenders. That created an artificially strong demand.
"The economic data certaintly wouldn't support a higher dollar," said Michael Kahn, a trader at the New York branch of Credit Suisse, the Swiss banking concern. "Thin trading and short-covering got the market moving."
More evidence of a prolonged United States bout with recession emerged yesterday. The National Association of Purchasing Management's closely watched index on the health of the nation's industry fell sharply in December, and the Government said construction spending fell in November after four months of improvement.
Tokyo financial markets remained closed yesterday in an extended break. In Europe, the dollar fetched 124.50 yen, down from 125.25 yen in Tokyo late Tuesday. Later in New York, the dollar fetched 124.60 yen, down from 124.78.
The British pound weakened in London to $1.8685, from $1.8718 late Tuesday. By the time trading concluded in New York, the pound traded at $1.8655, down from $1.8685 Tuesday.
Other late-dollar rates in New York vs. levels late Tuesday: 1.5315 marks, up from 1.5170; 1.3665 Swiss francs, up from 1.3590; 1.1509 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1555; 5.2305 French francs, up from 5.1845, and 1,158.00 Italian lire, up from 1,149.25.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
How Much Aid To Give the East?

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:
AMID great turmoil and doubts, Russia has taken its historic plunge to economic and political freedom. And the United States, perhaps belatedly, is moving to organize Western aid for Russia and the other republics of the former Soviet Union that must rebuild collapsing economies.
At Princeton University last month Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said the popularly elected leaders of Russia, Ukraine, Kazakhstan and the other republics are looking to America and the West for "guidance and help in launching genuine, far-reaching political and economic reform." But how much can the United States, running a budget deficit expected to exceed $350 billion this year, do to help the ex-Communist countries? 
 With the shortage of public funds, political pressures have been building on the Government to scale back its global commitments, pay more attention to domestic needs and strengthen America's ability to compete internationally.
Indeed, this may be the prime issue of the 1992 election. President Bush, accompanied by 21 American business executives, has billed his trip to Japan and other countries of the Pacific Rim as a move to create American jobs by opening markets and selling more American goods abroad.
Nevertheless, Secretary Baker will, sometime soon, summon a conference in Washington of the industrial countries to discuss measures to aid Russia and the other independent states. The date for the conference has not been disclosed; nor have which countries will be invited to attend and the specific agenda.
However, it seems evident that the United States, as it did during the Persian Gulf war, means to take the lead in mobilizing the capital and other resources of its partners to help rescue Russia and the others. In his address at Princeton, Mr. Baker said, "Together with our NATO allies, Japan, South Korea, the other O.E.C.D. states, our gulf coalition partners, we must pursue a diplomacy of collective engagement."
But there was caution in his call for aid. "We alone cannot determine whether these new democrats will succeed," he said. "Their success lies in their own hands, in the hard choices they make. But history will count our efforts a success if we help the democrats hold open opportunities to determine a better future." A major goal of the West, he added, will be to help promote "a process where even limited successes build hope and the authority of the democrats over time." Process and hope are not quite the same as money.
How much capital is really needed for the reconstruction and integration of Russia and Eastern Europe into the Western economy, and who will provide it? Nobody knows.
According to an estimate by David Suratgar of Morgan Grenfell & Company, writing in the journal World Link, the costs should amount to about $180 billion a year for 10 years for the capital stock of those countries in the East to reach the level of Western industrial countries. Since the Russians and others cannot possibly raise such sums internally, Mr. Suratgar estimates that their external financial requirements will come to more than $100 billion a year for 10 years.
That figure now looks out of reach. Writing in The Economist, Jeffrey Sachs of Harvard, who has been an adviser to the Russian and Polish Governments, proposes that about $30 billion a year go to Russia and the other independent republics for the next three or four years.
He suggests that the contributions be divided as follows: $5 billion a year from the International Monetary Fund, $4 billion from the World Bank, $3 billion from the new European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, plus $10 billion a year from the Western countries. He puts the United States and Japan down for $3 billion each. These sums look relatively modest. Germany alone is spending more than $50 billion a year on the integration of East Germany, with its population of only 20 million people.
Still, official capital is in tight supply. Government loans and grants to Russia and Eastern Europe will have to be augmented by the investments of private businesses, if they are to be integrated into the West. Private businesses in America, Europe and Japan have a huge contribution to make in transferring not only capital but also technology, marketing and managerial skills to the East. Through joint ventures, they can speed the process of privatization.
But the commercial risks are high, and private businesses will need the financial support, insurance or guarantees of Western governments, as well as their legal and diplomatic help. These are issues to be thrashed out when Mr. Baker assembles his foreign partners at the aid conference in Washington -- and as soon as possible, meets with Congressional leaders. Just as President Harry Truman needed the Republicans for the Marshall Plan, President Bush now needs the Democrats.

HEADLINE: Little Anger Among Those on Bush Trip

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN

 BODY:
For all the Japanese fears that the business executives joining President Bush on his Asian trip are coming to protest their trade policies, many of these leaders will probably bear a friendlier message. Many have already prospered from contracts with Japanese companies and see the trip as a chance to drum up business.
J. Bronce Henderson 3d, chief executive of Detroit Center Tool Inc., simply wishes to sell the Japanese his most advanced welding systems. For him, the President's trip represents an unusual opportunity to get the attention of top Japanese auto executives, said Paul Diettmer, the company's manager of advertising. 
 Detroit Center Tool has already sold its welding systems, which cost as much as $100 million, to Toyota in Canada and in California.
"We want to expose the Japanese to the quality technology we have available," Mr. Diettmer said. "You have to be persistent when working with the Japanese. You have to play by their rules and do your homework."
But if most of the executives traveling with the President bear glad tidings, the chairmen of the Big Three auto makers appear ready for battle. They have complained frequently that they are unfairly excluded from selling cars and trucks to the Japanese, and their views have received the most attention so far. The auto makers have called on the Japanese Government to restrain exports even more as a way of reducing the United States' $40 billion annual trade deficit with Japan.
For example, Harold A. Poling, the chairman of the Ford Motor Company, has proposed 20 percent annual reductions for five years. "I would say to them, 'You figure out how to do it,' " Mr. Poling said two weeks ago. The Chrysler Corporation has asked the President to limit the sales of Japanese cars, while the General Motors Corporation has made no specific proposal.
While sales of vehicles made by G.M., Ford and Chrysler have been battered by the Toyota Motor Corporation, the Nissan Motor Company, the Honda Motor Company and other Japanese auto makers, the Big Three are themselves important purchasers of Japanese-made vehicles, engines, machine tools and other parts.
Just one of the 21 executives on the trip was available to speak about it. Many of the others would rather allow the White House to take the lead at a time of some economic tension. Administration officials have expressed concern that the outspokenness of Lee A. Iacocca, the Chrysler chairman, could provoke a diplomatic uproar.
 
Some Past Victories
 The trip's roster includes executives who could testify to some notable victories in Japan. Motorola Inc., represented by Robert W. Galvin, a former chairman, has successfully sold telecommunications equipment in Japan, with the help of United States Government pressure.
Most delegates, like Maurice R. Greenberg of American International Group Inc., were invited because they represent private or government trade groups that promote business and cooperation between the United States and Asia. Mr. Greenberg is president of the U.S. Association of South East Asia Nations Business Council; his company has more than 10,000 insurance agents in Japan. James D. Robinson 3d, chairman of the American Express Company, is a member of the President's advisory council for trade policy.
Some members of the delegation represent smaller companies that are trying to crack the Japanese market. Robert J. Maricich, president of American of Martinsville , furniture company in Martinsville, Va., said that in 18 months of efforts in Japan, he had found business partners but no orders so far -- only encouraging prospects. "I think we've done everything we can do to get into the dance, but I don't think we'll know for another year whether we are dancing," he said.
Mr. Maricich said that his opportunities to do business had been fair. "I think we've discovered it's a pretty level playing field" in the furniture business, he told President Bush at a White House meeting a few weeks ago.
Mr. Maricich counsels cooperation, not confrontation. "I plan to tell the Japanese that it's important to minimize trade imbalances, but I don't believe in putting up restrictions in our country."
Mr. Bush started his trip Tuesday in Australia, and plans stops in Singapore and South Korea, but the most important action will take place in Japan. His four-day visit there begins next Tuesday.
The auto executives will arrive for the Japanese portion of the trip; only some of the others will be along for the entire trip. Beyond vague urgings for fair treatment, few American executives have offered concrete suggestions for Government action to help them succeed in Japan. Those who have done business there say there are few short cuts: Executives have to learn the language, spend time cultivating relationships and invest heavily in research and development.
 
A Host of Reasons
 "Japan has never been an easy market to do business in and never will be, for a host of cultural, historical and linguistic reasons that have nothing to do with government," said Steven Schlossstein, a Princeton, N.J., consultant to companies doing business in Japan.
Nevertheless, international trade experts think the visit to Japan could prod Japanese companies to do more business with their American counterparts so as to head off protectionist measures brewing in Congress. Lawmakers from Michigan and political opponents of the President promise to introduce legislation that would cap the Japanese share of the American auto market if the trade deficit is not reduced.
To prevent that, Japanese auto makers have pledged to increase purchases from United States suppliers. Many American suppliers wish to export to Japan -- and sell to Japanese companies in this country -- but have had little success penetrating the cozy relationships between Japanese auto makers and Japanese parts manufacturers.
American automotive suppliers have criticized the Japanese auto makers' practice of maintaining exclusive relationships with some suppliers. But manufacturing experts suggest that great perseverance can pay off.
The ASC Corporation of Southgate, Mich., will be represented in the delegation by the company's chairman, Heinz C. Prechter, who is also chairman of the President's Export Council. His company has won contracts to supply convertible tops to Toyota and other Japanese auto makers -- but only after 15 years of cultivating contacts in Japan. In a previous interview, Mr. Prechter said the lengthy wait reflected not unfairness but normal practices in a nation where companies feel great loyalty to their long-term suppliers.
 
Textron's Goals
 Textron Inc., whose chairman, Beverly F. Dolan, is traveling on the mission and also serves on the President's Export Council, wants to go beyond selling helicopters and some other products in Japan.
"We feel we have the quality and the expertise to supply the Japanese market" with auto parts including armrests and dashboards, a company spokesman said.
The Japanese blame foreign auto makers themselves for their scant sales in Japan, saying they have failed to develop vehicle models that are tailored to Japanese consumers, with steering wheels on the right-hand side.
But Japanese officials are said to be considering reductions in exports of vehicles to the United States, under the current voluntary agreement. American trade experts expect the Japanese to present President Bush with such a measure, or other concessions, if only as conciliatory gestures.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Market Place;
A Very Stingy Year for Dividends

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS

 BODY:
The year just ended was in some ways the worst on record in terms of dividend actions, with fewer companies providing good news for shareholders than at any time since comparable figures began to be compiled in 1955, the Standard & Poor's Corporation reported yesterday.
Nonetheless, the year ended with some limited signs of revival. In December, as in two of the previous three months, more companies announced dividend increases than had done so in the comparable month of 1990. That provided some hope that the decline in corporate profits might be about to end.
 
Fewest Increases on Record
 The poor overall dividend figures reflected the recession and the cash-flow problems that have hit many companies burdened by debts left over from the 1980's and hurt by a slowdown in sales. 
 The essential strength of the American economy is reflected in the fact that even in a bad year, there were more than three times as many good announcements -- of dividend increases, extra dividends or dividend reinstatements -- as bad ones -- dividend reductions and omissions.
The total of 1,458 good announcements was the smallest for any year since S.& P. began keeping such figures in 1955, and was down 14 percent from 1990. With the number of companies cutting payouts climbing, a total of 437 bad announcements were recorded, the most since the 1982 recession.
The ratio of good to bad, at 3.3 to 1, was the lowest since 1958, a recession year that saw a flood of dividend cuts and a ratio of just 2.7 to 1.
As recently as 1988, there were more than 12 good dividend announcements for every bad one.
One of the most closely watched figures is the number of companies announcing dividend increases, which fell 14 percent, to 1,086, in 1991. That was the lowest for any year since 1970 and 1971, when Federal wage and price controls held the figures down. Excluding that period, the 1991 figure was the lowest since an identical figure of 1,086 in 1962.
 
Still Awaiting 'Happy Days'
 Arnold Kaufman, the editor of S.& P.'s Outlook newsletter, noted that the increases were in relation to the depressed levels of late 1990, after the recession had begun and while Iraq was still occupying Kuwait. "The increase is not really an indication that happy days are here again," he said.
The seasonal high for dividend increases normally runs from November to February, as companies anticipate or react to good annual profit news. But while December's total of 102 dividend increases was up from 88 a year earlier, it was otherwise the lowest total for any December since 1960.
One bright point in the dividend picture was that fewer companies -- 250 -- omitted dividends in 1991, compared with 266 in 1990. But both years were the worst in almost a decade, trailing 1982, when 315 companies were forced to omit dividends.
Despite the recession, there appears to have been a small increase in the dividends paid on the stocks in the S.& P. 500 index as a group. That payout is computed based on what would be received by an owner of all 500 stocks, whose holdings of mostly fractional shares were worth a total of the S.& P. index's stated price, which was $417.26 yesterday. Mr. Kaufman estimated the figure for 1991 will be $12.20, only a quarter of a percent above the 1990 figure of $12.17.
It may seem amazing that the stock market could rise with the dividend picture so bleak, but history shows that stock prices are more likely to rise when the dividend news is less robust. By that measure, the 20 percent increase in the Dow Jones industrial average last year should have come as no surprise.
A way to measure that, known as the Dividend Dip indicator, compares the number of companies that increase payouts over a six-month period with the number that did so in the six-month period a year earlier. For the last half of 1991, that number was down 19.
Under the Dividend Dip indicator, invented by this columnist in the summer of 1987 when it gave a sell signal less than four months before that year's stock market crash, it is good to buy stocks so long as the change is negative. Indeed, this indicator is continuing to give a buy signal. Should the total for the first six months of this year be higher than the total in the 1991 period, however, that indicator would give a sell signal at the end of June.
The logic behind this may be that dividend actions are often a lagging indicator of the economy, while stock prices are a leading indicator. Many companies have a tradition of increasing dividends every year, and strive to continue doing so until the news is so bad they must stop. Similarly, companies may hesitate to raise dividends until they are confident that profits are rising.
Had an investor used the Dividend-Dip indicator since the end of 1956, when it gave its first buy signal, buying the stocks in the Dow when the indicator was bullish and staying out of the market when it was negative, an initial investment of $1,000 would now be worth $11,610, ignoring dividends and interest on the money earned while the money was not invested in stocks. In all, that investor would have owned stocks for 16.5 of the 35 years.
By contrast, a buy-and-hold strategy over the same period, again ignoring dividends, would have seen that $1,000 grow into $6,344.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Fewer File For Jobless Benefits

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2

 BODY:
The number of Americans filing new claims for unemployment benefits fell by 29,000 in the third week of December, erasing part of an earlier surge, the Government said today.
There were 438,000 Americans filing their first claims for unemployment assistance in the week that ended on Dec. 21, down from the previous week's revised figure of 467,000, the Labor Department said. 
 The latest decline was the second straight drop, after a 20,000 decrease during the second week of December, the department said.
 
Does Not Erase Surge
 But both declines combined still have not completely erased a 79,000 surge in early December, when claims climbed to nearly 500,000, back to the worst levels of the recession.
"The perception that the labor market is weak and has declined should remain intact," said Sam Kahan of Fuji Securities Inc. "Whether it's about to deteriorate again or whether it's about to improve, we can't tell from today's number."
The claims number can be extremely volatile from week to week, and analysts hesitate to read too much into a one-week movement. Instead, they look to a four-week average of claims for a better barometer of hiring practices.
With today's decline, the four-week average stands at 453,000, down from the previous four-week average of 463,000.
But the four-week average is up from the levels of September, when economists thought the nation's jobs picture might be improving.
 
Average at 450,000
 In August and September, Mr. Kahan said, the four-week average hovered close to 425,000. But since November, the average has been around 450,000, he said.
The number of Americans actually receiving unemployment benefits climbed to 3.5 million during the week that ended on Dec. 14, up by 128,000 from the previous week, the Labor Department said.
About 8.5 million Americans are out of work. The nation's unemployment rate is 6.8 percent.

HEADLINE: Excerpts From Mayor's Speech: A Vision of a City

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from yesterday's State of the City address by Mayor David N. Dinkins.
We have just ended another very difficult year, as life proved to be a little harder, a little harsher than the year before. It has been a year that began with the threat of war abroad and that concluded with tragedy and injustice here at home, as nine promising young people were taken from us so cruelly in a stairwell at City College. . . . 
 If the events of last year have taught us anything, it is that none of us can escape the hazards of this very real, very serious national recession.
I understand the feelings of hopelessness -- and helplessness -- that this recession has caused for too many New Yorkers. . . .
In facing these difficult times, we realize there are some things we cannot change by ourselves: a turnaround in the national economy will happen only when Washington commits itself to better lives for our people. . . . Indeed, as we work to fill gaps of billions of dollars where there once was Federal aid, we sometimes, feel, quite frankly, as if Washington has placed a giant boulder in the paths of all state and local officials, directing us to roll it up the steepest of hills. Yet, we cannot let the callous elimination of Federal dollars crush our dreams.
We must begin as I have always begun -- by hearing the voices of our people, especially of those whose pain is too great and whose voices are too small. For a government that succumbs to silence can accomplish nothing and will wither in the depths of its own isolation.
The voice of a young mother who wants to work, but who cannot find adequate day care facilities in which to place her children, resounds in my ears. Her words inspired my efforts to develop programs that help people find jobs while their children are in centers staffed by devoted and loving child care workers.
I remember the voices I heard one cold December morning during my visit to the bread line at the Church of St. Francis of Assisi. One man waiting in line told me: "I don't want my family and neighbors to see me this way. I don't intend to be here next year." I understood just what he meant. My resolve to build a shelter system that offers our thousands of homeless residents a dignified place to stay on their journey home was strengthened that day.
The grief-stricken voices of the family of James Zappalorti, a developmentally disabled young man from Staten Island who died merely because of whom he chose to love, cannot be erased from my memory. And I pledged to James's family that I will continue to fight for the passage of a bias-related violence bill -- legislation that has been held up for too long in Albany because of a handful of Senate Republicans.
The voice of a disabled person crystallized the cruelties of our own thoughtlessness as he explained to me the difficulty of pressing an elevator emergency button, if you must reach that button from a wheelchair. So I have made it my job to further the access of disabled residents throughout this city.
And today I also hear the voices of all our people saying much more needs to be done right now in order to turn this city around.
Now some have suggested that we simply cut and cut away at the services that affect the lives of the most vulnerable among us. But as long as I am Mayor, I refuse to do that. Of course bond ratings are important, but we are judged against a higher standard. We have so many who need so much; I have not turned my back on them, and I never will. I came into government hearing the voices of those in need, and I will never stop listening.

 	 	 		. . .	 	We all know that local government cannot change the course of a national economy that is headed in the wrong direction. Nor can we stand by and drift into ever-deeper waters of despair. We have developed a package of programs to help make a small dent in the burdens of our residents during this time of economic hardship. . . .
I know that a dozen years of reactionary politics in Washington have served to reduce the real incomes of families across America. . . . That's why I have proposed to stabilize property taxes over at least the next two years.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Our course is clear. We must hold firm to our vision of this city. A city that stands for openness and compassion, for fiscal integrity and prudence, and most of all, a city that stands for opportunity -- the opportunity that generations of immigrants understood when they saw Ellis Island for the first time. . . .
It is the opportunity that awaits two Brooklyn College graduates, Lisette Nieves, our newest Rhodes Scholar, and Marshall Scholar Toba Friedman -- daughters and granddaughters of families who came here seeking all that New York has to offer, two young women who earned the right to make their dreams come true. Graduates of our public school system, they prove that the energy and ambition that built this city still shine brightly today, and that the promise of New York is within reach of us all.

He offered several plans to help the poor as well as to ease the burdens of residents and businesses hit by the recession. (Ruby Washington/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Dinkins as a Populist: Hearing 'Our People'

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
Mayor David N. Dinkins's speech on the state of New York City was not so much a summary of the present as a political summons to the future, aimed at assuring restive supporters that he would not abandon the poor to balance the budget, even as he pledged new efforts to appease the middle class.
The Mayor's speech, delivered at the midpoint of his term with his popularity low and his electoral coalition shaken, was less a public report card than the product of having assessed his prospects in private and found them wanting. In forceful and unusually blunt tones, he unleashed what many in the invited audience of city officials and supporters said was the opening salvo of his re-election campaign. 
 "Now some have suggested that we simply cut and cut away at the services that affect the lives of the most vulnerable among us," he said. "But as long as I am Mayor, I refuse to do that. Of course bond ratings are important, but we are judged against a higher standard. We have so many who need so much.; I have not turned my back on them, and I never will. I came into government hearing the voices of those in need, and I will never stop listening."
How well that populist oratory can be translated into reality remains to be seen. The Mayor still faces billion-dollar budget gaps in each of the next several years, closing them will require new rounds of cuts in city services already bleeding and Mr. Dinkins has limited room to maneuver, especially since he reaffirmed his plans to hire thousands of new police officers. He has been unable to reach agreement with the municipal unions on shrinking the work force.
 
A Dual Message
 But by outlining a grab bag of proposals that would cost little money but could end up saving some eventually, the Mayor's aides said he hoped to send a dual message of fiscal conservatism administered with a compassionate approach. He spoke, for example, of placing management of more repossessed apartment buildings back in private hands, under the aegis of nonprofit groups, which could please business people who have urged the city to shed some of its burdens and grass-roots groups, who favor greater community control.
"That's the speech I've been waiting for for two years," said Barry Feinstein, president of Local 237 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters and an early Dinkins supporter who has lately been highly critical of him. "I could hug and kiss him for that kind of comment about what the city needs. Hopefully, now this may be the beginning of an initiative to get those programs accomplished, even with very limited resources."
At the same time, Alfred C. Cerullo 3d of Staten Island, the City Council's Republican minority leader, while not happy with the Mayor's attacks on Republicans in Washington, praised his pledge to freeze property tax rates for two years, eliminate permit fees for minor construction and free 5,000 small businesses from licensing and fee requirements.
"He obviously is reaching out to the middle class more publicly than I have ever seen him do before," Mr. Cerullo said.
In preparing the speech, Mr. Dinkins set himself the challenge of rallying a city racked by recession and the turmoil of his two years in office, and in delivering it, he acknowledged "the feelings of hopelessness -- and helplessness -- that this recession has caused for too many New Yorkers." But he insisted, "There is more hope in this city than there are street corners."
 
Listening to People
 Even as some of his own aides and supporters have complained that Mr. Dinkins has become too defensive amid the city's mounting problems, unwilling to listen to their advice or criticism, he promised to take the operations of City Hall to offices in each borough for a week at a time in the coming months, to hear "the voices of our people."
"For a government that succumbs to silence can accomplish nothing and will wither in the depths of its own isolation," he said.
Delivering on those promises will be much harder than delivering the speech. Some of his ideas, like creating a new class of taxi medallions, will undoubtedly face stiff political opposition, while others, like expanding neighborhood health clinics to relieve overcrowding in hospital emergency rooms, will mean moving big operations with meager resources.
The Mayor spoke passionately of his proposals for building new homeless shelters around the city, some in middle-class areas, to provide better health and mental care to residents, saying, "While we may disagree over the precise address of our new residences, I am certain we will agree that the thousands of residents who live on our streets are God's children too, and must have a place in our neighborhoods." But the political challenge of making the plan come true was apparent when the City Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, who would have to approve it, did not join the applause for that line.
 
No Financial Details
 "It was a wonderful speech," said Councilman Herbert E. Berman of Brooklyn, chairman of the Finance Committee. "The issue is how to implement the ideas. The policies he's outlined are wonderful. The issue is how you can carry them out, and that we have yet to see."
Mr. Dinkins did not provide financial or operational details for virtually any of his new proposals, or on his plans for keeping the budget balanced, deferring that until he presents his preliminary budget in two weeks.
Yet, unlike his state of the city speech a year ago, which struck such a relentlessly optimistic tone just as the depth of the city's problems was becoming apparent that it seemed unrealistic, this address took a more sober approach. He spoke of his efforts to lobby Washington and Albany for more aid, to make urban America's case with the rest of the country.
"But we are realistic," he said. "We know that, at least in the short run, our future is in our hands alone."

HEADLINE: New Measure Will Punish Fraud in Car Registration

BYLINE: By WAYNE KING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, Jan. 2

 BODY:
New Yorkers and other out-of-staters who try to beat high automobile-insurance rates by falsely registering their cars in New Jersey will face stiff fines -- up to $15,000 -- under a bill signed into law today by Gov. Jim Florio.
The new law makes it a violation of the state's Fraud Prevention Act for any out-of-state motorist to misrepresent his legal residence in applying for automobile insurance. First offenders can be fined $5,000, a second offense is subject to a fine of $10,000, and third and subsequent offenses, $15,000. 
 "People engage in this type of fraud to save money though New Jersey's lower auto insurance rates, so the best way to eliminate this type of fraud is to remove the economic incentive by fining violators," Governor Florio said in signing the bill in Newark today.
Although New Jersey residents complain about high insurance rates, they are still substantially lower than those paid in high-claim areas like New York City and Philadelphia, where investigators say rate evasion is most common.
 
Contrast in Rates
 Rates in New Jersey, according to the Insurance Department, currently average about $1,000 a year, but insuring a car in New York City or Philadelphia can cost more than $3,000 a year because of the high accident and theft rate.
The most common method of evading the high rates charged in those urban areas is to register a car in New Jersey using an address of a vacation home on the Jersey Shore, or arranging with New Jersey relatives to use their addresses, particularly in rural or suburban areas where rates are lower.
Mr. Florio said such evasions cost New Jersey drivers about $100 a year in added premiums to make up for claims made against policies fraudulently written using New Jersey addresses.
The extent of the problem was suggested last May 20, when investigators from the New Jersey Insurance Fraud Division went into Philadelphia and several New York City boroughs to list and photograph vehicles bearing New Jersey plates between 6 and 9:30 in the morning. They recorded a total of 1,147 New Jersey plates, 663 in New York City and 484 in Philadelphia, many on expensive luxury cars. The disparity in insurance rates is biggest on more expensive cars because of the higher cost of repairs or replacement.
After investigators checked the vehicle registrations against other records -- local tax rolls, credit reports, post office records, school registrations, utility bills, telephone directory listings, employment records, insurance applications, voter registrations and lease company records -- to determine the actual residence of the owners, about 800 were found to actually live in New Jersey.
But without a specific statute specifically making such fraudulent registation a crime, rate evaders were only subject to civil penalties if they filed a claim against their insurance. The normal course of action when an insurer discovered fraudulent registration, usually after a claim was filed, was to rescind the policy and refund the premium.
Rate evaders who had not filed any claims could in theory be prosecuted criminally for theft by deception -- getting a lower rate by lying about the address -- but prosecution and proof were difficult, and in 1989, the most recent year for which statistics were available, only 23 people were indicted for theft by deception in such cases.
 
13,000 Cases Investigated
 But the Fraud Division actually received more than 30,000 complaints of rate evasion between 1988 and 1990, when investigators began to focus on the problem. In 1990, about 13,000 cases were investigated, and nearly 40 percent involved rate evaders who had filed claims.
Investigators said 95 percent of the cases involved out-of-state residents fraudulently claiming New Jersey addresses.
New Jersey insurance officials also said the new law would allow insurance companies and law-enforcement officials broader authority to physically inspect vehicles for which applicants have requested insurance.
In some cases, the insured person simply lies on the application, creating a vehicle that does not exist, gets a policy, then reports the nonexistent car stolen and collects on the policy. Insurance companies refer to this type of fraud as "the phantom vehicle scheme."

HEADLINE: The Art Market

BYLINE: By Carol Vogel

 BODY:

It's Better to Receive
Museums can't stop talking about what they got for Christmas. Despite cuts in public and private aid caused by the recession, museums -- both big and small -- are reporting a rush of year-end gifts of top-quality artworks. The reason: a Federal tax law that permits donors of valuable objects to deduct their full market value, determined by an outside appraiser, on income-tax returns. 
 Initially the law was a one-year "window" that went into effect last January and was to expire at the end of 1991. But Congress extended it for six months after a lobbying campaign led by the American Association of Museums. The provision began as an experiment after Congressional leaders realized that the 1986 Tax Reform Act, which eliminated such deductions, had resulted in a significant drop in donations to museums.
Late this month, the House Ways and Means Committee is scheduled to hold hearings on all temporary tax provisions, with the possibility that the law will become permanent. But museum officials still worry that some members of Congress, concerned with the loss of tax revenue, will voice strong opposition.
For now, however, museums across the country were being flooded with gifts until the final hours of 1991, even though the new deadline is June 30. "Donors and their accountants still think in terms of the year end," said Ashton Hawkins, executive vice president and counsel to the trustees of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. "And the amount of gifts we've received is very heartening."
Mr. Hawkins reports that 285 donors gave the Met about $40 million worth of art in 1991. This is a significant increase from 1990, before the tax incentive, when 156 donors gave the Met artworks valued at $9 million. "There's been a pent-up desire to give," Mr. Hawkins said. "Donors have been waiting for this opportunity. And we hope the response shows the legislators how important this tax incentive is."
Peter Marzio, director of the Museum of Fine Arts in Houston, agreed. "It's been incredible," he said, "not just in terms of numbers but also the quality. We've gotten a lot of big-ticket items." Among them are a 1951 Magritte painting, "The Kiss"; Maurice Vlaminck's "The Barge at Le Pecq," from 1909, and a Georgia O'Keeffe, "White Shell With Red Hills," from 1938.
In fact, quality seems to be the buzzword among museum directors. "We've really gotten some wonderful things we've wanted for our collections," said Richard E. Oldenburg, director of the Museum of Modern Art. "Donors have been from all over the country." Among the artists whose work the museum has received recently are Monet, Philip Guston, Jim Dine and Ross Bleckner.
The Walker Art Center in Minneapolis is also touting donations that include works by big-name artists from Mark Rothko to Andy Warhol. "It's more than Santa; it's the Government," said Kathy Halbreich, the museum's director. "We would like to look at this not as a loophole, but as a future incentive. If you believe museums are important places, then there's a serious social urgency here, a real concern that this law won't be extended again. And that message needs to get across."
 
Auction Sales Slump
 In contrast with museums, 1991 was the year the auction houses stopped believing in Santa Claus. Their sales figures for the year show a dramatic slump. The area hit hardest by the recession was paintings, especially the Impressionist, modern and contemporary categories. At Sotheby's, worldwide sales for 1991 totaled $1.1 billion, a decline of 54.9 percent from a year earlier, when the company reported a total of $2.4 billion and an even more significant drop from 1989, when sales totaled $2.9 billion. Christie's is reporting 1991 worldwide sales at $1.03 billion, a steady slide from $1.96 billion in 1990 and $2.14 billion in 1989. Both companies had a difficult autumn. Sotheby's autumn sales worldwide amounted to $512.9 million, down 24.6 percent from 1990. Fall totals for Christie's worldwide came to $468 million, a 20 percent decline from 1990.
The economic recession and the Persian Gulf war were two major reasons for the drop. Another was the large decline in both volume and prices of the houses' sales of Impressionist, modern and contemporary paintings, which have traditionally been their bread and butter. "Several factors have contributed to the downturn," said Michael L. Ainslie, president and chief executive of Sotheby's Holdings, the auction house's parent company. "One of the biggest was the absence of quality. The uncertainty in the market has lead to a constriction of supply. For the most part, sellers have either been under financial pressures or they have been heirs with estate property."
Indeed, voluntary sellers are generally holding onto their property until the market shows signs of recovery. As a result, the auction houses are finding themselves in a Catch-22 situation. Since people are reluctant to offer works for sale, both Sotheby's and Christie's are having trouble putting together strong auctions that will generate high prices. "Fortunately, the few good things that came to us this last year did well," Mr. Ainslie said. "The result is that we are now seeing more voluntary sellers than we did a year ago. People want to know where price levels are, and this season has shown us a lot."
Categories like decorative arts and Old Masters, which didn't become wildly inflated when Japanese buyers began dominating sales in 1989, were the strongest in 1991. Sotheby's, for example, reports that decorative arts made up about 55 percent of its overall sales totals this year, compared with 38 percent and 30 percent in 1990 and 1989, respectively.
"These figures weren't really a surprise," Mr. Ainslie said. "Paintings had gotten to such outrageous levels they had to drop. And one of the benefits about being a full-line auction house is that the smaller departments have been able to pull us through these difficult times."
Christopher Burge, president of Christie's in New York, said that in departments like silver, porcelain, and French and English furniture, prices have been higher than in the boom years of the late 1980's. "And jewelry held firm, too, which was surprising, since it is the luxury end of the market," he said. "It shows that even though painting prices have slipped back to 1987 levels, as we predicted they would, there is still money out there waiting to be spent."
Mr. Burge said he believes that the field of contemporary paintings also shows hopeful signs. "The current group of younger artists who weren't on the scene five years ago are now appearing at auction," he said. "And for the first time the field has become international, in terms of artists and buyers."
But perhaps the biggest surprise in the auction house's new figures is that Christie's now has a 48 percent market share of worldwide sales, its highest since the mid-1950's, against Sotheby's 52 percent. "The big jump occurred in the first half of the year," Mr. Burge said. "In New York we now have over 50 percent of the Impressionist and modern market. They have taken the lead in the contemporary field."
Mr. Ainslie said: "Being a market leader is important to us. The reason for this year's decline is that Christie's had great numbers in their Old Masters sales. They did $135 million of business worldwide, and we did only $65 million. It's one field where we have to get more aggressive."
Both companies report that as profits decline, they are freezing salaries for their senior management. But Christie's reports that there will be no staff cuts. "We want to be fully staffed when the recovery begins," Mr. Burge said.
Sotheby's, the larger of the two houses, is looking at things differently. "We're examining every job carefully," Mr. Ainslie said.
 
Freud's Antiquities
 Experts analyzing Sigmund Freud's personal collection of antiquities agree: the master of psychoanalysis had a less-than-perfect eye for art. "There's nothing here I'd buy," said Edward H. Merrin, a Manhattan antiquities dealer after viewing the exhibition "The Sigmund Freud Antiquities: Fragments From a 'Buried Past,' " on view through Feb. 18 at the New-York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West, at 77th Street, Manhattan.
Michael Ward, another Manhattan dealer, said he believed the collection was of little value in today's market. "It's a totally different type of collection than anyone would put together today," he said. "It's not about connoisseurship, but about acquiring for symbolic and religious reasons."
Of the small solid-cast Roman figurine of Athena from the first or second century A.D. that held a central position on Freud's desk, Mr. Ward said: "It's crude. Artistically it doesn't represent the best Roman piece of its time." But Dr. Harold Blum of Roslyn Estates, L.I., a psychoanalyst, psychologist and executive director of Freud's archives, said the figurine was one of Freud's favorite pieces. "It had many meanings for him: wisdom, fertility, the protector of civilization," Dr. Blum said.
Indeed, the rich symbolism in the collection is what intrigues dealers far more than the quality of the works. "I was totally overwhelmed because it makes you think about the relevance of antiquities," said Torkom Demirjian, owner of Ariadne, a Madison Avenue gallery. "Freud used collecting as a means of self-discovery."
Dr. Blum said he believed Freud's preoccupation with objects was symbolic of his belief that so much of mental life is buried in the unconscious. "These pieces represent many senses -- for example, the childhood of man and the infancy of civilization," he said. "Antiquities were his way of linking the past with the present."
Even the dealers couldn't put a price on that.

HEADLINE: TV Weekend;
A Time Capsule's Messages to Posterity

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN

 BODY:
"The Class of the 20th Century," the 12-part series that begins on Sunday at 8 P.M. on the Arts & Entertainment Network, is billed as "a kaleidoscopic view of the 20th century, as seen through the eyes of people who helped shape it." The agglomeration is to be stored in the Museum of Television and Radio in Manhattan for anyone extant in the year 3000 who might like to know what things were like back now.
The series turns out to be an anthology of anecdotes, mainly from American show-business figures and television personalities, along with a smattering of well-known journalists, politicians and random celebrities. It will be of particular interest to contemporaries who care about the ruminations of Hugh Downs, Howard Cosell and Hildegarde. 
 Sunday's opener, which zips through the years 1900 to 1929 at 21st-century speed, contains segments on cars, World War I, the 1920's and Charles A. Lindbergh. Richard Dreyfuss, the narrator, barely manages to keep up. The result is not exactly, or inexactly, history, but it is a spirited show that is bound to stir memories in viewers of a certain age.
To the accompaniment of well-edited, if sometimes familiar, newsreel clips, Hildegarde remembers patriotic neighbors in the Midwest throwing rocks at German-American families like her own in 1917. Julia Child remembers making wine in a cellar during Prohibition. The fashion designer Bill Blass remembers his father's suicide after the stock-market crash.
There's the young Cab Calloway hi-de-ho-ing at the Cotton Club in the 1920's and the present-day Cab Calloway reminiscing about speakeasies. There's Calvin Coolidge, and there are Dr. Benjamin Spock and Studs Terkel delivering old Coolidge jokes. Here's Dr. C. Everett Koop describing the welcome-home parade for Colonel Lindbergh -- and there's the parade.
What anybody in the year 3000 will make of such material is problematic, especially in light of Joseph Heller's prediction here that the English language will be stone dead by then, along with the rest of Western civilization.
Each hour ends with a personal message to discoverers of this time capsule from several of its contributors. Assuming that Mr. Heller is incorrect, 31st-century viewers will be able to understand that Hildegarde wishes them peace and Senator Strom Thurmond wishes them health through exercise and diet. A more original and highly characteristic farewell comes from Joseph Papp, the New York City theater impresario who died recently. He wishes everybody a millennium without theater critics.
The series continues on Thursday evenings, beginning next week with the 1930's (radio, the Depression, Franklin D. Roosevelt, Joe Louis, Shirley Temple, Hitler) and concluding 10 weeks later with the present (AIDS, the environment, homelessness). No happy ending.
 
'Talking With David Frost'
Channels 13 and 49
Tonight at 9
In his annual White House chat with George and Barbara Bush, David Frost touches on all the big issues, from the recession to the Middle East, in a deferentially inquiring way. He presses the President as far as a courteous guest can if he wants to be invited back. Although the answers are not startling, they offer the outlines of the Republican campaign in this election year.
Mr. Bush grants that he was overly optimistic about the economy until just the other day, but he points out that so were "a lot of people." Will there be a real recovery this year, Mr. Frost asks? "Yes, no question about it," the President says. " He is equally upbeat about his prospects in November: "I think I'm going to be re-elected." As he sees it, the world's glass is not half full; it is "bountifully full." He even expresses confidence that Saddam Hussein, the President of Iraq, will be overthrown, but he declines to give a date.
Now and then, the President lapses into severe Bushese. Explaining his opposition to some forms of affirmative action, he says, "It gets into, quotas go into numerical, set numbers for doctors or for, it could go into all kinds of things." Reiterating his objections to television coverage of the Clarence Thomas hearings and the William K. Smith trial, he speaks of "this indulgence in such specificity that turned people off." But what is bothering him, it appears, is that people did not in fact turn their sets off. He proposes that this should be done for them. "That's not censorship," he adds.
The setting, a prototypical campaign image, is armchair-cozy. Mrs. Bush comes on briefly to tell of her concern for people with AIDS and to speak of the pleasures of family life. She is as easy to take as ever, even if her reference to herself as "white-haired and a little overweight" is beginning to seem scripted.
 
'Critical Condition'
Channel 4
Tonight at 7:30
In recent months, Kings County Hospital Center in Brooklyn, New York City's biggest municipal hospital, has been suffering the sort of battering that requires emergency treatment, and that is what it receives tonight on Channel 4. "Critical Condition," a 30-minute report by David Diaz, does not make light of the headlined failures, like the apparently preventable death of Yankel Rosenbaum, the Hasidic scholar who was stabbed during the racial violence in Crown Heights last summer, but it does explain how such things can happen.
At the root of the difficulties, Mr. Diaz emphasizes, is the hospital's obligation to attend to everyone who walks into its emergency room. That means 250,000 people a year, mild complaints along with critical cases, social problems along with medical ones. Patients must wait hours for treatment; doctors and nurses are overworked; resources are strained.
Mr. Diaz finds glimmers of hope in new, more efficient facilities and the staff's dedication, but his message, which seems like a mild antacid after the inflammatory exposes of most local news programs, is that Kings County Hospital, like New York City itself, is staggering under the burdens of poverty, homelessness, drugs, crime and attendant miseries of urban life.
 
'The Bill of Rights:
A 200th Anniversary Celebration'
Court Television
Tomorrow and Sunday at 11 A.M.
Evidence that Court Television is not exclusively interested in high-profile scandals like William K. Smith's rape trial will be available tomorrow and again Sunday, when the cable network carries the surprise talk given by the writer Salman Rushdie last month at the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism's tribute to the First Amendment. Mr. Rushdie, who has been in hiding since February 1989, when the Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini of Iran offered a reward for his execution for perceived blasphemies in his novel "The Satanic Verses," has nothing bad to say about freedom of speech. Nor does Floyd Abrams, the First Amendment specialist, or former Supreme Court Justice William J. Brennan Jr., who opens the hour with a quiet chat.
