HEADLINE: Review/Art;
At the Met, a Large Sampling Of Small South Asian Works

BYLINE: BY HOLLAND COTTER

 BODY:
For admirers of South and Southeast Asian art, the Samuel Eilenberg Collection has long been one of New York's hidden treasures. Mr. Eilenberg, a professor (now emeritus) of mathematics at Columbia, has spent decades building up one of the world's premier collections of small-scale Asian sculptures, chiefly in bronze, but including objects in silver, stone, terra cotta and stucco as well.
The Met purchased several pieces over the years, and in 1987 Mr. Eilenberg gave the museum more than 400 as a gift. Almost half of these works, supplemented by a few loans from Mr. Eilenberg himself, have been brought together in an exhibition titled "The Lotus Transcendent." Much of the material will be included in the Met's new Florence and Herbert Irving Galleries of Indian and Southeast Asian sculpture, to be completed in 1994. But schedules, economics and politics being what they are -- the Irving galleries' opening has already been put off more than once -- it is best to see this remarkable gathering while you can. 
 It isn't a show to be caught on the run between Seurat and Stuart Davis. A few of the sculptures make sense from across a room; the Gandharan terra-cotta head of a young man wearing a rakish turban is one, that of a god whose open-mouthed rapture lends him a startling vulnerability is another. But most are the size of what would be mere details in another context, and need slow, close-up viewing to reveal their beauties. This is true, for example, of the thumb-high Shunga-period bronze goddess who wears an outfit as chic as a Chanel suit and has weapons bristling from her coiffure; the tiny Buddhist goddess of dawn, Marichi, depicted as a sow with seven tiny piglets; the lovely Nepalese Shiva and Uma, casually leaning into each other as if posed for a family snapshot; and the minute (two-and-three-eighths-inch-high) Javanese silver Tara, her head bent forward and down as if tensed in adamant concentration.
The collection is especially rich in Javanese bronzes. Martin Lerner, the Met's curator of Indian and Southeast Asian art, who organized the show, said it was considered the most important group outside of Indonesia and the Netherlands. And anyone who saw the recent "Art of Indonesia" show either in Washington or at the Met will not want to miss what really amounts to a fascinating extension of that exhibition. The particular combination of gravity and dynamism found in the large-scale sculpture of the earlier show is fully evident here, and the wall text that describes Javanese artists as "Asia's consummate miniaturist sculptors" does not exaggerate.
"The Lotus Transcendent" offers historical as well as visual revelations. Asian art is often thought to be exclusively religious in nature, a misperception stemming from the fact that most of the secular work has been lost. But in the Eilenberg Collection we find it: in the terra-cotta pull toy of figures riding an elephant; in the carved stone box lids that were probably cheap knockoffs of silver originals made for a court, and in the stone plates carved with high relief scenes from Greek myths.
There is also the notion, only recently under revision, that the art of South and Southeast Asia -- and of many other non-Western cultures, for that matter -- is "timeless," reaching a classical phase early and then sinking into a gradual, static decrepitude. The work in this show tells a very different story. In the Indonesian pieces alone, the variety from early to late and even within a single period is dizzying. And in the art produced in the area we call Pakistan today, the influences of Mediterranean classical, Central Asian, Iranian, and indigenous Indian ideas and styles head a far-reaching list.
This may not amount to exactly the same thing as the pluralism of our own time, but it certainly suggests that the idea of a global culture is not an invention of the 1980's.
"The Lotus Transcendent: Indian and Southeast Asian Art from the Samuel Eilenberg Collection" remains at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82d Street, through June 28.

GRAPHIC: Photo: A terra-cotta head of a young man from the Pakistan Gandhara region, circa 4th Century. (The Metropolitan Museum of Art)

HEADLINE: DINKINS PROPOSES EFFORTS TO ROUSE NEW YORK ECONOMY

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS

 BODY:
In a broad, hopeful speech intended to build new confidence in his ability to lead New York City through hard economic times, Mayor David N. Dinkins announced measures yesterday to stimulate the city's sagging economy and to ease the burdens of residents and businesses hit hard by the recession.
Mr. Dinkins's second State of the City address, at the midpoint of his term, was studded with a mixture of ambitious ideas and simple gestures, some of which have been previously proposed, and he did not say how he would pay for his plans. The proposals include speeding payments to companies that do business with the city, pushing capital rebuilding projects ahead of schedule, freezing property-tax increases and reducing licensing rules and fees to aid small businesses. 
 While those steps seemed aimed at appeasing middle-class voters, Mr. Dinkins also addressed the poor, offering several plans to help them as well. [News analysis and excerpts, page B2.]
 
'Role of Leadership'
 The Mayor said he planned to open neighborhood health centers in low-income areas to reduce overcrowding in emergency rooms, double the number of schools that serve as community centers, put more housing into the hands of community and not-for-profit groups and create a new class of taxi medallions to expand service to residents outside central Manhattan.
Addressing the City Council chamber, which was packed with invited guests and city officials, Mr. Dinkins maintained that despite the persistent economic decline, New York City's "role of leadership has not changed -- and will not change." He cited recent investments of hundreds of millions of dollars by major corporations and foreign countries in the city as examples.
 
No Financial Details
 During his 45-minute speech, Mr. Dinkins spoke passionately of "hearing the voices of our people, especially those whose pain is too great and whose voices are too small," and he pledged not to abandon them.
"Bond ratings are important, but we are judged against a higher standard," Mr. Dinkins said.
But the Mayor offered no financial details about how and when the measures would be put into effect, especially when the city and state are once again facing mounting budget deficits that will force further budget cuts and even tougher choices. Instead, Mr. Dinkins said such details would be forthcoming when he introduces his preliminary budget for the coming year later this month.
Still, some of the Mayor's proposals could prove difficult to carry out and could take years to come to fruition. For example, the Mayor has proposed turning city vaccination and testing clinics into neighborhood health centers that provide a full range of services to reduce overcrowding in hospitals. The centers would also provide area residents with a family doctor who focuses on preventive medicine.
But the plan could fail to deliver services if some patients unaccustomed to visiting a doctor except in emergencies fail to go to clinics. In addition, the city must find money to upgrade the clinics into full service centers.
Some city and political officials sharply criticized the Mayor's speech, saying that it lacked substance and failed to address some of the city's most serious ills.
 
'Band-Aid Approach'
 The City Council President, Andrew J. Stein, who has indicated that he will run for mayor in the next election, called Mr. Dinkins's proposals "vague promises and cliches" that "will do little to alleviate New Yorkers' pain and anxiety about the future."
Mr. Stein said the Mayor's promise to freeze property taxes for two years is "a meaningless sop" because steep property tax increases in the last two years have already driven thousands of property owners into default and cost the city many jobs.
Citing the absence of any reference to support for public schools in the Mayor's address, Sandra Feldman, president of the United Federation of Teachers, said in a statement, "The Mayor's Band-Aid approach to curing the city's ills offers no hope to the one million school children suffering for an education that could prevent those ills in the first place."
While the Mayor is not legally required to give a State of the City address, most mayors have chosen to give the speech to announce major policy shifts or to gain support for programs and initiatives from City Council members and other local politicians. Mr. Dinkins's speech was crafted by his top staff advisers, including Deputy Mayors Norman Steisel, Bill Lynch and Sally Hernandez-Pinero.
Some politicians praised the Mayor's speech, calling it "right on the mark." Peter F. Vallone, the Council Speaker who has often criticized Mr. Dinkins's programs, said that the speech was "a shift in the right direction" and that "it's very important for the Council for the Mayor to succeed."
Ruth W. Messinger, the Manhattan Borough President, said, "I thought it was extremely well focused and addresses those pressing problems in our city that have gone overlooked for a long time." Ms. Messinger said the Mayor's call for expanded health care and cuts for small businesses was "extraordinary."
 
Gaps and Crimes
 In his speech, Mr. Dinkins lambasted the Federal Government for withdrawing funds to cities and states. "A turnaround in the national economy will happen only when Washington commits itself to better lives for people -- not to better bombs for our armies and tax breaks for the privileged," the Mayor said.
Despite dwindling Federal support, Mr. Dinkins said, his administration has managed to close a combined 1990 and 1991 budget deficit of $1.3 billion and to decrease reported crime by 6 percent in the last year, compared with a 2 percent increase in crime nationwide.
Reviving an idea that has circulated before, Mr. Dinkins said that he plans to restructure the taxi industry, by licensing livery vehicles to pick up people hailing them on the street. Only yellow, medallion cabs are now allowed to pick up people who hail them on the street. Under the Mayor's plan, livery-cab owners could buy a medallion that would allow them to pick up people who hail them, except south of 96th Street in Manhattan.
Yellow-taxi drivers and medallion owners expressed strong opposition yesterday to the Mayor's plan. "Mayor Dinkins, by proposing this new medallion system, you are taking food out of the mouths of our drivers," said Betty Lawrence, executive director of the Metropolitan Taxicab Board of Trade, which represents the city's major yellow cab fleet owners.
Ms. Lawrence said that despite recent stepped-up enforcement, the city's Taxi and Limousine Commission has been unsuccessful in preventing both gypsy and black cars from picking up people who hail them in central Manhattan. "We simply would not be able to compete with the flood of new taxis that would enter the market at substantially lower rates than yellow cab drivers have had to pay," Ms. Lawrence said.
Mr. Dinkins said he had directed the city's Office of Construction to develop a "counter cyclical" spending initiative that would inject capital construction money into the struggling local economy. In 1992, Mr. Dinkins said, the city will accelerate $125 million in capital improvements and, in the 1993 and 1994 fiscal years, more than $100 million in design work.
In the 1991 fiscal year, the city's Department of Environmental Protection failed to award more than $600 million in contracts, or almost half its capital budget for sewers and water main replacement, at an estimated cost of 8,000 jobs.

HEADLINE: FEW WOMEN FOUND IN TOP PUBLIC JOBS

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 2

 BODY:
Women in public service face a "glass ceiling" that often blocks them from advancing to top jobs in state and local governments, according to a survey made public today.
Women held only 31.3 percent of high-level state and local government jobs nationwide in 1990, while women in lower-level jobs accounted for 43.5 percent of the work force, the survey said. 
 The study was conducted by the Center for Women in Government, which is part of the Rockefeller College of Public Affairs and Policy and was based on data from the United States Equal Employment Opportunity Commission.
"There are a lot of women in government but they're not doing too well at the top," Sharon Harlan, director of research for the center, said. "There is a glass ceiling."
 
How Minority Women Fared
 Minority women did even worse proportionally, the study found, with black women making up 5.1 percent of the top managers, compared to 9.8 of other jobholders. The proportion of other minority women in management-level jobs is also low, the survey said.
"There are a lot of minority women in government, but they're at the bottom level," Ms. Harlan said.
The term "glass ceiling" was coined to describe institutional biases that prevent women from getting senior managerial positions in private industry. The Women in Public Service survey asserted that women working in local, county and state governments also faced barriers in getting high-level jobs like department heads, division chiefs, deputies and examiners.
Ms. Harlan said that while there had been several studies on the status of women in private industry, it was difficult to make comparisons with women in government because each study measured a different range of top jobs. For example, a report by the Department of Labor in Washington on the glass ceiling at the largest American corporations found that women made up about 6 percent of the top executives, but Ms. Harlan said that study looked at a significantly narrower band of top jobs than were included in the study on women in government.
But there are some indications that women fare better in government jobs than in private industry.
"If you look at cabinet-level state officials, appointed by governors, 19.8 percent are women," she said. "That's probably the category that would be most comparable to the top executives in the Labor Department study, and 19.8 percent is certainly higher than 6 percent."
The survey did not try to explain the differences, but Ms. Harlan said men were often favored for promotions and appointments simply because of institutional biases.
The survey reported that state governments had a poorer track record than local governments in placing a proportionate share of women in top jobs, although they tended to employ more women in general.
 
State Percentages Compared
 The survey said the national low was in Hawaii's state and local governments, where only 13.9 percent of their high-level jobs were held by women. Louisiana had the highest percentage, 38.5.
New York State's governments placed above the national average with a 35.6 percent managerial placement rate for women. Connecticut, with 29.6 percent, and New Jersey, with 27.3 percent, were below the average.
The survey does say, however, that women fared better when it took new hires into consideration. Women accounted for 40 percent of all top-level positions filled in 1990, the survey said.
"Yes, it's getting better, but that's not the main conclusion," Ms. Harlan said. "There still are a lot of structural barriers in place for women."
She added: 'At the rate it's changing, it's going to be a very long time before women reach equity. And in this economic climate, there's some concern that women will not be able to hold on to the gains they've made. We're getting ready to look at whether women are being laid off disproportionately."

HEADLINE: Australia's Focus, Like Bush's, Is Tokyo

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES

DATELINE: MELBOURNE, Australia, Friday, Jan. 3

 BODY:
President Bush wound up a three-day visit to Australia today, having proved his will to keep the United States in a strong position in Asia, but failing to dispel a gnawing fear that he lacks the means to do so.
Just as in Washington, Australian officials said today, the worries here center on Japan, whose growing influence the United States seems hard pressed to balance, much less channel to its own benefit. 
 Mr. Bush has elevated his unhappiness with Japanese trade barriers into a major election-year issue, making Japan both the focus and climax of the four-nation Pacific tour. In that respect, Australia has not given that tour an auspicious start.
 
'Wired Together'
 "We're not thinking about anything sudden," one Australian official involved in the talks with Mr. Bush said about fears of an American retreat from the area. "We're talking about a grim slide. If the U.S. decides in the end to concentrate on its sphere of influence and leave the area to Japan, Australia is going to be much the poorer.
"It's a lot better for us if we can keep you two wired together some way."
The worry that Washington and Tokyo will not find common ground and that Tokyo eventually will seek to push the United States out of a position of influence, is a frequent topic of Australia and its allies, the official said.
The official, who refused to be named, called the visit "very worthwhile in ventilating these things," and said both sides agreed on the dangers of an uncontrolled drift in relations between Tokyo and Washington.
 
Uncertain Strategy
 But he said that Prime Minister Paul Keating and others remain uncertain whether the Bush Administration has a strategy for coping with Japan's influence, or whether Washington can summon the economic clout to carry out any strategy it might devise.
More often, he said, the two economic powers vent their frustrations in specific disputes over issues like auto parts purchases, rather than examining cultural and economic differences.
Japan has shrewdly exploited a trading system that the United States singlehandedly built and has protected, at great expense, with its military might, the official said.
But rather than blame Japan, "Australia feels there has got to be an effort within the U.S. to revitalize the innards of American industry, to be more competitive," he said.
The White House said this week that it is aware of those concerns. It has lately depicted Mr. Bush's 12-day Asia journey as visible proof that its military and financial stake in the region is not simply unshaken, but that it is vital to the United States's economic future.
Mr. Bush, whose argument that exports create jobs is the foundation of his efforts to fight the recession, has remarked this week that American trade across the Pacific now far exceeds that with Europe, and is growing exponentially.
On the military front, the President is expected this weekend to disclose a new agreement in Singapore. The Pentagon has stationed jet fighters there under a so-called access agreement, in which American forces are placed on locally operated bases instead of on vast and expensive Pentagon-controlled compounds like the naval base at Subic Bay in the Philippines.
At Manila's insistence, the Navy's Seventh Fleet is pulling out of Subic Bay, and Singapore is said to be a top choice for some of its remnants.
Administration officials call these developments part of a shifting strategy for America's Pacific interests, in which Washington will serve less as sole defender of the region and more as a rallying force for regional interests.
That role worked in Iraq, where the Administration marshaled a global military effort to end the occupation of Kuwait, Administration officials said. They say they see a similar role in helping Pacific nations to share the burden of their own defense, and to cooperate in lowering trade barriers.
Reassuring as the Australians find that, both they and Mr. Bush acknowledged that, after the Cold War, economic power is the real measure of national strength.
"Bilateral defense arrangements with the U.S. and Japan and ourselves are important," the Australian official said. "But we think the current challenge is to ensure that the U.S. is engaged economically."
The President found the stop in Australia "constructive," the White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, said.
After visiting Canberra, Mr. Bush stopped briefly in Melbourne, the nation's southernmost big city, to speak to local business leaders.
 Mr. Bush then left for Singapore. He will travel next to Seoul before moving on to Japan on Jan. 7.

HEADLINE: Bush Signals He's Prepared For Tough Campaign in '92

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2

 BODY:
Acknowledging that it will be "very difficult" to get re-elected without an economic recovery, President Bush says he is girding for a "dog-eat-dog fight" in the campaign and will do whatever it takes to win.
In an interview with David Frost that is to be broadcast Friday night by the Public Broadcasting Service (9 o'clock Eastern standard time, and on Channels 13 and 49 in the New York area), Mr. Bush tried to project confidence about the economy, citing predictions that it would recover by July. 
 In an interview with Mr. Frost at this time last year, the President predicted that "the recession will be mild and that the whole country will come out of it in not too many months from now" -- a forecast he and his advisers have come to regret.
In the new interview Mr. Bush acknowledged that he would not be able to balance the Federal budget during his Presidency, even if he were re-elected, and that the Government would go on spending more than it earned for the rest of this century.
 
A Message of Concern
 The President raised the possibility of further reducing the Pentagon budget. The money could be used either for additional domestic spending, which would require renegotiating the 1990 budget agreement, or to reduce the Federal deficit.
Mr. Bush repeatedly said that he believed voters knew he was trying to turn around the economy and was personally concerned about struggling Americans, a message the White House has been trying hard to convey because of Democratic criticism.
In an apparent reference to his foreign policy record, Mr. Bush said, "I think also you got a whole wealth of other performance out there that the American people are grateful for."
But the President signaled that he was prepared to wage the kind of tough campaign that he ran in 1988 against his Republican primary opponents and then against Michael S. Dukakis, the Democratic nominee. "I'm certainly going into this as a dog-eat-dog fight," he said, "and I will do what I have to do to be re-elected."
 
The Hardest Decision
 To achieve that, Mr. Bush's campaign team has been trying to devise new ways to present him to voters as a reliable Commander in Chief, an accomplished diplomat, a conservative and, most important, as a President who is concerned about the economic troubles of ordinary Americans.
That sense permeated virtually all of Mr. Bush's remarks in the interview, including when he was asked about the tensest moment of the year.
Until recently, the President had always cited his decision to send American troops to war in the Persian Gulf.
But Mr. Bush said: "It began with that and it ended with the concern for Americans that are hurting because of this sluggish economy. I mean, when families are having trouble making ends meet or are thinking even if they have a job, 'I might not have one tomorrow.' Fear. You worry about that. I worry a lot about it.
"But I also worried a lot about sending some mother's son into battle. So as the year started with the agony of that and ended with the increased feeling on the other point, on the economic point."
The interview was recorded on Dec. 23, before Mr. Bush left for the Far East. In the interview the President sought to position himself as a conservative. He faces challenges from the right by Patrick J. Buchanan, the columnist and former Nixon and Reagan White House aide, and David Duke, the former Ku Klux Klan leader and neo-Nazi who ran unsuccessfully for governor of Louisiana last year.
"I'm basically a conservative," the President said, "and I've always been that way."
 
No Brickbats for Buchanan
 He did not hesitate to excoriate Mr. Duke, who has become an acceptable target for Republicans, calling him a racist and a bigot and predicting that if he ran as an independent he would get less than 10 percent of the vote.
But he held his fire against Mr. Buchanan, who is regarded by many Republican strategists as more mainstream, and therefore more threatening. Asked if he agreed with an article by William F. Buckley Jr. that accused Mr. Buchanan of making anti-Semitic remarks, the President said, "I'd let others make that determination."
Asked if he could be re-elected if there were no economic recovery, Mr. Bush said, "Sure, but it makes it very difficult."
He said twice that he was confident that he would win, but added: "I predicate that, of course, on that I think the economy is going to be doing much better. I think confidence will be coming back. I think people know that we are trying hard. I don't think they did at first."
 
Growth and Spending Caps
 Despite Mr. Bush's confidence, the interview suggested that he was finding it difficult to come up with proposals for economic growth, on which his advisers are now working, and stay within the 1990 budget agreement.
Mr. Bush said he expected additional cuts in military spending, but did not say if he would use that money to increase domestic programs. "Could be," he said. "Or might do something radical like reduce the deficit, which seems to be -- some people have a great interest in, including me."
The Washington Post said tonight that Richard G. Darman, the budget director, and Defense Secretary Dick Cheney had agreed on new cuts in Pentagon spending but that final decisions have not been made.

HEADLINE: West Acts to Defer Issue of New U.N. Council Seats

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Jan. 2

 BODY:
By allowing Russia to take over the Soviet Union's permanent Security Council seat last week, the three Western powers believe that they have postponed action for several years on demands by Germany, Japan and several large third world countries for permanent membership on the Council.
Diplomats now say a consensus is forming that the United Nations should not give serious consideration to reviewing the privileged position of the five World War II victors, who hold permanent Security Council seats and a veto over its decisions, before the middle of this decade. 
 Britain, which was given the permanent seat in 1945 along with the United States, France, China and the Soviet Union, now wants the Security Council to confirm Russia's enhanced position by holding its first-ever summit meeting this month at the level of heads of state or government.
Britain has told other permanent members that such a Council summit, coming just as Boutros Ghali takes up his duties as the new Secretary General, would underscore Russia's commitment to working through the United Nations for peace, nuclear non-proliferation and disarmament, officials say.
The Bush Administration appears to be supporting the call for a summit meeting, which would be presided over by Prime Minister John Major since Britain holds the Council's rotating presidency in January, American officials said today. But the attitude of France and China is unclear.
 
Opportunity for Review
 The collapse of the Soviet Union was a logical moment to reopen the United Nations founding charter and review the Security Council's composition, many nations contend.
But as the Soviet Union disintegrated the United States, with the support of Britain, France and China, moved swiftly, without public debate or any attempt to reopen the Charter, to insure that the former Soviet seat went to Russia as the largest and strongest of the former union's republics. The United States and its allies were able to get their way because their vetoes control all decisions of the Security Council, which must approve its own membership as well as any changes in the United Nations Charter.
"Frankly, we were lucky the General Assembly wasn't in session," a diplomat said. "Otherwise we might have had howls of fury to contend with."
The move, many diplomats say, showed that the five permanent members were determined to resist demands for any far-reaching changes in membership of the Council now that it is starting to act like the guardian of world order it is supposed to be.
 
Pressure for Change Grows
 The pressure for such changes is growing steadily, with many countries arguing that the privileges still held by the five World War II victors seem anachronistic 50 years later.
When this year's General Assembly debated the Council's role for the first time in a decade, industrial and developing countries were almost unanimous in saying the Council should be refashioned to represent the realities of today's world, not the world of 1945.
The countries defeated in the war are also pressing for the Charter to be changed to eliminate discriminatory clauses left over from the war, and this would unleash demands for reforms of the Security Council, too.
Germany and Japan both say they deserve a permanent Council seat as economic superpowers that are paying a rising share of United Nations bills.
Since most strife occurs in the developing world, leading third world nations argue that the Council would be a more effective peacemaker if they had permanent representation on it.
 
Confident of Holding Line
 Nevertheless, the present permanent members appear confident that they can hold the line against change until the middle of the decade, largely because Germany and Japan, the two strongest candidates for new seats, have softened their demands recently.
Japan's appetite for a permanent seat was appeased somewhat by its election to the Council this year for a two-year term as a rotating member.
Bonn softened its campaign for a permanent seat when the two Germanys reunited because it feared that such a demand, coming immediately after reunification, might alarm its neighbors.
One much-discussed change might merge the British and French permanent seats into a single seat for the 12 European Community members, taking care of Germany's aspirations.
Permanent seats without a veto might then go to Japan and such big developing countries as India, Egypt, Nigeria and Brazil.

HEADLINE: Little on Its Agenda, Congress Plays Wait-and-See as New Session Starts

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2

 BODY:
Congress will return to the capital to meet for a few minutes Friday, fulfilling a constitutional command that it begin its session on Jan. 3, but with little on the immediate agenda besides leadership meetings and a few news conferences.
In contrast to the scene a year ago, when most lawmakers were here early expecting to confront the grave issue of war in the Persian Gulf, few are in town now, and the choices they face seem harder to grasp. 
 The Democrats, who control the schedule, see the struggling economy and the unraveling health care system as issues on which they have a natural advantage over the Republicans and President Bush, in contrast to an issue of war last year that favored Presidential authority. But there is no consensus in the Democratic Party on how to deal with the recession as the election year begins, and even less agreement on what to do about health care.
So when the lawmakers snarled out of town six weeks ago, they planned to wait until Mr. Bush's State of the Union Message on Jan. 28 before setting a course of their own on those issues.
Nothing has happened since to change that intention, and the Democratic leadership meetings on Friday are expected to confirm that approach. But Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House majority leader, said today that Democrats would be ready to negotiate with the President, "if he wants to negotiate," when he returned from Asia on Jan. 10.
 
Real Business Later
 After the sessions Friday, the Senate will next meet Jan. 21 and the House the day after that. So late January will be the first real occasion for the leaders to get much of a sense of what is on the minds of "the followership," as one aide put it today.
The views of the House and Senate rank and file tend to matter more in an election year, and in the House in particular this will be a difficult one, for almost everyone who runs for re-election will have a district that is either slightly or drastically changed from the old one because of redistricting.
Traditional political issues like the economy are not the only problems on their minds, for this election is sure to be fueled also by attacks on Congress's own behavior, and a cost-of-living pay increase will take effect in January unless the rank and file stops it out of fear of the electorate and the movement that would limit the terms of members.
That sense of what the members want may be critical on the issue of tax cuts and economic stimulus, for the consistent message from professional economists at hearings last month was not to do anything drastic: It could be too little and too late to ease this recession and might harm the economy in the long run.
At the same time, the political message the lawmakers conveyed right back was that they were feeling the heat from their constituents and needed to do something. So some hearings on taxes and health care may follow Mr. Bush's address immediately, and the results of his visit to Japan will be examined to see whether there seems to be political mileage in some kind of trade legislation.
In the depth of a recession, principled arguments about free trade tend to carry less weight than the politics of lost jobs. A variety of measures have been introduced in each House, ranging from blunt anti-Japanese proposals to measure that would require the Administration to designate publicly the worst trade barriers the nation faces, then to focus its efforts on removing them.
 
Budget Accord Issue
 There may also be an early effort to change the budget agreement reached in 1990 in order that further reductions in military spending could be used to pay for domestic programs. The agreement prohibits such transfers until next year, and many lawmakers argue that military needs have plainly dropped with the dissolution of the Soviet Union so that the ban on such transfers now protects an artificially high level of Pentagon spending.
On all these issues, Mr. Gephardt said in an interview, "We want to respond as quickly as humanly possible." But then both Houses will take the second week of February off to go home for what they call a "district work period," and serious lawmaking on the economy, health care or trade will not get under way until they return.
The Senate will commence its legislative year, appropriately enough, with a vote on limiting debate on a motion to consider the Democratic version of an elementary education proposal. The Democratic bill would encourage students to choose among various public schools. Republicans prevented its consideration last fall because the Administration considers it too costly and because it does not allow public money to go with students who want to transfer to private or parochial schools.
After that issue is disposed of, the Senate plans to deal with legislation that would allow some cities to regulate prices for "basic" cable television service.
The House has no particular bills on its schedule for either this month or next. Its first sharply debated action may come in March on another move to provide more funds for the Resolution Trust Company, which is expected to run out of the $25 billion Congress provided in November for the savings and loan bailout. .
 
Important Conferences
 Some of the more important early legislative action may come in House-Senate conferences, especially in an effort to reconcile two different campaign finance measures. Some leaders, including House Speaker Thomas S. Foley of Washington, regard this legislation as a way to reclaim Congress's good name and head off the effort to amend the Constitution to limit how many years lawmakers may serve.
But the heaviest attention is sure to go to legislation that seeks to spur economic growth through changes in the tax laws. Republicans are seeking cuts in capital gains taxes, and Democrats want to reduce taxes on the middle class and offset them by raising taxes on people with the highest incomes.
Democratic leaders from both Houses and the chairmen of the committees that handle that legislation will meet Friday. Mr. Gephardt and Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the House Republican whip, have planned speeches dealing with domestic issues.

LENGTH: 549 words

HEADLINE: Who Won in Salvador? Everyone

 BODY:
After 11 years, El Salvador's Government and guerrilla armies have at last agreed to end a war neither can win in exchange for a peace from which both can gain.
The Government won a chance to turn its energies from killing to development, along with good prospects for foreign aid in reconstruction. The guerrillas won an official commitment to economic, social and political reforms, along with an opportunity for their fighters to return, safely, to normal pursuits. 
 El Salvador's people are also big winners; they will no longer have to endure a conflict that has killed 75,000 people and uprooted a million.
The peace agreement was brokered early Wednesday by the United Nations' departing Secretary General, Javier Perez de Cuellar, with help from Mexico and the United States. It was a signal accomplishment for U.N. mediation.
The Bush Administration, for its part, can claim vindication for its abandonment of ideological Reagan Administration crusades in Central America, which did little to encourage compromise.
The good will of outsiders would not have meant much without correspondingly constructive changes from Salvador's main combatants. Today's world is full of conflicts, from Afghanistan to Yugoslavia, that resist international efforts at settlement. Salvador's war was once in that category too. But changes since 1989 brought a breakthrough.
On the rebel side, the election defeat of the leftist Sandinista regime in neighboring Nicaragua surely played a sobering role. The military impact was slight; Sandinista leaders still run Nicaragua's armed forces. But even Marxist guerrilla leaders, if they were realistic, now had to acknowledge that a groundswell of Salvadoran popular support for their cause was becoming increasingly unlikely. Instead, Salvadoran elections in March 1989 brought the far right to power.
But President Alfredo Cristiani's rightist Government proved itself at least as realistic as guerrilla leaders. President Cristiani was confident he could prevent a rebel victory. But he had little hope of fighting the war to a military finish.
And the longer he persisted in fighting, the weaker his own power would become relative to that of military commanders. There was also an increasing risk that some military atrocity would provoke a cutoff of all aid from the U.S.
The Bush Administration used its diplomacy to press the Government toward peace. But without threats by Congressional Democrats to withhold aid on human rights grounds, Washington's leverage would have been far less credible.
Under the terms of Wednesday's agreement, the rebels promise to disband their military apparatus completely by October, with former guerrillas eligible to serve in a new National Police. Government armed forces will be cut in half from their present level of 53,000, and corrupt or abusive officers will be purged. Land reform will be accelerated, peasants in rebel areas provided with land and new social programs begun. Any details still unresolved as of next Friday will go to the new U.N. Secretary General, Boutros Ghali, for resolution.
The Salvador accord, like those for Namibia and Cambodia, shows the U.N.'s growing capacity to broker just settlements once combatants muster the wisdom and patriotism to prefer peace.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Japan, Jobs and Baloney

BYLINE: By LESLIE H. GELB; A. M. Rosenthal is traveling.

 BODY:
President Bush says his trip to Japan next week is about "jobs, jobs, jobs."
But even to a tin ear that sounds like politics, politics, politics. 
 Which means that Mr. Bush's stay in Japan, with 21 top U.S. corporate executives in tow, could amount to a lot of baloney, baloney, baloney.
Which would be too bad, because Japanese leaders are eager to help Mr. Bush for many reasons, not the least being their contempt for and fear of Japan-bashing Democrats. Which means the trip could produce gains for American trade and a triumph for the President personally if he would only cool his political posturing and act Presidential.
That recipe doesn't require babying Japan. More than most countries, Japan needs a good dose of pressure to open up its economy. But also more than in virtually any nation, Japanese will be responsive to U.S. pressure as long as Americans don't drive them into a corner. That point is getting lost in the current rhetoric, and it argues for a two-track U.S. trade policy where Washington squeezes without bashing and takes responsibility for its own economic mess.
Japan's economic stake in the U.S. is enormous. No matter that Japan's trade with Asia exceeded trade with America last year for the first time since 1945. The U.S. will remain Tokyo's largest single business partner, and the last thing Tokyo wants is a trade war with its best customer.
Nor do Tokyo's power brokers want to provoke Washington into withdrawing its still-large military presence from Japan. Such a departure would lead inevitably to a new and more powerful role for Japan's military. That prospect terrifies the Japanese almost as much as it does their Asian neighbors.
The neighbors would have a nervous breakdown if the Japanese military were cut loose from its American moorings, and Japanese leaders know that well. Typical is what Yukio Sato, the Foreign Ministry's top man on U.S. policy, told The Wall Street Journal the other day: "Some Japanese say, 'If U.S.-Japan relations go sour, we can always go back to Asia.' But there are no Asian countries that would welcome a Japan that left the U.S.-Japan alliance."
Beyond these crucial general concerns for good relations with the U.S., Japanese leaders have strong motives for strengthening George Bush's hand in particular. They can't stand the Democrats.
Congressional Democrats are earning this dislike by pushing the worst sort of protectionist legislation. This year's entry is a bill that would virtually cut off Japanese car imports and could even curtail sales of Japanese autos made in the U.S. if Japan's $42 billion trade surplus with America is not almost wiped out by 1997. Most of the Democratic Presidential candidates reinforce this message by hammering away at the loss of American jobs to Japanese imports.
It was this jobs drumbeat that frightened Mr. Bush's political advisers. And it caused them to charge down the wrong path of aping protectionist Democrats.
Japanese power brokers also recognized the drumbeat and moved quickly to pre-empt an embarrassing confrontation during the Bush visit. They lowered interest rates to stimulate their economy with the hopes of spurring imports, and they will sharply step up purchases of American auto parts. They will make additional concessions if the Bush entourage does not publicly cross the line between squeezing and bashing.
Japan needs America and will be responsive to American needs. Far more so -- and this is key -- if Mr. Bush shows he understands that opening up Japanese markets solves only part of the problem, and that the larger challenge is to insure higher quality American products once the barriers come down.
No amount of Japan-bashing will magically make U.S. cars better than Japan's. Americans understand that, which is why they buy so many Japanese autos even at higher prices. And autos alone account for three-quarters of the trade deficit with Japan.
George Bush is always at his best when he shows he knows these things, and when he acts like a President and not a pol. If he conveys such statesmanship next week, he will demonstrate that good trade policy is good jobs policy is good politics, and help save his own job.

HEADLINE: DEMOCRATS AGREE TO SEEK END OF BAN ON BUDGET SHIFTS

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3

 BODY:
Democratic Congressional leaders agreed today to move soon to break down the barriers in the 1990 budget law between military and domestic spending so savings from Pentagon cutbacks could pay for other programs, House Speaker Thomas S. Foley said.
Mr. Foley, a Washington Democrat, and George J. Mitchell of Maine, the Senate Democratic leader, both praised President Bush for indicating during a television interview tonight with David Frost a willingness to consider removing those barriers. "We commend the President for reviewing and reversing his position in the light of changing circumstance," Mr. Mitchell said. 
 Administration officials said today that while Mr. Bush had not decided among the various budget options he was considering while on his Asian trip, there was a "strong inclination" to call for a tax cut for the middle class. The most obvious way to pay for it, they said, was through cuts in the Defense Department's budget and removing the ban on shifting funds between the military and domestic budgets.
 
Talk of Early Action
 This tentative Administration approach was supported by Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the House Republican whip. He told a news conference, "I'd like to see virtually all the money available from any defense cuts go directly into a middle-class tax or some kind of pro-housing tax cut to stimulate the buying of new homes and that sort of thing."
Mr. Foley said there could be "early" action on such a change in the budget rules, which probably means late February. But he insisted that any amendment should preserve the larger principle of requiring that any new spending be offset by taxes or budget cuts, thus limiting growth in the budget deficit. "The pay-as-you-go principle should be maintained," he told reporters.
 That view was in sharp contrast to a proposal by two prominent Democratic Senators who urged a $55 billion increase in the deficit to stimulate the economy and fight the recession.
The Senators, Jim Sasser of Tennessee, chairman of the Senate Budget Committee, and Paul S. Sarbanes of Maryland, chairman of the Joint Economic Committee, said a deficit increase of that size was necessary to counter the drag on the economy caused by recent increases in local, state and Federal taxes and cuts in spending by government at all levels.
Mr. Foley identified changes in the budget act as one top issue discussed at a long meeting of the joint Democratic leadership. In addition to Mr. Mitchell and Mr. Foley, the meeting was attended by Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House majority leader, and the chairmen of the two committees in charge of tax legislation, Dan Rostenkowski of Illinois, who heads the House Ways and Means Committee, and Lloyd Bentsen of Texas, who heads the Senate Finance Committee.
Their meeting was devoted to making sure that they stayed in touch and did not surprise each other as they laid out Democratic views and alternatives to Bush Administration positions. Mr. Mitchell will speak at the National Press Club on Jan. 16 and Mr. Foley will speak there on Jan. 23 and give the official Democratic response to the President's State of the Union Message soon after it is delivered on Jan. 28.
Aside from the issue of changing the budget rules, the other main points they agreed to emphasize in any Democratic package were the need for a tax cut for the middle class and the importance of providing some kind of incentive for investment.
Mr. Rostenkowski and Mr. Bentsen have already introduced legislation for a tax cut for the middle class. Their approach differs from that of Republicans in that they would pay for the cuts by increasing taxes on people with high incomes. The Republicans would prefer to offset tax reductions for the middle class with money saved by Pentagon cuts, savings that the Democrats want to apply to domestic programs.
Most of the tax cuts that have been proposed so far have been fairly modest, leading critics to say that they would do little to stimulate the economy. Cuts in military spending slow down the economy in some areas, and it is not clear that additional cash in taxpayers' hands would provide enough stimulus to overcome that effect. Many critics have scorned the tax proposals now under discussion as little more than an attempt to buy votes in an election year.
Calling for some sort of investment incentive is a relatively new element in Democratic policy, since those present have repeatedly attacked what the Republicans argue is the best incentive for investment: a tax cut for capital gains. Democrats have denounced the idea as ineffective and a reward for the wealthy.
 
Shape of Republican Plan
 It is not clear just what is likely to emerge as the Administration's proposal. Administration officials said today that while Mr. Bush had said in the interview that reducing the deficit would be a worthy use of any savings from the military budget, his political advisers were pushing strongly for a tax cut for the middle class.
Nor was the Democratic approach today precise or decisive. The Democrats scheduled no news conference to proclaim their agreements, and Mr. Foley told reporters in a Capitol corridor that he did not want "to get into numbers" about how much should be cut from the military budget and spent on "the domestic needs of the country."
Mr. Mitchell was equally fuzzy. Talking to reporters before the leadership meeting, he called for an unspecified "major shift of revenues away from defense." He said, "We're engaged in a continuous process of consultation and review, and we hope very much to have action early in the new year."

HEADLINE: 6 EX-SOVIET STATES GAIN U.S. SUPPORT FOR TIE TO LENDERS

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3

 BODY:
The Bush Administration, in a policy switch aimed at more quickly assisting the economic transformation of Russia and five other former Soviet republics, urged today that they be admitted to full membership in the International Monetary Fund and World Bank.
Membership in the fund and the World Bank for Russia, Ukraine, Kazakhstan, Belarus, Kyrgyzstan and Armenia -- the former republics with which the United States is initially establishing diplomatic relations -- could allow them access to billions of dollars in development loans to help make the unsettling transition from a centralized to a free-market economy. 
 The American decision today to support full membership in the two international financial institutions reverses a longstanding Administration policy set before the collapse of the Soviet Union that had blocked Soviet membership.
 
Russia's Commitment
 Administration officials had said they were concerned that Moscow under President Mikhail S. Gorbachev was not sufficiently committed to the broad economic reform necessary to bring the country into line with Western economies.
But Russia under President Boris N. Yeltsin has demonstrated its willingness to back away from central controls, and Mr. Yeltsin's example has been followed in other republics whose economies are linked to Russia's, officials said.
Until the breakup of the Soviet Union, the Administration had also been opposed to the introduction into the fund of such a large centralized economy that was unwilling to share financial data or accept institutional oversight, which have been the prerequisites for membership. When the fund and the bank were established after World War II, the Soviet Union spurned membership. The republics that have emerged from the breakup are smaller entities, and they have not objected to the requirements of membership.
 
$12 Billion From U.S.
 The Administration's move precedes by a few weeks the assembling of a large international conference in Washington to discuss aid to the newly independent nations joined in a Commonwealth of Independent States. Dates for that conference are not yet final, the State Department said today, but it is likely to occur about Jan. 22, financial experts say.
The announcement today by the Treasury Department made no mention of whether Washington would now hasten to fulfill a commitment to provide access to $12 billion requested by the fund as part of a $60 billion increase in the institution's capital base needed to meet rising borrowing demands. The American portion is awaiting authorization by Congress, where the lawmakers are under election-year pressure to tend to domestic problems aggravated by recession in the United States.
It is a matter of debate among financial analysts whether it would have been easier for the newly independent republics to make the transition to a free-market economy if the Soviet Union had been a member of the I.M.F. and World Bank before its demise. Although Washington had withheld backing for Soviet membership, it had not objected to the entry of other Communist nations with centrally planned economies, including China and Romania.
"The dramatic developments in the former Soviet Union have created new opportunities and challenges for international financial cooperation," Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said in a statement today announcing the American policy change. United States backing virtually assures that the former republics will be admitted to the two institutions, which have 156 nations as members.
"Membership in the I.M.F. and World Bank will further market-oriented economic reform in these newly independent nations," Mr. Brady said. "We will work with them to assure that their applications are considered as quickly as possible."
Mr. Brady also said that the United States was prepared to support membership for the other former Soviet republics that Washington recognizes but with which it has not yet decided to establish full diplomatic realtions: Azerbaijan, Turkmenistan, Uzbekistan, Tajikistan, Georgia and Moldova. The United States is awaiting assurances from those republics on their political and economic development, including the protection of democratic rights.
"The benefits of technical assistance and expertise provided by the I.M.F. and World Bank, pending full membership, should continue to be available to all 12 states of the former Soviet Union," Mr. Brady said.
 
Fund's Technical Aid
 For about six months before its collapse at the end of the year, the Soviet Union had been eligible for a specially created associate membership in the two international financial institutions, allowing Moscow to receive advice but not loans. That had allowed fund and bank experts to visit and begin to study the Soviet economy. Analysts who had visited the Soviet Union within the year before its collapse were estimating that the country might need something like $5 billion in start-up funds for economic restructuring.
But a spokesman for the fund said today that the time it takes for a country to become a functioning member of the institution varies greatly. Czechoslovakia completed the process in about eight months; Poland took four years. Apart from submitting a formal application for membership, the republics would have to enact enabling legislation to join the fund, which in turn has to collect the economic data necessary to calculate a nation's initial capital subscription.
"Everybody wants to get together and work as quickly as possible on this one," said the spokesman, who declined to be idenitifed. He said that the fund has been providing some technical assistance to what is now the new commonwealth since October.
 
No Opposition Expected
 Experts have visited the former Soviet republics, and there are plans to send teams on additional visits in the next six to eight weeks. The task before them is formidable. The records kept through decades of the mismanaged Soviet centralized economy are generally considered to be unreliable.
"Some of us think it would have been nice if Moscow had come in a couple of years ago so that in this crisis period, the fund and the bank would already have been there to help," said John Williamson, a senior fellow at the Institute for International Economics in Washington.
Analysts do not expect opposition to membership for the former Soviet republics from other industrial nations. It is widely accepted that the International Monetary Fund will assist the republics in stabilizing currencies, which plunged sharply in value with abrupt economic restructuring.
 
Conditions for Loans
 In general, the fund's function is to help countries frame and carry out large-scale plans to reform malfunctioning economies, often providing financial support to cushion the process of change and adjustment.
The International Monetary Fund, set up after World War II as an independent financial institution working in cooperation with the United Nations, gets its capital from a combination of local currencies and hard currencies or gold paid into the organization by member countries according to quotas established when they join. The status of what were believed to be considerable Soviet reserves is unknown. The ruble is now a weak and nonconvertible currency.
The fund makes money available to members with loans safeguarded by agreements to abide by certain conditions of financial management in domestic economic policy and foreign exchange.
Some third world nations have objected to restraints imposed on their policies as infringement of sovereignty, but the fund and the bank are strengthening those oversight functions as demands for money proliferate.
The World Bank is normally involved in specific and more narrowly focused development projects like roads and dams and the management of specific services or industries in state and private sectors. The bank could, for example, provide expertise to the former Soviet republics on how to convert government industries into investor-owned companies.
To borrow from the World Bank, a nation must have a per capita income lower than $4,000 a year. Recent surveys by development organizations indicate that most if not all of the former Soviet republics will meet that criterion.
But it is unlikely that any would qualify for International Development Assistance loans, which are reserved for the least-developed nations with incomes under $500 per capita per year.

HEADLINE: U.S. and Allies to Seek U.N. Support Against Libya

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Jan. 3

 BODY:
Before seeking international sanctions, the United States, Britain and France plan to ask the United Nations Security Council to support their demand that Libya turn over agents accused in the bombings of two airliners, Western diplomats said today.
The three countries would ask the Council to approve sanctions against Libya only if Tripoli refused to obey the proposed order by the Security Council, which would also demand compensation. 
 Libya has been asked to extradite two agents in the bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland in December 1988, which killed 270 people, and turn over four men charged in a blast aboard a French airliner over the Sahara in September 1989 that killed 170. Should Libya still refuse to turn over the agents, the three nations would probably seek some sort of mandatory ban on all civilian air traffic to and from the country and on the sale of commercial aircraft and spare parts to Libya, diplomats said.
 
Step-by-Step Approach
 The three Western allies had previously indicated that they might threaten Libya with immediate trade penalties. But after sounding out other Security Council members, they opted for a slower step-by-step approach similar to the one used by the Council to increase pressure on Iraq to give up Kuwait during the Persian Gulf crisis.
Britain's United Nations representative, Sir David Hannay, who is President of the Council this month, confirmed today that Britain, France and the United States, all permanent members of the Council, are discussing the possibility of bringing the Libyan matter before the Council this month.
Sir David said that Prime Minister John Major was talking to other Security Council members about the possibility of convening a meeting of the heads of government of nations belonging to the Council this month. No date has been set for such a meeting.
In November, the United States and Britain jointly charged two Libyans with involvement in blowing up the Pan Am plane. France had issued arrest warrants in October for four Libyan officials, including a brother-in-law of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, in connection with the bombing of the French plane, which belonged to the airline Union de Transports Aeriens.
The United States, France and Britain began campaigning for support of their two-stage strategy to win Libyan compliance on Thursday, sending ambassadors to put their case to foreign ministers in the capitals of the 12 other countries that are members of the Security Council.
But they expect an uphill struggle with some countries, which are reluctant to pass judgment on accusations of state-sponsored terrorism against another country.
The three allies recognize that Colonel Qaddafi is maneuvering to divide the Security Council by offering to put the accused men on trial in Libya or hand them over to some international tribunal for judgment, rather then surrendering them to the United States, France and Britain.
The Bush Administration formally repeated its demands on Libya today without suggesting any change in its tactics.
"Should Libya continue to fail to comply voluntarily with our demands for justice, we have ruled out no option to gain their compliance," said Richard A. Boucher, a State Department spokesman.
But a senior Administration official cautioned that a decision on whether to press for sanctions can only be made after the allies have assessed the Council's response to an initial call for a resolution supporting extraditions.
"This is an unprecedented action we are asking for, and it is going to be very difficult," the official said.
The United States representative at the United Nations, Thomas R Pickering, has advised the Administration that to get the Security Council action it wants over Libya, Washington must be prepared to mount a diplomatic campaign of comparable intensity to the one undertaken during the Persian Gulf crisis, diplomatic officials said.
President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt has already expressed unhappiness over the planned initiative, the officials said. A few weeks ago Mr. Mubarak was so concerned about American intentions that he called President Bush to urge him not to take any new military action against Libya.
Today the United States, France and Britain sent their United Nations representatives to explain their position to the new United Nations Secretary General, Boutros Ghali, who is said to be worried that a new crisis is developing over the Libyan issue.
The three allies deliberately postponed their campaign against Libya until this month after calculating that changes in the roster of Security Council members effective Jan. 1 would make the body more sympathetic to their plans.
 
Cuba and Yemen Depart
 Cuba and Yemen, which voted against many of the gulf war resolutions affecting Iraq, have left the Council after completing two-year terms, as have the Ivory Coast, Zaire and Romania. Their places have been taken by Venezuela, Japan, Morocco, Cape Verde and Hungary.
Now that Japan has assumed one of the seats reserved for African and Asian states, the number of Council members belonging to the so-called non-aligned movement has fallen from seven to six. That means the non-aligned nations can no longer prevent the adoption of resolutions by the 15-member Council by voting as a bloc; only nine votes are needed to adopt a resolution.
Morocco, however, may be reluctant to see the Council act against Libya, its northern African neighbor.

HEADLINE: Cuban Pilot Defects With 33 Others in a Daring Helicopter Flight

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MIAMI, Jan. 3

 BODY:
In a daring escape from one of the world's last remaining Communist nations, a pilot for the Cuban national airline commandeered a helicopter in Havana today and flew 33 relatives and friends to a small suburban airport here.
The group, which included nine children and infants, immediately requested political asylum and was taken to an Immigration and Naturalization Service detention center here to be processed. 
 "We just could not stand it there anymore," one female passenger said shortly after landing at Tamiami Airport, a small strip south of Miami normally used by pleasure craft and other small planes.
 
'I Truly Feel Complete'
 "Do you have any idea what it is like to be able to bring out four children and my grandchildren like this?" asked another passenger, who identified herself as Maria Lopez. "Now I truly feel complete."
Immigration officials said they expected all 34 Cuban refugees to be released quickly to their relatives here, perhaps as early as this weekend. Unlike people from Haiti and other Latin American countries, Cubans are eligible for a special immigration program that grants them legal residency in the United States in little more than a year.
More than 7,000 Haitians, for example, are currently being detained at a United States military base at Guantanamo, Cuba, while American courts decide if they can be forcibly repatriated to their homeland, a policy favored by the Bush Administration.
The Haitian exodus began after a military regime overthrew an elected civilian president last fall, but Washington, which has refused to recognize the new government, says it nonetheless regards the Haitians as economic, rather than political, refugees.
 
Based at Cuban Resort
 The leader of today's mass defection was identified as German Pompa, a pilot with Cubana Airlines who also holds the rank of lieutenant in the Cuban Air Force. Mr. Pompa was based in Varadero, a beach resort east of Havana catering to foreign tourists and members of the Communist Party elite, and regularly flew visitors and officials on helicopter excursions from the local airport.
Orestes Lorenzo Perez, a former Cuban military pilot who defected to the United States last year and said he had once been Mr. Pompa's commanding officer, talked to Mr. Pompa minutes after his arrival this morning. Mr. Perez said Mr. Pompa told him he went to the Varadero airport early this morning and boarded the craft. Mr. Pompa was accompanied, he said, by two friends who wore the uniforms of crew members so that the suspicions of airport security officers would not be aroused.
"They then flew to a prearranged spot nearby, where family members and friends were waiting," Mr. Perez said. "The passengers climbed on board in a hurry, and they flew off, keeping an altitude of less than 30 feet above the water so that the Cuban Air Force would not detect them and shoot them down."
United States Customs Service officials said a "slow, low-flying object" was first detected flying over the Straits of Florida shortly after 8 A.M. Two Government airplanes sent to intercept the aircraft quickly identified it as a Russian-made MI-8 helicopter, and accompanied the craft until it touched down around 9:15.
 
New Year's Greetings
 "The first thing he said to me was, 'Happy New Year,' " said Sebastian Ortega, a customs official who was in radio contact with Mr. Pompa during the flight. "Other than that we didn't do very much talking. We just wanted to make sure we got him down on the ground safe and sound."
Late this morning some small plastic flight bags that the passengers brought with them, including one that proclaimed "Cuba Awaits You," were still on board the helicopter as it sat on the tarmac at Tamiami Airport, with customs agents and Miami police officers guarding it.
Under the terms of an international air hijacking agreement that both the United States and Cuba have signed, the helicopter must be returned to Cuba. A spokesman for the Cuban Interests Section in Washington said this afternoon that the Cuban Government expected to send a crew to Florida to pick up the craft and fly it back to Havana as soon as arrangements could be made.
Inside the commandeered helicopter were seats for three crew members and seat belts for 18 passengers, indicating that the craft made its 200-mile journey dangerously overloaded.
"I was a little bit nervous in the beginning," said one of the passengers, a man in his 30's. "But after 30 minutes I knew we were out of danger."
Mr. Perez and other friends of the passengers said today's escape had been carefully planned for several weeks and that there had been at least one attempted escape that was aborted at the last moment. Shortly after their arrival several of the passengers used mobile telephones to call relatives in Miami, and their conversations made it clear that those family members also knew that some sort of escape effort was in the works.
As news of the helicopter flight spread on Spanish-language radio and television stations here, curious Cuban-Americans drove to the airport in the hope of catching a glimpse of the latest additions to Miami's flourishing exile community and the craft in which they escaped.
"The next thing you know, they will be coming in submarines," said one radio commentator, rejoicing that "once again the Cuban people have made a fool of Fidel Castro."
Today's flight to freedom comes amid Cuba's worst economic and political crisis since Mr. Castro seized power 33 years ago this month. Deprived of subsidies, oil and markets for its sugar exports as a result of the collapse of Communism in the former Soviet Union and Eastern Europe, the Cuban economy has over the last two years sunk virtually to a subsistence level.
Food and fuel have long been rationed, but new restrictions on electricity and gasoline consumption, including the elimination of many bus lines, went into effect on Jan. 1. Television, newspapers, movie theaters and sports arenas have also cut back their operations, leaving the population with little diversion during what Mr. Castro calls a "special period" that he has admitted will intensify this year.
 
'No Freedom of Expression'
 At the same time, state security has stepped up its vigilance. "There is no freedom of expression there," one of the passengers on the helicopter, a teen-ager, told reporters today. "The minute you say something they throw you in jail."
In the first nine months of 1991 more than 2,000 Cubans fled to Florida aboard rafts, inner tubes or small boats, compared with 467 during the previous year, according to the immigration agency. The State Department says an additional 30,000 Cubans arrived in the United States to visit relatives and are believed by the United States authorities here to have overstayed their visas.
In a desperate attempt to flee the island just last week, an unknown Havana resident hooked a trapeze-like device to the wing of a charter flight leaving the Havana airport for Miami. As passengers watched helplessly, the man lost consciousness and fell from his perch into the sea shortly after takeoff.
Last March, Mr. Perez, flying a supersonic MIG-27 jet fighter, landed at a United States naval air station just north of Key West. That defection raised questions about the efficiency of the Pentagon's air defense network.
This time, however, the helicopter, which has a maximum speed of about 150 knots, was spotted soon after it left Havana. Michael Sheehan, a spokesman for the Customs Service in Miami, said two aircraft based at Homestead Air Force Base south of here were then ordered into the air, and spotted the helicopter about 20 miles south of Marathon, in the Florida Keys.
Customs officials said tail markings indicating the craft belonged to Cuba's state airline and the absence of guns quickly made it clear to them that they were dealing with a mass defection.
"We had no reason to believe this group was hostile," said the customs agent who piloted the Citation jet that intercepted the helicopter and accompanied it to the airstrip.
The pilot, who spoke on condition that he not be named, added: "As we approached we could see the people inside, smiling and waving at us. When they landed they were even more excited. It looked like they were kissing the ground."

HEADLINE: Election Panel Is Hoping To Replenish Its Funds

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3

 BODY:
The Federal Election Commission, hoping to stave off a $150 million shortage projected by 1996 in the taxpayer-financed campaign fund, announced today that it would begin a public relations effort and an appeal to Congress to replenish its coffers.
Joan Aikens, the chairwoman of the commission, said the Presidential Election Campaign Fund would probably not run out of money in the 1992 campaign season, but only because Presidential candidates had made lower demands on the public financing mechanism this year. 
 "The candidates this year have started later," she said. "There are fewer candidates running, and they have raised less money."
To raise more money for the fund before April 15, when income taxes are due, the commission has hired a public relations firm to produce $120,000 in broadcasting and print advertising intended to encourage taxpayers to check off a box on their tax returns that directs the Government to divert $1 to the campaign fund.
At the same time, the commission is asking Congress to consider raising the checkoff amount or allocating special grants to head off the expected deficit.
A $1 contribution does not increase or decrease tax liability, and the money for the campaign fund is drawn from the Treasury Department's general fund once every four years. But the number of taxpayers who have opted to contribute to the fund has declined steadily since 1988.
Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas has the lead among the Democratic candidates in the race for the Federal matching funds disbursed by the the election commission. Fund-raising reports made public on Thursday showed that the Clinton campaign raised $3.3 million last year, $2 million of it December.
The Governor requested $831,209 in matching funds for February and had previously received $579,364, which was paid out this week.
Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa, the second most successful Democratic fund-raiser, submitted a request for $269,469 in matching funds for February to be added to the $1 million paid out to his campaign this week. He raised more than $2 million last year.
Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska requested $258,565 for his campaign for February, which would be added to the $574,597 he qualified for last month.
Lenora Fulani, the Presidential candidate of the New Alliance Party, received $624,497 in matching funds last month and has requested $141,269 more for next month.
President Bush's fund-raising and requests for matching funds total more than $3.6 million to date, far outstripping that any of the Democratic candidates.
Federal financing from the campaign fund is used to match contributions of $250 or less, dollar for dollar.
Two-thirds of the money in the campaign finance fund is to be reserved for the general election campaign this year, and only 21 percent of the money is to be expended in the primaries. The rest is spent on party conventions.
 
'Structural Flaw' in Program
 Mrs. Aikens said the fund would continue to be stretched in future years, in part because of what she described as a "structural flaw" in the program that has limited the check-off amount to $1 while inflation continued to rise.
"In 1974 the statutory limit was established at $20 million," she said at a news conference today. "This year each party nominee will receive $55 million, representing a 280 percent increase in payout since 1974."
If more candidates run in 1996, as is likely if an incumbent is not running for re-election, even more pressure would be put on the fund to increase contributions. If that occurred, Mrs. Aiken said, "there may not be any public money available for the primary election campaigns in 1996, not because of a lack of taxpayer participation but because of the effects of inflation."
Last month the Democratic National Committee filed suit to force the Treasury Department to change the way money flows into the campaign fund so that a shortage could be avoided this year. Even though the election commission says there is little likelihood of a shortage occurring, a Democratic official said the rules should be changed.
 
No Lobbying Effort Planned
 Mrs. Aikens said the commission would not lobby for any rules changes and would take no position in the Democrats' dispute with the Treasury Department. "We send legislative recomendations to the Congress every year," she said. "What they choose to do with it is entirely up to them."
She was unwilling to predict whether the public relations effort would result in any significant increase in contributions to the campaign fund.
In the television advertisements a woman, a black couple, an Asian man and an elderly man are seen filling out their tax forms as an announcer's voice informs them of the tax check-off option and gives them a toll-free number to call for more information.
Presidential candidates qualify for public financing if they agree to limit the amount of private money they receive in primary campaigns and reject all private financing during the general election.
To qualify for matching funds, Presidential candidates must raise $100,000 in contributions from individuals from diverse areas, with at least $5,000 coming from a minimum of 20 states.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Markets
The stock market rally steamed further into uncharted territory, shoving the Dow past 3,200 for the first time. Just a week after passing 3,100, the Dow closed at 3,201.48, up 29.07. [Page 33.] 
 Prices of Treasury securities again slipped a bit, as worries resurfaced about what sort of fiscal package Congress and the Administration were likely to concoct. [36.]
The dollar rose broadly, strengthened by new weakness in the German mark. [42.]
Gold prices dipped on a report that Russia will end a state monopoly on mining and open up the republic to prospecting. [42.]
 
Companies
Seaman Furniture filed for bankruptcy protection. The company, a Kohlberg, Kravis leveraged buyout and the largest furniture retailer in the Northeast, cited a "prolonged recession." [33.]
