HEADLINE: U.S. ACCUSES IRAQ OF BLOCKING AID

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3

 BODY:
The State Department accused Iraq today of continuing to impede international aid to its 18 million people and called on President Saddam Hussein's Government to immediately resume sales of crude oil under United Nations supervision to help feed its people.
A department spokesman, Richard A. Boucher, catalogued several recent attempts by Iraqi officials to block the distribution of donated food and medicine to tens of thousands of Iraqis. Many Iraqis are said to be suffering from disease and malnutrition brought on in part by a 17-month-old trade embargo that has further devastated the Iraq's economy and prevented it from recovering from the effects of the Persian Gulf war. 
 In a separate statement titled "Humanitarian Issues in Iraq," the State Department said: "The reports of suffering of the Iraqi people are extensive, well documented and compelling. But there is a limit to what the international community can do in the absence of Iraqi cooperation.
"It is not the international sanctions which starve Iraq's innocent civilian population," the document continued. "It is the policies of Saddam Hussein's regime."
Three months have passed since the United Nations Security Council laid down procedures for Iraq to resume limited crude oil sales to finance food and medicine costs and to begin to pay reparations to Kuwait. Iraq's oil commerce had provided more than 90 percent of its national income.
 
Iraq Rejects Monitored Sales
 Iraq has refused to accept supervised sales and the monitoring that would go along with them as an infringement on sovereignty.
The Administration today praised Turkey's recent decision to extend the allied military and relief effort to protect and help feed Iraq's northern Kurdish minority through June. About 1,800 Air Force and other American military personnel are still taking part in the operation.
Turkey's cooperation in accepting American, British and French air forces and their daily flights over Iraqi territory is helping to keep Bush Administration options open for a continuing pressure campaign against Baghdad in the coming year.
The Pentagon last month submitted a plan to the White House on how United States forces would assist a coup attempt against Mr. Hussein if the coup leaders asked for American backing, Administration officials have said. No such request has been received, officials said, but the contingency planning was deemed necessary by President Bush's senior advisers in the event international sanctions succeed in breaking Mr. Hussein's tenacious grip on power in Baghdad.
Mr. Boucher, reading an Administration statement and referring to Resolutions 706 and 712 passed in October, said: "The United Nations Security Council has provided the means for Iraq to raise nearly a billion dollars from the sale of oil to meet the near-term humanitarian needs of the Iraqi people. We call on the Iraqi Government to immediately and unconditionally accept these."

HEADLINE: Dow Up 29, Past 3,200

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON Jr.

 BODY:
The stock market rally steamed further into uncharted territory yesterday, shoving the Dow Jones industrial average through the 3,200 level for the first time. Just a week after passing 3,100, the Dow closed at 3,201.48, up 29.07 points.
Posting its sixth straight record, the Dow rode an initial spurt of buying and then climbed gradually, reaching 3,200 in the final hour of trading. It was the Dow's 11th consecutive rise. 
 "The primary bull trend is still very much in force," said Anthony Ludovici, senior investment analyst at Tucker Anthony. Calling the market overvalued at current prices, he said the market's strength "definitely reflects optimism about the future."
Money continues to gush into stock funds from bonds and money markets. Fidelity Investments reported yesterday that on a single day -- Dec. 30 -- the company's equity funds under management grew by a remarkable $1 billion from a combination of new sales, fund transfers and market appreciation.
 
Other Records Set
 Trading was active yesterday, as the total number of exchanged shares reached 224.3 million. Gaining issues topped losing ones by 1,079 to 680.
Records were again set by the Nasdaq composite index, up 6.20 points, to 592.65, and by the Standard & Poor's index of 500 issues, which rose 2.08 points, to 419.34.
Before yesterday, the American Stock Exchange index was one of the market's few main indicators that had not set a record in the current rally. That barrier fell, too, as the index rose 3.32, to 398.83, surpassing the 397.03 set on Oct. 10, 1989.
The Dow's advance was paced by steady gains in several auto stocks, in apparent anticipation of an economic recovery.
 
Big 3 Are Up
 "Auto stocks will be the direct beneficiaries of an upturn," said Paul Kronlokken, a technical analyst at Piper Jaffrey in Minneapolis. "A lot of analysts have turned their tides on them from lukewarm to warm."
General Motors, which faltered last month as news of impending layoffs was announced, rose yesterday by 1 1/2, to 32 1/2. Ford went up 1 1/4, to 30 3/8, and Chrysler climbed 1, to 13 1/2. All three were among the day's 10 most active stocks.
Mr. Ludovici said he thought the market had also interpreted President Bush's decision to take auto executives on his trip to Japan as a reinforcement of the Administration's message that it would work to bring down trade barriers.
"The Administration is going to take steps to improve the economy," he said. "That's what this market is reflecting."
A byproduct of current low interest rates, Mr. Ludovici noted, is easier financing for consumers who purchase cars.
Mr. Ludovici added, however, that a surge by stocks in the first quarter last year was based on the expectation of an economic recovery, sparked by the victory in the Persian Gulf war. But when the recovery never came, the market essentially moved sideways for most of the year.
"It's very possible we'll see a similar situation," he said.
 
Getting on Bandwagon
 Mr. Kronlokken of Piper, Jaffrey conceded that the current rally had surprised him.
"I think it caught a lot of people by surprise," Mr. Kronlokken said. "Which causes more buying. More people want to leap on the bandwagon."
Yet he cautioned that he found it difficult to figure out if the market was becoming overheated -- and ready for a setback -- or poised for a further climb.
Among the most heavily traded stocks yesterday was Wal-Mart Stores, with 3.78 million shares changing hands. The stock fell 1 3/8, to 57 3/4, despite announcing that December sales in its stores were up 26 percent, to 5.86 billion from a year earlier.
Several other retail stocks moved sharply as December sales figures were released. Woolworth rose 1 1/8, to 28 1/8, after announcing that total sales for December through the 28th rose 4.8 percent, to $1.45 billion from $1.39 billion.
 
Dayton Hudson Drops
 Dayton Hudson dropped 1 1/2, to 60 1/4, after it announced that lower-than-expected sales would have a substantial impact on the earnings. Dayton Hudson's same-store sales gained 1.5 percent for the four weeks ended Dec. 28. The Gap climbed 2 3/4, to 58 3/4.
In Nasdaq trading, Scimed Life Systems leapt 8 1/4, to 90 1/2, after the company disclosed new products to be introduced in the next 90 days.
A mutual fund manager trying to keep up with the heavy flow of cash into stock funds said he had noticed a trend toward smaller growth stocks.
"We seem to be in a stock-picking environment," said Michael Hines, senior vice president for marketing at Fidelity Investments.
Mr. Hines said that new sales at Fidelity in December ran at about double the rate of November, but that in the final week of December, buying of stock funds by existing and new customers was up eightfold over November's daily average.
The market's sharp rise in late December, he said, combined with new sales and fund transfers to lift the value of the firm's total equity funds under management by about $1 billion, to $50.9 billion on Dec. 30.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Weyerhaeuser Taking Big Charge

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 3

 BODY:
The Weyerhaeuser Company said today that it would take year-end special charges and a credit that would reduce its 1991 after-tax earnings by about $344 million, or $1.70 a share. The charges will result in Weyerhaeuser's first annual or quarterly loss since it began reporting in 1933.
"These actions should put a number of uncertainties behind us and allow the company to begin 1992 with a clean slate," said John W. Creighton, Weyerhaeuser's president and chief executive. 
 Weyerhaeuser's shares fell slightly on the news today, before recovering to close at $28.125, up 75 cents a share, on the New York Stock Exchange.
The forest-products company said several factors necessitated the charges, among them that the economic recession had been longer and deeper than expected, which had generated losses associated with real estate land values and partnerships.
Weyerhaeuser, based in Tacoma, Wash., also said that contractions in the supply of timber from public lands in the Northwest would cause the early closing of some manufacturing plants and would contribute to losses from contractual obligations. Modernization or closing of some plants with environmental and operations problems will be required. Environmental cleanup costs, and severance costs associated with plant closings were also a factor.
The company also said it would put into effect new accounting standards relating to post-retirement employee health benefits and to income taxes, causing a charge of $125 million, and a credit of $64 million, respectively.
The charges "are really an aggregation of little tag-ends that they seem to have taken care of all at once," said Evadna Lynn, an analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. in New York. "The negative side is that it's one more piece of bad news, and people are saying 'how many more until we see this company turn around.' ".
Ms. Lynn added that the charge was not that big and was not related to the company's operating results.

HEADLINE: Productivity Was Up 0.9% In 3d Quarter

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3

 BODY:
Worker productivity rose at a slight rate of nine-tenths of 1 percent in the summer, a much weaker advance than had first been reported, the Government said today.
"It's consistent with an economy moving sideways," said Robert Dederick, chief economist at the Northern Trust Company. "These slow productivity gains are a product of a struggling economy." 
 Non-farm productivity, defined as output per hour of work, rose nine-tenths of 1 percent from July through September, rather than the 2.4 percent rebound first reported, the Labor Department said in revising its earlier numbers.
 
3 Quarters in a Row
 Although a rise of nine-tenths of 1 percent is small, it was still the third straight quarterly advance, the first such streak in nearly four years.
"It is promising that productivity growth is tending to show some gains," said Allen Sinai, chief economist at the Boston Company.
Increased productivity is considered vital to improving the standard of living without increasing inflation.
The report also included encouraging data on inflation. Unit labor costs, considered a crucial barometer of business expenses, rose 1.9 percent in the third quarter, well below the 2.6 percent increase in the second quarter and the 5.3 percent surge for all of last year.
"Wages are really being held down these days," Mr. Dederick said. "While that's tough for the worker, it is acting to contain inflation."
The productivity revision is not surprising since the Government also recently revised its calculations of overall economic growth for the July-September quarter.
The gross domestic product, or the nation's total output of goods and services, edged up 1.7 percent for the third quarter, below the 2.5 percent reported earlier.
In the third quarter, while output grew 1.6 percent, hours worked rose seven-tenths of 1 percent.
 
An Upward Revision
 Today's report revised productivity upward for the second quarter. Productivity increased at an annual rate of 1.9 percent from April through June, more than the increase of five-tenths of 1 percent first reported.
Since July 1990, when the recession began, productivity has been lackluster. This year, it has increased at least slightly each quarter.
Factory productivity grew 3.8 percent in the third quarter while total business productivity, including farming, grew 1.1 percent, the Labor Department said.
For all of 1990, non-farm productivity fell one-tenth of 1 percent, after a retreat of nine-tenths of 1 percent the previous year. That was the first back-to-back slide in a decade.

HEADLINE: With Local News and Memories, a Paper Ends Its Run

BYLINE: By CHARLES STRUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ELIZABETH, N.J., Jan. 3

 BODY:
Shailesh Patel, the owner of Brown's Cigar Store, looked up from his calculator at the stacks of daily newspapers arranged on bleacher-style shelving next to the door.
"See that?" he said, pointing to the one empty space that a few hours earlier held more than 200 copies of The Daily Journal. "All gone." 
 Mr. Patel was correct in two ways. He had sold out his daily allotment of the paper. And those copies -- with "Farewell" printed in bold black type across the front page -- were the last Daily Journals he would ever sell.
The oldest newspaper in New Jersey, founded by a group of Revolutionary patriots in 1779, has died, and for the first time in 212 years, Elizabeth is without its own newspaper.
The paper has had a series of owners and had a peak circulation of just over 60,000. But during the last decade, The Daily Journal, which published Monday through Saturday, failed to thrive in this aging industrial city of 110,000. As the paper's readership aged or moved to the suburbs, circulation leveled off at about 30,000. Then came the recession.
"We were holding our own up to then," said Richard J. Vezza, the publisher for North Jersey Newspapers, which acquired The Daily Journal almost seven years ago.
 
After 212 Years, 28 Pages
 After two straight years of steep losses -- particularly in classified advertising, he said -- the owners decided to sell or close. The staff was notified Nov. 1, and despite some deadline negotiations with the only potential buyer, there was never much hope for salvation.
Another of the North Jersey Newspapers, The Hudson Dispatch of Union City, was acquired by The Jersey Journal of Jersey City last April and ceased independent publication.
This morning's Daily Journal, a 28-page paper in four sections, contained the usual mix of local, national, foreign and sports news, as well as more than four pages of reminiscences about the paper, articles about its alumni and praise from citizens and public figures.
Where classified advertising fell short, The Journal inserted a filler ad promoting itself. The Star-Ledger of Newark, the state's largest paper, took two full-page ads, one inviting new subscribers and the other inviting Daily Journal carriers to apply for a Star-Ledger paper route.
Between 90 and 100 employees worked in The Daily Journal's modern offices at 295 Broad Street in downtown Elizabeth. In one large room, 25 reporters and editors shared space with the business and advertising departments and the composing room.
 
Most Employees Laid Off
 Eighty-four people will be laid off by the closing, Mr. Vezza said. The others will be absorbed by North Jersey Newspapers, which, in addition to The North Jersey Herald & News, publishes 13 weeklies. One of those, the Suburban News of Westfield, will be circulated in Elizabeth.
Staffers in the advertising department were on the phone throughout the day to solicit ads for the successor weekly. Reporters and editors wandered in later in the day, weary from an impromptu wake that kept them at a local tavern until 3 A.M.
Throughout its tenure, the paper's concerns were unabashedly local. The front page on Thursday was a showcase for two standard stories of local news. One featured the parents of the first child born in Union County in 1992, the other an account of a house fire that started in a mattress and killed a Roselle man.
Like many papers its size, The Daily Journal was often a farm team for larger newspapers. Sometimes, staff members stayed longer. Among them was Mike Murray, 29 years old, the managing editor.
"It was a little somber for me last night, because this is the only job I ever had," said Mr. Murray, who worked part time for The Daily Journal's sports department while in college. He became a sports reporter in 1985, after two years playing minor league ball for the White Sox.
"This is the paper that was on my parents' doorstep since I was 5 years old and we moved to Rahway," he said.
 
A Habit Hard to Break
 It was also the paper that showcased the talents of local athletes, he said. A call from The Daily Journal's sports editor could help a young athlete win a sports scholarship or gain visibility with college coaches.
And for many like Mr. Murray who were born or grew up here, The Daily Journal was a habit that will be hard to break.
Shortly after noon, an elderly woman marched into Mr. Patel's newspaper and tobacco shop near the train station, stared at the stacks of papers and asked of no one in particular, "No Journal?"
"All gone," Mr. Patel said again. But the woman misunderstood his double-edged reply and went off down the street to find a copy.
Informed that The Daily Journal had gone out of business, she seemed shocked. Shooing her informant away, she said, "You know I've read the paper all my life. I buy it every day."
"It'll be back," she said. "Don't you think?"

Mr. Vezza wrote a note in the deserted newsroom of The Daily Journal, which closed yesterday after 212 years. Eighty-four people will be laid off. (Keith Meyers/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Deep Recession Takes Aim at New Jersey Papers

BYLINE: By ALEX S. JONES

 BODY:
The Daily Journal of Elizabeth closed yesterday in the latest manifestation of the very hard times New Jersey newspapers are facing.
Indeed, the state's especially crowded newspaper competition and the deep recession in the state suggest that The Journal could easily be joined by other papers in the months to come. 
 Even the strongest newspapers have been affected by a huge decline in real estate, job, automobile and retail advertising in New Jersey. For example, The Record, which is based in Hackensack and has long prospered in Bergen County, has a $110 million debt for a printing plant it ordered when business was booming. The Record's payroll is smaller by 400 employees than it was in 1988. Among the missing are 186 employees dismissed last summer.
"That hadn't happened since my grandfather had a layoff in 1931," said Malcolm A. Borg, the owner of The Record, "and I didn't enjoy it."
In some ways, the New Jersey newspaper business -- especially the counties closest to New York -- is typical of the business in all suburban areas, where metropolitan and suburban papers fight for advertising with each other and with such competitors as dozens of new cable television channels and companies that deliver advertising circulars by mail.
But New Jersey is different from other places in that every aspect of its situation is exaggerated: it is more competitive, its economy boomed more spectacularly than most in the 80's, and many newspaper executives fear that its economy is less likely than many others to rebound significantly.
As a result, newspaper profits are off almost everywhere in the state, and some of the more vulnerable newspapers -- like The Daily Journal in depressed Elizabeth -- have slipped into an unprofitability from which there may be no recovery.
New Jersey residents probably live in the most newspaper-rich environment in the nation. The New York Times, The Daily News, USA Today and The Wall Street Journal are all readily available in New Jersey, and The Philadelphia Inquirer circulates widely in the southern part of the state. This year The Times plans to open a new printing plant in Edison, N.J., that will give it added flexibility to produce editions aimed at readers in specific areas and thus increase its ability to pursue advertising in New Jersey.
The Star-Ledger, which is based in Newark and owned by the Newhouse family, which also owns Conde Nast magazines, circulates throughout the state with an array of special "zoned" editions and local sections. In a typical example of The Star-Ledger's aggressive marketing savvy, its Sunday sports section is encyclopedic, tracking sports throughout the state in great detail. Not surprisingly, its 700,000 Sunday circulation dwarfs that of every other paper in New Jersey.
The Record in Hackensack and The Asbury Park Press could be considered regional dailies, and they have expanded their areas of coverage in recent years, often encroaching on the turf of smaller dailies. For instance, The Press has challenged The Ocean County Observer in Toms River, which is owned by Goodson Newspapers.
 
A Little Stronger
 Though The Star-Ledger, The Record and The Asbury Park Press have all been hurt in the advertising crunch, they have more fundamental strength than any other dailies in the state. But a newspaper executive who spoke on condition of anonymity said that declining profits have prompted the Plangere family to quietly seek a buyer for The Asbury Park Press, and The Record is hoping to sell its new presses to reduce its debt, then lease the presses back.
In the next category are small dailies that have been squeezed from above by the local sections of larger papers and from below by a swarm of non-daily papers that have formed networks covering large areas.
The small, community daily is probably New Jersey's most endangered type of newspaper. The Central New Jersey Home News in New Brunswick is an example. The paper has been in the family of William M. Boyd, its owner, since 1879, and it covers about half of Middlesex County. Also based in Middlesex County is The News Tribune of Woodbridge and Perth Amboy, which is owned by Mr. Borg, owner of The Record. In the 80's, said Mr. Boyd, "we were really booming along" as the job market produced double-digit increases in help-wanted and real-estate classified advertising each year. Everyone prospered.
It was during this period that W. Dean Singleton, chief executive officer of Media News Group Inc., began assembling his chain of daily and non-daily newspapers in New Jersey, including The Daily Journal in Elizabeth.
 
Bonuses Decline
 Indeed, though Elizabeth was one of the state's most decaying urban centers, real-estate prices were increasing so fast that it seemed even Elizabeth might be revived by people looking for affordable housing in the expanding job market.
Then came the stock market crash of 1987. The bonuses of New Jersey residents working on Wall Street dwindled, and service industry jobs began to decline with them. What had gone up fast began to decline just as rapidly.
In 1991, in the face of a revenue shortfall and huge social-service obligations built up during the fat years, the New Jersey Legislature passed a $2.8 billion tax increase package.
While the economy was being buffeted for many reasons, consumer confidence -- and advertising -- took a decided turn for the worse. "Everything came to a screeching halt," said Mr. Singleton.
Neither Mr. Boyd's Home News nor Mr. Borg's News Tribune is faring well now in Middlesex County. Mr. Boyd has put The Home News up for sale, and Mr. Borg has said that he intends to buy it, but cannot afford to do so right now.
Mr. Borg, whose candor extends to posting a notice at The Record last year announcing his decision to seek help for alcohol abuse, said that buying The Home News would make economic sense only if it could then be closed.
The most unpredictable parts of New Jersey's newspaper industry are its many non-dailies, which range from groups clustered in various parts of the state to independents, including The Two River Times, a weekly in Monmouth County founded in 1990 and soon after bought by Geraldo Rivera, who lives in the Red Bank area.
Claudia Ansorge, who owns 25 percent of The Times and serves as publisher, describes trying to start a paper in such a miserable economic environment as being "a dance between the raindrops," but thanks in part to Mr. Rivera's willingness to sign copies in shopping malls and other promotions, ad sales and circulation are growing.
But stand-alone non-daily papers are almost a relic of the past because, in groups -- and almost only in groups -- they have proven to be potent vehicles for attracting advertising away from dailies.
The potential profit was sufficient during the 80's boom to attract Malcolm Forbes, whose family now owns a group of non-dailies in New Jersey, which is one of several similar groups around the state.
With the closure of The Daily Record in Elizabeth, Mr. Singleton will own only one daily in New Jersey, The North Jersey Herald and News in Passaic, but he will own about two dozen non-dailies in Passaic, Union and Bergen counties with mid-week circulation of more than 650,000 and weekend circulation of nearly 500,000. He also plans to start a non-daily in Elizabeth.
Just as the dailies have suffered, so have the non-dailies, and many are thought to be losing money or close to it.
Mr. Singleton said that December was the first month in more than two years in which revenues at his New Jersey papers improved compared to the year before, and he said this was a promising sign for all of New Jersey's battered papers.
But he added that his optimism was all but unique.

HEADLINE: Politicians Assail Hertz For New York Surcharge

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
Kathleen Restifo and Dr. David Bernstein rented from Hertz this weekend, but she will be doing all the driving. She's from Philadelphia; he's from Brooklyn.
Dr. Bernstein had reserved a car a few days ago for a weekend getaway, but on Thursday, Hertz announced that it would apply a surcharge to rentals by most New York City residents; when he arrived at the rental counter at 222 East 40th Street in Manhattan yesterday after work, he was told that the extra cost for the two-day rental would be $68. 
 Dr. Bernstein, a psychologist at the Bronx Veterans Affairs Hospital, was disgusted. "I'm surprised they don't just shut down the operation," he said. "Why don't they just get out of town? Unless they want an elite, corporate clientele, which is maybe what they're after."
There were moments of individual outrage yesterday at rental counters around the area and at telephones where callers tried to reserve cars, and there was an organized demonstration of anger as officials lined up to condemn Hertz for the surcharge policy it announced on Thursday. Forty demonstrators paraded in front of a midtown rental outlet and chanted "Hertz hurts New York," and other car rental concerns offered theories of what motivated the company.
Hertz said it was imposing the surcharges -- $3 a day for residents of Manhattan, $15 for Queens, $34 for Brooklyn, $56 for the Bronx and nothing for Staten Island residents or corporate customers -- because of large losses that it attributes to New York State's insurance law. Company officials yesterday released information to bolster their argument that the law that allows for "vicarious liablity" suits has made it unprofitable to operate in New York City. Under the vicarious liability law, a rental company can be forced to pay for any damage caused by one of its cars, even if neither the company nor the person to whom it rented was at fault.
 
Case in Brooklyn
 A spokesman for Hertz, Joseph M. Russo, said the law meant, for example, that the company had paid $2.5 million in the case of a a Brooklyn resident who gave the keys to his rented car to his cousin, an unemployed, unlicensed driver who was under age 25 -- Hertz's minimum. Driving in New York City at excessive speed, the cousin hit a pedestrian, who fell into a coma after suffering a fractured skull and brain damage. The pedestrian lost 98 percent of the use of his right arm, and was so disabled that he was unable to propel a wheelchair. The pedestrian sued for $7.5 million, and the suit was settled.
The explanation for the surcharges did not go far with public officials. Howard Golden, the Brooklyn Borough President, said in a statement, "Hertz has put discrimination in the driver's seat." The charge, he said, was "an outrageous act of bias, dividing our people into privileged and underprivileged classes."
New York Attorney General Robert Abrams, the New York State Consumer Protection Board, the New York City Department of Consumer Affairs and even the New York Civil Liberties Union all said they were investigating. The Attorney General's office said its staff would meet with Hertz next week.
Around the rental car industry, reaction varied. At Avis, a lobbyist who has been trying to have New York amend its vicarious liability law said the $45 million loss figure quoted by Hertz for the last three years was about what Avis would expect, given Hertz's volume of business. The lobbyist, Jerome L. Wilson, a lawyer with the firm of Rogers and Wells, said New York is so hard on rental cars that of Avis's nationwide reserve fund for accidents, 25 percent is dedicated to New York State, despite the fact that New York represents only 8 percent of Avis's business.
But Mr. Russo, of Hertz, insisted that the problem was not damage to the cars themselves.
"The cars range in price from $12,000 to $20,000," he said. "Suppose you total it, or you steal the thing. You lose an average of $15,000 per vehicle, that's it."
Referring to the vicarious liability suits, he said, "Here, we're talking about $220,000, $230,000, $2 million or $3 million."
But others said the problem did not justify Hertz's solution, which would appear to write off business from renters in those three boroughs.
 
$7 Million Judgment
 At Alamo, which rents from a location near Newark International Airport and which would like to enter the New York City market, Charles D. Platt, the president, said his company had recently paid $7 million in a vicarious liability suit. But Mr. Platt, who worked for General Motors in Manhattan for years, said that he did not think vicarious liability was the issue for Hertz.
"Local renters don't have the same motives," he said. "They're renting a car because they don't have enough money to buy a car, or they are wise enough to know -- and you never have to worry about a New Yorker being savvy -- that if you wreck that car, you don't have to be responsible for it."
Hertz is 49 percent owned by the Ford Motor Company. The other owners are Volvo of North America, 26 percent; Commerzbank, a German bank, 5 percent, and Hertz management, 20 percent.

Kathleen Restifo of Philadelphia will be doing the driving. (C. M. Hardt for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Threats by Phone: Free Speech or Just Another Evil?

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ANSONIA, Conn., Jan. 3

 BODY:
The answering machine at Gary Hale's home has lost its angry edge. No longer does it play back obscene messages attacking Mr. Hale, a state senator, for casting one of the pivotal votes last summer that gave Connecticut an income tax.
But vitriolic messages left on that machine months ago, at the height of protests against the new tax, have come home to some of the people who called him. One anonymous caller has been identified and charged with harassment. The police say other arrests are possible. 
 The police investigation into the calls has raised alarms over the stifling of free expression in politics, at the same time that it has revealed just how low the level of discourse in Connecticut sank in 1991. What seems most clear is the depth of the anger Mr. Hale stirred by casting the decisive vote for an income tax he had vowed to oppose.
"Gary Hale's in the middle of a hornets' nest," said Robert C. Pollack, managing editor of The Evening Sentinel, a Naugatuck Valley newspaper that found sentiment running 62 to 1 against the income tax among 5,000 readers who took part in a straw vote. "People in the valley blame him."
John R. Williams, a well-known civil liberties lawyer who represents the person arrested, 27-year-old Robert Wall of Shelton, describes Mr. Wall's arrest as "a wonderful First Amendment case."
"I was amazed, when I saw the warrant, that the judge even signed the thing," Mr. Williams said. "I was also somewhat surprised that the prosecutor didn't throw the case out when we first went to court. I think the reason is that it's highly political."
Mr. Hale became a target for income-tax opponents in August when he and two other senators gave up their opposition to the tax. Their votes created an 18-18 tie in the Senate that was broken in favor of the income tax by Lieut. Gov. Eunice Groark.
Mr. Hale says he still opposes the income tax, and last month he voted for its repeal. But with the state in financial crisis last summer, he said, "I felt the responsible thing to do was try to break the deadlock." His price: assurances of a low-interest loan fund for expanding businesses.
 
'Burn Your House Down'
 "People calling me and yelling or swearing doesn't really bother me," Mr. Hale said. "I've been a senator for five years." But on Aug. 23, the day after Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. signed the income tax into law, he announced that his home and family had been threatened by anonymous callers who left messages on his answering machine.
"One said, 'You better stay awake all night or I'm going to burn your house down,' " Mr. Hale said. "The second said, 'Your two kids are going to pay for your vote in Hartford.' "
In an interview this week, Mr. Hale said, "I certainly don't mind anger or criticism directed at me. But I don't think when I signed up for this job I invited abuse of my family."
Mr. Hale went to the Ansonia and the State Capitol police. They suggested the telephone company install a trap on his line that could identify the source of calls. The calls continued, building to a peak as a giant anti-tax rally in Hartford on Oct. 5 approached.
About 5 percent of the calls, Mr. Hale estimates, were threatening or obscene, and anonymous. He reported the date and time of those calls so they could be traced. He also had his machine's recordings.
Senator Hale was not alone in receiving threats and talking with the police. Some legislators received death threats, and some stopped using their legislative license plates. On Oct. 5, more than 40,000 people railed against the income tax at an angry rally at the State Capitol. Governor Weicker was spat at and sworn at. The telephone numbers of legislators who voted for the tax boomed out over the public-address system.
That night, at 7:23, the telephone rang at Mr. Hale's house in the big downstairs room that includes both his office and his 4-year-old daughter's play room. The answering machine began recording.
According to a police transcript, the call began with several variations on a common vulgarity. The caller then said people would never vote for Mr. Hale again, adding, "You are stupid. You made a mistake. You're gone, boy, you're gone. You're through in this town."
That was one of several calls traced to Mr. Wall, who was charged with one count of harassment, a misdemeanor, on Dec. 6.
Mr. Wall's lawyer, Mr. Williams, said the call was not harassment, but the free speech of a constituent calling a legislator. "If that isn't the protected criticism of a public official, I don't know what is," he said of the transcript.
 
Suspect Feels Humiliated
 The fact that the message was anonymous, Mr. Williams said, does not matter. "The right of anonymous complaint is an essential ingredient of the First Amendment," he said.
Mr. Wall also protested, in an interview with The Evening Sentinel, that he had been set up, degraded and humiliated by his very public arrest. He acknowledged swearing in the Oct. 5 call, but said he was only doing what the Senator had asked people to do: share their feelings about the income tax.
Ansonia's police chief, James J. McGrath, said his officers have spoken to other people who have been traced to anonymous calls to Mr. Hale, and there may be more arrests.
"Nobody is arrested for just calling him and complaining about the income-tax bill," he emphasized. "It's more than that. It's harassing or threatening him."
Several people called by the Ansonia police in turn called the Connecticut Taxpayers Committee. The anti-tax group, which has organized protests and telephone campaigns against legislators who voted for the income tax, acknowledges sending thousands of pieces of mail listing Mr. Hale's telephone numbers into his district.
The committee's chairman, Tom Scott, a former senator from Milford, said, "We ask people to call legislators. In fact, we insist that they call legislators. But we ask that they call at reasonable hours, and that they be firm but polite.
"So long as the threat is limited to political retaliation," he said, "it's protected speech."
Mr. Williams said he found it ironic that in a First Amendment case, Mr. Wall's staunchest defenders would include many strong advocates of the income tax, like himself. But Senator Hale made no apologies for going to the police. Every call that he reported, he said, was "anonymous and involved either obscenities or threats."
"If someone called up and said, 'To hell with you, I'm against the income tax,' and left a name and number, I didn't report those calls," he said. "I have no sympathy for those who are being investigated."
Mr. Hale's telephone was quiet during the Legislature's special session in December, when he joined in an unsuccessful effort to repeal the income tax. Since the investigation became public, he said, only one person has left a message about the tax. That person favored it, and left his name and number.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
President Is Installed At Economists Group

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
William Vickrey, a grand old man of public finance whose avant-garde ideas have influenced economists since the late 1930's, has become the new president of the 20,000-member American Economics Association.
Mr. Vickrey, 78 years old, a professor of economics at Columbia University, will hold the post -- largely an honorary one -- for the usual one-year term. As president-elect last year, he took over the new position yesterday at the start of the organization's yearly meeting in New Orleans, succeeding Thomas Schelling of Harvard University. 
 Becoming the group's president "is the greatest tribute, short of the Nobel Prize, that an economist could receive," Mr. Vickrey said in an interview.
One of his main jobs is to preside over the meeting, which is a three-day affair that entails more than 500 different seminars on topics ranging from taxation in the 1990's to women in the work force. It also includes the biggest job fair in the world for academic economists.
Mr. Vickrey, tall, white-haired and rumpled, criticizes the economics profession for "not really coming up with sound solutions to basic problems."
"Too many economists," he said, "are basically astronomers, admiring our wonderful free-market system, or weathermen, predicting what the economy is going to do."
Mr. Vickery himself has concentrated on a handful of innovative proposals that were radical when they were introduced but have now become part of mainstream thinking. They have included a method for pricing subway rides, a model for preventing traffic tie-ups at toll plazas and a way to tax income fairly no matter when it was earned.
"Like Ronald Coase, who won the Nobel Prize this year, he has written only a few papers, but each one has been influential," said Henry Aaron, an expert on taxation at the Brookings Institution.
Mr. Vickrey counts himself a radical and expresses the radical's usual frustration. "My whole career has been spent making eminently sensible suggestions that have gotten nowhere," he said.
In fact, however, Singapore has a Vickrey-style traffic-congestion tax, and most cities, except Mr. Vickrey's own New York, charge subway riders by distance and time of day, a method he first proposed for New York a couple of decades ago. Indeed, one panel moderator who introduced Mr. Vickrey yesterday, pointed out that Mr. Vickrey helped write Japan's postwar tax system during the American occupation.
Born in Vancouver, British Columbia, Mr. Vickrey grew up in New York. After earning a B.A. in mathematics at Yale, he studied economics at Columbia University, where he has taught nearly his entire career. A conscientious objector during World War II, he spent part of his alternative service designing a new inheritance tax for Puerto Rico.
Mr. Vickrey astonished his students and fellow faculty members for years by roller skating from his commuter train stop in Harlem to his university office. His addiction to crossword puzzles is so overpowering that he has been known to do them surreptitiously during lectures by visiting eminences.
And his catnapping is notorious. "He is known for sleeping through every seminar" he attends, said a Columbia colleague, who added, "But he always asks the first question -- and it's usually a good one."

HEADLINE: Treasuries Slip on Budget Concerns

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities slipped a bit again yesterday, as worries arose again about what sort of fiscal package Congress and the Bush Administration were likely to concoct over the next few months.
Talk about tax cuts and the like was stimulated by an article yesterday in The Washington Post, which quoted President Bush as saying the 1990 budget accord might be reopened to shift spending planned for the military into domestic areas. 
"What the President actually said was constructive, in that he said he did not want to bust the budget," said Ward McCarthy, a managing director of Stone & McCarthy Research Associates, a firm in Princeton, N.J., that provides research and commentary on developments in the foreign exchange and fixed-income markets.
"But the market is still very sensitive to the fiscal situation, and has become conditioned to expect the worst from Washington," he added.
 
Protectionism and Profits
 Market participants said concern also arose about protectionist-sounding rhetoric that had fallen into Mr. Bush's public pronouncements during his trip to the Far East.
In addition, the urge remained to take profits after a prolonged rally.
"To get some selling after what we have seen is not surprising," one government bond trader said. "But the market has a good tone to it, largely because there is widespread anticipation that the economic news next week will be favorable to fixed-income investors."
Specifically, analysts are expecting a report on producer prices to show that inflation at the wholesale level was mild during December. And there is every reason to assume that the December employment report, scheduled to be released by the Labor Department next Friday, will show a fairly large decline in the number of non-farm payroll employees.
 
30-Year Bonds at 7.47%
 In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 percent 30-year bonds due in 2021 were offered late yesterday at a price of 106 9/32 , down 5/32 , to yield 7.47 percent, compared with 7.46 percent late on Thursday and 7.51 percent on Dec. 27.
Among note issues, the 7.50 percent 10-year notes were offered at 104 25/32 , down 13/32 , to yield 6.82 percent. The 6 1/8 percent five-year notes were offered at 100 15/32 , down by 3/8 a point, to yield 6.48 percent. And the 5 percent two-year notes dipped by 1/32 , to a late offered price of 100 14/32 , to yield 4.76 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates were narrowly mixed.
Three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 3.83 percent late yesterday, down by a basis point, or one-hundredth of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates rose by a similar amount, to a late offered rate of 3.86 percent.
 
World Bank Plans Sale
 The prospect that next week will be a very busy one in the investment-grade corporate bond market was heightened yesterday, when the World Bank said it intended to sell $1.5 billion in global bonds. In the past, such issues have generally had maturities of 5 to 10 years.
The bank said yesterday that the maturity of the securities to be sold next week would be toward the longer end of that range.
In the corporate bond market yesterday, the Cigna Corporation offered $100 million in 15-year notes through an underwriting syndicate led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.
The 8.25 percent notes were priced at $100, or par, 1.42 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 7.50 percent 10-year notes at the time of pricing.
The securities are rated A-1 by Moody's Investors Service Inc. and A+ by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
 
Money Supply Down
 In other developments, the Federal Reserve Board reported yesterday that the two broadest measures of the nation's money supply fell in the week that ended on Dec. 23.
M-1, the nation's basic money supply, rose by $100 million.
The reported declines in M-2, the aggregate most closely monitored by the Fed, and in M-3 were much larger than expected. But the report had no effect on prices in the credit markets.

HEADLINE: Despite a Lingering Recession, More People Are Giving to the Neediest Cases

BYLINE: By J. PEDER ZANE

 BODY:
A dramatic surge in the number of donations enabled The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund to top $3.5 million yesterday as it entered the second half of the campaign.
Thirty-four days into the campaign, the Neediest Cases has received 9,789 donations, a 21.5 percent increase from last year when 8,060 contributions were made in the same period. 
 But the average size of donations has been smaller this year so that the campaign is only slightly ahead of last year's pace in the amount of money received. With two months to go, the 80th annual appeal must raise an additional $900,000 to match last year's total of $4.4 million.
Arthur Gelb, who is president of The New York Times Company Foundation, which administers the Neediest Cases, said he is surprised and heartened that so many more people have decided to give despite the deepening recession.
 
Need for More Donations
 "The remarkable response to the Neediest Cases so far, in times of growing hardship, is a tribute to the loyalty and generosity of Times readers." he said. "Letters accompanying donations show how concerned many of our readers are about the harsh impact of governmental cuts in social services and the importance of private assistance in keeping such programs alive."
Mr. Gelb quickly added that there is still a long way to go. He noted that in the final two months of last year's campaign, $1.4 million was raised from 7,520 donations. "Our hope is that the dramatic success of the fund's drive will encourage further giving in the second half of the campaign," Mr. Gelb said, "so that donations will match or even surpass last year's record."
Since it was founded in 1912 by Adolph S. Ochs, who was then the publisher of The New York Times, the Neediest Cases Fund has raised money for New York's sick, poor and disabled. What began as the "Hundred Neediest Cases" has expanded to meet the needs of thousands of individuals.
As in the past, The New York Times is covering all of the campaign's overhead so that every dollar collected can be passed on directly to seven charities. The money provides many forms of relief including food for the hungry, homes for the homeless and clothing for those without. The seven charities also use the money to provide job training for the disabled, counseling for substance abusers, child abusers and services that address the complex problems confronted by people with AIDS.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Gold Off on Report of Plans To Open Up Russian Mining

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Gold prices fell yesterday on a report that Russia would end the former state monopoly on mining and open up the new republic to prospecting.
Traders on the Commodity Exchange in New York said they were initially confused by the report that the republics making up what was formerly the world's third-largest gold producer would end the state monopoly on mining. 
 "I thought it was bullish when I first looked at the news," said a trader for a large Swiss bank. "But now I see it's not."
Fears that the breakup of the Soviet Union would disrupt gold, platinum and crude oil exports have provided background support to those markets for months.
The active February gold contract fell $1.70 an ounce yesterday, to $351.50, after the administrator of the large Magadan gold-producing district said the Government of the Russian republic planned to allow regions to give licenses for prospecting.
Silver prices, which peaked at $4.04 an ounce in the most active March contract, retreated later to close 0.3 cent lower at $3.972 an ounce.
Silver had jumped on Thursday in a speculative rally tied to the stock market's surge and vague hopes that the United States economy would emerge from recession and stimulate demand.
The prices of platinum, of which the former Soviet Union is a leading producer, also fell on the mining report. The January contract declined $4.10 an ounce, to $333.50, on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
Oil futures traded choppily yesterday, reversing course several times and finally ending lower.
February oil closed 26 cents lower at $19.23 a barrel after reaching an earlier high of $19.78. February heating oil gained 0.58 cent, to 52.14 cents a gallon, and unleaded gasoline for February eased 0.17 cent, to 55.27 cents a gallon.
Most of the action was viewed as technical, as the February contract failed to break through the $19.80-a- barrel level and then "slid quickly and scared a lot of length out of the market," said Tom Bentz, an analyst with United Energy Inc.
Poor weather in the North Sea forced a suspension of loadings and caused some futures buying, but traders said the weather was forecast to improve over the weekend.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Rallies in Broad Rise As Mark Shows Weakness

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar rose broadly in foreign-exchange dealings yesterday, strengthened by new weakness in the German mark and speculation that the dollar's recent weakness may be overdone.
Currency market strategists said there was nothing in the domestic economic news to warrant a rise in the dollar. New statistics released by the Government yesterday showing modest improvements in factory orders and labor productivity did little to suggest that the United States is climbing out of recession. 
 Nonetheless, traders said the striking declines in interest rates in the United States that helped weaken the dollar last month have already been digested by the foreign exchange market, which is now looking for something new to provide direction for the currency.
 
Hints by German Officials
 Others said the dollar rallied on signs that the strength of the German mark was under increasing pressure. There have been hints dropped by German monetary officials that the nation is heading into a recession, suggesting interest rates in Germany will have to decline. Lower rates would make investments denominated in marks worth less.
The dollar strengthened sharply in Europe, to 1.5480 marks, up from 1.5275 Thursday. Later, in New York the dollar fetched 1.5435 marks, up from 1.5315 Thursday.
"We've had a pretty good rally for the dollar today," said Andrew Hodge, vice president of corporate treasury services at the New York branch of Bank Brussels Lambert. "I think you're seeing some serious mark weakness."
Still, considerable skepticism prevails in the market over the strength of the dollar. Many traders believe it will head lower.
Some said President Bush's trip to Japan next week, with the stated goal of narrowing the enormous trade deficit, could yield some kind of currency-management arrangement with the Japanese that would result in a cheaper dollar. Such a shift would help raise American exports by making them more affordable in Japan.
Tokyo markets remained closed in an extended New Year holiday. In Europe, the dollar fetched 124.80 yen, up from 124.50 yen late Thursday. By the time trading concluded in New York, the dollar fetched 124.65 yen, up from 124.60 late Thursday.
The British pound fell in London, to $1.8445, from $1.8685 Thursday. In New York, the pound fetched $1.8485, down from $1.8655 Thursday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, versus levels late Thursday, were: 1.3730 Swiss francs, up from 1.3665; 1.1466 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1509; 5.2675 French francs, down from 5.2905, and 1,165.00 Italian lire, up from 1,158.00.

HEADLINE: Your Money;
Help for Workers Posted Overseas

BYLINE: By Jan M. Rosen

 BODY:
WITH the economic integration of Western Europe this year and the remarkable drive by Eastern Europe toward a market economy, American companies are increasing their presence abroad. But people who assume that a transfer to Brussels is like a move to, say, Boston, can find that financial disasters arise.
Even in Western Europe, consumer banking practices often do not meet American expectations, and in Eastern Europe and the third world many services may not be available at all. Also, most people assigned overseas continue to have financial obligations at home -- mortgage and tuition payments, insurance premiums, investment accounts, credit cards, taxes, perhaps alimony or support for elderly parents. All of this calls for arranging financial affairs in advance. 
 Robert A. De Rosa, a Citibank vice president who is director of personal banking services for overseas executives, said, "Although businesses preparing their people for overseas assignments generally review factors such as housing, children's education, shipping personal belongings, cultural and language training, rarely do companies, even the more experienced ones, think about expatriates' banking needs until funds are lost in transit, checks start to bounce and credit ratings are damaged."
Mr. De Rosa experienced difficulties firsthand when the bank posted him to Italy, which led him to start the personal banking unit eight years ago to serve Citibank's own international staff. In the clubby atmosphere of American business people abroad, others soon wanted to become clients.
Today the unit serves 4,000 clients from 40 companies in 91 countries. In some cases, corporations provide the service to personnel as a benefit; in others, individuals sign up on their own at fees ranging from $25 to $60 a month, depending on the level of service needed.
"Some people go abroad and try having in-laws, for example, pay the bills," Mr. De Rosa said. "Even when they are diligent, it can strain the best of relationships," and bills mailed overseas often get lost or arrive after the due date. Sometimes job performance suffers because people become so preoccupied with financial snarls, he added.
The bank sets up personal arrangements for each client. For example, it may arrange to have a certain amount from each paycheck wired overseas for the client to use, and a certain portion deposited at Citibank. A personal banker can then pay agreed-upon bills or invest in mutual funds or through discount brokerage services, as agreed.
Not infrequently, Mr. De Rosa said, the personal bankers get involved in sorting out distant emergencies, like canceling credit cards for, and wiring money to, the panic-stricken executive who telephoned from Thailand that his wallet had been stolen. The department is at 666 Fifth Avenue; more details can be provided by calling either Mr. De Rosa or Helen Benjamin of the corporate sales and marketing department at (212) 307-8511.
 
 
Estimated Taxes
 Estimated tax payments for the fourth quarter of 1991 are due on Wednesday, Jan. 15, and tax professionals report that clients are asking about the rigorous new standards Congress imposed on estimated payments in November, when it sought to speed up revenue collections to pay for extended unemployment benefits.
The standards do not affect 1991 estimates. Taxpayers will not be subject to penalties if they have paid an amount equal to either 90 percent of their current liability or 100 percent of their 1990 liability through payroll withholding, estimated taxes or a combination.
But starting with payments due on June 15, 1992, certain taxpayers may no longer use the prior-year safe harbor. Generally, estimates will have to be based on current income for taxpayers who meet all of the following conditions:
* Their adjusted gross income exceeds $75,000, or $37,500 if married and filing separately.
* Their adjusted gross income increased by more than $40,000 over the previous year, or $20,000 if married and filing separately.
* They made estimated payments for any of the preceding three tax years or were penalized for their failure to do so.
Matthew R. Rosenberg, senior tax partner of Anchin Block & Anchin in New York, said he foresaw "an administrative nightmare for closely held family businesses," in getting accurate figures by midyear. Suppose, for example, a garment maker is owed money by a department store that later files for bankruptcy protection.
He is advising clients like family businesses and musicians to get records into better shape now.
Barry Salzberg, a partner in Deloitte & Touche, said, "I see a lot of problems with my client base," many of whom are in partnerships. Both tax experts predicted that some people would have to pay penalties because the necessary data would not be available, or the penalty would be less than the bookkeeping overtime needed.

HEADLINE: Mortgage Rates Fall to 8.24%

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP)

 BODY:
Average interest charged on 30-year fixed-rate mortgages has dropped to its lowest level in more than 18 years, according to a national survey released today.
Fixed rates this week averaged 8.24 percent, down from 8.35 percent the previous week, the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation said. It was the lowest since rates averaged 8.18 percent during the week ending July 27, 1973. 
 On one-year adjustable-rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 5.94 percent, down from 6.02 percent a week earlier and the lowest since the corporation, known as Fredie Mac, began tracking these types of mortgages in 1984.
Freddie Mac, reporting on 15-year mortgages for the first time, said they averaged 7.79 percent.
Mortgage rates have been falling since the spring but were given an added shove Dec. 20 when the Federal Reserve announced a one percentage point reduction in its discount rate, the rate it charges on loans to banks.
Economists are expecting the lowest mortgage rates in nearly a generation to spur a revival of home sales. The cuts have already motivated millions of homeowners to refinance existing mortgages.

HEADLINE: Junk Mail to Throw Into the Nearest VCR

BYLINE: By BARRY MEIER

 BODY:
As some companies scramble to generate sales, consumers are increasingly seeing high-tech forms of advertising -- videotapes and computer disks that promote products, including some that are mailed to consumers' homes.
Last September, for example, some newsstand copies of Elle magazine came with a videocassette that contained a two-and-a-half minute commercial for Spellbound, a perfume made by Estee Lauder. And for Christmas, the Hartmarx Corporation, the Chicago clothing manufacturer and retailer, mailed videotaped catalogues to the homes of some 150,000 customers. 
 These high-tech approaches to direct advertising are still relatively new. For one thing, they have been far more expensive than printed catalogues. But with many companies struggling in the recession, some are willing to gamble on novel strategies.
"It's so different that some companies figure that maybe it will work," said Lisa Caugherty, a spokeswoman for the Direct Marketing Association, a trade group in New York City.
With videocassette recorders in 71 percent of American homes and with growing numbers of personal computers, this new approach to marketing becomes more attractive. But like junk mail, much of it will also be thrown away.
In recent years, high-tech marketing has taken several forms. Some companies, like Spiegel, have sold videotapes about fashion through their catalogues as a means of promoting clothing sales. Others, like Compaq Computer, have mailed prospective customers informational disks for personal computers promoting new computers.
Toyota the maker of Lexus, has been among the most frequent users of direct videotape advertising. In 1989, just before the Lexus went on the market, thousands of tapes on the new cars were mailed out to car enthusiasts, said Ann Pollack, the Lexus product marketing manager.
That promotion was so successful that last year the company sent videotapes featuring new models to thousands of potential customers before any publicity about them appeared elsewhere, Ms. Pollack said. The idea behind these six-minute programs was to entice consumers into showrooms when the new cars arrived, Ms. Pollack said.
 
$1 Million for Hartmarx Video
 The Hartmarx videotape, "A Perfect Picture for Christmas," showed a large family around a Christmas with each person wearing clothing from Hartmarx. It cost about $1 million to produce, which the company said was not much more than its printed Christmas catalogue. The video catalogue was sent only to customers who had bought at Hartmarx stores in the past year, the company said.
In terms of packaging, it would be hard to equal Estee Lauder's promotion. The videotape and Elle magazine came in a stiff plastic wrapper. Inside the box holding the tape was more promotional material including a piece of scented cardboard cut in the shape of a perfume bottle and listing prices.
The videotape features stark images of a man and woman intermingled with pictures of crashing waves. The videotape was distributed with Elle magazine at newsstands in 10 cities including New York, Los Angeles and Washington.
A spokeswoman for Estee Lauder said officials were not available this week for interviews about the promotion. But in a news release in August, Robin Burns, the company president, said the videotape was an effort to reach potential customers at home. "She can smell the fragrance via a scented blotter and make her selection at the same time she is enjoying the fantasy and romance of the commercial," the statement said.
Ms. Caugherty of the direct marketing group said the Hartmarx promotion had been well received by consumers and that she expected other companies would be trying similar promotions soon.
"Whenever there is a chance to stand out in a consumer's mailbox, it's a plus," she said.

HEADLINE: Credit Reports: The Overhaul Rolls On

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE

 BODY:
After years of increasing consumer complaints about errors in credit reports, invasion of privacy and the cost of obtaining the records, the Federal Government and credit bureaus themselves are finally reacting to the pressure.
Here are some recent developments: 
 *United States Representative Esteban E. Torres, a California Democrat and the chairman of the House subcommittee on consumer affairs, introduced a bill intended to foster more privacy and greater accuracy in the reports. A similar bill is expected to be introduced in the Senate.
*Equifax, one of the three major chains in the $1-billion-a-year industry, has stopped selling personal information from its reports for direct marketing. It has also opened a national center with an "800" number -- (800) 685-1111 -- to answer consumers' questions.
*TRW, another giant chain, has announced that starting April 30, free copies of credit reports will be given annually to all consumers who request them. The company has also settled lawsuits with the Federal Trade Commission and 19 states by agreeing, among other things, to change certain procedures, resulting in easier-to-read reports and disclosure of credit-risk scores used to predict credit worthiness. Despite these settlements, a consumer-fraud lawsuit against TRW by the State of Vermont is still pending.
 
'Fundamental Decision'
 "Credit bureaus have made a fundamental decision that the negative publicity they've been receiving is not good for business," said Elgie Holstein, the director of the Bankcard Holders of America, a nonprofit group in Herndon, Va. "They decided that the only way to forestall truly punitive legislation is to overhaul the way they deal with consumers."
D. Barry Connelly, the executive vice president of Associated Credit Bureaus, the industry's trade association, said that Congress would probably pass a new law amending the 20-year-old Fair Credit Reporting Act.
"We're willing to work toward passage of a piece of legislation that meets the legitimate needs of consumers, while offering a vehicle for the industry to provide quality service," he said. "Our product is built for usage by the credit grantor who pays for it, but it's a misconception to believe that the industry doesn't want the consumer to understand what the report says."
At hearings on the House bill last October, industry representatives gave cautious backing to some of the proposed changes. For example, Oscar Marquis, the vice president and general counsel of the Trans Union Corporation, another major company in the field, said that he supported "the requirement that disputed information be reverified and corrected within 30 days of the time the dispute is received by the credit bureau, in all but the most extraordinary cases."
Credit-bureau experts predict that the Torres bill will reach the floor of the House by spring. A companion measure that Senator Alan J. Dixon, Democrat of Illinois, plans to introduce may come up for discussion even earlier.
"There has to be a review administratively so that we can get the errors fixed," Senator Dixon said. "You don't want the huge Federal bureaucracy to get all over this thing, but we have not yet determined a good, workable plan for that yet."
Until any law is passed, it will largely be up to the credit bureaus to bolster their images among consumers. The move last month by Equifax to establish an information service center, with a toll-free telephone number, is designed to do just that.
"We recognize that the accuracy level could be better," said John A. Baker, a senior vice president. "The purpose of this development is to recognize that consumers are our customers and that we have an obligation to service them with professionalism."
Similarly, TRW broke ranks with the rest of the industry with an offer of free credit reports to anyone who asks for one. (The company has not yet announced the address.) A report now typically costs $15 to $20, except in the four states that have limits: California at $8, Connecticut at $10, Maine at $2 and Maryland at $5.
"The current rates are outrageous," said Mary J. Culnan, an associate professor at Georgetown University's business school. "It costs the credit bureaus a couple of bucks to put them out, and they should be sold at cost."
 
$7.50 Maximum
 TRW's settlement with the F.T.C. and the states sets a maximum fee of $7.50, adjusted each year for inflation, for copies of credit reports. What this means is that by April 30, TRW will offer one free report every year and additional copies for no more than $7.50 each.
"We wanted to involve consumers in the credit-granting system," said Susan Murdy, a TRW spokeswoman. "This makes them an active partner with us."
An annual check of your credit-bureau records is a good idea, particularly when it's free. But since the Big Three may have different information about you in their files, you would have to check with each company to be sure that no inaccuracies have crept in. Local numbers can be found in the Yellow Pages, usually under "Credit Reporting Agencies."
The F.T.C. is still seeking more enforcement powers over credit bureaus, including the authority to impose civil penalties for violations. And Vermont is still pressing its own suit against TRW, alleging the use of false and misleading credit reports.
In New York City, the Department of Consumer Affairs has reported that 35 percent of the credit-reporting agencies in the city disregard Federal law by making it easy to get unauthorized copies of someone else's credit file. Much of the criticism has been focused on middlemen, or resellers, who buy credit information from the Big Three and sell it to others. Some of these reports find their way to unauthorized users.
"Dealing in personal financial data calls for vigilance, not velocity," said Mark Green, Consumer Affairs Commissioner. "As computers get more sophisticated, some of our most intimate information is passed around to strangers more quickly and more widely and more cheaply than ever."

HEADLINE: ON PRO HOCKEY;
What's Up Inside the Rinks and With Outside Issues

BYLINE: By Joe Lapointe

 BODY:
A survey of hockey's wintry landscape shows everything heating up. It is a busy and interesting time for legal matters, for trades and trade talk and for the intriguing National Hockey League race at the halfway point.
Behind the scenes, the issue is pension money involving the league and its players association. 
 In Camden, N.J., a Federal judge refused to dismiss a lawsuit against the league by several former players over the disposition of funds. A similar suit is under way in Toronto and the league thought one was enough. The judge thought otherwise.
In Boston, the Federal Bureau of Investigation is looking into broader matters of the union under the leadership of Alan Eagleson, who has been replaced as executive director by Bob Goodenow. All this comes while Goodenow tries to negotiate a new collective-bargaining agreement with the team owners to replace the one that expired on Sept. 15.
No strike deadline has been set or even threatened, although the start of the Stanley Cup playoffs in April marks the point when players will have earned most of their wages and owners will begin to harvest much of their profit.
Until then, the 22 league teams will scramble for 16 post-season berths. The second quarter of the season saw Washington and Vancouver maintain their first-place status but fall back to the pack after bursting ahead in the first six weeks. Two old-line clubs, Detroit and the Rangers, gained the most ground in the second 20-game segment of this 75th anniversary season.
The Red Wings, with three balanced scoring lines, lead the Norris Division, where Chicago and St. Louis have suddenly slid to mediocrity.
Detroit's Nicklas Lidstrom, a defenseman from Sweden, is a strong candidate for rookie of the year. His plus/minus rating of plus-23 is tied for third-best in the league. Brett Hull leads the Blues and the league with 38 goals, but St. Louis isn't what it was last season.
The Rangers, with a second-quarter surge, seem so improved behind Mark Messier and Brian Leetch, who may be approaching his prime as an attacking defenseman. Still, this team is only 4 points better than it was at the same juncture last season.
Can Messier stay fresh and reverse the recent Ranger trend of fading in the stretch? Will General Manager Neil (rhymes with "deal") Smith attempt another blockbuster trade?
A make-it-or-break-it team for the second half is the Boston Bruins, whose .500 play can be excused by the absence of Cam Neely until Thursday night and the newness of Coach Rick Bowness.
Neely, a Messieric presence, returned Thursday night after recovering from a severe thigh injury suffered last spring. The Bruins made a big trade Thursday, sending Gary Galley and Wes Walz to Philadelphia for Gord Murphy, Brian Dobbin and a draft choice.
Bowness has been feuding with some of his players. If this trade and the return of Neely don't spark an improvement, look for more changes on the roster or behind the bench. Boston management isn't in the habit of finishing .500. Although second in the Adams, the Bruins remain 15 points behind the Montreal Canadiens, who cruise along in disciplined, dispassionate fashion.
They are so unlike the hot-headed Sabres, who pile up the penalty minutes and cling to fourth place only because Quebec brings up the near rear, just 3 points back.
Newly arrived star center Pat LaFontaine says newly arrived Coach John Muckler now wants to make the Sabres more of a skating, freewheeling team, the way the Oilers were when Muckler coached in Edmonton. It's a good idea, but hard to accomplish during the season.
In the Patrick, Scotty Bowman's Penguins are starting to play like defending Stanley Cup champions, despite two consecutive losses to the Devils. They lead the league in goals with 186. On the other hand, only four teams have given up more than their 149. With the death of Coach Bob Johnson and the sale of the franchise in recent weeks, they have been the league's most newsworthy team off ice and the most fun to watch on it, especially on the power play.
Another team in this category for the coming quarter might be the Devils, an equal-opportunity employer who must be putting "help wanted" ads in Russian newspapers. They just signed their fourth former member of the Soviet national team. (Will Viktor Tikhonov take over for Tom McVie?)
Things aren't as lively in the Smythe, where the sluggish, fourth-place Los Angeles Kings typify a divisionwide recession. The Winnipeg Jets hold second place with a .500 record and the Edmonton Oilers, a point behind Los Angeles, have a way of sneaking up from back in the pack and peaking for the playoffs.
Calgary began a housecleaning by sending Doug Gilmour to Toronto in Thursday's 10-man deal. But the most interesting team in this bunch has been the expansion San Jose Sharks, and only for their novelty value.
Keeping them company at the bottom of the league are the Islanders, the Maple Leafs and Quebec. What do the Leafs and the Islanders have in common? Both have general managers who developed sparkling reputations in the 1980's. Now, it's 1992 for Cliff Fletcher and Bill Torrey. Is it later than they think?
After signing Grant Fuhr to a long-term contract, Fletcher now hears his goalie rip the efforts of his teammates. After trading two of his longtime stars, Torrey sees his roster filled with new faces and his record worse than it was last season at this time. New ownership might not be the only change in the pipeline at Nassau Coliseum.
And shouldn't something change at the Colisee in Quebec, where the Nordiques' owner, Marcel Aubut, holding the rights to the reluctant Lindros, acts like the dog in the manger?
If the Nordiques still have a chance to make the playoffs when Lindros gets back from the Olympics, a major deal (attention, Neil Smith) could rearrange the league map for the fourth quarter and make at least two teams much better.
