HEADLINE: Seaman Furniture Files Chapter 11

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE

 BODY:
The Seaman Furniture Company, a Kohlberg, Kravis & Roberts leveraged buyout and the largest furniture retailer in the Northeast, filed yesterday for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. The company cited a "severe and prolonged recession" in its markets.
The company, based in Uniondale, L.I., said that it would close 15 of its 37 stores and that more than 300 of its 1,300 employees would lose their jobs. 
 Yesterday's filing in Federal Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan results from two trends: an economic downturn that has been particularly hard on retailers, especially in the Northeast, and the continued unwinding of the leveraged buyout spree of the last decade.
In its filing, the company said it had liabilities of $363.7 million and assets of $141.3 million as of Oct. 31. The Christmas season was unlikely to have improved the situation, since it is generally a slow time for furniture retailers, with few shoppers making such major purchases during the holiday season.
Seaman is the second Kohlberg, Kravis buyout to file for bankruptcy protection. While Seaman is a relatively small holding in the firm's portfolio, the filing tarnishes Kohlberg, Kravis's reputation for finding profits in the financial transformation of mundane companies. In early 1990, the Hillsborough Holdings Corporation, a company formed to acquire Jim Walter, a large building-materials company in Tampa, Fla., also filed for bankruptcy protection.
Seaman has aimed to sell high volumes of low-priced furniture through the help of its aggressive television advertisements. But it has had a history of problems since it was taken private in 1988 in a $360 million deal.
In late 1989, Seaman said it could not meet its principal and interest payments. Its senior lenders and bondholders agreed to accept large losses in return for a larger equity position in the company.
At that time, Kohlberg, Kravis's ownership fell from 80 percent to 37 percent, and the firm's investors had to put in an additional $28 million. The company's banks, led by the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation, acquired nearly one-third of the company in return for forgiving more than $100 million in debt and agreeing to defer principal payments until 1992.
Despite this, the company has been unable to turn a profit while servicing a remaining debt burden of about $310 million. In the first quarter, which ended July 31, 1991, Seaman's reported a net loss of $6.4 million, compared with a net loss of $1.2 million in all of 1990.
"We want to restructure the company, under the supervision of the court, to a debt level that the business can support," said Matthew D. Serra, Seaman's chief executive. "The reason for the filing is the prolonged downturn in sales. It's been much longer than we've expected.
Seaman executives calculated yesterday that a more manageable debt burden for the company might be in the neighborhood of $20 million.
 
Expression of Optimism
 Mr. Serra remained optimistic about Seaman's prospects. He said that the 22 stores to remain open contributed about 80 percent of the company's volume. He added that four of the stores to be shut had already been scheduled to close. With the cutbacks, the company will withdraw entirely from the Philadelphia area.
Scott M. Sperling, a partner at the Harvard Management Company, which has invested with Kohlberg, Kravis since 1982, said the bankruptcy filing "isn't good news from the perspective of the value of the Seaman's equity." But he said the filing was a "rational and prudent reaction" to the difficult retailing environment and the company's debt burden.
"Seaman's obviously had problems because of the amount of debt it took on, and therefore it has been more vulnerable than other retailers might be," Mr. Sperling said.
To support its operations during reorganization, Seaman has obtained a $25 million commitment from the GE Capital Corporation, the financing arm of the General Electric Company. Such loans to a company already in bankruptcy reorganization usually receive priority in repayment. Seaman will use the money to pay suppliers and vendors. "It will help us run the business in terms of working capital and meeting all our financial needs," Mr. Serra said.
Seaman's largest unsecured creditors include Credit Agricole of France, with $21.9 million; National Westminster Bank of Britain, $18.76 million; First Bank National Association of Minneapolis, $17.5 million; Nippon Credit Bank of Japan, $12.9 million; National Australia Bank Ltd., $7.75 million; town of Islip (L.I.) Industrial Development Agency, $5.5 million, and the Saudi International Bank, $5.169 million.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Store-closing signs in the window of a Seaman's Furniture store in Philadelphia yesterday after the company filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection and said it would withdraw from the Philadelphia market. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Letter: On Research;
Utilizing Former Soviet Scientists

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Forget Dr. No" (editorial, Dec. 22) correctly calls attention to the major problem of the future of the scientists of the former Soviet Union. But to suggest that Western governments and foundations support scientific work inside the former Soviet Union is dead wrong! 
 First of all, it will not work. "A Soviet (Russian) Academy Is Adrift" (news article, Dec. 14) cited the extensive emigration of hundreds of the best scientists. Giving funds to the laboratories of the defunct Soviet Academy of Sciences may well result in support of mediocre or politically favored work. To assure proper use of Western funds, an army of Western scientists would be needed. Talented scientists in Eastern Europe, India, China, Pakistan (to name a few regions) are also underemployed and are potential candidates to be attracted to "rogue" projects in bandit nations like Iraq.
The United States would do far better to reverse the downslide of support for employment of trained scientists in this country: (1) by a major increase of funding for basic and applied research in American universities; (2) by increasing the opportunities for permanent and visiting positions in major national laboratories such as Brookhaven, Argonne, Los Alamos; (3) by giving governmental tax write-offs for private industrial research laboratories.
All these mechanisms were used after World War II with great success, resulting in uncountable patents, in creation of new industries such as electronics, and in other major achievements.
Yes, save Soviet scientists! Have them come here and join American scientists to solve the nation's and the world's pressing technical problems -- such as the need for renewable energy sources, for the immunization and cure of AIDS, for weather prediction, for preservation of the global environment. But don't throw good money into a decaying and chaotic bureaucracy that has outlived its usefulness!
 
JOSEPH L. BIRMAN
Distinguished Professor of Physics, City College, CUNY
New York, Dec. 22, 1991

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter; Editorial

HEADLINE: Environmentalists Get Little Corporate Aid

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Contrary to your Dec. 23 report that environmentalists are seeking corporate gifts, the Wilderness Society is not about to lay off any employees. There were some layoffs in 1991, but in the last month we have added two ecologists and two resource economists. Our financial picture is improving, not worsening. 
 Indeed, our situation does not support your thesis. The funds we receive from businesses, primarily from the Timberland Company, amount to just 1 percent of our budget. That hardly makes us vulnerable should Timberland decide to pull out.
Moreover, Timberland is much less likely to do so than a company like General Electric, which is ending its backing of the National Audubon Society. Timberland's executives are committed advocates for the protection of natural environments.
At the Wilderness Society, we will not take funds from companies whose interests are at odds with our guiding philosophy of public lands protection. Otherwise, we welcome help from the business world, though we suspect that the vast majority of our support will continue to come, as it has for the last 55 years, from our members.
Finally, there is no basis for saying the 10 largest environmental groups have become "political action enterprises." Yes, environmental groups advocate certain legislation, but most of us are limited by tax law to devoting only a small percentage of our budgets to such activity, and we stay below that ceiling. Most important, we do not engage in election campaigns.
 
GEORGE T. FRAMPTON JR.
President, Wilderness Society
Washington, Dec. 23, 1991

HEADLINE: Cold War Static On Fiber Optics

BYLINE: By Antony J. Blinken; Antony J. Blinken is the author of "Ally Versus Ally: America, Europe and the Siberian Pipeline Crisis."

 BODY:
In a hangover of the cold war, the Bush Administration is continuing an embargo on the sale of sophisticated telecommunications technology to the former Soviet Union. This misguided policy prevents American companies from helping the Russians when they really need it and making a buck at the same time.
Washington's error became embarrassingly clear -- and costly -- when a German company, using a loophole in the trade restriction, recently sold high-speed fiber-optic cable to Moscow at the expense of an American manufacturer, U S West. Unless the Administration rescinds the embargo, it risks putting the U.S. telecommunications industry at a competitive disadvantage in its effort to capture a huge market. 
 The ban on the export of high-speed fiber-optic cable is administered by something called the Coordinating Committee on Multilateral Export Controls, whose members are the NATO countries minus Iceland, plus Australia and Japan.
When the East bloc collapsed, Western European nations and U.S. manufacturers successfully pressed Washington to eliminate many of the committee's restrictions. But despite intensive lobbying, Bush Administration officials refused to lift controls on high-speed fiber-optic cable, the bulwark of a modern telecommunications system.
The National Security Agency, the leading opponent of telecommunications exports to the former Soviet Union, believes that uncertainty and instability in the republics justifies this decision. If one or more of the independent republics turns hostile to Western interests, the agency reasons, the wiretap-proof fiber optics would make them more potent adversaries. As evidence, officials cite our inability to eavesdrop on Mr. Hussein's fiber-optic command and control system in the gulf war.
But the National Security Agency isn't all-powerful, and the U.S. can't prevent countries that don't belong to the export committee from selling their own fiber-optic technology to Moscow or Kiev or wherever. The German sale just before Christmas makes the point. Carl Zeiss Jena, the company in the deal, is based in what used to be East Germany, and is not bound by Western rules, which exempt Eastern European companies that did business with the Soviet Union in the past.
In any case, a fiber-optic network in the new commonwealth may be in our security interest. With the disintegration of the Soviet Union, a central nuclear command with modern communications could better prevent the misuse of nuclear weapons by the new states. It also makes sense for a U.S. company to build the Soviet network since that company would know where the cables are buried and how they are used.
Russian technology is on the brink of developing its own fiber-optic cable. "The bottom line is that technology moves forward," said Ed Mattix, a spokesman for U S West, whose plans to manufacture a $500 million trans-Soviet line with French, British, German and Korean partners were put on ice by the export committee. U S West is continuing to negotiate with the Russians, hoping that the export committee will reverse its policy.
Beyond dollars and common sense, a larger point is at issue. To build a stable democracy in an atmosphere of economic crisis, modernizing an archaic infrastructure, including a hopelessly outmoded telecommunications system, is one of the first tasks at hand. By doing what we can to promote a functioning economy in the new commonwealth, we help prevent a return to authoritarianism.
Economic embargoes that assume a possible revival of a threat in the former empire are ineffective at best, and costly to American business. At worst, they perpetuate the economic chaos on which authoritarian leaders feed. By selling fiber optics in and among the republics, it's a good bet that we can help them and, in so doing, help ourselves.

HEADLINE: A Growing Leadership Role for Women

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY

 BODY:
WHEN Dorcas T. Helfant took her first job selling homes in a small real estate office in Portsmouth, Va., in the mid-60's, she was the only person on the sales team who wore a skirt.
"I was surrounded by men in my first sales job," said Mrs. Helfant, speaking from the vantage point of nearly 25 years in the residential brokerage business. 
 Today she has plenty of female company. Nearly half of those working in residential sales are women. In the last decade, the ranks of women in brokering, ownership and management positions have swelled.
Now her election as the first woman to head the 83-year-old National Association of Realtors, an 800,000-member organization, is coming as a symbol of the rise of women to leadership positions as the heads of real-estate businesses. Mrs. Helfant owns a brokerage business in Virginia Beach, Va. She took office as president of the realtors' association in November.
"Women have been doing well in residential sales for a long time," said Mrs. Helfant. "But one of the changes I have seen is that we do not view sales as just a way to make money; many more women have an entrepreneurial attitude about the business."
It took changes in attitudes about women in business, as well as the statutory clout of civil rights legislation, for women to start moving into ownership and management in significant numbers. Women leveled the playing field in sales by proving they were as capable as their male colleagues at handling the technical, financial and legal aspects of real estate transactions.
Despite the gains, the market's tumble of the last few years has left many companies, including those owned by women, treading water. Some offices have survived by cutting the sizes of their sales and management staffs, others by diversifying the services they offer. More sales outfits in New York City and its suburbs are depending on fees from rental transactions or management services to bolster sagging sales commissions.
In real estate sales the first rung of the ladder is that of sales agent. Licenses are required for anyone working as a sales agent, which is the stepping stone to brokering.
Brokers are professionals who have taken additional course work and passed more stringent state licensing requirements. A broker's license is required of anyone who handles a real estate transaction or owns a real estate sales business. But but not all of the people who hold brokers' licenses use them to maintain businesses. The N.A.R. says that while in the past the term broker was synonymous with owner, today about half of its members holding brokers' licenses hold ownership interests in businesses.
Surveys by the N.A.R. of its members show women making numerical as well as proportionate gains in sales and brokering. In 1975, fewer than 4 out of 10 full-time sales agents were women. By 1987, the date of the most recent survey, two-thirds of the people working full-time as sales agents were women.
BETWEEN 1975 and 1987, the proportion of member women working as brokers rose from 18 percent to more than 36 percent of the N.A.R.'s membership.
In 1975, women brokers earned 60 percent of what men did -- $15,000, compared to $25,000. By 1987, women were earning 75 percent of what men did. The average was $30,000 for women to $40,000 for men.
Although the N.A.R. has no similar comparative statistics that would show an increase in the percentage of women who own or are partners in real estate sales businesses, there is little doubt that the numbers have expanded. In a 1990 survey made by the Women's Council of N.A.R., 28 percent of the members said they have ownership interests in brokerage businesses.
But these gains in the home-sales field are not reflected in all the many aspects of real estate. On the commercial side, including the development, leasing, selling and managing of office and other investment properties, women are a still a distinct minority. Nor have they become prominent in residential construction.
"When I started in 1978 there were no women to have lunch with," said Jamie Covello, a rental space broker and director with Cushman & Wakefield, the largest brokerage company in Manhattan. "There are now other women in all aspects of commercial even though we are still few in number."
Ms. Covello said the door to commercial brokering opened for women during the surge in office development in Manhattan in the early 1980's.
Once inside, many did very well.
"The demands of the economy made the business much more intellectual, less macho," she said. "That was an advantage to us."
Cushman & Wakefield refused to say how many women in the company work as brokers or property managers.
Some of the women who came in during the office market boom, Ms. Covello said, were the first casualties of its downward slide.
"Some women left when the demand for space dried up," she said.
The shrinking market in both residential sales and commercial leasing and development have cut the numbers of people in every segment of the industry. In New York state, for example, more than 37,000 sales agents and brokers appear to have have dropped out of the business in the last two years. The number of sales agent licenses held by the New York Department of State, the licensing authority, fell from 117,096 to 83,971 between 1989 and 1991.
Brokers left the business, too. In November 1989, the Department of State reported 45,104 licensed brokers. By 1991, there were 41,042.
EVEN though most brokerage offices do not pay salaries -- sales-agent income overwhelmingly is commission-only -- for the owners of the business the expenses can be considerable. Operating costs such as rent, supplies and equipment as well as fees for multiple listing service membership and support-staff wages must be met no matter what the commission income is in a given month.
While some have thrown in the towel, others have survived if not thrived.
Manhattan has seen a half dozen real estate office merge or go under. Many of those remaining include some headed by women among them Donna Olshan, Adrienne Albert, Susan W. Bird and Barbara Corcoran.
Audrey Short, owner of Audrey Short Companies, a Realty World franchise, in Princeton, N.J., said her 1991 business was 15 percent ahead of 1990's. The Short office had 119 transactions in 1990 and 144 in 1991.
"People are still buying and selling," said Mrs. Short, "but today they are doing it not because they want to, but because they have to."
The growth of Mrs. Short's business to the point where she now runs a sales force of 20 agents illustrates the career paths that women have taken in recent years. She hung out her shingle on Nassau Street, Princeton's picturesque commercial strip, in 1971. Back then Princeton University and Johnson & Johnson in nearby New Brunswick were the area's largest employers.
But beginning in the late 1970's, Princeton planted the seeds for growth by offering up to1,600 acres of university-owned land to lease for private development. Other property owners followed Princeton's lead and corporate office parks, shopping centers and hotels sprouted along Route 1 there.
The economic boom blew up a fair wind for Audrey Short's sails.
"This area became hot," said Mrs. Short. "Companies like I.B.M., Exxon and Prudential started moving in."
And with them came home-buying employees. By 1984, Mrs. Short said, her sales force was selling homes from Raritan Bay to the Delaware River. She opened an office in East Brunswick to handle the added business.
Today many of the same companies that expanded in the 1980's are now retrenching. To accommodate the economy's change, Mrs. Short has changed tack; her bread and butter these days comes from relocation transactions.
Working through the corporate relocation departments of companies, brokerage companies handle not only sales but they also take care of the homes waiting to be sold in exchange for the listing. That usually includes paying mortgages, taxes and utility bills as well as arranging for repairs and re-painting as it is needed.
But even companies that have managed to state afloat, say business is harder.
Faye Radin, a broker for more than 20 years, started her own business, Rand Realty, on Staten Island in 1983 when the borough was feeling the ripples of the boom years on Wall Street just across the harbor. But from a high of 12 full-time sales agents and brokers in 1986, the office now has four selling full time and two part-time sales people.
Recently the office relocated to less expensive space, and these days the transactions also include land sales, commercial deals and rentals as well as home sales. Mrs. Radin said that it takes more work to make a sale than it did a few years ago.
"These days it counts to be known in the community," said Mrs. Radin. "Referrals are important. This is when networking and civic involvement pays off."
Despite overall sluggish sales, the industry is still attracting some newcomers. Denise Jacobs, relocated from Wall Street, joined Rand Realty last year. Ms. Jacobs job as a financial manager was eliminated by the company she had worked for more than seven years.
"I have found that my background in finance has helped me," said Ms. Jacobs, who is near to closing her fourth sale since July. "And the cliches about working for yourself are true."
Not all brokers or salespeople see owning a brokerage business as a career zenith. For many there is enough challenge and commission income in sales work alone. The N.A.R. says that one in 10 earn $100,000 a year or more.
If the market downturn has been something of a litmus test for the industry, some professionals, including Mrs. Helfant, feel the repercussions have not been only negatives. The bad times have forced many sales people and the brokers they work for to rely on some of the skills that may have gotten rusty during the boom times.
"SUCCESS is determined less today by the forces of the market and more by the hard work, energy and enthusiasm of the sales person or broker," she said.
"Times are tougher, but it is still possible to do well."
Mrs. Helfant when brokers and sales people bemoan the market, she tells the story of her own shaky start in the business.
"Times are tough," she said. "But I do not know many people who work for nearly a year before making a sale. But I did."
So disheartened, that she nearly quit to take a job at Sears.
But five deals came through in month 12 and the Sears personnel department never saw her again.
One of Mrs. Helfant's goals while president of the N.A.R. is to establish a mechanism for attracting more young people -- especially women -- into the field. The Woman's Council, says the median age of its members is 49 years.
"Women have many choices today," she said. "and real estate still tends to be the second or third career. I would like to see that change."

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: Saratoga Square;
New Site for Houses

 BODY:
Three years ago, in accepting City Hall's plan to house several hundred homeless people in the area between Bedford-Stuyvesant and Ocean Hill-Brownsville, Borough President Howard Golden of Brooklyn insisted on a broader solution to the crisis.
"What we were trying to push for was a neighborhood approach," Mr. Golden's executive assistant, Marilyn Gelber, said last week. "Yes, we'd approve a considerable number of homeless units but it was more important that it be part of a balanced plan." 
 Now working its way through city review is the second part of the overall plan for the Saratoga Square urban renewal area, bounded roughly by Atlantic Avenue and Bainbridge Street, Ralph and Rockaway Avenues.
The project, which Ms. Gelber said has already been approved by Community Boards 3 and 16, involves the construction of 376 two-family, owner-occupied homes, sponsored by the New York City Housing Partnership, in a program jointly administered with the city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development. An additional 555 units are to be rehabilitated in some 116 existing buildings.
"It's an interesting area because it really hasn't had any private investment for several decades," said Kathryn Wylde, president of the partnership, "so this will be opening up a new homeownership community."
Using a portion of the city's capital budget that is under his power to allocate, Mr. Golden is earmarking $10,000 a unit for the new construction. That is added to city and Federal subsidies of $25,000 a unit. The goal, Ms. Wylde said, is to bring the purchase price within the range of families with annual incomes as low as $25,000.

HEADLINE: Talking: Small Co-ops;
Shopping Around to Refinance

BYLINE: By ANDREE BROOKS

 BODY:
IT'S always difficult for a New York City co-op in a brownstone or other structure with less than 20 shareholders to find a lender willing to refinance the underlying mortgage, especially for under $500,000.
Even in the best of times -- which these are not -- most bankers shun such loans. 
 "There's very little money in them," said Bernard G. Walpin, an Upper West Side lawyer who helps co-ops with refinancing difficulties. This is because the documentation needed to process such a loan is as cumbersome for a few thousand dollars as it is for a few million.
Marcie Waterman, a Manhattan lawyer specializing in co-ops, said bankers have also shied away because the risk is spread over relatively few families. They have argued that it increases the danger of default, especially in a softer market where the shareholder with financial problems cannot extricate himself easily and quickly by selling.
What should the small co-op do?
Harry Avradinis, president of NYM Capital Group of Manhattan, mortgage brokers, warned that the single most detrimental move would be to wait until a few months before the refinancng deadline. Options will become more limited and it could jeopardize the resale potential of all the units.
Buyers, he noted, are usually advised by their lawyers to steer clear of any co-op that must seek refinancing within a year for fear that the new terms could make maintenance payments prohibitively expensive.
Waiting in the hope that interest rates will drop even lower could be equally foolhardy, Mr. Avrandinis said. Smaller co-ops have traditionally been charged higher interest and origination charges because the loan is viewed as riskier.
The process should start, say these experts, by comparing options. These might include finding out how much it might cost to stay with the same lender (who may become the lender of last resort), seeking other lenders that might take on the loan to compare rates and terms and even analyzing what it might cost to simply retire all or part of the balance by assessing each shareholder for a proportionate amount -- as a seven-unit brownstone in the East 70's recently did.
The small co-op will need to compile the kind of documentation and financial analysis that may be difficult for a lay board to do without professional help. Thus, experts suggest hiring a mortgage broker to find a lender (usually a small neighborhood bank or private investor), prepare the papers and negotiate on its behalf. The broker should be able to demonstrate that he or she has obtained similar loans within the last year, since the highly specialized small co-op market tends not to be fully understood by all mortgage brokers.
A recommendation from a lawyer or accountant familiar with small co-ops is one way to find such a broker. Referrals can also be made by the Council of New York Cooperatives (497-7400). The fee charged by the broker is customarily 1 percent of the loan amount plus origination charges imposed by the lender. Occasionally a slightly lower flat fee can be negotiated.
Patrick Niland, a mortgage broker and principal with First Funding Group of Rochester, N.Y., said the small co-op must get its financial house in order before approaching anyone. Lenders, he said, tend to scrutinize the financial profile of individual shareholders far more closely than in larger co-ops. Thus the board should make sure everyone's credit rating is relatively clean.
"If there's a problem with one or two shareholders, they need to have an explanation ready," he said, "such as pointing out that the person is going through a divorce. Or somehow show that they are clearing the matter up."
THE board will also need to compile all pertinent papers to show that the co-op is truly creditworthy, he said. This will include a solid record of on-time maintenance collections and payments on the existing underlying mortgage, maintenance payments that have kept pace with increased costs rather than being subsidized by a reserve fund and a full complement of owners rather than one or two units still owned by a sponsor.
Mr. Walpin favors negotiating with the sponsor for an extension of the term if he still owns the underlying loan -- a strong possibility in small co-ops. "If you've been paying promptly, it's a good deal for him," said Mr. Walpin. "Sometimes you can even get him to make a concession or two on the rates."
If the loan needed is only around $100,000 it might be less costly to look for an alternative solution, since hardly a bank in the city will even consider such a low sum. Moreover, those that do charge origination costs that may be excessive in relation to the loan amount. National Bank of New York -- one bank making underlying loans of this size -- charges about $6,500, not including mortgage recording taxes of 2 percent, which may or may not be due depending on how the mortgage is being structured.
Thus, several co-ops are deciding instead to divide the amount among each shareholder, turning it into a special assessment. Steven Allen, a board member at 413 East 85th Street, a nine-unit brownstone, said his co-op is considering such a move. He argued that it would allow maintenance costs to drop and values to rise, thus not really costing shareholders too much more.
Stuart Bruck, a mortgage broker with Time Equities, the real estate concern, added that if one or two shareholders couldn't afford such a charge -- or qualify for an individual loan for the amount -- the total could be redivided among the remaining shareholders with the missing shareholders paying higher maintenance charges to cover their portion of debt service.
Sheldon Gartenstein, vice president of The National Cooperative Bank, another lender actively writing co-op loans under $500,000, has found that many smaller co-ops have become so fed up with the costs and difficulties associated with regularly refinancing the underlying mortgage they increasingly opt for self-liquidating terms.
As an example he said that a $400,000 loan at 9.5 percent would cost a co-op $4,177 a month to liquidate in 15 years. By contrast the co-op would still be paying $3,167 a month if it decided to pay interest only for the first five years and partially amortize the principal for the remainding ten years. Moreover, there would still be an outstanding balance of $334,700 at the end of the 15-year term. Thus, paying an extra $1,000 a month spread over all shareholders can be a far better deal.

HEADLINE: ART;
A Show That Evokes the Spirit and Principles of Kwanzaa

BYLINE: By VIVIEN RAYNOR

DATELINE: NEWARK

 BODY:
DR. MAULANA KARENGA is chairman of the black studies department on the Long Beach campus of California State University. His fame derives not from this, however, but from his having instituted the celebration of Kwanzaa, in 1966. The word is Swahili and denotes the fruits of the harvest; the holiday, which is not yet in the American calendar, lasts from Dec. 26 to Jan. 1.
By all accounts Kwanzaa is celebrated by eating, gift-giving, music, events like the recent Holiday Expo '91 at Manhattan Community College and, last but not least, the show here at Aljira. As this demonstrates, Kwanzaa is not another field day for Mammon. It is, rather, an opportunity for people of African descent to focus on principles vital to their survival with self-esteem. There are seven of these: unity (Umoja), self-determination (Kujichagulia), collective work and responsibililty (Ujima), cooperative economics (Ujamaa), purpose (Nia), creativity (Kuumba) and faith (Imani). 
 As Carl Hazlewood, Aljira's curator, has said, the works in the show don't illustrate the principles so much as evoke them. For outsiders, it is a matter of being primed to look for them, and because the art itself is a distraction, the search is at best sporadic. Though Mr. Hazlewood says this is but a "neighborhood" show, it includes works by established artists and by promising unknowns.
That much abused word, icon, can for once be used accurately to describe an assemblage by Janet Taylor Pickett. One of three, it features a reproduction of a Renaissance Madonna and Child with the faces replaced by photographs of black counterparts, and it is framed by irregular pieces of found wood painted matte black. Most of these assemblages incorporate nails, pushpins, brass-headed tacks and strips cut from tin cans. But in this one, the base metal serves as halo and moon as well as decoration, and it confers a mystical quality inspiring reverence.
The artist performs the same transmutation with three arched washboards -- two with bright metal ribs, one with dull -- cock feathers and hands, two of them photographed in black and white and two cut out of wood and gilded. The whole Byzantine-looking thing is titled "Grandmother's Hands."
Hard by the washboards is Ben Jones's "Shango Series," which seems, at first, no more than a white calligraphic pattern scattered on a black ground with green showing through. Actually, the white shapes, which have African significance, come with barely visible forms -- breasts, a penis -- that are scratched in the black, all of them allusions to the artist's preoccupation with issues like AIDS and socialism.
This painting is preparation for other works that are more than they appear to be. For example, one of Christopher Robinson's pictures is a tribute to Bob Marley, the other a vision of Moses and the Golden Calf. Though they are turbulent statements about color and line, it is easy to disentangle the shapes buried in them -- Marley's outline standing beside a tree, the calf on its back, mouth open.
Still, the piece that requires the most unraveling is the shrine-like installation, a joint effort by Shamba Farrar, and Grace Williams, with Thomas Heath, Pat Phipps, Kalief el Hadji and Taj. Three masked figures sprayed on unstretched canvas preside over objects that include on one side a black doll's head with a collar of feathers mounted on a pedestal wrapped in dime-store mats and, on the other, a cabinet crammed with, among other things, a cross, trinkets and a load of garlic.
On the floor between is a pile of earth and sawdust decorated with salt poured in a line (between this and the garlic, the devil doesn't have a prayer here), together with piles of fruit and ginger root.
Incidentally, the salt lines connect nicely with the white "Kwanzaa" inscribed in the painting of that title by Ujima Kuumba Majied, who took two of the principles for names.
Some color interpreters believe that the choice of yellow denotes a desire for release. "Mickey D's," by Arthur Coppedge, is a solution of chrome yellow in which are suspended the red awning of a McDonald's, a figure in pink at a pay phone, a bus stop and a parking meter. The company doesn't deserve such affectionate tribute; then again, as feeder of billions, , maybe it does.
Dudley Charles, a Guyanan newcomer to the scene, has a technique and color sense so delicate as to defy description. In "Forest Light," he covers the canvas with a low relief of crumpled paper, then glazes it with washes of greens, pinks, lavender and lemon yellow. It is a surface that changes like reflections in water, and though sweet in flavor, it does not cloy.
Gwendolyn Verner's watercolors of still-life harvests, Don Miller's renderings in the same medium of tribal Africa and Richard Gaines's black-and-white painting about men and women complete the group. But this is not the end. In the next-door gallery are 10 paintings by Fausto Sevila, and these, too, are not what seem to be.
In fact, most are erotic images that come on as statements about thick color laid on with abandon and a certain comic flair. One of the best is "Black Bean Soup With Onions in Oil and Vinegar," a vertical stretch of chestnut brown impasto dotted with small black shapes and relieved by occasional touches of emerald green.
Both shows close Jan. 18. Aljira is at 2 Washington Place and is open Wednesday through Sunday from noon to 6 P.M.

HEADLINE: MUSIC;
In Chappaqua, the Revival of a Chamber Group

BYLINE: By ROBERT SHERMAN

 BODY:
CHAMBER MUSIC lovers can look forward to next Saturday at the Chappaqua Library Theater, when the renamed and reorganized Chappaqua Chamber Orchestra performs a revival program.
"Friends of chamber music can mark a joyous event on their calendars," said Mary Rohde, publicity chairwoman of the group. "Both players and former subscribers have been eager for this community orchestra to resume its excellent concerts." 
 Robert Brown, a trustee of the ensemble and a cellist in the larger orchestra for 27 years, added: "We're coming back because of an unexpected but very welcome ground swell from the community. We hope that with an orchestra scaled back to chamber music dimensions, a pleasant hall to play in and an excellent young conductor in James Sadewhite, we can make fine music again and still hold our budget in line."
The move returns the ensemble to its roots as a chamber orchestra, which is how it presented its first concert in February 1959, and as a community group. (Almost everyone involved is a local resident.) The concertmaster, Mary Ann Meade, is from Mahopac; Mark Kusnir, principal of the second violins, is a Stony Pointer. The new maestro is an Irvington resident, and so on. Even the guest soloist at the opening concert, the prize-winning young Taiwanese pianist Hui-Mei Lin, now lives in Pleasantville.
As for this first program -- which begins at 8 P.M. -- it hews to the classically tried and true: Handel's "Entrance of the Queen of Sheba" and two works by Mozart -- the "Prague" Symphony and the Piano Concerto in B flat, K. 450. For reservations, call 273-1633 or 238-8138.
A good reason to return to Pleasantville next Sunday at 3 P.M. is that town's Chamber Music Society, which despite the poor economic climate for the arts, is maintaining its free-admissions policy while continuing to present top-notch ensembles.
The society can also congratulate itself on its talent-discovering, having arranged an appearance three years ago for the fledgling Eroica Trio. Since then, the ensemble has sprung to national prominence, making its New York debut in the eminent Chamber Series at the 92d Street Y, touring successfully from coast to coast and -- as winners of the 1991 Naumburg Competition, perhaps the most prestigious chamber music award in the country -- performing next month at Alice Tully Hall.
For its return to the Pleasantville Presbyterian Church, the Eroica Trio have chosen a fascinating program, with trios of Lalo (a rarity to begin with) and Brahms enclosing the first Westchester hearing of "Angel Chant," composed last year by Augusta Read Thomas. For more information, call 769-1827.
Downtown Music at Grace, the innovative series at Grace Episcopal Church in White Plains, has developed into one of the county's prime outlets for organ music -- both solo and in various instrumental and vocal combinations. The 1992 cycle gets under way Wednesday at 12:30 P.M. with a recital by Stephen Rapp, organist and choirmaster at Christ's Church in Rye. The all-Bach program includes a revision of a Vivaldi concerto, a Sarabande with Partita, two choral preludes and the G minor Prelude and Fugue. Details: 949-2874.
If jazz is more your beat, head across the Hudson to the Rockland Center for the Arts in West Nyack, where Saturday at 8 P.M. the vibraphone-guitar duo of Dave Samuel and Joe Beck will play original tunes along with such American classics as "Body and Soul" and several pieces from the jazz song book of Quincy Jones. For more information, call 358-0877.
The first major vocal concert of 1992 is coming up next Sunday at 3 P.M. in Ossining High School when the Choral Arts Society gathers to perform "King David." The music director, Timothy Vernon, has proclaimed this "the year of the dramatic choral work." Certainly the designation fits Arthur Honegger's brilliantly evocative setting of the biblical story.
The entrance of the Witch of Endor is probably the most riveting moment in the cantata, but the spoken narratives, some beautifully lyric solos and the rousing choral episodes make this one of the most exciting and accessible choral pieces composed in this century.
The actor Barrett Clark (a lifelong Ossining resident) will be the narrator. Linda Lehr portrays the Witch, and the other vocal soloists are Mary McGarvey, Kathleen Shimetz and Vincent Di Benedetto.
Incidentally, the Choral Arts Society welcomes new singers, so those who would like to participate in the May concert (a joint performance of Daniel Pinkham's "Garden Party" with Mr. Vernon's other county group, the Westchester Boys Choir) should call 723-2336.
January is usually a time when most choral ensembles seek to swell their ranks. Among local groups that have sent out membership calls are:
The Master Singers of Westchester, entering its 21st year with a spring program of Haydn and Bach; rehearsals begin tomorrow at 8 P.M. in Bedford's Fox Lane School; 277-5370.
The Taghkanic Chorale, continuing its 25th anniversary season with a March "Choral Masters" program of Mozart, Faure and Handel; first rehearsal: Tuesday 8 P.M. at the Yorktown Community Center; 621-1240.
The Westchester Choral Society, celebrating its golden anniversary in May with a performance of the Verdi Requiem; auditions are from 7 to 7:45 P.M. on the next three Wednesdays of the month at St. Bartholomew's Church in White Plains; 693-2453.
The Pleasantville Cantata Singers, looking ahead to a May program of Bach, Buxtehude and Faure; auditions are scheduled a week from tomorrow and the following Monday, Jan. 20, at the United Methodist Church of Pleasantville; 769-2314, evenings).
It is a bit of a drive, but the concerts of the Hudson Valley Philharmonic are also beckoning, with Bach (and Mozart) Friday at 8 P.M. at the Bardavon Opera House in Poughkeepsie and Saturday at 8 P.M. in the Ulster Performing Arts Center in Kingston. (For information, call 454-1222.)
The orchestra is, in effect, holding on-the-job auditions for the vacant post of music director, and the guest maestro for these concerts is Neal Gittleman, associate conductor of the Milwaukee Symphony. His program will include Bach's Brandenburg Concerto No. 2, Mozart's "Prague" Symphony and Dvorak's Seventh Symphony.

HEADLINE: 'J. F. K.';
A Hollow Catharsis

 BODY:
To the Editor:
It appears to be fashionable these days to expend great quantities of creative energy making bold statements about victimized American citizens. The arts, of course, reflect society in general. A prolonged recession has hurt many of us and has scared the rest. Artistic endeavors like "J. F. K." capitalize on our fears by reinforcing the attitude that we aren't responsible: someone else did it -- we need to get even. Instead of being ennobled by the creative experience, we get a hollow catharsis of anger and defensiveness. It's a cheap substitute. 
 Oliver Stone's descent into polemic reduces his obvious movie making skill to propaganda of the rankest kind. The haze of controversy surrounding "J. F. K." suggests that Mr. Stone may have missed his real story: James Garrison as a good man tempted to evil in a good cause. It's certainly more fascinating than another didactic plunge into conspiracy theory.
 
JOEL DEITCH
Roswell, Ga.

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY;
America's Cup In San Diego

 BODY:
A series of tour packages for yacht racing enthusiasts who plan to attend the America's Cup to be held in San Diego from Jan. 14 to May 23 is being offered by Aerotours International. The programs consist of three nights at the Regency Plaza Hotel in San Diego, a car for four days from Dollar Rent-A-Car (economy class, unlimited mileage), valet parking at the hotel, a one-day pass on the America's Cup viewing vessel and a discount card providing access to several syndicates' compounds and discounts on sightseeing, shopping and local attractions. The card allows two days at SeaWorld, a day at the San Diego Zoo and a one-day cruise to Ensenada, Mexico, aboard the Pacific Star.
Prices for the fly-drive packages are $222 a person from Jan. 14 to March 26; $267, March 27 to April 13; $346, April 14 to 30; $465, May 1 to 24. All prices are based on double occupancy; single supplements are available. AeroTours, which specializes in trips to Australia, organized visits to Perth during the Cup events in 1987.More information: Aerotours, 36 East Third Street, New York, N.Y. 10003; (212) 979-5000 or (800) 223-4555. 
 A brochure outlining various packages with accommodations and race viewing is available from America's Cup Services, Travel, 600 West Broadway, San Diego, Calif. 92101; (800) 922-8792 or (619) 685-1363.

HEADLINE: World Markets;
The Strange Appeal of a Slowdown

BYLINE: By Jonathan Fuerbringer

 BODY:
The pace of investment by those who helped to discover the world's emerging stock markets is slowing down because many of the great bargains, like Latin America, have already been well mined.
According to a survey by Kleiman International Consultants, a majority of institutional investors in these markets said they expect to hold onto their current level of investment in these volatile markets in 1992. Those who plan to increase their share of investment expect it to be at a rate lower than last year. 
 In 1991, investment in emerging markets climbed by an average of 2 percent, to a total of 9.5 percent of all the funds invested in international markets by the firms surveyed. This was down sharply from the jump of 7.5 percent in 1990 and even below the 2.5 percent increase in 1989.
While these investors are slowing down, however, others are still climbing on the bandwagon, according to Antoine W. van Agtmael, president of Emerging Markets Management in Washington, D.C. The new flow of money, he said, is from traditionally conservative sources, like pension funds, that had shunned these markets as too volatile and too risky until it became clear that the opportunity for big returns could not be ignored.
"My expectation was that by this time I would have seen an ebb in the flood," he said. "But there remains a much stronger interest than I had anticipated."
Yet returns for the closed-end mutual funds that specialize in emerging markets have slowed. After a sparkling 51.5 percent total return, including dividends, in 1989, returns fell 10.9 percent in 1990, according to Lipper Analytical Services. Through November of last year, total returns are up 13.5. But the increase would have disappeared without the 73.8 percent surge in returns from Latin American funds.
The sharp investment increase in 1990 was overdone. It came with the sudden growth of funds designed to target these emerging markets, which did so well in 1989. The slowdown last year was, in part, a response to the slump of the economy worldwide, the survey respondents said.
But a longer-term reason is that the rapid rise of these markets is no longer a secret, and more of the money flowing in is from pension-fund investors and other middle-of-the-road managers rather than those who are specialists in emerging-country markets and high-risk investors who led the way into these frontier markets. Now some of the pioneers are out looking for other "undiscovered" markets, like those in Pakistan, India, Nigeria, and even Botswana, said Gary Kleiman, whose consulting firm did the survey.
He said that for the new wave of investors, the quality of regulation and trading procedures of these popular emerging markets, like those in Latin America and Taiwan, South Korea and Thailand, will play a bigger role in determining where to invest. Still, the survey showed that emerging markets had a long way to go in developing regulations and settlement procedures before they will be anywhere close to Western standards.
According to the survey, regulatory enforcement is still a major problem. But the institutions said Mexico and Malaysia were making progress. In terms of the worst enforcement, Indonesia was cited, both in "overt manipulation" and "lack of regulatory oversight."
The survey also showed how quickly money can move from one favorite emerging market to another. This is something investors should remember when considering single-country funds, in which the returns depend on both the individual stocks chosen by the fund and on the overall popularity of the particular fund itself.
In 1991, the share of investment in Latin America jumped to 36 percent, more than double the 16 percent level of the previous year. At the same time, the favorite of the previous year, the Pacific Rim markets, suffered, with its portion of investment plunging from 68 percent to 33 percent last year.
 
A Turnaround in 1991
 Last year was a much better year than 1990 in world stock markets. As a whole, the Financial Times index of world markets rose 16.5 percent, compared with a plunge of 19 percent in 1990.
But, of course, not all industry segments soared. Automobile stocks, for instance, again ended near the bottom of the performance list. In 1991, autombile stocks finshed 28th out of 36 industry categories ranked in the Financial Times index. They were up just 3.88 percent. This was better, but not much better, than 1990, when auto stocks finished last, down 25.85 percent.
Beverage and tobacco stocks managed to stay near the top of the industry list. In 1990, they were No. 1, down just 1.22 percent. Last year, they were No. 3, up 35.23 percent.
One big reversal was made by business services and computer software stocks. This group surged to No. 1, up 51.97 percent in 1991 after ranking 16th, down 13.43 percent, in 1990. Textiles and clothing moved up to fifth place, up 26.15 percent, from the 29th position in 1990, down 19.59 percent.
Media stocks, helped by a Top 10 performance by Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation, held their ground, finishing 18th in 1991 after a 15th-place finish in 1990.

HEADLINE: Making a Difference;
From Campus to Car Czar

BYLINE: By BARBARA PRESLEY NOBLE

 BODY:
As president of the College of William and Mary, Paul R. Verkuil is surrounded by history and quiet: his office in a Colonial building on the school's Williamsburg, Va., campus is in what Mr. Verkuil describes as a "cocoon-like 18th-century environment."
Mr. Verkuil is about to get a rough dose of the year 2000. He is moving to the Orlando, Fla., area to become president and chief executive of the American Automobile Association, the 32.5 million-member emergency service cum travel agency cum insurance company cum whatever else might be useful to motorists. He succeeds James B. Creal, who has led the organization for 20 years. 
 Speaking from his office in the association's new corporate headquarters in Heathrow, Fla., where he was hanging pictures last week, Mr. Verkuil (pronounced ver-KYLE) said the shift from academia to one of the largest membership organizations in the country is not the great leap it seems. As a federation of local clubs with strong ties to a central organization, the A.A.A. resembles a university. "It isn't hierarchical," he said. "You have to be able to convince people to do what you want them to do."
Mr. Verkuil, 52, who has done scholarly work in law and economics and transportation regulation issues, plans to put more effort into the A.A.A.'s activities in Washington, the association's home base until 1989. The association lobbied to tilt the balance of funds of the recent $151 billion transportation bill toward highway reconstruction.
The A.A.A. has been criticized for using its muscle to push the interests of motorists at the expense of public transportation, an orientation for which Mr. Verkuil, like Mr. Creal before him, is unapologetic.
"We represent the motorists and the life style that the predominant number of Americans want to maintain," said Mr. Verkuil.
The A.A.A. is about to turn Orlando, a sprawling city that regularly hits the top of the places-on-the-move charts, into a lab for an automobile navigation experiment. The computerized Travtek system, which the A.A.A. is sponsoring with several corporations and government agencies, will supply drivers with traffic data via radio waves, allowing them to avoid congestion, police emergencies and construction bottlenecks.
Until William and Mary's Charter Day celebration in early February, Mr. Verkuil will run both the college and the association.

LENGTH: 1808 words

HEADLINE: Business Diary/December 29 - January 3

BYLINE: By Joel Kurtzman

 BODY:

 
 
ECONOMY

 
Mr. Bush's Road Show Hits the Pacific
 
With the economy in a slump, it's a good time to take a trip. So President Bush and his entourage, including highly paid (some say overpaid) business leaders, are touring the Pacific, trying to talk the trade deficit down and American exports up. Last week they reached Australia. That was a good place to start since it is one of handful of nations to run a trade deficit with the United States. But Mr. Bush was greeted by Australian farmers complaining that America subsidizes its food exports. This week the mobile White House makes its most important stop: Japan, which is running the largest trade and current account surpluses ever. Japan is scrambling to make it at least appear it is doing something to reverse that trend, especially in an American election year. Mr. Bush is "the key person standing against protectionism," one official said. Since the United States accounts for almost half of its surpluses, Japan thinks Mr. Bush is a valuable man to keep on board.
 
 
Signs of Recovery . . .
 
Fatter order books are a sign of better times. When the nation's factories crank up to produce goods to fill the orders, they start hiring and spending more. According to the Commerce Department, that chain of events is beginning to unfold, although still without much snap. Factory orders rose by 0.6 percent in November. Those gains are "consistent with the idea of a weak recovery," said Jean Sundrla, an economist at Evans Economics in Washington.

 
. . . Or Maybe Not
 
It's not just the economists who disagree, it's the data. The monthly survey of 300 purchasing managers by the National Association of Purchasing Management showed a decline in orders. The index fell to 46.5 in December from after declining to 50.1 in November. A reading below 50 percent indicates the economy is contracting. Which numbers are most reliable? Last week the Federal Reserve said the index sometimes sends "false signals."

 
Buying Stocks Again
 
One beneficiary of low interest rates has been the stock market. The Dow Jones industrial average surged to 3,201.48, its highest level ever, while interest rates hovered at their lowest levels since Edsels roamed the roads. Those low rates have brought individuals back into the stock markets. "Where else can you put your money right now?" said Lewis Sperber, managing partner of Sperber Adams, a retail brokerage in Westport, Conn. "You can renew a C.D. for 2 percent less than what you bought it for, or buy G.M.'s preferred stock, which gives you a yield of 8.8 percent. Which would you rather do?"


Consumers Continue to Fret
 
Though the stock market is rallying, it has done little so far to lift the spirits of the consumer. Consumer confidence, according to the Conference Board, fell to 52.4 in December, from 54.7 in November. The index was a confident 100 in 1985. To arrive at its findings, the board polls 6,000 households. What worries consumers now has been worrying them all year: the fear of losing their jobs. Since consumers account for two-thirds of all economic activity, their mood is a good indicator of future strength or weakness. "Clearly, an appreciable improvement in the consumer's spirits is a prerequisite for economic recovery," said Fabian Linden, the survey director.


An R.& D. Slowdown
 
Since the end of World War II, America's growth has been fueled by the success of its laboratories in turning out everything from microchips to genetically engineered products. But research and development -- whose payoffs are often years in the future -- is being trimmed, according to a study by the Batelle Memorial Institute, a research group in Columbus, Ohio. America will invest just 2.8 percent more in R.& D. in 1992 than it did the year before, far below the average annual increase. Why the slowdown? "Given the situation with the Federal budget and a generally sluggish economy, we've expected a slowdown in R.& D. spending for some time," said Douglas E. Olesen, president of the institute.

 
A Word From Commerce
 
The Government peers ahead with the aid of its index of leading economic indicators. Among other things, it measures hours worked, building permits issued and changes in unfilled manufacturing orders and is supposed to forecast developments six months hence. Bad news. The Commerce Department said the index slipped by 0.3 percent in November, the fourth straight month without an advance. "The economy truly is weak," said Daniel Laufenberg of I.D.S. Financial Services in Minneapolis. No spark, the index indicates, before the second quarter.
 
There is at least one area where the Government is getting more efficient. The Food and Drug Administration said it had shortened the time it takes to approve a new drug to an average of 22 months last year, from 33 months in 1986.
 
 
 
 
INTERNATIONAL

 
Inflation in Rubles
 
In Russia, they called last week's price rises "price liberalization." The measures, brought into existence by Russian President Boris N. Yeltsin, allow factories, retailers and regional authorities to set prices on most of the goods they sell. (The price of vodka is still controlled). These reforms, Mr. Yeltsin says, will make prices reflect the cost of production and fill the country's empty shelves with goods. But not everyone agrees the reforms will work. There is still no privatization plan or banking system, they say. And nothing has been decided about how to stabilize the nearly worthless ruble. "This is not 'price liberalization' but simply the decentralization of price setting," said Sergie A. Zverev, an economist in Moscow. "There is no orientation on market forces, there is no Federal Reserve system, no way to gauge the money mass," he said. In other words, the reforms have not been thought through.

 
Japan Offers a Little Help
 
One of America's post-World War II jobs, analysts say, was to be the world's market of last resort. America's huge buying power -- and willingness to run trade deficits -- could be relied upon to pull the world out a slump. But with America mired in slow growth, it can no longer pull with both oars. Last week, So Japan's central bank made a gesture by lowering its discount rate to 4.5 percent from 5 percent. That was supposed to get companies to start buying capital goods, which -- coincidentally -- America produces in abundance. "With the latest reduction there will be a substantial impact on corporate investment," said Susumu Nozaki, an economist at Tokai Bank in Tokyo.


In Singapore, a Gum Ban
 
While the United States struggles to interdict shipments of illicit drugs, Singapore -- which President Bush visited last week -- is interdicting, well, chewing gum. Lawmakers on that tidy island are tired of stepping in the stuff. So last week a law went into effect making it illegal to "import, sell and manufacture chewing gum," said Hock-Seng Chen, a First Secretary of the Singapore Embassy in Washington. Selling gum now carries a fine of up to $2,000 and smuggling, up to $10,000 and a year in prison. What about chewing it? "As far as we know that's still legal," he said.
 
 
 
 
COMPANIES

 
In for a Fight at Zales
 
When the Zales Corporation, the big jewelry and retail chain, told its creditors it would miss a $52 million payment and begin restructuring itself, its bondholders rolled up their sleeves for a fight. The restructuring plan, which includes shutting 400 of Zales' 2,000 stores and laying off as many as 2,500 employees, was "silly," said David Glatstein, president of the Dallas investment company Barre & Company, who is leading the creditors' group. Zales has $850 million in debt, mostly in high-interest junkbonds, from a 1986 leverage buyout. Last week, Mr. Glatstein and the creditors filed a suit in Dallas seeking to put Zales into involuntary bankruptcy. "We had warned everybody, if the company didn't make its payments, that we were going to do this," Mr. Glatstein said. A ruling is expected in three weeks.


Honda Sues a Customer
 
Honda has a reputation for quality, but not with everyone, it seems. So in an odd reversal, the American Honda Motor Company said it was suing a customer. Daniel Gregory -- who bought a 1990 Honda CRX -- was unhappy with the car. So Mr. Gregory used Honda's toll-free complaint number. Trouble was, Honda said in an affidavit, Mr. Gregory used it too frequently -- more than 100 times in a single day. No one else could get through.
Sales 'R' Up at Toys 'R' Us
It may have been a dismal Christmas for most of the nation's retailers, but at least one of them is smiling. Toys 'R' Us reported last week that sales for the season were up 16.4 percent, to $2.5 billion. Some of those gains came from price cutting at the chain. But investors did not seem to mind. Toys 'R' Us stock jumped $2 a share on the announcement to 34 3/4 and closed the week at 34 3/8.

 
A Big Contract for Harris
 
For the Harris Corporation, it was a big win. Last week, the Federal Aviation Administration selected Harris to produce and install the nation's next-generation air traffic control system. The government contract runs for 14 years and totals $1.7 billion. Harris won this one in the trenches. Last summer, the F.A.A. pitted Harris's hardware against a rival offering from American Telephone and Telegraph Technologies Inc., a subsidiary of A.T.& T. The Harris system links air traffic controllers to pilots and to each other. And it is supposed to be reliable. The specs allow it to be down just 4 seconds a year.


Tough Terms for MGM's Owner
 
In an industry where deal-making is considered an art, Giancarlo Parretti's purchase of MGM-UA was hardly a masterpiece. Mr. Parretti, the Italian financier whose Pathe Communications Company paid $1.4 billion to acquire MGM, was accused of having mob connections, of being anti-Semitic and of not paying his Italian taxes. (He was arrested in Italy last week for tax evasion.) But Mr. Parretti's real problem may have been that he simply did not have enough money to buy the studio and run it. So Mr. Paretti made another deal with Credit Lyonnais, the big French bank. The bank agreed to lend the studio money, but only if Mr. Parretti agreed to stay away from the lot. Not the best of terms for a mogul. In June, the bank said Mr. Parretti was meddling in the studio's affairs. It filed charges in a Delaware court. Last week the court said Mr. Parretti had reneged on the agreement. Though Mr. Parretti still owns most of MGM's stock, he has been forced to cede all control to the bank.

Last week the Seaman Furniture Company filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankrupcy law.

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS;
Who Would Move Money Where

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD

 BODY:
When investors believe the economy will worsen, they are more likely to seek professional investment advice. But affluent and ordinary investors look for guidance in different places, according to Russ Alan Prince and Richard K. Weingarten in a report called "Marketing Mutual Funds," to be published in February by Renaissance Inc. of Carmel, Ind.
In one survey, 298 investors with at least $1 million in liquid assets said they would tend to abandon mutual funds in favor of private money managers when times are bad, returning to funds as the outlook brightens. But for another 3,442 investors surveyed at random, the opposite is true: a worsening economy would generally cause a movement into funds. Because very affluent individuals make up only a small part of the investing public, continuing economic weakness may actually be good news for the fund industry, Mr. Weingarten said.

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds;
Strategies for a New Ball Game

BYLINE: By Carole Gould

 BODY:
After a banner year, when the average stock fund rose 30.7 percent, mutual fund investors may wonder where to go from here.
The outlook is not so bright for 1992. Most experts predict a less-than-robust economic recovery that slows investment returns to just 10 percent or so. 
 Three fund investment advisers, asked to craft model portfolios for 1992, all included a mix of small-company and growth stock funds; two added a smattering of bond funds.
Here is what the advisers have to say.
Kenneth E. Gregory, principal in the San Francisco-based money management firm Litman/Gregory, believes that small-capitalization stocks, the biggest winners in 1991, will keep their lead this year. Small companies usually perform better than big concerns during economic recoveries, as they have the potential of growing faster. Not incidentally, they are beginning to regain favor with institutional investors. Strong earnings growth is worth a big premium in a stagnating economy, and today's premium is low by historic standards, he says.
He would put 70 percent of his portfolio into stocks, split between United States and international stock funds. Most of the domestic holdings would be in two small-company funds: Brandywine, an aggressive play, and Monetta, a more conservative fund that holds small and medium-size companies.
The rest of the United States stock-fund component is split between IAI Stock, a conservative growth fund with larger capitalization stocks, and Gabelli Asset, a growth fund.
On the international side, Mr. Gregory likes Harbor International, which invests overseas but downplays Japanese and German issues. And because interest rates are still falling, rewarding bondholders with capital gains, he would put 30 percent of the portfolio into the Pimit Total Return fund.
Mr. Gregory believes the market may drop in the first half of the year; after the decline, he would shift the allocation, moving half of the money in Pimit into stock funds, so that the portfolio would then have an 85 percent stake in stocks and 15 percent in bonds.
The Pimit fund is also a favorite of Anthony J. Ogorek, an investment adviser in Buffalo. Mr. Ogorek says that while short-term interest rates have fallen dramatically, long-term rates have not hit bottom yet. He would put 20 percent of his portfolio into Pimit, which holds a mix of corporate and government bonds and is yielding about 7.7 percent, because "it's a diversified, conservative fund that doesn't bet the farm on one interest rate projection," he said.
A far riskier choice for investors who want to play falling long-term interest rates this year is Benham Target 2000, which holds zero-coupon bonds.
Historically, when small stocks outperform the overall market, their run has lasted eight to 14 years, Mr. Ogorek says. So he expects last year's small-cap revival to stay in place for several years, though he cautions investors not to expect the same outstanding returns that they got in 1991, when the small-stock group returned an average of 51.6 percent, according to Lipper Analytical Services.
He would allocate 20 percent of his portfolio to a small-stock fund, namely Twentieth Century Ultra, a top-performing but volatile fund that has outperformed the Standard & Poor's 500-stock average by an average of 8 percentage points annually for the past five years. For investors looking for a more cautious small-company play, he likes Sit New Beginning Growth.
He would split the balance of his investment in United States stocks between Selected American Shares, a growth-and-income fund, (30 percent) and Financial Strategic Health Sciences, which invests in health maintenance organizations, discount mail-order pharmacies and similar cost-cutting health-care plays (10 percent).
The final 20 percent would be invested in Harbor International, the foreign stock fund.
Kurt Brouwer, partner in Brouwer & Janachowski, an investment advisory firm in San Francisco, would put 32 percent of a conservative growth portfolio into small-company stock funds. Among his picks are Pennsylvania Mutual, a "value" fund whose managers look for stocks that are cheap relative to the company's probable worth. (Growth managers, who look for earnings that are expected to outpace the average, were among the big winners in 1991.) Another pick: GIT Equity Special Growth Portfolio, which invests mainly in very small companies with market capitalizations of $150 million or so.
Another 48 percent of the portfolio would go to large-capitalization stock funds, divided between the Janus Fund, a conservative fund with a growth orientation, and Gabelli Asset Fund, which takes a value approach to investing.
He also likes Warburg Pincus Counsellors Capital Appreciation, a growth fund that invests in a mix of small- and large-cap stocks.
The remainder of the portfolio would go to the international play, and he would invest in, yes, Harbor International, a value-oriented stock fund.

HEADLINE: Recovery Is All in the Job

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"More Layoffs? Hold the Applause" (Forum, Dec. 1) hit the nail right on the head. It is about time that a prominent economist stated the real reason for our current recession. 
 What frightens me is how little the politicians seem to relate to us average Americans. Don't they realize we will use our credit cards regardless of how high the interest charged, as long as we have jobs generating an income with which to pay the bills? We also will continue to spend no matter how high taxes are, as long as we are not fearing layoffs. But take away our jobs, or job security, and we will stick to buying the bare necessities for fear of living next year in a cardboard box.
If more of our powerful people could get this fact through to Washington and corporate America, we could probably look forward to a real recovery.
 
EILEEN F. MONROE
Cold Spring, N.Y., Dec. 1

HEADLINE: Usual Suspects;
Blaming Japan Has Its Risks; So Does Bush's Visit to Tokyo

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR

 BODY:
EVEN by the rigorous standards of an American election year, Tokyo is a long way to go to try to win votes back home. But in his three-day visit this week to Japan, President Bush will be doing precisely that, prodding the Japanese to open their markets and buy more American goods to help, he says, "create jobs and restore prosperity" in the United States.
Mr. Bush and his advisers recognize that with the end of the cold war and the collapse of the Soviet Union, the international threat that most worries voters is no longer nuclear warfare but something far more subtle -- an erosion of living standards as American industries lag in the global competition with foreign rivals, especially Japan. And those concerns have been magnified by recent announcements from pillars of corporate America, like General Motors and I.B.M., that they are cutting thousands of workers and permanently shrinking. 
 Yet in linking this national sense of economic insecurity to trade conflicts with Japan, Mr. Bush is on slippery ground, ideologically, politically and economically. For more than a decade, the United States-Japan trade issue has seemed intractable, always with us, never resolved. American policy toward Japan on trade has been divided and confused. On both sides, the debate has been colored by half-truths, hypocrisy and cultural chauvinism.
It's hard to make a credible argument that Japan is to blame for the American economic slump, despite the comments last week by Representative John D. Dingell, Democrat of Michigan, who said that the recession was "made in Japan," and Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher, who remarked that Japan was partly responsible for deepening the slump. In fact, United States exports to Japan have increased and the trade deficit has declined in recent years, from a peak of $56 billion in 1987 to an estimated $41 billion. In a $5.5 trillion economy, such an imbalance does not loom so large.
Still, America does have genuine trade grievances with Japan. A joint study by the Commerce Department and Japan's Ministry of International Trade and Industry found that because it is so difficult to reach Japanese consumers, American products are typically 40 percent more expensive in Japan than in the United States. Japan is also far more closed to foreign direct investment -- acquiring companies, building factories or buying real estate -- than are most developed nations. The United States is host to 29 percent of the world total of this "inward investment," while the 12-nation European Community attracts 35 percent, according to the Commerce Department's International Trade Administration. Japan, by contrast, receives less than 1 percent of foreign direct investment.
 
Internal Barriers
 From machine tools in the 1960's to supercomputers in the 1980's, Japan has tended to open up to foreign imports only after a Japanese alternative has been developed. Barriers at the border -- quotas and high tariffs -- are rare these days, but internal barriers involving inspections, product standards and a labyrinthine distribution system can still be formidable. And the outsiders' sense that they are discriminated against is sometimes fanned by loose comments from Japanese breaking ranks with the official party line that Japan is a free-trade paradise. A former head of Nippon Telegraph and Telephone once said that the only things he could imagine buying from foreigners were mops and telephone poles.
In government and academia, the debate over American trade policy toward Japan has been divided for more than a decade by two perspectives -- the macroeconomic versus the anecdotal. From the Olympian redoubt of macroeconomics, the trade deficit with Japan seems negligible. But for the trench warriors of business trying to crack the Japanese market the anecdotal evidence can be compelling.
The subject of fairness in trade matters, not the esoterica of trade deficits or economic theory, is an issue with political resonance. The theme of economic nationalism -- embracing education, training, technology development and getting tough on trade issues -- appeals to many voters, especially independents and Democrats who voted for Mr. Bush in 1988, said Ruy Teixeira, a sociologist at the Brookings Institution. "Trade is the most visible item in that cluster of issues," he said. "But people are not going to go out and vote tomorrow based on trade. If it's going to become an election issue, people are going to have to be primed for it."
But whether Mr. Bush will be able to score any political gains from his Japan trip is uncertain. He goes to Tokyo trailed by a retinue of American executives, a group heavily weighted with representatives from Detroit, like Robert C. Stempel of General Motors and Lee Iacocca of Chrysler. The Administration is pressing Japanese car companies to use more American parts, especially in their factories in the United States, and for the Japanese to buy more American cars.
This strikes many analysts as leading with the Presidential chin. Americans may believe that trade with Japan is unfair in some ways but, according to consumer surveys, they also believe that Japan makes better cars. Moreover, Detroit has never really made an effort to sell cars in Japan and American automakers increasingly use Japanese and other foreign parts. "For the Administration or Detroit to portray this as a nationalist issue is just shameless," said William Niskanen, chairman of the Cato Institute, a research group in Washington.
The success stories in United States-Japan trade tend to result not from dramatic gestures but steady prodding and working with the grain of change. Selling American cigarettes and beef are recent examples, as well as finally getting Toys "R" Us stores into Japan.
The inefficient Japanese retail and distribution system, which Toys "R" Us is sidestepping with its huge stores, developed as a way of privatizing unemployment as Japan changed from an agrarian to an urban society. People coming off the farms became shopkeepers and wholesalers, protected by regulations limiting big stores. Consumers paid more for their goods, but unemployment was rare. The system has long outlived its social purpose. Japan has a labor shortage, and powerful interests in Japan, not just the Americans, think things should be changed.
"What works is when you have the facts on your side and you help the Japanese get out of a bind," said Michael B. Smith, a former United States deputy trade representative.
And the lessons can flow both ways. Coming during a recession, says Chalmers Johnson, a professor at the University of California at San Diego, President Bush's trip to Japan may highlight the more active role that the Japanese Government plays in its economy, nurturing new industries and spreading the social pain of hard times. Politically, the danger for Mr. Bush is that Americans may reasonably conclude that, if anywhere, the nation's recession was made in Washington, not Tokyo.
