HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
The Salvadorans Make Peace in a 'Negotiated Revolution'

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS

 BODY:
AT the height of President Ronald Reagan's crusade against Communist subversion in Central America, he and his aides liked to say that the United States would never let the guerrillas in El Salvador "shoot their way into power." And in the end that the guerrillas have helped draw to their tiny country's 12-year-old civil war, they have not proved Mr. Reagan wrong.
But while the settlement they announced with the Government of President Alfredo Cristiani in the first minutes of the new year did not give them actual power, leaders of the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front have won at least paper rights to participate in the political process of their country's transformation. Never, in the memories of diplomats who oversaw the last 25 rounds of negotiations between the two sides, has a such a conflict ended with agreement to such sweeping reform in advance of new elections. "This is the closest that any process has ever come to a negotiated revolution,"said the United Nations' principal mediator, Alvaro de Soto. 
 The essential difference between the final peace treaty to be signed in Mexico City on Jan. 16 and the trenchant public vows that El Salvador's revolutionary groups took as they launched their unified war in 1980 is that the rebels have given up their claim to even a share of power. Perhaps they did not end "the power of the great lords of land and capital" as they swore they would, and Salvadoran dependence on "Yankee imperialism" may not have been "liquidated." But the institutional changes for which the guerrillas are to trade in their stolen assault rifles and surface-to-air missiles should prove far more valuable than any quota of soldiers to the democratic society that the rebels say they now want to help build.
Under the accords, the Salvadoran armed forces that the United States spent $1.09 billion to turn from a bloody praetorian guard into a powerful and less abusive counterinsurgency force will be cut almost in half and a reviewing panel approved by the rebels is to purge officers found to be excessively brutal or corrupt. Paramilitary and civil defense forces and the military's intelligence directorate are all to be disbanded. And in the neat, concrete-block military academy that has produced some of the most virulent anti-Communists in Latin America, doctrine will be rewritten. No longer will the armed forces' mission include the prosecution of an enemy within.
If such changes are sure to raise objections among commanders who have come to think of themselves as a front line in the defense of national values, the creation of a new civilian police force will not be much less complicated. Though former guerrillas and former National Police agents will be allowed to join the new force in equal numbers, most of the new recruits are to be Salvadorans less cultured in the violence.
It is a measure of the changes that have already taken place in El Salvador that accords on economic and political issues at the heart of the war are somewhat less sensitive. Some farmland that the Government has agreed to try to secure for peasants in rebel-held zones has already been written off by its owners. Powerful families whose fortunes were harvested from coffee lands by miserably paid workers have shifted to nontraditional exports. The idea of an economic policy forum of labor, business and government representatives is less startling after one hears a Marxist guerrilla commander argue for the privatization of El Salvador's banks. And political freedoms for the rebels have become less unthinkable as moderate leftists like Ruben Zamora have returned from exile.
Until their negotiations finally ended two minutes before a midnight deadline, rebel and government delegates seemed to make the point with their tenacity that a mere end of the cold war would not force them into unwanted concessions. But negotiators on both sides acknowledged that changes beyond El Salvador had enormous impact on the process. Two years before the Berlin wall came down, Nicaragua's Sandinista Government began pulling away from the Salvadoran rebels. The Iran-contra affair and President Bush's shift to less ideological policies in Central America undercut those who still argued that a military solution was possible.
But in a crowded nation where the hatreds are as personal as they are intense, some of the most important transformations have been individual. After launching a national offensive in November 1989 in which some 2,000 people died, rebel leaders acknowledged that Salvadorans were not about to rise up to help them seize power. Their turn toward a more political struggle increased the importance of rebel moderates like Salvador Samayoa, a member in the junta installed after the October 1979 military coup that set off the war. And whatever the depth of his conviction, Joaquin Villalobos, the most militaristic of the rebel commanders, now talks of pragmatism and social democracy as guiding ideals.
With the offensive, military leaders came to accept more openly that the guerrillas could not be defeated on the battlefield. During the peace process, Col. Mauricio Ernesto Vargas, a government negotiator, helped to keep his side at the table even as some comrades in arms called him a traitor. With army opposition to the talks apparently rising, the conservative defense minister, Gen. Rene Emilio Ponce, flew to New York with Mr. Cristiani and told the rebels that he supported the peace.
 
Behind the Peace
 Yet perhaps more than anyone else in El Salvador, it was Mr. Cristiani who made the peace happen. Four years after he was named to lead the Nationalist Republican Alliance by its ultrarightist founder, Roberto d'Aubuisson, Mr. Cristiani began as President to move the party toward the center. Twice, Mr. Cristiani seemed to resist joining the negotiations in New York as criticism of the talks grew more strident in San Salvador. And even after he approved the final aspects of the New Year's accords, he skipped the signing ceremony. But he embraced the treaty's reforms as his own. He accepted guerrilla demands, Mr. Cristiani explained, when he felt they "had justification and reason and the goal of the accord was to strengthen and consolidate our democracy."
Mr. Cristiani said he believed that "the immense majority of Salvadorans" would understand this. And on both sides, officials argued that with help from abroad commensurate to the destruction that was sponsored in El Salvador, a spirit of reconciliation could be fostered. But none of them brushed off the threat of extremist violence, particularly from the right. The fear is that the mistrust that permeated the talks will likely follow them.
Still, among the negotiators at least, there was a palpable shift in mood. On the morning after the Government delegation left town, Mr. Samayoa, the rebel negotiator, sat down to breakfast in the hotel where the President had stayed and ordered French toast with Italian bread. "It's Cristiani's favorite," he said.
 
 
 
COUNTRY BY COUNTRY
CENTRAL AMERICA'S ROAD AHEAD

 
THE cold war is over and the ideological differences largely laid aside, but Central America still needs work. Plagued by limping economies, emigration and its convenience for drug traffickers, the region will still be chasing stability. But it will have to rely less on an increasingly distracted Washington for help. At a glance, these are the countries and where they stand:
Costa Rica -- A demilitarized oasis and the oldest democracy in the region, Costa Rica sees itself as a model for the road ahead. Its former President, Oscar Arias Sanchez, fostered peace with a plan that became the framework for solutions in Central America. But Costa Rica has a troubled economy and, coincidentally, a threatened environment; its rain forests are a draw for tourism.
Nicaragua -- With the contra war over and repatriation of the rebels accomplished in good part, Nicaragua now fights for continuing unity. President Violeta Chamorro, swept into office over the Sandinistas in elections nearly two years ago, remains too weak to confront the old guard head-on and so has settled into a partnership in hopes of healing what remains of the rift. The prospects for United States aid, once the most hopeful in the neighborhood, are dimming as El Salvador stokes American guilt for its suffering.
Honduras -- For many years the poorest economy in the region until Nicaragua surpassed it, Honduras found itself militarized in the 80's by the United States, which used it as a training ground in the years of conflict in its front and back yards. In any given week, Honduras is host to an average of 1,200 American troops. One question is whether there will be a reawakening of El Salvador's longtime antipathy, which led to the so-called Soccer War of 1969 and which was suspended while the civil war occupied the Salvadoran military.
Guatemala -- There is still a civil war in Central America, the longest-lived at 30 years and counting, and it is here, although peace talks are under way. One feared obstacle to the end of violence is Guatemala's emergence as a growing site for opium to make heroin and as a transshipment point for drug traffic.
Panama -- Historically considered South American, Panama is now looking up the isthmus for economic opportunity, especially in hopes of benefitting from a regional trade bloc that leaders have been working to develop. Its economy faltered in the years of confrontation that led to the 1989 American invasion that ousted Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, and businesses that fled the country have not returned in force. The return of the general, who is on trial in Miami on drug trafficking charges, remains a possibility. The drug traffic, meanwhile, has not abated in his absence, and may have even expanded.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
The Arab World Comes to the End of Illusions

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM

DATELINE: ALGIERS

 BODY:
ACROSS the Arab world almost a year after the end of the gulf war, people are comparing that crisis and its aftermath to the thunderclap of the 1967 defeat of the Arabs by Israel in the Six Day War.
That event is deeply engraved in the consciousness of an entire generation that was emerging then from school and that today administers the Arab world. The "naksa" (setback), as it is known in Arabic, set off a chain reaction that changed the Arab status quo in the late 1960's and 70's. Eventually Egypt made peace with Israel, and some Arab countries, notably Egypt and the Arab gulf states, realigned themselves with the West even as anti-Western leaders like Saddam Hussein and Muammar el-Qaddafi consolidated their power. 
 Now the gulf crisis has again scattered the Arab alignment, changing it from a configuration the world had come to know -- and often be comfortable with. One dramatic example is Jordan, which the West had come to depend on as an ally, but which sided with Iraq in the war; the lesson appears to be how quickly the friendship of a monarch like King Hussein can be turned into something else when his people insist on voicing their deepest yearnings and anger.
In Saudi Arabia and in other lands like Morocco and Tunisia that Western governments have long considered "safe," substantial segments of the population also showed extreme hostility to the Western alliance against Iraq -- revealing how much bitterness can lie just beneath a seemingly tranquil surface.
Now new alliances are forming in the Arab world, but they are far from clear yet. For the United States and the rest of the industrialized world, whatever new order is taking shape in this strategically located region of 250 million people and vast natural resources is bound to be of crucial importance.
The oft-expressed desire of the countries of the region remains to copy Western development, and the political profile of regions like North Africa is of special interest to Western Europe, where several million Muslims from Algeria, Morocco and Tunisia live. Yet the Arab world's suspicions of Western intentions dates all the way back to the Crusades, and it remains a world to be won over.
 
'Year of Torment'
 It was in this context that the Egyptian newspaper Al Ahram said in an editorial Friday that "the year 1991 was to a large extent a tragic one for our Arab world, a year of torment and division." That is a judgment echoed by publication after publication in the Arab world throughout the year, and often heard in private conversations.
Indeed, it seems that 1991 saw the demise of every illusion -- and some realities -- that had long supported this region's hopes for greater political and economic power.
At the beginning of the year, the vision of political harmony, already fragmented by years of competition, was wrecked altogether by the gulf war, in which half the Arab countries fought Iraq while the other half sympathized with it. At the end of the year, the vision of achieving unity through Islam was also in shambles, as the Sudan and Algeria appeared to be drifting toward a version of theocracy in which Islamic doctrine would be as militantly politicized as it is in Iran -- and, as such, a threat to traditionalist Muslim Arab regimes like those of Egypt, Saudi Arabia, Jordan and Morocco.
At the same time, the evaporation of the Soviet system deprived radical Arab regimes of a dependable supporter and supplier; the vision of a liberated Palestine and of a unified Arab front to face Israel collapsed when Palestinians and other Arabs sat down for peace talks with Israel, and the continued weakness of oil prices demonstrated in the most striking way to what extent the "oil weapon" had lost its edge.
In other words, every element in the collection of stratagems and illusions that King Hussein had called "the Arab system" had collapsed. By far the biggest trauma was provided by the gulf war itself. Many Arabs today compare the impact of the gulf crisis on the Arab psyche, mind and beliefs with that of Israel's defeat in 1967 of the Egyptian, Syrian and Jordanian armies. That war left Israel occupying the West Bank, the Gaza Strip and the Golan Heights as well as Sinai, which it eventually returned to Egypt under the Camp David peace treaty.
Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt, who waged another war against Israel in 1973 but then traveled to Jerusalem to make peace, was only the most prominent example of the Arab leaders who emerged after that defeat and took their lessons from it. Eventually an entire generation of administrators instituted the pragmatic, moderate pro-Western policies that have characterized Tunisia, Morocco, Egypt, Saudi Arabia and its Arab gulf allies and Jordan. While none of these governments can be described as truly democratic, they have given their citizens a broader degree of personal and political freedom, and they manage their economies with some degree of free enterprise.
Others, like Libya, Iraq, Syria, Yemen and the Sudan remain in the throes of "revolutionary" ideologies, but these countries are clearly struggling, with their social and economic agendas ambiguous beyond the plain objective of keeping the current leaders in power.
It is too early to see what the ultimate consequences of the gulf crisis will be; the Arab world is still busy settling scores and assessing damage. But some political scientists say one thing is clear -- the Arab world that emerged in the 1970's and 1980's is under enormous stress. "The gulf war raises many questions for the Arab world, starting with the most critical issue, which is the failure of the Arab states to play a more active and constructive role in the resolution of an inter-Arab conflict," said Clovis F. Maksoud, the former representative in Washington and observer at the United Nations for the Arab League. "The crisis has gone on to allow a glimpse into the collective anxieties of the Arab world."
 
Reaching the Limits
 One conclusion already being drawn is that the Arab world has reached the limits of its own contradictions. It is, for example, not possible to speak of a "brotherly Arab world" when one Arab nation invades and rapes another while others justify this as a struggle between the rich and the poor. It is also impossible for economies like those of Saudi Arabia, which is by any economic standard a part of the first world, to "interact" in any significant way with destitute third-world partners like Algeria and Egypt.
Finally, it is impossible to present a unified policy vis-a-vis Israel when several Arab governments -- and the Palestinians -- enter peace talks with Israel while the Palestine Liberation Organization leader, Yasir Arafat, promotes the concept of Islamic holy war against Israel, as the P.L.O. did on Dec. 11 at the summit meeting in Dakar, Senegal, of leaders of the Islamic nations.
The P.L.O. proposal to those 45 heads of state, including leaders of 22 Arab countries, was roundly defeated. And at about the same time, with hardly a ripple of protest from the Arabs, the international community swiftly erased its 1975 United Nations resolution declaring Zionism to be a form of racism.
Such turnabouts in their fortunes and policies leave many Arabs awaiting new visionaries to supply new pillars for their collapsed faith in the future. But first, a big question must be answered: Where does the Arab world fit in the so-called new world order? One hint of the confusion on even this point is that Arab regimes have failed so far to take a clear position on the one principle that seems to be emerging as a central tenet of this new world order, as seen from the West: respect for human rights in a framework of democracy.
"We wish for the Arab world in this coming year to achieve significant progress in those domains," Al Ahram said in its editorial.
But the first truly free parliamentary elections in the region were hardly an endorsement for the principle. The results, in Algeria last week, gave a ringing victory to Islamic fundamentalists whose proclaimed aim is to abolish the freedom of choice for others, and this left considerable doubt that the democracy many Arabs yearn for will be a priority on the Arab agenda.

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
For a Limited Time Only: The Presidential Primary Season

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT

 BODY:
FIRST there were no candidates willing to enter the race. Then a non-candidate, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, stole the limelight. Then the holidays came, and who had time to worry about a bunch of Presidential contenders slogging around in New Hampshire?
Now 1992 has arrived and it seems as if the race for the Democratic nomination is just beginning. In fact, it's almost over. 
 After years of complaining that the nominating process drags on too long, Americans are about to get the kind of primary campaign that they said they always wanted: a short one. The hesitant beginning not only gave the campaign a late start, it also set conditions for an early finish. None of the candidates has had time to assemble a large war chest or a far-flung organization, so none of them is likely to survive more than a few primary losses.
"This is less like a playoff series, and more like sudden death," said Ann Lewis, a Democratic consultant. "The winner is most likely to be the person who starts scoring early, and who doesn't make any mistakes."
On top of the financial constraints, scheduling changes, too, are promoting a short primary race this year. So many states have moved their primary dates up that the election schedule, once weighted toward spring, now has a decidedly wintry feel. Most political analysts predict that, barring any bombshells or surprise late entrances, the Democratic nomination will be sewn up by the time tulip season rolls around.
"If you were going to bet, you'd bet you will know the nominee by April," said Geoffrey Garin, another Democratic consultant. "The field is going to get smaller pretty quickly."
 
Heading for New Hampshire
 This week, the campaign season begins in earnest with a mass political migration to New Hampshire, the site of the first primary. The six major Democratic candidates are fighting it out there in what for some is likely to be a make-or-break battle. They are: former Gov. Jerry Brown of California, Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa, Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska, former Senator Paul Tsongas of Massachusetts and Gov. L. Douglas Wilder of Virginia. Dr. Lenora B. Fulani, of the New Alliance Party, will also be running as a Democrat in New Hampshire.
Patrick Buchanan, the conservative columnist, will be in New Hampshire, too, trying to wrestle Republican delegates away from President Bush. While Mr. Buchanan is given virtually no chance of winning the nomination, he could embarrass Mr. Bush with a strong showing on Feb. 18. He made his first request for Federal matching funds last week and declared that he would match Mr. Bush's spending in New Hampshire "dollar for dollar."
With the caveat that a campaign can be thrown into turmoil at any moment, here is a schedule of key dates for the weeks ahead:
Feb. 10: The Iowa caucuses. Any Iowa Democrat who wants to participate may go to a school or a living room and, in a public vote, raise a hand for his or her candidate. In the past the caucus has been a critical early test. But with Senator Harkin, an Iowa native, in the race this year, the caucus is viewed as little more than a warm-up exercise. Still, a strong second-place showing could bolster the candidacy of a non-native, while a weaker-than-expected win by Mr. Harkin would be a serious setback.
Feb. 18: The New Hampshire primary. The nation's earliest Presidential primary has taken on near-mythic significance this year. For any Democrat besides Governor Clinton, whose base is in the South, a poor showing in the state could prove fatal. "The current crop of candidates will be cut in half by the morning after New Hampshire," said Hank Morris, a New York-based Democratic consultant.
On the Republican side, supporters of President Bush are concerned that Mr. Buchanan could receive a strong protest vote in the recession-racked state. Buchanan forces meanwhile are working to diminish expectations. "If Pat gets 10, 15, 20 percent, it will be a devastating blow," said Paul Nagy, Mr. Buchanan's New Hampshire director.
 
 
Battling for 0.4 Percent

 
Feb. 25: The South Dakota primary. Only four-tenths of 1 percent of the national convention delegates are at stake in the race, but it is the last chance for candidates to score an early win before the main primary season begins.
March 3: Several states hold primaries or caucuses, including Colorado, Maryland and Minnesota. Georgia is expected to join them, providing the first test of Southern strength.
March 10: "Super Tuesday." The campaign heads south in a big way, with voters in a dozen states, including Florida, Texas, Louisiana and Mississippi, going to the polls. It is expected to be a good day for Mr. Clinton; if it is not, it could prove ruinous for him.
March 17: The campaign moves to the Rust Belt with primaries in Illinois and Michigan. These are important contests for the Democratic Party, whose strategy for winning the Presidency depends heavily on carrying major industrialized states. If the field has not already been pared to two dominant contenders at this point, most analysts expect these races to do it. When the votes are counted, half of the pledged delegates to the Democratic convention will have been chosen.
April 7: The New York and Wisconsin primaries. When the polls close, more than 60 percent of the delegates will have been chosen; most politicians expect the likely nominee to have emerged by this point. "Everything," Mr. Morris said, "is going to collapse in April."
June 2: The last five primaries, including those of California and New Jersey. If the nominee has not yet been chosen he will be by the end of this day, or the race will remain deadlocked going into the convention.
July 13-16: Democratic convention, New York City.
Aug. 17-20: Republican convention, Houston.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
A Battle Looms for Bush On Another Asian Front

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
WHEN President Bush returns to Washington this week, he is likely to find that many members of Congress are at least as disturbed by his policy toward China, which is not included on his Asian trip, as they are about his policy toward Japan. A common lament on Capitol Hill is that the President does not have a consistent or credible policy for dealing with Beijing, whose human rights record is flawed, whose support of authoritarian regimes in Asia is expanding, and whose role in the international arms market is a cause of concern worldwide.
The perception that China policy -- or the lack of it -- is a weak point in Mr. Bush's handling of foreign affairs stands out all the more because he has more personal knowledge of the Chinese than did any of his predecessors. In 1974-75 he headed the United States Liaison Office in Beijing, the precursor to the embassy. 
 Criticisms have been growing since Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d visited China in mid-November and returned with very little to show for the trip, apart from Chinese agreement to adhere to the Missile Technology Control Regime, an international accord designed to restrict the export of missiles and missile technology. China said it would adhere to the agreement but asked the United States to lift sanctions that bar some high-speed computer sales and the transfer of satellite parts.
 
A Quiet Approach
 Last week the State Department said that only a few details remained to be put in place in order to remove those sanctions; meanwhile, the Administration's good will toward the Chinese appeared likely to be further boosted by a recent vote in China's legislature in favor of signing the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty, a signal that Beijing may be ready to deliver in the next few months on promises that it will adhere to the accord.
It is on such signals that the Administration bases its argument for its approach to China -- the assertion that a quiet approach is the most effective. "It has now been two and a half years since the tragedy of Tiananmen," Mr. Baker said at a news conference in Beijing during the November visit. "Unless we were to keep United States-China relations in the deep freeze forever, we had to start talking."
But Nancy Pelosi, the California Democrat who heads the Congressional Working Group on China, characterized the moves to lift the sanctions as an unnecessary capitulation to a nation that has enjoyed most-favored-nation trade status while other countries with centralized economies, including the former Soviet Union, did not. Representative Pelosi is the author of a bill that would require President Bush to show in his legally mandated annual review of China's trade status that Beijing was freeing political prisoners, refraining from selling missiles to Syria or Iran in contravention of the new agreement and making progress in other areas of human rights and trade. Her bill, having won wide Republican support, passed the House in November by a vote of 409 to 21. The Senate is to take it up this month.
"One of the first countries Bush visited as President was China," Mrs. Pelosi said in an interview. "Since his visit, we have run up a $30 billion trade deficit with the Chinese, most of it since Tiananmen Square in 1989. I don't think that most members of Congress want to isolate China any more than the President does. The disagreement between the President and Congress is that our relationship with China or any other country should be one that makes trade fairer, the political climate freer and the world safer. Our relations with China meet none of those tests now."
While the Communist governments of Europe have been collapsing, Communism in Asia is retrenching, with China in the lead. Vietnam has dramatically improved relations with Beijing, and China, North Korea and Vietnam share the view that there can be economic development without political pluralism in Asia. These societies are different, a Vietnamese official said recently, arguing that consensus there is more acceptable than combative multiparty politics.
China has also given its blessing to some of Asia's anti-Communist military regimes; it is a major arms supplier to the Orwellian junta that rules Myanmar, formerly Burma, and it is a friend of Thailand, where a military coup overthrew an elected government almost a year ago. In Cambodia, Beijing still supports the Khmer Rouge as the country attempts to rebuild itself, more than 15 years after Chinese-Vietnamese-Khmer Rouge cooperation helped Pol Pot to capture the country in 1975 and to try to remake its society in a fanatical leftist reign of terror that left more than a million people dead.
Ben Kiernan, professor of Southeast Asian history at Yale, said in an interview that it was China that "brought the Khmer Rouge back to center stage" as negotiations on a peace settlement for Cambodia dragged on through the late 1980's. And Representative Chester G. Atkins, a Massachusetts Democrat who is a member of the House Appropriations Committee, accuses Washington of playing down opposition to the Khmer Rouge to placate the Chinese.
The Administration argues that the accord signed in Paris last fall to end the Cambodian civil war would have been impossible without cooperation from China. But whether that agreement will be enough to prevent a Khmer Rouge return to power is another question. One Democratic Congressman who agrees with the Administration on the need to accept the Khmer Rouge into the government -- if only to lessen the chances that it would become a very dangerous wrecker outside the system -- is Stephen J. Solarz of New York. But Mr. Solarz also is calling for more urgent pressure from the United States on China and the United Nations to insure a quick transition to democracy in Cambodia. "The Khmer Rouge," he said last week, "are already out there in the villages booting out local officials."

LENGTH: 1710 words

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Opinions Considered: A Talk With Tom Wicker

 BODY:
TOM WICKER, whose "In the Nation" began appearing in this newspaper in 1966, wrote his final column under that title last Sunday and took off for a well-earned rest -- a week or so -- before getting on with other writing projects including three books and various assignments for The Times. 
 On New Year's Eve Mr. Wicker talked by phone with R.W. Apple Jr., chief Washington correspondent of The Times, and editors of The Week in Review about questions and people that have engaged him through a life in journalism that began as editor of a small-town newspaper in the South. Here are excerpts from the conversation.
 
How Politics Went From Soapbox to the Tube

 
Q. You've been at The Times for 30-something years as a reporter and Washington bureau chief and columnist, and in all you've been in journalism since 1949. What changes in the politics and the governing of the country have you seen?
A. Television has worked enormous changes, in politics and in the governing of the country, as in life generally. It's my view that those changes have been so great that we don't yet fully realize exactly what they are; until we do, we're not really going to know how to cope.
Television has made national politics more accessible, in the sense that a viewer in the smallest town knows the President of the United States better than he knows his governor or his congressman or perhaps even his mayor, depending on where he lives.
Q. More accessible but less participatory?
A. Clearly less participatory. For example, the subsidies the Government now provides for Presidential candidates go very heavily into television and very little into things like bumper stickers or front-yard placards or having people stuff envelopes. What used to be -- I would say well into the 60's -- what used to be the absolute essence of politics, the participation of individuals, has been greatly lessened.
Q. Has that in turn weakened the ability of politics to take up problems that the people care about? Is it such a one-way street that Presidents are more cut off than they were 20 or 30 years ago?
A. I'm not absolutely certain of that, because I think a President could, if he would, be better informed than I regard President Bush as being. But because television is so powerful and its reach is so broad it's much easier for a President, or a governor or a senator, to try to avoid the issue that is on people's minds, like the recession, and to try to create some other issue.
The major problem the country faces in 1992, at least it would seem now, is the economic recession and the long-term economic problem. I don't believe that President Bush could absolutely take the country's mind off of that by something like the Willie Horton ad. But he could more nearly do that now, because of television, than he might have been able to do in the past.
Q. Newspapers have changed too, of course, since you began as the editor of The Sandhill Citizen in Aberdeen, N.C.
A. You really can't get away from the influence of television on newspapers, either. But to the extent you can, the major changes I've seen have been cyclical or, one might say, circular. Following the war in Vietnam and on into the 70's with Watergate, journalists became much more skeptical and inquiring than they had been. They began to go behind things more clearly, to challenge political candidates, because they had been burned by too great a willingness to acquiesce in the views of politicians. Unfortunately, that lesson didn't last too long and by now journalism has lapsed too nearly back into acquiescence.
 
J.F.K. (and 'J.F.K.') and Vietnam

 
Q. There's been a lot of speculation over the last 25 years about what John Kennedy would have done about Vietnam. In an ancillary way, this has come up again because of the Oliver Stone movie. What's your view -- where was Kennedy really going before 1963 and what sort of policy would he have followed in Vietnam?
A. Well, in my book "J.F.K. and L.B.J.," I speculated on that -- and I think my evidence has grown since then -- it's entirely possible that Kennedy, if he wouldn't actually have withdrawn from Vietnam, would never have carried us as far into it as President Johnson did. This is one of the very few things I agree with Oliver Stone about in his new film.
I base that primarily on the rather subjective judgment that all Presidents feel the need to prove themselves as tough guys. Kennedy had already done that, if not at the Bay of Pigs, certainly in the Cuban missile crisis. And I think he didn't feel that necessity anymore. President Johnson did when he took over. And it's true, I think, that Kennedy had looked at that situation in Southeast Asia and seen it as one that could lead us into great difficulties.
It's possible that he would have over the years eased us out. I hasten to add that I do not think that that's established as fact.
The fact of which Oliver Stone makes a great deal -- that they were going to withdraw 1,000 troops at the end of 1963 -- I don't think is tremendously significant. I've always regarded that as being much more nearly a political manifestation for 1964.
 
On Playing the Race Card

 
Q. Relations between the races: this is an abiding concern of yours. Where do we stand today? Are we making progress or not?
A. I think the attitudes between the races, the fear and the animosity that exist today, are greater than, let us say, at the time of the Brown case, the famous school desegregation decision in 1954. Now that's a judgment that's very difficult to make, and I'm sure if you were living in the worst parts of Alabama or Mississippi at that time, you wouldn't agree.
The great triumph of the civil rights movement, in fact, is the progress in the South. A great deal needed to be done. And, of course, that's why so much has been done: segregation was obvious and it was state-supported; it could be attacked in the courts; it was, and it was ended.
But even there, the attitudes have not necessarily been changed. And the attitudes meanwhile in New York City and Boston and other places -- my own feeling is that racial animosities and fears in New York City are far greater than anything I ever knew growing up in the segregated South.
Where have we gone wrong? In the approach to legal segregation and discrimination problems, we've done rather well. In the greater problem of reconciling people and causing them to live peacefully together and to accord respect to each other, we've not done so well.
Q. Why should George Bush who, after all, grew up in an environment where he met a lot of right-thinking people about civil rights, have been willing to play the Willie Horton card and in general move as he has?
A. I don't want to comment on what George Bush's motives may be; I don't know him that well. But I would certainly say that he is impressed by the power of the right wing within the Republican Party. And the right wing of the Republican party is not the most advanced in liberal thinking on the race question.
I also think, and this is a guess, that he simply doesn't fully understand the conditions that exist. After three -- or is it four? -- major civil rights laws have been passed and a number of things have happened, a lot of Americans feel: "Well, we've done all of that. The civil rights revolution is over. We were confronted with a crisis; we solved it; and now here these people are -- they want more." George Bush may be one of them. But I emphasize that that is a supposition.
Q. You have been identified with a number of other issues that aren't what most people would call light entertainment -- criminal justice, nuclear weapons, the global environment, to name some. Does a columnist choose topics like that, or do they choose him?
A. Some of these things come about circumstantially. I've written a great deal since 1971 about criminal justice issues, primarily because of my almost accidental involvement in the Attica prison revolt in 1971. I was called in there as a sort of an observer to -- as I thought at least -- to observe whatever agreement was being worked out and to give it some validity, to see to it that the state would keep its part of the bargain. That wasn't the case at all; those of us who went to Attica, we turned out to be the negotiators, which is a rather odd role for journalists and one in which I was uncomfortable.
But that whole thing awakened my interest in criminal justice matters, and since then I have devoted a great many of my columns and of my thought and concern to those issues, which are really important to American life.
In the same way I almost never wrote anything about nuclear weapons which, of course, were a major issue of the time, but it just wasn't something that engaged me. And then the SALT II treaty failed in the late 70's, failed in the Senate. And that struck me with such force -- that an arms limitation treaty would fail -- that I began to get into that subject. And in the 80's, I suppose I wrote about nuclear weapons and nuclear arms negotiations as much as any other single issue. And I'm glad I did.
As far as environmental questions are concerned, it's almost the same way. Just as the years passed, it began to be clear to me that these were issues of enormous importance. Back in the 60's I used to write about clean water and clean air because I was a fisherman and I was interested in those things, but I wasn't thinking about it in any great cosmic, global sense, you know.
 
The Measure of Greatness

 
Q. You've had a close-up view of so many extraordinary people over the years. Do you have any heroes out of all that?
A. I think it tends to work the other way. Which doesn't mean that I look at all those people with contempt -- quite the opposite. But the journalist's perspective makes you see the feet of clay and the warts, and that's a good thing. I found them in many cases to be truly engaging human beings and admirable persons but not really, in the long run, impeccable heroes, or even just heroes without the "impeccable."
We should try to see people as clearly as we can. Then if a hero does come into view, why, we can give him his due.
Q. Happy New Year, Tom.
A. Same to you. Bye.

HEADLINE: THE REGION;
New Business Would be Nice But So Would Breaking Even

BYLINE: By SARAH BARTLETT

 BODY:
OF all the departures by city officials at this mid-point in the Dinkins administration, the one that is likely to prove most significant is that of the deputy mayor of finance and economic development, Sally Hernandez-Pinero.
With businesses threatening daily to leave the city, unemployment at over 10 percent and pervasive doubts about the city's ability to compete with other urban centers, the person who charts the next round of economic development policies could have great influence over the direction of the city. 
 "I think this is an absolutely critical job," said Peter C. Goldmark Jr., president of the Rockefeller Foundation and a former executive director of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. "At the end of the next two years, people have to be able to sense that a couple of things have been done to turn things around over the long term and to show us that there is a future."
Ms. Hernandez-Pinero's resignation has not yet been officially confirmed. But it is an open secret at City Hall that she will be leaving shortly to spend more time with her two young children, and a search has been under way for her successor for over a month. Ms. Hernandez-Pinero, who was formerly the commissioner of the Financial Services Corporation, a now-defunct agency that offered loans, grants and energy cost reductions to keep employers in the city, is expected to remain a key Dinkins adviser, and to become one of the Housing Authority's three board members.
Among the many names being bandied about as her replacement are Arthur C. Levitt Jr., former head of the American Stock Exchange and chairman of a newspaper and magazine company, Thomas S. Johnson, former president of both Chemical Bank and the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation, Roger C. Altman, an investment banker and former Assistant Secretary of the Treasury in the Carter Administration who is co-chairman of the mayor's Management Advisory Task Force, and Carl Weisbrod, president of the city's Economic Development Corporation.
Traditionally, the city's economic development agencies have tried to promote development projects and help companies willing to stay in the city. That can mean anything from making small-business loans to offering technical assistance to helping with property tax relief to administering cable franchises.
Already, the various constituencies around the city are vying for their candidates and the chance to make sure that their pet issues are at the top of the next deputy mayor's list. The New York City Partnership, which represents the city's largest businesses, would like someone from the business community who will press their case for a freeze on property taxes and a smaller, leaner city government. The real estate community wants the next person to be sympathetic to granting tax incentives to build more buildings. And labor groups want to see someone who will accelerate investment in public works projects, thus creating jobs.
 
'Captive to Entrenched Forces'
 "The danger is that whoever comes in will become captive to some of the entrenched forces in the city," said Mitchell L. Moss, professor of urban planning at New York University's Robert F. Wagner Graduate School of Public Service. That would be a great shame, he feels, because now is the moment when a person free of ties to the traditional power structure could take a bolder, more creative approach.
Some experts, including Mr. Moss, say this is the moment to redefine the job, and they offer a few innovative suggestions.
First of all, they say, forget about trying to correct the problems caused by the current recession. It's too late.
Instead, maybe the next deputy mayor should be an "investment czar" who oversees all capital spending, speeding up its pace when necessary and focusing energy on the city's ailing infrastructure.
Or maybe he or she should be in charge of city efforts to persuade the various public authorities in the region to coordinate the spending of the hundreds of millions of dollars they pour into local projects. Right now, city officials have limited contact with them, Mr. Goldmark said.
Maybe the next deputy mayor should have ties not to the city's business community, but to overseas businesses who could send more European, Asian and Latin American companies here.
Maybe the Department of Cultural Affairs should be in the deputy mayor's portfolio, recognizing its role in attracting people and resources to the city.
 
Too Little Time
 Thus far the administration seems to be persuaded that its most critical need is to find someone acceptable to the city's traumatized large businesses.
"The Mayor feels very strongly that it needs to be someone recognized in the business community," said Ms. Hernandez-Pinero. "They'll embrace and support one of their own." Also, she said, there is simply not enough time left in this term of the Dinkins administration for any successor to her to build the necessary credibility with the big businesses that play such a major role in the economy.
Some people argue that this is exactly the wrong approach to be taking at this time. If anything, they argue, there has been too much focus on short-term rescue efforts for businesses in trouble and not enough on fashioning plans to propel the city into the next century.
Ms. Hernandez-Pinero, for instance, has struggled to rethink the way the city has been subsidizing old-line manufacturers, the lack of support offered to many promising new businesses, and the merits of taking a more regional approach to economic development -- competing with Atlanta, for instance, rather than with Jersey City. But she has gotten bound up in endless meetings over the budget crisis. And she says she has had to spend 25 to 30 percent of her time trying to come up with ways to keep companies that are threatening to leave. Focusing on the broader policy issues, she said with a sigh, has been the hardest part of her job.

HEADLINE: HEADLINERS;
Right Numbers

 BODY:
In her more than 13 years as the head of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, Janet L. Norwood earned a reputation for having zero tolerance for numbers that lied. Dr. Norwood, who retired last week, is known not merely as a stickler for accuracy -- that goes with the territory -- but also for refusing to let her statistics be pressed into political service. She would say that if you mess with the data base -- perhaps by manipulating unemployment figures to justify an economic policy -- you mess with democracy. Such attitudes led one senator to deem her "a national treasure." Discussing her retirement last week, the 68-year-old Dr. Norton expressed concern that Washington might not be managing the ever growing stream of economic information as well as some others. "We are really not operating internationally as effectively as we ought," she said. "I'm concerned about the increasing effectiveness of other countries. I worry about where we will be 10 or 15 years from now."

HEADLINE: THE REGION;
Suddenly, Towns Fight To Keep Their Garbage

BYLINE: By SARAH LYALL

DATELINE: BABYLON, L.I.

 BODY:
YEARS ago, the town of Babylon was so concerned about the dwindling space in its landfill that the supervisor himself patrolled the dump with a gun, turning away out-of-town garbage. But now that the dump is closed and Babylon burns its trash in an incinerator, the town is finding itself in a strange and unforeseen situation: it wants all the garbage it can get.
It doesn't seem to make sense. But Babylon's situation is being repeated throughout New York and New Jersey, and the reason lies in the changing nature of trash disposal in the garbage-glutted Northeast. As alternatives dwindle and prices go up, municipalities are finding that the only way to pay for their new, expensive electricity-generating incinerators or recycling operations is to take in as much trash as possible and charge their residents hefty fees for dumping it. 
 The town of North Hempstead, L.I., for example, has seen its garbage costs go up and up over the years. It now pays about $24 million a year to run its recycling program, pay off debts incurred to buy land next to its landfill, operate the huge town transfer station, and clean up its closed landfill, which is on the Federal Superfund list of toxic waste sites needing attention soon. To pay for all this, it charges its residents $104 a ton for garbage through their villages or garbage districts and demands that everyone within the town use the town's facilities.
"You build a system to handle a certain amount of waste, and then you need that much waste to pay for the system," explained Thomas Melito, deputy supervisor of the town of Babylon.
But now the local facilities are often the worst deals around for the garbage-hauler. In Essex County, N.J., for instance, the "tipping fee" -- the price to drop off a load at the county incinerator -- is between $60 and $70 a ton. But the tipping fees at landfills from Pennsylvania to Oklahoma can be as low $12 or $13 a ton, and the incinerator -- which needs about 2,500 tons of trash a day to pay off its debts and burn steadily enough to generate steam for the electric power it sells -- sometimes finds itself scrambling for trash.
"There are cheaper rates elsewhere, and the garbage tends to go to the lowest price," said Deborah Schneekloth, project manager for the incinerator.
All this leads to a lot of confusion, as municipalities that once fought to keep trash out are now trying to keep it in. It's very hard, even though many towns and counties like North Hempstead have "flow control" laws which say that any garbage generated within their borders belongs to them. In their desire to enforce the laws, some towns have been reduced to actually trailing the trash to insure that it ends up in the right place.
 
Get in a Car
 "You literally have to get into a car and follow a garbage truck around," said Ray E. Cowen, Long Island regional director of the State Department of Environmental Conservation.
Flow-control laws have generally stood up to court challenges. But in a ruling that sent frissons through the garbage community, a State Supreme Court Justice declared North Hempstead's flow control law unconstitutional last week. If the decision is upheld it could deny the town some 95,000 tons of trash a year and even drive its Solid Waste Management Authority into bankruptcy.
Meanwhile, Long Island is bleeding garbage. It is hard to tell how much, but Mr. Cowen estimated that some 2,000 of the 10,000 tons of trash generated here each day go unaccounted for and are probably shipped off the island, mostly in violation of flow-control laws.
"It seems that there's a complicated shell game being played with Long Island's trash," said Steven A. Romalewski, a garbage expert for the New York Public Interest Research Group, which suports environmental and consumer causes. "Garbage is being moved around and we really don't know where it's going."
Connecticut, which wrote plans and long-term contracts years ago, seems to have avoided most of this problem. But in New York and New Jersey, where there are thousands of garbage districts and garbage-collection methods, it is virtually impossible to keep track of all the trash.
In Washington County in upstate New York, the incinerator is short about 300 tons of trash a day it needs, said James D. Willis, director of solid waste for the Warren-Washington Counties Industrial Development Agency. And in the town of Huntington on Long Island, an incinerator with a capacity of 900 or so tons a day has been taking in just 550 a day.
"There's plenty of garbage around, but it's not coming in," said Herbert A. Smith, the departing director of Huntington's resource recovery project.
The companies that ship garbage to the Midwest at the lower prices argue that this is simply the free market at work. But environmental and municipal officials say free-market economics and won't protect garbage exporters for long. New York and New Jersey, they say, are finally beginning to pay the true cost of garbage disposal at home. The rest of the country, they believe, will eventually follow suit.
"It's not a level playing field," Mr. Cowen said. "The low prices that people are being quoted involve some sort of out-of-state shipment to facilities that don't have the same regulations that we have in New York State. And in fact, what we're going to see is that these out-of-state options may dry up."
This spring, Congress is to consider legislation that would allow states to impose huge surcharges on out-of-state garbage, or to ban shipments of it altogether. When that happens, Mr. Cowen said, New York and New Jersey will be forced to handle their own garbage themselves.
"We're getting lulled into a false sense of security by these low-ball contracts," Mr. Cowen said. "Something's going to happen on the Federal level that will chase the waste back to Long Island, and when that happens, I don't know if we're going to be ready for it."

HEADLINE: BUSH TO PROPOSE INCOME TAX CREDIT FOR HEALTH COSTS

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4

 BODY:
In his budget request to Congress later this month, President Bush intends to propose tax credits to help people buy health insurance, further cuts in military spending and major new restrictions on the payment of Government benefits to the affluent, Administration officials say.
Mr. Bush's advisers say the tax credits will be the centerpiece of his election-year strategy to show that he has a substantial domestic policy and to fend off attacks by Democrats who contend he has no plan to aid the 34 million Americans who lack health insurance. 
 The President is also under political pressure to revive the economy. His budget is expected to forecast economic growth for 1992 of 2.5 percent to 3 percent, about the range expected by many private economists.
 
$2,000 Credit Is Weighed
 To combat the recession, Mr. Bush is expected to propose some type of tax benefits for first-time home buyers, and Administration officials said they were considering a tax credit of up to $2,000 for such buyers. While traveling today in Singapore, Mr. Bush said he would like to put any savings from cuts in the military budget "into the pockets of the American taxpayer."
Administration officials say the President also intends to propose once again a cut in the tax on capital gains, the profits from investments. He is also likely to ask Congress to restore some sort of tax credit for business investment in plants and equipment.
Even some Republicans question whether those measures would be sufficient to stimulate the economy, but Administration officials see them as necessary for political reasons.
A budget request is always a political document, and that is particularly true in a Presidential election year. Mr. Bush's campaign strategists say he probably cannot get re-elected on foreign policy and domestic promises alone, and they see the budget request as a manifesto for the campaign.
The President's budget request for the 1993 fiscal year will comply with overall spending limits set in the bipartisan budget agreement enacted in November 1990, Administration officials said. But they said he was considering removing the ban on shifting money between the military and domestic budgets.
The officials said that in view of the collapse of the Soviet Union and the demise of communism throughout the former Soviet bloc, Mr. Bush will propose a military budget below the maximum allowed by the 1990 budget law. They predicted that he would seek $285 billion in military spending for the next fiscal year, which begins in October. The limit for military spending is $291.5 billion.
By moving on his own to pare the military budget, Mr. Bush hopes to pre-empt efforts by Congress to make deeper cuts, officials said. He is likely to seek cancellation of weapons systems like the Seawolf, a nuclear-powered submarine whose main mission -- attacking Soviet submarines -- now seems outdated, budget officials said.
 
Tax Credits for Insurance
 Administration officials say the tax credits for buying health insurance are consistent with the Republican precept that the Government not impose costly new mandates on employers or establish a vast new Federal program of national health insurance to supplant the private market.
Tax credits are a prominent feature of a health-care bill introduced in November by Senator John H. Chafee of Rhode Island and 20 other Republican Senators. That bill, like the proposals being drafted by the Administration, would authorize tax credits to help individuals, families and businesses buy health insurance or health-care services.
Administration officials say Mr. Bush will describe his philosophy and general approach to "health-care reform" in his State of the Union Message, scheduled for Jan. 28, or in his 1993 budget request, which goes to Congress within a few days of the speech. Detailed proposals would follow a few months later.
"Serious decisions have been made, but some hard political calls remain," said Gail R. Wilensky, head of the Federal Health Care Financing Administration, which runs Medicare and Medicaid, the health programs for the elderly and the poor.
Tax credits are offset against income taxes; a tax credit of $500 reduces a person's tax liability by that amount. Under the proposal contemplated by the Administration, the credit would be refundable. In other words, the Government would pay an amount equal to the credit to people so poor that they pay no income tax.
 
Having to 'Face Realities'
 As for the military budget, Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, said in an interview this week: "It's almost a certainty that there will be further reductions in defense spending. We've just got to face realities."
Mr. McCain sits on the Armed Services Committee and supports the Pentagon on most issues. But he favors cancellation of the Seawolf submarine, which, when loaded with weapons and electronic equipment, costs more than $2 billion a vessel. The Administration said last year it was planning to buy seven of the submarines from 1992 through 1997.
"It is an excellent piece of equipment, but it consumes over one-fourth of the entire shipbuilding budget," Mr. McCain said. "I don't believe the threat it was designed to face, Soviet submarines, is there any more, certainly not with the priority that deserves that type of expenditure."
The Electric Boat division of the General Dynamics Corporation, in Groton, Conn., is building the first Seawolf and expects to deliver it to the Navy in 1996, said Neil D. Ruenzel, spokesman for the shipyard.
Mr. McCain also wants to end production of B-2, or Stealth, bombers. He predicted there would be "a free-for-all" over the Pentagon budget as Congress re-examines the 1990 budget agreement and reassesses threats to national security.
 
Trimming Benefits to Rich
 As part of his budget request, Mr. Bush is expected to propose some type of tax relief for middle-income families. He also intends to make a systematic effort to cut Government costs of providing benefits to high-income households under programs like Medicare and farm-price supports. Last February, Mr. Bush floated the idea of limiting benefits for the most affluent families. Now, Administration officials say, Mr. Bush plans to expand the idea.
Mr. Bush's new proposal would more than triple the monthly Medicare premium, now $31.80, for people with incomes exceeding $125,000 a year.
Medicare, Social Security and veterans' compensation are called "entitlement programs" because anyone who meets the criteria is entitled to benefits. Last month Mr. Bush expressed concern about their growth, saying: "When you take a look at some of the entitlement programs, therein lies the real expansion of Government spending. What can be done about them? We're talking about that right now."
Mr. Bush overruled his budget director, Richard G. Darman, in one politically sensitive area: health-care benefits for veterans.
The Secretary of Veterans Affairs, Edward J. Derwinski, appealed successfully to Mr. Bush to restore money that Mr. Darman cut from the department's 1993 budget request.
In an interview, Mr. Derwinski said Mr. Darman would have allowed an increase of $750 million above the 1992 budget for veterans' health care, which totals $13.6 billion. After talking to the President, Mr. Derwinski won an increase of $1 billion over the 1992 figure. In recent years, Congress and veterans' groups have insisted on an increase of at least $1 billion a year in this account.
The Department of Veterans Affairs is the largest health-care provider in the United States, with 172 hospitals, 127 nursing homes and 93 clinics.
In his budget request last year, Mr. Bush predicted incorrectly that the recession would be "short and shallow." The new forecast is less rosy, and assumes that the economy will be flat or will shrink slightly in the first three months of this year; it envisions slight growth in the second quarter, followed by stronger growth in the remainder of the year.
The condition of the economy influences the outcome of Presidential elections. In the six elections since World War II in which the candidate of the incumbent party prevailed, the economy grew an average of 4.6 percent. In the five elections in which the incumbent party lost, the average growth was 3 percent.

HEADLINE: U.S. Sees Major Policy Shift in Plan for Commonwealth Loans

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

 BODY:
The United States' decision to endorse full membership in two international lending institutions for six former Soviet republics is the latest sign of a sweeping change in American policy toward taking responsibility for their economic recovery, Administration and banking officials said yesterday.
The changes, first spelled out by Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d last month in his Soviet policy speech at Princeton, are forcing agencies across the Federal Government to reconsider longstanding policies. 
 The Treasury Department had opposed full membership for the Soviet Union for more than a year, but changed its position after the United States recently gave formal recognition to the 12 former republics and established diplomatic ties with Russia, Ukraine, Kazakhstan, Belarus, Kyrgyzstan and Armenia. The State Department also pushed for greater assistance, said Administration officials who spoke on condition of anonymity.
"The Baker speech in Princeton signaled a fundamental shift from confrontation to collective engagement," an official said.
Enabling Russia and five other former republics to borrow money from the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund will allow industrialized countries to provide money with less effect on their recession-strained budgets.
A series of several separate applications, instead of the single application received from the entire Soviet Union in July, will also ease but not eliminate the major bureaucratic obstacle to membership in the International Monetary Fund, Administration and banking officials said.
Whereas the entire Soviet Union might have been judged to have a larger economy than Britain or France, thereby giving it the basis to claim a powerful permanent seat on the lending institution's executive board, Russia by itself does not have so large an economy.
Russian membership in the International Monetary Fund alone could result in loans of up to $5 billion a year, although Administration officials said smaller amounts were more likely.
 
Plunging Ruble
 The exact amount of annual borrowing would depend on the size of the initial Russian contribution, which could vary from $2 billion to nearly $5 billion under the organization's bylaws, depending on several factors including the exchange rate used to calculate the size of the Russian economy. The ruble has plunged to more than 100 to the dollar.
Only 23 percent of the initial contribution would have to be given in internationally traded currencies like the dollar, the German mark or the Japanese yen, a sum that likely would be lent by Western governments.
The announcement Friday of the United States' endorsement of full membership also represents a raid on two huge sums of money and thousands of economic development experts who for the last two decades have been dedicated largely to helping the third world. The International Monetary Fund and the World Bank already find their staffs stretched thin.
The fund has already been forced for the first time in its 46-year history to tell several dozen member countries that it can no longer perform annual reviews of their economic policies, but instead will do them every two years. The reviews have traditionally provided an objective basis for political debate in those countries and international lending to them.
And unless the fund's 156 member countries agree soon to lend it an extra $60 billion, the institution might be forced to cut back on lending to the third world next year, people with an intimate knowledge of the institution's financial health said. The increase was to have been approved by the end of last month by the members, but the United States has yet to adopt the necessary legislation.

HEADLINE: U.S. Exit From Manila: Making of a Hasty Retreat

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4

 BODY:
Seven months ago, the Bush Administration was on the brink of a deal with the Philippine Government to extend by seven years its lease on two huge military bases in the Philippines.
Today, the United States military is packing up ships, supplies and ammunition, and preparing to leave the Philippines by the end of the year, closing out an American military presence in the country that has lasted nearly a century. 
 One small American naval operation will be transferred from the Philippines to Singapore, President Bush announced there early today. Mr. Bush, on the second stop of a four-nation Asian and Pacific trip, said the Seventh Fleet's logistics operations will be based in Singapore.
How the Administration's expectations of a long, phased Philippine withdrawal collapsed into a hasty retreat from two of its largest and oldest overseas bases is the result of an unusual combination of events, including the eruption of a volcano, the demise of the Soviet Union, an assertion of Philippine nationalism, and shrinking Pentagon budgets.
 
Slow Pullout Planned
 Closing the sprawling Subic Bay naval base, coupled with the abandoning of Clark Air Base this past summer after the eruption of Mount Pinatubo, forces the largest reduction to date of United States forces in the western Pacific.
American negotiators, who opened talks in Manila in May 1990 on the future of the bases, say they braced themselves for months of intense bargaining in a political climate that emphasized Philippine sovereignty interests. Indeed, Washington planned to gradually withdraw its forces over the life of a new lease. But the Administration's final decisions were largely driven by events outside the negotiators' control.
American negotiators and senior Navy officers say they also considered the risks and advantages of staying or leaving. For all its highly touted ship-repair yards, supply depots and training centers, how much was Subic Bay really worth to the United States? If Manila's asking price was too steep, what was the political risk of browbeating the Philippine Government into accepting less? What were the costs of alternate sites in the Pacific region?
"We wanted an agreement, but not at any price," said Richard L. Armitage, a former Assistant Secretary of Defense who was the chief American negotiator in the talks with Manila.
 
Lost Training Ranges
 Mr. Armitage and current Pentagon officials said that a review of the installations' security value, made before the negotiations, downgraded them from vital to important.
Collapsing into 12 months what, under a previous proposal, was essentially a 10-year withdrawal has forced the American military to scramble. Pacific commanders say the greatest loss will be the prized Philippine naval, marine and air force training ranges -- especially a bombing range near Clark. But replacing Subic Bay will be less costly than expected, they say, partly because its functions will be parceled out to other bases rather than moved in whole. The Navy had estimated in the late 1980's that it would cost more than $3 billion to duplicate Subic Bay at a single site elsewhere in the region.
"It's not going to be as bad as we originally thought," Adm. Charles R. Larson, head of American forces in the Pacific, said in a telephone interview. "We've found that most functions can be disestablished or relocated without significant construction costs."
The Air Force has moved to a new bombing range in Alaska. The Navy has started shipping tons of ammunition to Hawaii, and plans to spread depots and ship-repair work to installations in Guam, Japan and Singapore. Training areas in Japan and South Korea are being readied for Marines and special-operations forces.
 
Countering the Soviets
 Subic Bay, in particular, has been important to the Navy since Commodore George Dewey sailed into Manila Bay to vanquish the occupying Spanish fleet in 1898. After the Philippines gained independence in 1946, Clark, Subic Bay and several smaller installations remained under a series of negotiated pacts.
The importance of Clark and Subic Bay increased after the Vietnam War, when the Soviet Navy began operating from the Cam Ranh Bay naval base in Vietnam, an installation on one of the world's finest harbors.
Subic Bay employs 29,000 Filipinos and pumps more than $300 million into the Philippine economy. But bases have been increasingly unpopular with Philippine nationalists, for whom the bases were a symbol of colonialism and dependency.
In simplest terms, Manila's decision last month to evict the United States stemmed from an impasse in tense, 20-month-long negotiations about extending the 1947 base agreement.
During that time, the value of the bases eroded under the combined weight of the decline of the Soviet Union, Mount Pinatubo's continuing eruptions, growing frustration in Congress with the Government of President Corazon C. Aquino, and lawmakers' opposition to financing bases overseas when installations at home were closing.
Negotiators were under marching orders from Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney and Secretary of States James A. Baker 3d to avoid striking what Mr. Armitage called a "straight real-estate deal." Rather, they were to seek a broader, regional security partnership with Manila that called for a reduction in American troops at the bases.
 
Narrowing Differences
 As the first of eight rounds of discussions opened in May 1990, Mrs. Aquino served American negotiators with notice that her Government was canceling the existing base agreement, effective in September 1991.
The Philippine negotiating team, headed by Foreign Secretary Raul Manglapus, demanded $825 million a year in cash and aid to extend the lease for seven years. The United States countered with an offer of $363 million a year for a decade. By May, the two sides had narrowed their differences. Only a few technical details remained on a tentative seven-year pact of $363 million in annual aid.
Then came the act of God no one predicted: the eruption of Mount Pinatubo in June. The value of Clark, buried under tons of volcanic ash, plummeted, and the base was abandoned. Washington was willing to pay $203 million a year for just Subic, and for at least 10 years -- terms the Aquino Government agreed to on Aug. 27.
But that smaller aid offer insulted many fervent Philippine nationalists, some of whom had spokesmen in the country's Senate. Many of the nationalists were upset that their dreams of converting Clark into a commercial airport were no longer possible.
 
'We'll Pactk Up and Leave'
 "No amount of bases money can take the place of sovereignty, independence and the well-being of future generations of Filipinos," Senator Agapito Aquino, President Aquino's brother-in-law, said at the time.
With a Sept. 16 ratification vote planned in the Philippine Senate, senior American officials dug in their heels in the hope that "shock therapy" would sway undecided legislators.
"We've made our best offer," said President Bush a week before the vote. "There will be no change on the part of the United States."
The same day, Defense Secretary Cheney said that while a treaty rejection would be a "a real tragedy for the Philippines, we'll pack up and leave -- that's it."
Treaty supporters in the 23-member Senate fell 5 votes short of the two-thirds margin -- 16 votes -- that was needed for approval.
