HEADLINE: Pennsylvania City Hopes It's Bouncing Back From the Bottom

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHESTER, Pa., Jan. 4

 BODY:
This small city of 42,000 people, surrounded by the thriving middle-class suburbs west of Philadelphia, has one of the highest concentrations of urban problems in America.
Its schools and public housing rank among the worst, as do the city's rates for crime, joblessness, truancy, teen-age pregnancy and infant mortality. Homelessness, drug abuse and AIDS are major problems. 
 But a series of startling changes in Chester is raising hopes among residents that the city is bouncing back after hitting bottom.
The United States Department of Housing and Urban Development, saying that the city's housing authority was in "total and complete breakdown," took over management of that agency last month. This month, the state increased its supervision of the school system, forcing its officials to address the truancy rate and what has regularly been the highest teacher absentee rate and lowest standardized test scores in the state.
Attacking corruption, the county district attorney recently won convictions of a member of the City Council and three members of the city's redevelopment authority on charges that included ethics violations and accepting bribes from contractors.
And in a stunning upset, a grass-roots voter-registration drive helped Democrats win control of city government in the November elections. Republicans, who outnumber Democrats 2 to 1 in this predominantly black city, have controlled the government since 1866.
 
Intriguing to the Experts
 Urban experts say Chester is an intriguing case study because it has all the virulent social problems of an inner city, but the number of people affected is relatively small and the city's isolation amid suburbs protects it from the sprawling blight common in big cities.
These experts also say the five-mile-square city has great development potential because of its abundance of inexpensive land and its convenient location: Chester is on the Delaware River three miles west of Philadelphia International Airport and has easy access to regional rail lines and interstate highways.
"Chester would be a good laboratory for trying to deal with hard social problems," said Richard P. Nathan, director of the Rockefeller Institute of Government in Albany. "The new leadership should have success with that argument in reaching out for foundation grants and trying to obtain more county, state and Federal support."
Indeed, the city's newly elected leaders, who take office Monday, say they are aware of the potential benefits that come with the city's plight and they plan to take advantage of offers of help they have already received from political, academic and community leaders.
Chester's decline is of relatively recent vintage. William Penn, having bought Pennsylvania from King Charles II, sailed up the Delaware River in 1682, stepped ashore here and named the settlement Chester, after the English city of his birth. The community thrived for 175 years, building the first iron-clad ships and becoming one of the world's busiest shipyards.
 
A Feeling of History
 That sense of history is more alive on the west side of Chester, where most of the whites live in old stone houses on Nob Hill, near the well-groomed campus of Widener University. Interstate 95 separates this suburban scene from the east side, with its blighted business district and waterfront littered with abandoned industrial buildings.
The east side still evokes the feeling of a Colonial village with narrow winding streets and small brick buildings, but each intersection has a knot of homeless beggars and all the movie theaters, the bowling alleys and a skating rink have closed.
"No one wants to live the way we do in Chester," said Barbara Bohannan-Sheppard, a 41-year-old nurse who operated a day care center in her home before she became the first Democrat to win a mayoral election here since 1905. "We have good qualified people in Chester, but the example we've set for our children has been that if you want to be a success you better stand on the corner or push drugs or do something illegal."
The election of Ms. Bohannan-Sheppard, who as Mayor is on the five-member City Council, and two other Democratic council members, will give Democrats their first majority on the council in 125 years.
"We're going to have town meetings, we're going to work as a team and we're going to step on a lot of toes to make changes around here," Ms. Bohannan-Sheppard said in a recent interview.
On a wintry day, several residents shared the feelings of guarded optimism about the future. But some were wary of counting on the new administration. "Taxes are too high here, and a lot of businesses are pulling out of Chester," said William F. Severs, the manager of a downtown shoe store. Last month, the city raised real estate taxes, already among the highest in the county, by 26 percent to $144 for $1,000 of assessed value from $114.
The newly elected officials have no government experience, but are brimming with optimism. "A lot of people are lined up to help us: lawyers, judges, the Governor's office, even the Mayor of Wilmington," said Annette Burton, a 51-year-old community college administrator, mother of 10 children and one of two Democratic council members. Charles McLaughlin, a 54-year-old aircraft inspector and union official, was the other.
Chester's Republican Party machine, one of the nation's oldest, has also been called one of the most corrupt in recent decades by state officials. The Pennsylvania Crime Commission, an investigative agency of the State Legislature, said in a report last year that Chester's government had been dominated by "a triad of criminals, corrupt politicians and rogue law-enforcement officers" since the 1960's.
During Chester's long prosperity as an industrial center, unskilled workers found high-paying jobs in steel mills, shipyards, aircraft engine factories, slaughterhouses and a Ford Motor Company plant. But at an increasing pace over the last 40 years, because of high labor costs and increased competition, all but two major companies closed or moved to the South; at the same time, more Southern blacks moved into Chester and many white residents moved to the suburbs.
As the population fell, from 63,000 as recently as 1970 to 42,000 last year, it became two-thirds black and increasingly poor and elderly. About one of every six residents lives in public housing, one family in three receives public assistance and about one adult in three is unemployed, the city estimates.
 
Powerful Republican Boss
 But the Republicans stayed in power, with the help of patronage jobs and favors. Last year's crime commission report concluded: "Government in Chester is Jack Nacrelli," referring to John H. Nacrelli, the 61-year-old Republican Party boss, who holds no official position.
Mr. Nacrelli was Mayor from 1968 until 1979, when he was convicted of racketeering and income tax evasion for taking $22,000 in bribes from an illegal gambling operation with ties to organized crime. The report says Mr. Nacrelli continued to run a "shadow government" during and after his two-year imprisonment and made most political appointments in city agencies and the school system.
Mr. Nacrelli, who has apparently moved, could not be located for comment on the report.
 
Facing a Big Deficit

The outgoing City Council, facing a projected deficit of 17 percent in its $22 million budget for the fiscal year 1992, convened Dec. 27 and, amid a raucous demonstration by city employees, voted unanimously to lay off nearly a quarter of the municipal work force. In all, 15 of 105 police officers and 56 other workers were laid off immediately.
Members of the new administration said they would reconsider the layoffs and would submit a new budget by the end of February. Ms. Bohannan-Sheppard, the newly elected Mayor, said, "We can't even get a copy of the budget, and they say they have zero money in the bank."
But the city's backers are optimistic. "Chester is the kind of place where you walk down the street and men still tip their hats to you, and the churches are filled on Sundays," said Ann G. Torregrossa, executive director of the Delaware County Legal Assistance Association in Chester and the lead lawyer on several successful lawsuits on behalf of citizens' housing and school groups.
"If there is a place where we should be able to turn things around, it's Chester," she said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: "We're going to have town meetings, we're going to work as a team and we're going to step on a lot of toes to make changes around here," said Barbara Bohannan-Sheppard, the newly elected mayor of Chester, Pa., She recently visited the city's William Penn Housing Project. (Bill Cramer for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Arabs Delay Leaving for Talks But U.S. Expects a Resumption

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4

 BODY:
Syria, Lebanon and Jordan postponed the departure of their negotiating teams today for the second round of peace talks with Israel in Washington, joining the Palestinians in protest over Israel's planned deportation of 12 Palestinians from the occupied territories.
United States officials said, however, that they expected the Palestinians, Syrians, Jordanians and Lebanese to turn up in Washington, where the talks are scheduled to resume at the State Department on Tuesday. The officials said that the four delegations apparently felt the need to make some gesture of protest over the Israeli actions, but that none of them appeared to want to scuttle the talks over the issue.
 
More Explosive Issue
 The chief Palestinian spokeswoman, Hanan Ashrawi, said by telephone from her home in the West Bank that the Palestinians "are making our point" by delaying their departure. But she said it was her "surmise" that the Palestinians and others would end up going to Washington, now that the United States has strongly condemned the Israeli deportation orders. At the first round of Washington negotiations in December, Israel postponed its delegation's arrival in protest the venue of the talks, which Israel had wanted to hold in the Middle East. 
 While the postponements are troubling, United States officials are more worried about another issue that could have a far more lasting and explosive impact on the negotiations: Israel's pending request for $10 billion in housing loan guarantees to resettle Soviet Jews. The loan request is coming up for reconsideration coincidental with this second round of peace talks in Washington, and how the Bush Administration responds to the Israeli request could drive either Israel or the Arabs away from the negotiating table.
When the Israeli loan guarantee request was first raised last September, the Bush Administration insisted despite Israeli complaints that it be postponed 120 days so that the issue would not complicate Washington's efforts to get the first round of the peace talks convened in Madrid.
 
U.S. Plans Demands
 The reason the loan issue might have complicated the peace talks is that the Administration intends to demand certain restrictions on any new settlements that Israel might build as a precondition for the loan guarantees. United States officials knew that this demand would lead to a dispute with the Israeli Government that might have dissuaded Israel from taking part in the peace talks.
Administration officials say recent actions by the Israeli Government have not diminished the inclination of President Bush and Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d to insist on restrictions on Israel's use of any American loan guarantees in building settlements in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip.
The actions American officials point to range from the Israeli Government's decision to allow Jewish settlers to buy homes in Silwan, an Arab neighborhood in East Jerusalem, over the protests of Mayor Teddy Kollek, to Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's promise to far-right members of his coalition last week that he would spend two-thirds of his 1992 housing construction budget -- some $350 million -- on new Jewish settlements.
One Administration official said Prime Minister Shamir is behaving in a "very short-sighted manner." The official said Mr. Shamir appears to be doing almost anything to placate far-right parties to hold his coalition together, without considering how his actions might affect President Bush and the American public at precisely the time the loan guarantee issue is coming up again.
"Obviously this is something that we will be watching very closely," said Rashid Khalidi, a historian at the University of Chicago who has served as an adviser to the Palestinian delegation. "The continuation of settlements affects vital Palestinian interests and ultimately the peace process itself. There can be peace or there can be settlements, but there can't be both."
 
No Decisions Made
 According to senior Administration officials, no decisions have been made yet on how Washington will respond to the Israeli request. All the Administration has been telling the Israelis for the past four months is that if and when such guarantees are granted, Washington reserves the right to attach certain "terms and conditions" on how the money is spent.
Israeli officials say that since September they have been trying to find out from the Administration what "terms and conditions" they might attach, particularly regarding Israeli settlement activities. "Unfortunately we have not received any answers," one Israeli official said.
"We'll address that when the President gets back from Asia next week," a senior Administration official said about the loan guarantee issue. "I would not speculate on what the outcome might be."
These loan guarantees would allow Israel to raise money from commercial banks at preferential rates of interest. The cost to the American budget depends on certain accounting rules, but would probably require at least $200 million to be set aside.
 
American Jews Mute Support
 Interestingly, many prominent American Jews, who actively lobbied the Administration for the guarantees back in September, have since adopted a much more low-key approach.
In part they recognize that the mood in America has shifted against foreign aid. In part, they realize that pro-Israeli members of Congress cannot pass the guarantees without President Bush's endorsement, and therefore the Israelis are simply going to have to negotiate with Mr. Bush about his terms. Their shift in approach is also a silent protest against Prime Minister Shamir's policies.
"It is not that the Jewish community is any less committed to the guarantees or their need, but they are aware that they are living in a totally changed political climate," said Henry Siegman, executive director of the American Jewish Congress. "It is difficult for the American Jewish community to mount a major campaign here for the guarantees because they are so important for Israel, if the Israeli Government says continuing settlements is even more important."
Abraham Foxman, executive director of the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith, added: "Domestic concerns mandate a lower profile in support of the guarantees. It would be counterproductive to have a debate on the issue at this time. We are saying to our Government and the Israeli Government, 'Work it out.' "
 
U.S. Has 3 Options
 In the view of pro-Israeli lobbyists, the Administration has basically three options. One would be for the President to postpone the issue again. This would put the primarily Democratic sponsors of the Israeli loan request in the uncomfortable position of having to take the lead in sponsoring a major foreign aid program in the middle of the election year with the economy in recession. To do nothing, though, would run the risk that the Israelis would use that as an excuse to drag their feet in the peace negotiations.
The second option would be for the Administration to support the loan guarantees -- although not necessarily the $2 billion a year for five years that Israel is seeking -- while insisting that they be granted only on condition that Israel totally freeze all settlement building activity in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip.
The problem with that option is that the Israelis would argue that the United States had forfeited its role as an "honest broker" in the negotiations by forcing Israel to freeze settlements, instead of leaving this to be negotiated with the Arabs in return for Arab concessions.
The third option -- and the one that seems to be gaining the most support in Congress -- would be for the United States to agree to limited guarantees on the condition that an amount equivalent to what Israel spends on settlements in the West Bank and Gaza Strip be deducted each year from the total. In 1991 that was roughly $560 million.
This option is explosive, though, because the Administration would have to declare whether Israeli building in East Jerusalem would be considered part of building in the occupied territories. Israel has annexed East Jerusalem, but that annexation has never been recognized by Washington. For the United States to exclude East Jerusalem building activities from the total would be to alienate the Palestinians, but to include it would mean another fight with the Israelis.

HEADLINE: Reporter's Notebook;
For Bush, Jog Overseas Beats Running at Home

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SINGAPORE, Sunday, Jan. 5

 BODY:
After President Bush took his morning jog New Year's Day at a college in Sydney, Australia, someone asked whether he had made any resolutions. He responded, as expected, with pledges to work for peace and prosperity and a slightly faster two miles around the track. And then he said something revealing.
"I'll tell you something," he said. "We are blessed with family, with kids that come home, and with the loyalty and strength that one gets when one is in public life from sons and a daughter. And so I don't have to ask for any more there, but if I were, I would simply say 'Keep it strong, Lord, because we're going into one hell of a year over there.' It's politics from tomorrow on. And it isn't very pleasant." 
 Mr. Bush clearly loves being President, flying around the world, tackling problems and schmoozing with fellow statesmen. Just as clearly, he dislikes and is somewhat daunted by the prospect of going back before the voters this year and asking for another four years on the job as he is beset by an endless recession and plummeting ratings in opinion polls.
Never has that been more evident than in the last week, as the President swept through Australia and Singapore at the start of a four-nation crusade to promote free trade and American exports. It is a trip that is redolent of re-election politics, aimed squarely at shoring up his domestic recession-fighting credentials.
But the man it was designed to showcase seemed almost at times to be fighting the impulse to campaign, or even to think about going back "over there," to Washington and New Hampshire.
 
Echoes From Past: Cheers
 Australia, in particular, seemed to remind Mr. Bush of those halcyon days when he stood atop the popularity ratings and his jaunts overseas were political pluses instead of liabilities. The President reveled openly in the friendly crowds and diplomatic adulation. Asked if he was happy to be there, Mr. Bush shot back: "You got that right."
He confided that he had brought his golf "sticks" on Air Force One, though he was unable to find time to play, and wished openly that he could fire up his beloved speedboat in the sparkling waters off Sydney. In Singapore, he held a campaign-style rally Saturday at the Singapore American school, which caters to the 9,000 American expatriates here.
And he escorted guest after guest on tours of Air Force One, a hulking Boeing 747 that has been walled off inside into a maze of staterooms and high-tech conference centers.
"I was just showing the Prime Minster around," he said one day in Canberra, popping into the big plane's press room with Australia's new leader, Paul Keating. Mr. Keating gazed around and remarked, "When you've got one of these, you know you've made it."
The President just smiled.
 
Do We Have to Go Home?
 In fact, the only times during Mr. Bush's three-day Australia stopover that his brow furrowed and clouds materialized over his head were when he spoke of returning home.
"There is no way that I can tell you what it feels like to travel with so little hostility on the street," he told a crowd during a cruise in Sydney harbor. "I'm a man that knows every hand gesture you've ever seen -- and I haven't learned a new one since I've been here. So something is terribly wrong."
Dedicating a maritime museum, Mr. Bush talked about his love of fishing, then quickly added: "Please don't repeat that for the people back in the United States. I think sometimes they think the only thing I like to do is go fishing."
Both impromptu remarks drew broad laughter from his audience. But in the larger context of Mr. Bush's statements this week, the jests sometimes seemed strained.
By the time he arrived in Singapore, Mr. Bush seemed to have shifted into a somewhat grim campaign mode, denouncing Democratic budget proposals as "crazy" and belittling Democrats' efforts to make hay out of his coming showdown with Japanese officials over trade barriers.
Earlier, Mr. Bush seemed equally grim about the coming campaign, expressing a determination to win, and saying that he will do whatever it takes to get re-elected.
He will not have to wait long. While in Singapore, the White House announced that the President would travel to New Hampshire on Jan. 15, three days after his return.
 
Down to Business
 In the meantime, the President has set about more mundane work in the last half of his overseas trip, which goes on with a two-day visit to South Korea to discuss trade and arms-control efforts involving North Korea's nuclear program before the final stop in Japan.
In Singapore, the President announced actions aimed at shoring up Washington's standing in Southeast Asia. Chief among them was an agreement in principle to shift logistics operations for the Navy's Seventh Fleet from Subic Bay, in the Philippines, to Singapore harbor.
Mr. Bush also announced a new program that will encourage the sharing of environmental studies and technologies among Washington and Asian allies in a region that is being seriously degraded by wildfire development.
Finally, Mr. Bush officially lifted a 16-year-old trade embargo against Cambodia, which recently agreed to a United Nations-sponsored plan to end its long civil war. The United States imposed the trade ban in 1975, when the Communist Khmer Rouge Government stood accused of slaughtering Cambodian citizens in a bid to gain absolute control of the country.

GRAPHIC: Photo: During a visit to Singapore, President Bush waved to youngsters yesterday as he left a rally at the American School. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: Massachusetts Town Refuses Tax Increase To Rehire Teachers

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON, Jan. 4

 BODY:
Residents of the tiny Massachusetts town of Wales, which laid off five of the seven teachers at its lone elementary school last year because of budget problems, voted Friday against increasing property taxes to pay for rehiring the teachers.
By 407-to-249, voters turned down a measure that would have raised $160,745 to bring back the teachers immediately. By a nearly identical margin, the residents approved a second measure raising $20,000 to maintain their garbage collection services. 
 The referendum marks the second time in two months that voters have rejected tax increases for the school. After the first attempt failed in November, the town laid off the elementary school teachers, leaving only two teachers and a principal to instruct 199 children in kindergarten through sixth grade. Two of the classes each have more than 50 students, and the third class, serving students in kindergarten through second grade, has 75 students.
Friday's referendum would have raised the average property tax bill $200 a year to provide at least one teacher for each grade. School officials blamed the recession for the proposal's failure.
"I think people find themselves on hard times and were unwilling to tax themselves," said David Roach, the Superintendent of Schools for Wales and four neighboring towns. "We didn't effectively make the case that the needs for the schools and the kids should transcend that."
Officials also said the state's recent approval of $30 million in emergency school aid may also have been a factor in the defeat, even though communities will have to pay back half of any aid they receive. School officials said they planned to apply for the emergency aid later this month.
"People said, 'See, the state is bailing us out,"' said the school's principal, Joseph DiFabio. "It's a sad day for the children of Wales."

HEADLINE: BOATING;
Smaller Craft Are Biggest News at the Boat Show

BYLINE: By BARBARA LLOYD

 BODY:
The boating market continues to reel from a two-year slowdown made worse by a widening recession. But a glimmer of light still flickers in the ailing industry, sustained by sales of the ever-popular 16-foot outboard runabout.
Organizers of the New York National Boat Show, which begins Saturday at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center in Manhattan, have addressed boaters' slimmer wallets and general skittishness with plans to exhibit a variety of craft that fit the small-boat niche. Among them will be ski boats, small aluminum fishing boats, day sailers and cruising boats. Costs can be expected to vary between about $5,000 to $10,000. 
 The small runabout or day sailer is often the boat that families want to know about. With that in mind, boat show organizers are targeting Friday, Jan. 17, as Family Day, and are offering free admission to children 12 years and younger who come accompanied by a parent.
"It goes along with the line of thought that boating is a family sport," said Michael Duffy, show manager, in a recent interview. "Having a special day is an effort to make families aware that they can water-ski, fish, cruise, sun-bathe, or sail with a boat."
 
Declining Sales
 Over all, new boat sales dropped 18 percent from 1990 to 1991, according to estimates from the National Marine Manufacturers Association, an industry trade group that tracks sales. Those numbers were somewhat better than ones posted for 1989-1990, when sales declined 21 percent.
Without the sale of runabouts, the picture would be far bleaker. Half of the new boat sales in 1991, or about 227,000 craft, fit into the outboard runabout category.
Among the manufacturers showing small- to medium-sized boats in New York will be Sea Ray, Bayliner, Fisher, Chris-Craft, Wellcraft, Yamaha, Robalo and Penn Yan.
Another relatively popular area in a sagging boat market is inflatables. The boats are popular because they tend to weigh less than conventional boats of the same size. Jeff McCurdy, a sales manager at Achilles USA, a Japanese firm with an office in East Rutherford, N.J., contends that the inflatable is economical. "They have more stability than other boats, and don't need as much horsepower to go," said McCurdy.
Achilles plans to show its new HB110 Sport, an 11-foot inflatable boat with a hard fiberglass bottom. The boat, which takes outboard engines up to 25 horsepower, costs about $5,000.
Among sailboat manufacturers, Howmar Boat Corporation of Moosup, Conn., will display its 14-foot Phantom. It is an open skiff that costs $1,700. Flying Scot of Deer Park, Md., will show its 19-foot day sailer, a traditional boat designed 30 years ago with a centerboard that allows the boat to maneuver in little more than two feet of water. It costs $8,890.
More expensive craft, in both sail and power, also will be on display at the New York show. Master Craft, a firm in Maryville, Tenn., which makes only water-ski boats, plans to exhibit its new Pro Sport 205. It is a 20-foot inboard speedboat with a 250 horsepower engine, powerful enough for tournament towing. It costs about $25,000.
The company, which produces ski boats from 19 to 25 feet, has not felt the slump that builders of luxury yachts and sailboats have experienced, said David Wilson, creative director for Master craft. Other boat builders are entering the ski boat market this season to take advantage of water-skiing's pocket of success.
On the luxury yacht end, Bluewater Marine of Mora, Minn., will be displaying a boat that organizers have named the queen of the show. Its Bluewater 53 is designed with three staterooms, two heads with full bathtubs and an unusual galley-kitchen area that has full-sized appliances. Its price is about $390,000.
The luxury boat market has been hit particularly hard in the last two years. Although the recession has taken its toll, manufacturers have bitterly complained about an excise tax approved by Congress last year that places a 10 percent levy on boats costing more than $100,000.
Greg Proteau, a spokesman for the national manufacturers association, said recently that the tax has "crippled" the luxury-boat market, causing the loss of 20,000 jobs in the marine market.
Some manufacturers are expanding into other areas. Fountain Powerboats of Washington, N.C., a firm known for its high-speed luxury sport boats, plans to introduce a new line of mid-size saltwater fishing boats at the New York show. Models that range from 25 to 31 feet are being built with the same deep-vee construction as Fountain's sport boats. A 27-foot fishing boat with a center console will be on display; the craft costs about $58,000.
A wide variety of marine equipment also will be at the boat show, including the newest outboard engines and the latest in navigational equipment. Numerous companies plan to display global positioning systems -- navigational tools that access satellites for pinpointing a boat's location, speed and course.
The Javits center is situated between 34th and 39th Streets, and between 11th and 12th Avenues on the city's West Side along the Hudson River. The show lasts through next Sunday. General admission is $8; $3 for children 6-12. On Friday, entrance to a pre-show Red Carpet Day costs a special admission fee of $20. For boat show information, call 212-216-3616, starting tomorrow.

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
Metaphor For Failure

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
President Bush's visit to Japan this week, with his entourage of business executives, is a metaphor for what ails America. There in a neat package are symbols of corporate failure, social division and lame political response.
The most prominent businessmen in the delegation are the leaders of the U.S. auto industry: the C.E.O.'s of General Motors, Ford and Chrysler. And what is their message to Japan and the world? That when an American leads his company into disastrous losses, his response is to whine about the competition and indulge his personal greed. 
 Ten years ago the U.S. manufacturers won "voluntary" restraints on Japanese auto exports to this country. They said they wanted the protection temporarily: a breathing space to modernize their products and production methods.
After 10 years the American manufacturers are in worse trouble than ever. General Motors lost between $6 and $8 billion in 1991. Last month the company announced drastic measures to cut jobs and close plants over the next three years, steps that experts thought were long overdue. Ford and Chrysler are also losing heavily.
Having failed to make good enough use of the protection they were given, the car companies want more. President Bush is expected to press Japan for new export quotas. The losers will be American consumers, who buy Japanese cars not out of some bias but because they are very good cars.
Mr. Bush talks passionately about free trade and fair competition. But by bringing the Big Three auto executives along, he tells his Japanese hosts that what he really wants is an unfair protected position for inefficient American manufacturers.
There is another reason why the Japanese are likely to be unimpressed. That is the record of the American automobile chiefs in lining their own pockets while they run their companies into the ground.
The loudest of the auto C.E.O.'s is Lee Iacocca of Chrysler. In 1990 he was paid $4.65 million and given $718,000 in Chrysler shares. And the company bought two houses from him because he could not get what he wanted for them in a falling real estate market.
G.M.'s chairman, Robert Stempel, got $2.18 million in immediate and deferred compensation in 1990. His predecessor, Roger Smith, who presided over much of the company's slide, gets an annual pension of $1.2 million.
In Japan, managers whose companies do so badly resign. The ethic is personal responsibility -- which does not seem a bad idea for any society.
Moreover, Japan has a very different idea of what top business executives should be paid. The American pattern, with C.E.O.'s getting 160 times the pay of an average worker, seems to the Japanese to be grossly disproportionate and socially divisive.
The Wall Street Journal provided some comparative figures last week in a compelling story by Jill Abramson and Christopher J. Chipello. It should be required reading for all interested in the comparative rise of Japanese and decline of American industry.
The 12 major C.E.O.'s who are with Mr. Bush earned, on average, a little more than $2 million in 1990. Chief executives in Japan get about one-sixth of that figure: between $300,000 and $400,000 a year. And they pay a top marginal income tax rate of 65 percent.
A President of the United States who sought serious answers to the decline of American manufacturing might go to Japan to learn. He would learn about the ethic of responsibility, and about a system that values the production-line worker and not just the executive.
If he had an open mind, that President would also learn how much Japan has achieved by industrial policy -- by government working with industry to support civilian research and development and point capital toward promising areas. He would see what a difference it makes when the government does something about education instead of just talking.
But we do not have that President. We have one who repeats the cliches of free enterprise good, government bad. We have one who cares about short-run politics instead of the long-run problems -- the critical problems -- of the American economy. We have one whose answer to our recession is to blame the Japanese.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Mayor Halfway

 BODY:
The intelligent State of the City speech that Mayor David Dinkins gave last week contained some good ideas and sounded New York City's traditional theme of compassionate leadership for all urban America. Yet it was just a speech, one of many he has given that reflect his performance over two years.
He certainly sounds as if he knows how to lift New York City from its recessionary torpor. Yet he has not yet pushed hard enough to master the city's fiscal fates, never pressed his appointees hard enough and never rallied his fellow citizens insistently enough. 
 Elected to govern in a flush summer, David Dinkins is serving in a harsh winter. The people of New York got just what they voted for, a decorous, conciliatory mayor, likely to lower heated voices and calm racial tension. Yet almost before he took office, the sudden economic chill demanded an aggressive leader willing to make harsh, unpopular decisions. If Mr. Dinkins has a chance of saving his city from economic recession and emotional depression, he will have to get tougher.
After a flawed start, Mr. Dinkins has lived up to his reputation as a conciliator. In the early days, he let a destructive black boycott of a Korean grocery in Brooklyn drag on for months without using his personal moral suasion to stop it. But he has learned. When Crown Heights erupted following the accidental death of a black child hit by a car a Hasidic man was driving, Mr. Dinkins was at his peace-making best, wading gamely through hisses, boos and worse to calm the community.
The Mayor's own top priority is to fulfill his inaugural day promise to be "the toughest mayor on crime this city has ever seen." It's too soon to assess his plan for more police and community patrols. Nor is it possible to measure the effect of cutting all other city services to pay for the police. But it can at least be argued that New Yorkers already feel better knowing the police plan exists and that, once it's fully implemented, it may cut street crime.
Still, the overwhelming priority is dealing with tough times, and by that criterion the Dinkins administration has repeatedly fallen short. The city budget is constantly being revamped, not only because the economy is dragging but because Mr. Dinkins is, too.
The Mayor has yet to make the bold innovations so necessary in times of duress. What an opportunity he has to force changes in wasteful civil service rules and labor practices, to introduce competition by privatizing some services, truly to create a leaner, more efficient government.
Mr. Dinkins has made some managerial progress, cutting down on overtime, reducing city cars and consolidating economic development offices. But when it comes to the labor force, half the budget, he has never overcome the damaging precedent of an unaffordably high wage increase to the teachers 15 months ago. He has yet to wrest significant concessions or productivity savings from any city union and has never presented a plausible plan to cut the work force.
Spending so much on labor inevitably means spending very much less on others, especially the poor, whom Mr. Dinkins considers his fundamental constituents.
The Mayor can do better, but not by himself. He is still missing a strong group of advisers and commissioners to whom he can comfortably delegate. Many of his appointees are undistinguished. And the most talented, demoralized, are job-hunting.
Mr. Dinkins would do himself and the city a favor by revamping and strengthening his team. With strong aides, working in a cooperative climate, Mr. Dinkins can blunt, perhaps even conquer, a mood of civic sourness that sometimes drives him to defensive despair. For instance, he sometimes claims he is being held to a higher standard because he is black.
That is not a credible contention. New York has its share of racists, but if anything, most New Yorkers want their first black Mayor to succeed. His ability to say the right things suggests that, in the second half of his term, he still can.

HEADLINE: Recycle the Budget Agreement

BYLINE: Jim Sasser, Democrat of Tennessee, is chairman of the Senate Budget Committee.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
One year after its implementation, the budget agreement of 1990 has achieved a bizarre status: worshiped as a kind of totem by the Bush Administration, it is simultaneously scorned by fiscal zealots as a sham that did nothing to reduce the Federal deficit.
Both views are wrong. The budget agreement did cut the deficit. It's just that cutting the deficit did nothing to help our stagnant economy, which, as a perverse consequence, will yield a record $362 billion deficit in fiscal 1992. In short, the budget agreement performed as advertised and failed miserably anyway. 
 As we struggle to recover from what is now the longest recession since the Depression, it has become clear that the budget agreement needs emergency alterations to stimulate the torpid economy. These changes must include a temporary tax break for middle-income families and enhanced unemployment benefits. We also need a package of grants to state and local governments to restore cuts in education and public services.
We should also scrap the rule that prohibits the transfer of funds from defense to domestic spending. Even Mr. Bush expressed in a recent interview a willingness to join Congressional Democrats in removing this barrier.
The savings achieved by the agreement were ambitious and genuine. The summit meeting produced $482 billion in deficit reduction. Of that, $338 billion in painful program cuts and tax increases were put into law by the 1990 Reconciliation Act. The rest was achieved through caps on spending and pay-as-you-go requirements.
Despite all this, the deficit projections have grown more outrageous. When the Congressional Budget Office made its initial post-summit estimates in December 1990, it projected the total deficit declining from $253 billion in 1991 to $29 billion in 1995. In August, it revised its estimates upward by an eye-popping $539 billion over the five years of the agreement, with the projected 1995 deficit hovering at $150 billion. The next report is due later this month, and all signs say it will confirm the bleak projections.
What happened? The recession stole a huge portion of the savings we struggled over last year. Of the total $539 billion in deficit increases, only $3 billion -- or 0.6 percent -- can be attributed to Presidential and Congressional spending beyond the agreed upon limits. Government did not actively dig this hole.
Much of the fiscal atrophy is the result of so-called technical re-estimates. We lost $82 billion over five years in personal tax receipts because of Treasury Department computer models that did not take adequate account of the declines in real estate, which caused and compounded the downturn.
We've also had to raise our estimates of spending in areas such as Medicaid and food stamps. Those unexpected drains on the Treasury, mostly the result of growing unemployment and increasing poverty, are controlled by courts and regulators as much as economics.
Other elements, however, have been induced solely by the recession. Some $25 billion a year in deficit increases, or $145 billion by 1995, will be revenue losses resulting from declines in personal income and poor corporate profits.
Thus, out of the summit meeting's $482 billion in deficit reduction, we have lost a minimum of $200 billion to sheer economic stagnation in the first six months of the agreement. And the loss is swelling.
The lesson is largely one of timing. We moved to reduce the deficit to insure long-term economic stability. But we did it at the worst possible moment. We had a window of opportunity in 1989 with a new President and a growing economy. Many of us urged immediate action. Instead, we ended up delaying and taking contractionary steps at almost the precise moment when the economy stopped growing.
Deficit reduction is not an end in itself and the agreement is not holy writ. The economy must get through the recession before we can minister to its long-term fiscal soundness. To achieve that end, we have little choice but to revise the agreement.

HEADLINE: An Open Letter To Bobby Bonilla

 BODY:
Dear Bobby:
Congratulations on your new contract. It must feel great knowing that you and your family are secure for life. So Bobby, why are you so sour? Why do you persist in bashing the Pirates' management at every turn? Are you so concerned that selling yourself to the highest bidder doesn't square with your "great guy" image? Does maintaining that image require the presence of other, non-economic factors? Is that what's behind this modern-day tragedy you've created in which those simultaneously wicked and bumbling Pirates executives are solely to blame for your leaving Pittsburgh? Bobby, are you trying to kid us or yourself? Listen, forget the image thing and just enjoy your fortune; you're not such a great guy, anyway, and the money hasn't a thing to do with it. 
 A great guy would have made a graceful exit. A great guy would have publicly thanked the Pirates for providing him the opportunity to grow into a $29 million player. A great guy would have thanked his teammates for giving him the thrill of participating in two National League championship playoffs. A truly great guy would have expressed his gratitude to the fans of Pittsburgh for their warm support.
Look, Bobby, you've said this is a business; now you should start acting as though you mean it. The situation boils down to a very simple business proposition: You acted in what you perceived to be your best interests by signing with the Mets, and the Pirates acted in what they perceived to be their best interests by letting you go. Maybe the Pirates felt they couldn't afford to pay you $29 million. Or perhaps the Pirates felt that while they could afford the freight, you weren't worth more than their last offer.
Interestingly, before you signed, many people opined that you should command a larger contract than you merited strictly for your on-the-field performance because of "intangibles"; i.e., because you're such a great guy. As I recall, the Pirates' last offer was for about $24 million, which would be about at the level where the "great-guy premium" part of your $29 million contract kicks in. That makes the Pirates' handling of your contract negotiations look pretty responsible.
Bobby, there are no villains in this saga, and there are no heroes, either. There aren't even any great guys.
 
JIM WHALEN
Pittsburgh

HEADLINE: ABOUT CARS;
Sweeping Up the Rubble of the Year

BYLINE: By Marshall Schuon

 BODY:
LAST year seems to have wound down in a grump, at least among some readers. And, for the first column of 1992, we might as well get rid of some of the rocks and pebbles that have rolled this way.
 
 
A Bummer of a Bimmer?

 
Dear Sir:
Based on your article, "With the 325i, BMW Drops the 4th Shoe," (The Times, Dec. 1), I'm convinced you're about as qualified to evaluate cars as a graham cracker.
I own a 1992 325i and I'm exceptionally pleased with all aspects of the car. As for the "weak detent between low and reverse," I have to force it into reverse, and my wife let the car sit in the garage for three days because she didn't know the "trick" to get it into reverse.
Maybe this BMW isn't the greatest car on the road. Time will tell. But it's an excellent complete package. Come to your senses!
 
HOLLARD R. EARLE
Long Valley, N.J
A graham cracker? I tend to think of myself as Cracker Jack.

Dear Sir:

First, the windshield developed a long vertical crack at 200 miles, and at about the same time a defective sensor told us we were without coolant. Highland Park, Ill.
 Given the volume of mail, this is a problem that is on the minds of a lot of people. Automotive engineers are among them, and they say they are trying. They also maintain that vans have gotten a bad rap, so to speak.
Dear Sir:
Just weeks before your column appeared, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration responded to Congressional questions on the safety of light trucks and vans and stated the following:
"NHTSA is aware of the greater use of light trucks and multipurpose vehicles such as vans as passenger-carrying vehicles. In spite of these increases, accident data have shown that the average occupant fatality rate for all types of light trucks and vans (LTV's) is identical to that of passenger cars.
"In side impact crashes, the number of fatalities per million registered vehicles for LTV's is significantly lower than that for passenger cars (25.5 vs. 57.3). Although this may be in part because the side door sills are somewhat higher on some LTV's than on passenger cars, nonetheless LTV's have a lower fatality rate, even though they have not had to meet the same safety standard as passenger cars."
We agree on this point. For the record, the only manner in which Chrysler minivans do not meet all passenger car standards are the side-impact door beams and the unbelted driver-restraint requirement. Both of these will be resolved in late 1993, when a passenger air bag will also be added.
One certainty about adding door beams is an increase in weight and an offsetting reduction in fuel economy. We have preferred to invest our minivan resources in the first and only integrated child seat, the first minivan air bag, antilock brakes and all-wheel drive.
 
RONALD S. ZAROWITZ
Highland Park, Mich.
Zarowitz is manager of car and truck safety for Chrysler Corporation. He is also the inventor of Chrysler's new child safety seats.

HEADLINE: Stabilize the Banks and Reverse the Recession

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"The Economy: Go Fast, and Slow" (editorial, Dec. 19) distinguishes between short-term and long-term economic problems, but neglects the banking crisis, which affects both. 
 Because of the speculative excesses of the 1980's and some regulatory excesses of the 90's, many banks and savings and loan institutions are afraid or unable to lend. This means small entrepreneurs -- who otherwise might exploit low interest rates to start or expand businesses, create jobs and help lead us out of the recession -- are having a tough time finding credit.
Many banks and savings and loans were too eager to lend in the 1980's. But sharp policy reversals compounded the problem. After fostering a real estate boom with the 1981 tax cut and its extraordinary shelters for real estate, nervous law makers in Washington did an about-face in 1986. They took the best shelters away all at once and punctured the real estate bubble. The result was to gut savings and loans portfolios.
Policy makers committed a similar reversal on savings and loan regulation. After encouraging massive deregulation in the early 80's, they observed the resulting failures and secured tough reregulation in 1989. Unfortunately, the reregulation has not only disciplined incompetent and dishonest managers, but has also straitjacketed competent and honest ones.
What we need is greater regulatory flexibility -- institution by institution. Those institutions with good track records should be allowed some leeway on capital requirements and portfolio restrictions. The last thing we want to do is sharply reverse our policy again, but some regulatory moderation is in order.
And what about the banks? Many need more capital. We suggest another look at a program from the 1930's that worked. Beginning in 1933, a Government agency called the Reconstruction Finance Corporation began buying preferred stock in the country's banks. While this added cash to bank balance sheets, it was not a give-away program. The R.F.C. demanded dividends on the stocks it bought. Once the banks regained strength, the R.F.C. sold its stock and recouped the original investment.
The R.F.C. stock purchasing program was one of the most successful parts of the New Deal.
Stabilizing banks and savings and loans -- without give-aways -- will help pull us out of the recession and open the way to sustained growth.
 
EDWARD YARDENI, DAVID A. MOSS
New Haven, Dec. 26, 1991
 
The writers are, respectively, chief economist at C. J. Lawrence, brokers, and a doctoral candidate in economic history at Yale University.

HEADLINE: Stabilize the Banks and Reverse the Recession;
Buy American

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "The Economy: Go Fast, and Slow" (editorial, Dec. 19): We look to the Federal Government as the sole force capable of reversing our deepening economic morass. It is the sole organized force, but consumers can turn the economy around by simply buying American-made products. 
 Our Government cannot openly support a buy American policy for obvious reasons. But organized labor, big business and especially the news media must begin to educate the public that we are in large part to blame for our economic woes.
American consumers provide well over $100 billion in foreign aid each year by buying Dutch shavers, Korean shirts and Japanese cars (that figure more than doubles if the drug trade is included). Each year, $100 billion flows out of the United States that should have been recycled into more jobs in the United States. The buying power of American consumers is no longer strong enough to support the world. We are barely supporting ourselves
As the number of employed American consumers shrinks, so does confidence and spending. This feeds on itself. An economic jump start such as you refer to in the Robert Solow-Francis Bator proposal is a good and temporary first step. It may buy time to devise a flexible, long-term economic scheme that allows the United States to insulate its capitalistic integrity, short of outright protectionism, from often unfair practices of some in the international community. And our Government must be a partner. Corporations alone cannot successfully compete against foreign corporate monoliths in partnership with their governments.
The key word may be "temporary," but we had best recognize that something much more potent and innovative is required for our long-term health.
 
GARY HALBERSTADT
Bridgewater, N.J., Dec. 19, 1991

HEADLINE: Stabilize the Banks and Reverse the Recession;
Pension Borrowing

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "The Economy: Go Fast, and Slow" (editorial, Dec. 19), you imply that a business could borrow from its own pension fund and use these "tax-subsidized" dollars for "tax-subsidized" investments. This ambiguity results from the preceding sentences, which paraphrased read: It makes little sense to allow businesses to deduct the entire cost of long-lived investments with tax laws that also permit tax-free contributions to pension funds. 
 Pension fund rules prohibit a "party in interest" (a trustee) to borrow from the plan to which it contributes. This clarification is essential.
You recommend only a temporary tax cut to stimulate the economy. Your emphasis on temporary would be more credible if you had been equally adamant in recommending that 1990's tax hikes should be made temporary as well. After all, when Congress raised its own salaries by $28,000, was this a temporary spending increase?
 
DAVID L. LITTMANN
First V.P. and Senior Economist, Manufacturers National Corporation
Detroit, Dec. 20, 1991

HEADLINE: Stabilize the Banks and Reverse the Recession;
Not by Neglect Alone

 BODY:
To the Editor:
It is surely accurate to say that Presidential neglect contributes greatly to our domestic economic plight. However, neglect conveys a flavor of just not getting around to something. It would be more appropriate to remain mindful of the active role that Reagan-Bush planning and policies have played in bringing us to where we are. 
 It may be tempting to think that Presidents Reagan and Bush were merely foolish or shortsighted, but indeed the increasing concentration of wealth in the hands of the few and the increasing impoverishment of the many were not achieved through carelessness or accident. It would have taken more stupidity than I can credit to them to believe that decreased spending on education, health and social needs, the breaking of unions and similar policies would produce a larger dependent population and a smaller work force capable of producing and earning the wealth needed to support a healthy economy.
Let's not blame them merely for what they are failing to do now, but also for the years of what they have already done.
 
NORMA J. HART
New York, Dec. 17, 1991

SECTION: Section 4; Page 12; Column 6; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 286 words

HEADLINE: Stabilize the Banks and Reverse the Recession;
Help Small Business

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The state of the economy has produced an environment that allows our major corporations to downsize rapidly. The news media have been making much of this, though it has been going on for some time without fanfare. With the coming Presidential election, our politicians have noted the increasing number of unemployed. What has gone unnoticed is that many of the people losing jobs at large companies have been re-employed by small companies. Small businesses provide more jobs than big business. Yet we seem to do everything possible to stifle the creation of new companies. 
 Our lawmakers have enacted well-meaning laws to create such agencies as the Occupational Safety and Health Administration and the Environmental Protection Agency. Litigation and increasing health care costs have drastically increased the insurance costs required to run a business. It's small wonder that only the very brave start new businesses, and most, unfortunately, fail.
To me, as a small-business man, the solution is simple. We should establish an agency, directly tied to the President, to provide a pool of venture capital for new businesses. Legislation should eliminate tax liability to start-up companies for their first five years and limit tax liability for the next five years. The Government could even take a minority interest in these companies with a provision that the investment be disposed of after the 10-year grace period. The employees of these companies would, of course, pay the usual taxes.
The need for providing new jobs is crucial, and with enlightened government assistance, we can achieve this goal.
 
JACK B. FREEMAN
President, Aremco Products
Ossining, N.Y., Dec. 20, 1991

HEADLINE: Stabilize the Banks and Reverse the Recession;
Forget Van Buren

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Milton Hindus (letter, Dec. 17) rightly restores to our reading list the autobiography of Martin Van Buren, a wise and literate man; and, we should add, radically misguided. 
 In listening to the wisdom of the elders, it is necessary to distinguish between those who warn us that problems are recurrent and those who say that the best thing to do about them is nothing. George Bush has placed himself squarely with Martin Van Buren and Herbert Hoover.
We don't know what cures economic and political diseases nearly as well as we know that they are recurrent. We do know that the function of leadership is to make an energetic, compassionate and informed effort to do better. The spirit of commonwealth requires no less.
The elders we fail to listen to at our peril are not beguiling and prudential men like Van Buren. Van Buren is better read as a 19th-century novel of manners than as a wise man for our times.
 
E. S. GOLDMAN
South Orleans, Mass., Dec. 23, 1991

SECTION: Section 7; Page 12; Column 1; Book Review Desk

HEADLINE: Playing as a Team

BYLINE: By D. J. R. Bruckner; D. J. R. Bruckner is an editor of The Book Review. His most recent book is a critical appraisal of the life and work of F. W. Goudy, the American type designer.

 BODY:

KURT WOLFF
A Portrait in Essays and Letters.
Edited by Michael Ermarth.
Translated by Deborah Lucas Schneider.
Illustrated. 223 pp. Chicago:
The University of Chicago Press. $24.95. 
 KURT WOLFF, perhaps the most discriminating publisher in this century, turned down one of the all-time best sellers, Axel Munthe's "Story of San Michele," because he found it "unbelievably trite, vain and embarrassing." Around the same time he received a letter from an "idiotic 'professor' " writing "from Trieste in bad German" offering translation rights to a novel. He refused and later surmised he had lost James Joyce's "Ulysses." Just before that, he had a letter from Oswald Spengler offering "The Decline of the West," but he returned the manuscript unread since he thought other, more academic publishers might handle it, and he did not like "the undistinguished handwriting of the letter." He remained proud of the first rejection four decades later, contrite about the others; but he talked about them all to a large radio audience when he was in his 70's.
By then he was a legend. As a university student in Germany he had begun to work for a small Leipzig publisher, and in 1913, when he was 26, he established the Kurt Wolff Verlag and then went on to found or acquire half a dozen other publishing houses, including Hyperion and Pantheon Casa Editrice, that expanded the horizons of publishing everywhere. In the 1940's, as a refugee in New York, he founded Pantheon Books, and when he left that house, started, with his wife, the Helen and Kurt Wolff imprint with Harcourt, Brace and World.
Before World War I a handful of independent, rebellious German publishers set the world's standards for good book making. Wolff moved in among them and soon rose above even them, known everywhere for the quality of design and manufacture of his popular-priced books, for the new authors he found, for the artwork he commissioned and then for the art books done by some of his illustrators. In a lifetime of publishing, a mere sample of his authors and artists would include Franz Kafka, Heinrich Mann, Robert Walser, Max Brod, Karl Kraus, Oskar Kokoschka, Franz Werfel, Lou Andreas-Salome, Arnold Zweig, Karel Capek, Frans Masereel, Joseph Roth, Stefan George, Georges Bernanos, Robert Musil, Paul Valery, Werner Heisenberg, Marc Chagall, Giuseppe di Lampedusa, Joy Adamson, Rachel Carson, Boris Pasternak and Gunter Grass. When he started Pantheon Books in his one-room apartment in Greenwich Village in the 1940's, Paul and Mary Mellon entrusted to him the publication of their Bollingen Foundation's series, not only a most diverse and intellectually demanding roster of new books, but one honored everywhere for their beauty. And Wolff took personal responsibility for everything he did. The breadth of his culture is scarcely believable, but there it is.
Since he died in 1963, at 76, little has been printed about him in this country. At last, the University of Chicago Press has gathered essays and letters from two small volumes published in Germany 25 years ago -- some of these essays Wolff wrote for broadcast on German radio -- along with material supplied by Helen Wolff, into a fine volume edited by Michael Ermarth and translated, often with spirit but sometimes with too much caution, by Deborah Lucas Schneider.
Some of the letters in "Kurt Wolff: A Portrait in Essays and Letters" to and from people like Kafka, Hermann Hesse, Pasternak and others are invaluable; Wolff's recollections of his authors are intoxicating. But most impressive is just Wolff -- his engaging voice, learned, unassuming, patrician, warm, good-humored -- and his testimony about how to make good books. There is no training that will make a publisher, he says; but one ought to have taste, literary discernment and a grand passion for the work undertaken, along with the patience of an all-forgiving lover, since, by definition, every creative artist is "unbalanced." His formula is too modest; the emotional and intellectual depth revealed in his writings and the scope of learning disclosed, as in a letter to Pasternak about music and philosophy, teach a great respect for what it takes to make a good publisher.
In practical terms, he thinks no one who is the head of a big company issuing hundreds of titles a year can be a publisher. Such people might know what merchants understand -- glands, feelings, what makes the flesh crawl -- but a publisher must be personally responsible for every page of every book. He must have an informed instinct for typography, design, paper, ink, binding, art -- the whole elusive craft that makes a book a splendid object. He must be possessed by intense passion for the author's work and have a mission to publish what people ought to read. Aristocratic? The adjective would not have bothered him at all.
Wolff would not option future works of his authors; such a practice reeked of peonage. To read his open negotiations with other publishers when an author wanted to change houses is to learn something about candor and decency not often seen in the world of modern publishing. Dr. Johnson said, somewhat ironically, that in the 18th century, by enabling authors to earn a living, publishers -- he knew that even then most were mere merchants and more than a few were very slippery -- had become "the patrons of literature," replacing the princes and lords of the past. Wolff was one of the few in the centuries since who was really princely. This little book is a kind of guide to right conduct for the next aspirant.
There were compensations. To have had the trust of the people who came to him with their work was the greatest of them. His recollections of some are thrilling, troubling, painful. A glimpse of a triumphant Max Brod introducing an exquisitely intimidated Kafka has the beauty and terror of a Goya painting, and one imagines he can hear Kafka telling Wolff: "I will always be more grateful to you for returning my manuscripts than for publishing them." His portrait of his friend Franz Werfel is filled with deep shadows; he captures the uncontrolled literary enthusiasms of the man, his unworldly assumptions about life, his volatility, his egotism and the sometimes treacherous reversals of loyalty that injured his friends and himself. The candor of this essay is as remarkable as Wolff's affection for the man he sees so clearly.
Then there is Lou Andreas-Salome, the bewitching Russian savante who was, as Wolff says, "Nietzsche's fiancee, Freud's pupil and friend, and Rilke's lover." The enchantment that overwhelmed Wolff as she talked sweeps over the reader who, like Wolff, can see before him the fabled figures she conjures up from her past; one raises one's eyes from the page and expects to meet the gaze of Wagner, Tolstoy, Turgenev.
But the best portrait of all is of Karl Kraus, the Viennese critic around whom all of German-speaking Europe divided in camps of what Wolff calls fanatic admirers and fanatic enemies, the second and larger group mostly made up of renegades from the first. The "hypocrisy, baseness and sheer idiocy" he encountered everywhere in print drove Kraus to "apocalyptic creations" that infuriated multitudes, driving them to excessive denunciations that only made them ridiculous. "Kraus invariably held the position of the uncompromising moralist," Wolff says, "leaving [his foes] no line of defense." That eloquent remark calls up the famous Greek definition of tyranny as a fine position because there is no retreat from it.
KRAUS'S intellect defined the age. No one can understand German literature and thought in this century, or the turbulent rise of Central European Jews into the cultural forefront of the Continent, without grappling honestly with his work. Yet, as the profound critical appraisals of Kraus by Walter Benjamin and Erich Heller fade into the archives after 50 years, he is unknown in this country except for occasional vilification. Thus Wolff's humane account is all the more valuable. As a sensitive, imaginative portrayal of how a great intellectual really lives it is as fine a piece of writing as Saul Bellow's presentation of Harold Rosenberg in that lovely long short story "What Kind of Day Did You Have?"
Yet the handling of this essay points out a serious weakness in this book: lack of commentary. The essay, for instance, contains a Kraus poem lampooning Werfel, which, to ridicule cultural pretensions, employs the governing metaphor of a convert to Catholicism who thinks baptism will wash away all his provincialism, including his Yiddish-saturated German. Unexplained, this looks ominous. If the editor had indicated Kraus's own history as a Jew who became a Catholic without ever experiencing religion and then, just in time to annoy the rising Nazis, abandoned both identities; and if he had given some account of the dominant modes of conversation in Vienna early in this century, with all the pugilistic posturing between the imperial capital and Werfel's hometown of Prague, the reader might see these verses for what they are: the rough and tumble of a Dryden or a Swift, not the sinister cruelty we might imagine in hindsight. Also, the translation of the poem, by the venerable Walter Arndt, is literal and thus incomprehensible; a good paraphrase in the diction of Dryden, or of Ira Gershwin, would have made things clear. As Wolff read this on the radio, it would have been understandable to a German audience; here, without notes, it is a muddle. That is only one case, if the most serious, of omission of needed notation. One other that deserves mention is the virtually total failure to identify German publishers Wolff refers to.
In the end, who will not envy such a man or wish that such a publisher might appear again? His life was glorious but tough. The German inflation of the 20's gutted his capital (he preserves the rueful witticism of a Weimar comic who, when, the German mark sank to five billion to the dollar, said "Well, that's about all the dollar is worth"). That mighty fact, combined with Wolff's conclusion, as Helen Wolff says in a biographical introduction, that there was a decline in public taste and "nothing new" to publish, moved Wolff to close down all his enterprises and spend the next 10 years in Italy and France.
When the Nazis engulfed France in 1940, the Wolffs came to New York and founded Pantheon. They were joined by Jacques Schiffrin, the creator of the Editions Pleiade in Paris; and the catalogues of Pantheon Books for a dozen years form a splendid monument to them all. But Kurt Wolff was nothing if not independent, and in 1959, after what Helen Wolff refers to as "disagreements," he left Pantheon, moved to Switzerland and published his last few books under the Wolff imprint.
A difficult man, it is clear enough from his own words -- for all his passion for good writing, his warmth, gentleness and loyalty. Even a reader at a distance can be made uneasy by his clarity, unyielding logic and lofty rules of conduct. But it is all so inspiring. This book has an odd effect. It could fill one with despair over the vulgarity, meanness and sheer ugliness of too many books now. But it doesn't. It brings admiration and gratitude. One wants more. Not biography. What is so fine is Wolff himself. To be talked to in confidence by such a human being lifts the spirit.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Kurt Wolff in 1963, shortly before his death.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Biography; Review
