HEADLINE: All About/Basketball Shoes;
High Tops: High Style, High Tech, High Cost

BYLINE: By GLENN RIFKIN

 BODY:
When Michael Jordan of the Chicago Bulls basketball team began advertising basketball shoes a few years ago -- the Air Jordan line by Nike Inc. -- he was selling high-tech style as much as performance. Unlike their low-tech, black-and-white predecessors, today's basketball shoes are made of light-weight leathers and synthetics dyed in a dazzling array of colors with vivid, high-contrast, graphic designs. They are also constructed with sophisticated cushioning devices and fitting systems.
And they are expensive. PF Flyers and U.S. Keds, the standbys of a generation or two ago, rarely cost more than $10 or $15 a pair -- roughly $20 now. Today's popular styles can cost as much as $160. 
 High style -- and higher prices -- have made basketball shoes big business. They are now the largest niche in the $7.6 billion wholesale market for sport shoes. According to the Sporting Goods Manufacturers Association, an industry group in North Palm Beach, Fla., wholesale sales of basketball shoes -- high tech as well as canvas -- totaled about $1.7 billion in 1990. Most of those sales -- about 85 percent -- were for just five brands: Nike, Reebok, Converse, L.A. Gear and Adidas.
The market for basketball shoes has been growing rapidly, too. Between 1986 and 1990, the market grew at a rate of about 19 percent a year, according to Sporting Goods Intelligence, an industry newsletter in Glen Mills, Penn. Last year, largely because of the recession and market saturation, the market expanded by just 4.1 percent.
But industry analysts are hopeful that 1992 will show strong growth. "With excitement building around the Olympics, I expect 1992 to be a peak year for basketball shoes," said Dick Silverman, associate publisher of Footwear News, a trade newspaper in New York.
 
Venerable Converse
The Canvas Sneaker Fades Away
 When it comes to breeding, Converse Inc., the North Reading, Mass., athletic-shoe maker, is the original. Converse has been making its popular All Star canvas basketball sneaker since 1917. In 1923, it renamed the shoe the Chuck Taylor All Star after Chuck Taylor, a popular basketball player of the time who joined the company as a spokesman in 1921. Converse has sold more than 500 million pairs of All Stars.
But despite Converse's early start, the market is now dominated by Nike, of Beaverton, Ore. and Reebok, of Stoughton, Mass. Nike, which sells about $500 million worth of basketball shoes a year, has about 40 percent of the market. Reebok, which does not disclose sales figures for specific shoe categories, has about 16 percent of the market. Converse retains 9 percent of the market.
Nike and Reebok spent about $130 million each in 1991 on television advertising for their products, in what was called the "sneaker wars." The commercials feature players from the National Basketball Association and claim the companies' high-tech shoes gave the players an edge.
"I can't deny that a lot of this is about marketing," said Peter Ruppe, Nike's manager for basketball marketing. "But the key thing is to make a great product."
While the companies' advertising appeals may be pitched to athletes, 80 percent of the sporting shoes purchased are never used in play. "A large majority of these shoes are being worn as street wear," Mr. Silverman said. "The companies don't want to own up to that," he said.
Even so, play-related advertising sells shoes. According to John Horan, publisher of Sporting Goods Intelligence, which surveys retailers, in 1990, 37 percent of all basketball shoe buyers based their purchases on advertising; 25 percent based their decisions on technology and 23 percent were motivated by fashion. Only 10 percent bought basketball shoes on the basis of information about quality and price.
 
Nike Nonpareil
Wear the Shoe, Be Like Mike?
 Even its competitors admit that when it comes to marketing and promotion, Nike is without peer. Mickey Bell, executive vice president of Converse, credits Nike with changing the rules of the game in the early 1980's by focusing on marketing rather than manufacturing issues.
The breakthrough came when Nike signed rising superstar Michael Jordan and introduced the Air Jordan line in 1985. "That changed everything," Mr. Bell said. Building brand recognition by tying it to a single star athlete fueled Nike's success.
Along with Mr. Jordan, Nike features National Basketball Association stars like David Robinson, Charles Barkley and Scottie Pippen to sell its Air Force and Air Flight lines. It pays John Thompson, coach of Georgetown University's Hoyas basketball team, $200,000 a year to endorse its shoes.
Mr. Ruppe acknowledges that Mr. Jordan, who is paid about $6 million annually by Nike, was the "paradigm" for today's advertising. Television ads featuring Mr. Jordan and film maker Spike Lee continue to win awards and drive Nike sales. Nike's overall slogan is "Just Do It." But its other slogan, "It's gotta be the shoes!" is now frequently heard on the nation's basketball courts after a stirring play is made in a pickup game. Mr. Ruppe said that Air Jordans, which sell for about $130, make up about 10 percent of its basketball shoe sales.
For the fall of 1992, Nike will offer 17 models of basketball shoes, ranging in price from $50 to $130. The most popular model sells for about $75.
Reebok, which only entered the basketball shoe arena in 1986, has challenged Nike with its own high-visibility marketing campaign. Its slogan is "Life is Short, Play Hard." Rather than tie its brands to a specific athlete, Reebok tries to "talk the talk and walk the walk" of the average basketball player, according to John Morgan, vice president of the performance division.
Most recently, Reebok tied its fortunes to its Pump technology, along with a new line of outdoor sneakers called Blacktop. The hugely successful Pump shoe, which incorporates an inflatable bladder into the upper portion of the sneaker, helped Reebok gain market share at Nike's expense.
The company has sold more than 6 million pairs of Pumps, bringing in more than $750 million in revenues since they were introduced in 1989. Reebok offers nearly a dozen models of basketball shoes ranging in price from $50 to $160. Mr. Morgan said the company's mainstay is its $55 shoe, which accounts for 40 percent of its basketball shoe sales.
 
Shoe Technology
The Science of Fine-Tuning
 "Fit is the battleground," said Nike's Mr. Ruppe. Nike continues to tinker with its Air technology, which uses lightweight stretch material along with its patented midsole system, to provide better cushioning.
Nike is intent on reducing the weight of its shoes and improving the cushioning without adding features like bladders. The hope, Mr. Ruppe said, is to offer a high-performance shoe for a lower price "to make it accessible for kids who can't spend over $100." A long list of new technologies is being incorporated into basketball shoes.
"The shoes are genuinely better. It's not just marketing hype," Mr. Horan said. "No N.B.A. player would want to go through a season with Chuck Taylor All Stars today."
Converse will introduce its React System in 1992. According to Mr. Bell, React incorporates a "responsive gas-charged fluid" that flows through compartments within the shoe. The system includes an ankle wrap that adjusts to fit an individual's ankle and a heel module to stabilize against shock.
"Technology is the missing link we needed in basketball," Mr. Bell said. "We had great price, great ads, but we were missing technology." Reebok, whose Pump line sales are already slowing down, is still committed to the technology.
"We're evolving it to the cutting edge," Mr. Morgan said. The $160 Double Pump shoe, with two bladders and a switching device to allow the wearer to inflate different sections of the shoe, will appear this year.
 
 
 
YOUNG, MALE AND WILLING TO SPEND

Andrew Albert, a 33-year old newsletter publisher from West Orange, N.J., plays pickup basketball at least once a week. He owns two pairs of basketball shoes: a pair of Adidas sneakers for outdoor play and a pair of Nikes for inside the gym.
Mr. Albert is typical of many older players who have made basketball a lifelong pursuit -- and who buy their shoes on sale. He paid $57 for his Nikes. "I wouldn't spend $100 on shoes," he said. "Anything over $60 and I break into a sweat."
While Mr. Albert is an important customer, he is not the most important for the manufacturers. According to John Morgan, vice president of the performance shoe division of Reebok International Ltd., the most frequent purchasers basketball shoes are male and between the ages of 12 and 20. "They buy 70 percent of the shoes," he said.
These young buyers do not wait until the prices are marked down to spend their money. According to John Horan, publisher of a trade industry newsletter, teen-agers are willing to pay $90 or more for their shoes. "A 15-year old isn't very sensitive to what is happening in the economy," he said. "If they have to cut lawns or rake leaves to get the shoes, they'll do it."
The most important sales outlets for basketball shoes are the national and regional speciality-shoe chains like the Foot Locker, Athlete's Foot and Athletic Attic. These stores, which sell at full retail price, are often located in malls. That makes them particularly attractive to the 14-to-17-year-old group. Following these stores in importance are the sporting goods stores and discount chains.
Nike and Reebok produce most of their shoes in South Korea, Taiwan, China and Indonesia. With their minimal production costs, basketball shoes are quite profitable. The wholesale cost of the $130 Air Jordan is $68.75, said John Ruppe, Nike's manager for basketball-shoe marketing. The cost of making them is about $30.

HEADLINE: Computer Companies Say State Tax Hampers Them

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

 BODY:
PAUL M. COFONI, vice president of Computer Sciences Corporation and manager of its center in Norwich, sees big growth for his industry in the next few years, he said. But he is not sure whether any of that growth will be in Connecticut, he said, because the state puts a 6 percent tax on computer services.
During the next three years the total spent nationwide on computer services will grow to $15 billion from $7 billion, Mr. Cofoni said. "If we're successful, and we know we will be, we'll have a major share of that," he said. But he cannot predict how many of those new jobs will be in Connecticut, he said, or whether the 500 jobs the company has in the state now will still be around. 
 Mr. Cofoni and executives of other computer service companies in the state said they were concerned that the state's tax on services would hamper their ability to compete. The only other state that taxes computer services is Texas, at a rate of 1.5 percent, they said.
 
'It's Very Easy to Move'
 A. Searle Field, Deputy Commissioner of the State Economic Development Department, said he knew of six companies, with a total of 3,000 to 4,000 employees, that were considering leaving the state because of the tax, which was imposed in 1975. More worrisome, he said, is that few other companies will bring their computer centers, with thousands of new high-paying jobs, to Connecticut if the tax is in place.
"With computers and telecommunications, it's very easy to move to another state," Mr. Field said. "And there's going to be a significant cost to the state if we lose these jobs."
Mr. Field said computer and telecommunications services are lumped into a category with seven other types of business activities for tax purposes. Together they generate $68 million in tax revenues, he said, so the loss of taxes would not be significant in a $7 billion state budget.
The income tax and sales taxes paid by people in the jobs will more than outweigh any loss from the services tax, he said, noting that Computer Sciences employees in Norwich are paid an average of $40,000 a year. But if the companies are forced out, those taxes, and the payroll of $20 million, are lost, he said.
Mr. Field said he expected legislation to be submitted next year to exempt computer and telecommunications services from the tax. But State Senator William A. DiBella, Democrat of Hartford, a member of the Commerce and Finance Committees, said he was not sure how well it would fare.
"I don't think, when we see the analysis of the fiscal impact, that it's going to fly," Mr. DiBella said. "I have no problem looking at it, but I'm very skeptical. There are hundreds of other industries that are job creating as well. We can't exempt them without looking at the fiscal impact."
 
Heavier Tax on Airplanes
 Mr. Field said staff members of the Economic Development Department have been meeting with other state officials on proposed tax changes that would make Connecticut more competitive in attracting new business. Although the effort was inspired by the tax on computer and telecommunications services, he said, the meetings have also looked at the way Connecticut taxes airplanes that are kept in the state.
The tax on airplanes is so much heavier than those in surrounding states, Mr. Field said, that owners have taken to storing their planes at airports in Westchester County and in places like Westerly, R.I., Worcester, Mass., to avoid the tax. That means the state loses that tax, plus levies on sales of fuel, parts and repairs, he said.
"In good times there's no need to examine every nickel and dime in a corporate budget," Mr. Field said. "But when times get tough, they start focusing on every marginal expense and finding ways to cut them. We have to position the state for long-term success."
Joseph F. Brennan, lawyer for the Connecticut Business and Industry Association, said the group is working with the Economic Development Department on possible modifications to the state tax structure that would help businesses. In addition to the tax on computer and telecommunications services, the group is examining how manufacturing equipment is taxed, and other ways to stop the loss of manufacturing jobs in the state, he said.
The association is looking at "areas we feel would go the longest toward improving the business climate," Mr. Brennan said. He said the organization's government affairs program will probably be released in January. But he noted that computer services have been taxed in Connecticut since 1975, so he was not sure how much of an effect the tax was having.
Mr. Cofoni said the situation for computer services is critical now because of the potential for growth. Until now, most companies have handled their own data processing and computer system development, so the services were not taxed. But many Fortune 500 corporations, and most smaller companies, have hired outside computer service companies or are planning to do so, he said. A specialized company handling computer services for several clients can afford better, more efficient computers and make better use of its staff, he said.
 
'Get Out of the Blocks'
 Computer Sciences, which is based in El Segundo, Calif., is among the leaders in the field, along with companies like I.B.M. and Electronic Data Systems, Mr. Cofoni said. But the field is exploding, he said, and any company could take the lead.
"For us to be successful, we need to get out of the blocks real quick and have a profitable operation on the first few contracts we win," Mr. Cofoni said. He said he was having discussions with 17 potential clients.
"We're projecting a half-billion dollars of growth in 1992 and a billion dollars a year by 1995," he said. "What that can mean is substantial numbers of jobs here in southeastern Connecticut."
In an area that is heavily dependent on military contractors and is thus suffering because of Federal cutbacks, that growth could ease the transition to a diversified economy, Mr. Cofoni said.
"This is the time to catch it," he said. "If we wait, five years from now it will be too late. The market is emerging too fast."
If Connecticut does not repeal the tax, Computer Sciences probably will not expand its Connecticut operation and might be forced to close it, the company has told Norwich city officials. Mr. Cofoni declined to say if the center would shut down, but he warned: "Management has to reserve all of its alternatives. I can't rule anything out."
 
'A Hit Like No One Else'
 The situation is devastating, Mr. Field said, because the levy on computer services is separate from the state's corporate profits tax, which was recently lowered to 10 percent from 14 percent as a way of making the state more attractive to business.
A business with gross revenues of $100,000 might make a $4,000 profit, and pay $400 in corporate tax, he said. But a computer services company pays the 6 percent tax on the entire $100,000, or $6,000, which would leave it with a $2,000 deficit if it operates with the same profit margin.
"That's a hit like no one else gets," Mr. Field said. "Companies don't have the kind of profit margins to cover that. They have a 3 or 4 percent profit, especially in times like this. It's a case where we're clearly at a competitive disadvantage."
Mr. Field declined to name the other companies he said are considering moving out of Connecticut, but he said the Governor has talked about putting together a package of grants and inducements to attract more computer service jobs to Connecticut if the tax situation is resolved.
"We have the opportunity in front of us to see significant growth," Mr. Field said. "And we're not talking about simple data processing here. That kind of thing can be done in other countries for $1 an hour, and we can't compete with that. These are jobs in design, in research and development, high-paying jobs. That is what the manufacturing of the future will consist of."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: A Shelter Reaches Out to 'Children in Crisis'

BYLINE: By VALERIE CRUICE

 BODY:
A FEW months ago the parents snapped. They deposited their three children -- 2, 4 and 6 years old -- on a neighbor's doorstep, saying only, "Please take care of them." Then the couple, residents of an affluent town in lower Fairfield County, took off.
The youngsters ended up in three different foster homes across the state. If they had been 12 and older, they could have found help together at the Youth Shelter on Prospect Street in Greenwich, which provides around-the-clock crisis intervention and is a temporary home for teen-agers with family problems. 
 As of March 1, families with younger children will have the same services available at a new shelter called Kids in Crisis, which will be housed temporarily at the Greenwich site. Ultimately, both shelters will operate from a single building in the Stamford-Greenwich area.
The new program for children up to 11 will be the first of its kind in the United States, said the executive director of the private, nonprofit Youth Shelter, Shari Shapiro, who had told the story of the vanishing parents.
The need for expanded service came to light in a study conducted recently for the Youth Shelter by the Junior League of Greenwich.
"What came back from over 125 professionals -- day care workers, pediatricians, social workers, child care providers -- was that there's an overwhelming need to help children in crisis, birth to 11," Mrs. Shapiro said. "We had an amazing response. We had pediatricians who put children in hospital beds to keep them safe, or would not release a newborn because the home was not a safe place for that child to be."
 
A Tragic Story
 Mrs. Shapiro told a tragic story that might have had a different ending if the Kids in Crisis center had been in place:
"A young mother in Norwalk with a 2-year-old and a 2 1/2-month-old baby and suffering from severe postpartum blues called the Youth Shelter. She gave counselors there her phone number but not her address. We were very frightened that she was going to harm herself or her children. We traced her address. But a call came from her boyfriend. She had just slit her wrists.
"So much of what we do is working with the family as a whole. Those children under 12, there's no safe place, and no one they can call 24 hours a day. There are virtually no foster homes in lower Fairfield County -- at a time when the needs are increasing."
In October the Federal Department of Housing and Human Services awarded a three-year grant totaling $600,000 to the State Department of Children and Youth Services to develop Kids in Crisis, known in the official argot as a regional crisis nursery. A joint venture of the Junior League of Greenwich and the Youth Shelter, Kids in Crisis will need $694,000 annually, Mrs. Shapiro said, and setting up the combined shelters at a new site will require $1.5 million.
 
Bustle of Activity
 On a recent morning the Youth Shelter bustled with activity. A man delivered boxes of donated food, telephones rang, counselors conferred with each other and laughter occasionally filled the hallways. Sign-up sheets for chores and television time hung on a kitchen wall. The smell of frying eggs and sausages permeated the air. While most of the inhabitants had gone off to school, two girls remained for tutoring.
One of the girls came from an affluent family, the other from a poor one. One was articulate and outgoing; she had been at the shelter for six weeks, having gotten an extension on the normal three-week stay. The other, who arrived just a week before with only the clothes on her back, had little to say. But both said they were driven out of their homes by overwhelming family problems, and they had become friends.
"When I got here last week, she gave me a big hug," said the new girl, a 15-year-old, one of eight children. "I was already welcomed when I walked in the door." She said that because of problems with her father, she and her mother had been seeing a social worker who referred them to the Youth Shelter. "It's the only place I can go right now," she said, seated at the big dining table.
The other girl, also 15, who had just led a visitor on a tour of the house, came to the Youth Shelter from a foster family, she said, but her problems originated with her mother.
"My mother abused me, and I couldn't take it anymore," she said. "When I was 11, I ran away a few times and came to live with my grandparents in Newtown. Then I went into the hospital for depression, because my mother said she was coming to take me back. I was in for 40 days, out for a week and 3 days, and back in for 17 days. I tried to kill myself."
"I didn't know that," said her new friend.
The other girl continued: "When I went back to the hospital the second time, I was assigned a social worker. From there I went to the Waterbury shelter. I left there and went to a foster home in Danbury, and from there to a foster home in Ridgefield. Then I went back to the hospital and here. It's the best shelter. It's clean, the staff pay attention to you."
Two counselors are on duty 24 hours a day in the locked shelter. "That's what I need, someone to listen to me," said the newcomer.
Both girls have hopes for the future, they said. The new arrival hopes "to go back home and straighten things out with my father, get to know him, work things out," she said.
The other girl said: "I hope to get into a foster home in Ridgefield. And if that doesn't come through, I hope to go to a group home in Westport called Project Return." She no longer wants to kill herself, she said.
Lin Lavery, chairwoman of the Kids in Crisis project, said, "When you heal the child, you heal the community." To help raise the money for the expanded program, she enlisted the actor-director Ron Howard, who lives in Greenwich, to appear in a fund-raising video.
"We really wanted to get across what we do," Mrs. Lavery said. "We wanted someone who was a family person, who represents the image of a healthy family, a commitment to family."
Mr. Howard, father of four, donated a morning to appear in the three-minute video, which will be offered to television stations as a public service message. But before making the commitment, he and his wife spent two hours at the Youth Shelter.
"I had never been to one of these places," he said in a telephone interview. "I didn't know what to expect. We were very impressed with it. We met some of the kids who were there. I thought it was very impressive in its humanistic environment. I was surprised in an area in Fairfield County how busy they are and the range of people they have -- in age, economic background, racial background."
Mr. Howard does not appear in many public service announcements, he said.
"I try to steer clear of it," he said. "You have to have some sense of what you're talking about. I have a good feeling about this. They are dealing with a very intense reality in terms of these kids. Their function is not to take people out of their homes but to provide a place where people can go and solve their problems.
"It takes a lot for people to collect themselves in a rational way. I hope my children never need a place like this. But if my children are feeling backed into a corner, it's very important to know that it exists."
The Youth Shelter is facing a dramatic growth in the demand for its service, Mrs. Shapiro said, thanks to a growing public awareness of its availability and increased pressures on families from the economic downturn. She pointed out that when the shelter opened in 1980, 125 teen-agers were helped during the year. By 1989 that number had jumped to 892. In the last fiscal year 1,418 young people sought asylum.
"We're working with families that are very, very wealthy as well as those who don't have a penny to their name," Mrs. Shapiro said. "A crisis can happen in any family."
The Youth Shelter -- which serves Darien, Greenwich, New Canaan, Norwalk, Stamford, Weston, Westport and Wilton -- works with 78 agencies to help families cope with their problems.
One girl who was confined to a wheelchair repeatedly fled from her home to escape her fast-track, alcohol-abusing divorced parents, shelter staff members said. Counselors from the shelter worked with the girls' parents, referring them to an appropriate agency to seek help with their problems.
"It's critical that people know who we are: the parents, the kids, the clergy, the police, schools -- every way you can imagine -- friends, relatives and grandparents," said Mrs. Shapiro. To get the word out to youngsters, an annual Youth Press Conference is held in the fall, for students from school newspapers and journalism and video classes in all eight towns.

HEADLINE: DINING OUT;
Getting Off to a Fast Start in Great Neck

BYLINE: By JOANNE STARKEY

 BODY:
THE six-week-old North Street Grill in Great Neck is the Island's hottest new restaurant. It has the look, ownership expertise and exciting menu that make it the last word in 1990's dining.
The multi-level restaurant that has emerged on the site of the old Maude Craig's is a stunner. It is earthy, sturdy and southwestern, yet light, airy and modern. 
 Imposing stained-glass light fixtures typify this fusion. They glow with a blend of Art Deco and American Indian geometric designs. The dining room is dominated by them, along with the high ceilings, wood timbers, skylights and a bustling open kitchen.
The culinary superstar behind this new enterprise is Brendan Walsh, who earned his chef stripes at Arizona 206 in Manhattan and Coyote Grill in Island Park. Mr. Walsh is part owner of North Street Grill and oversees its kitchen, as well as the one at Coyote Grill.
The menu hints at Mr. Walsh's Southwestern style, with a salsa here and a chili-spiked hollandaise there, but the offerings are a far cry from straight Santa Fe fare. The food is up-to-the-minute American with an overlay of Italian trendsetters like focaccia, polenta, wood-oven pizza and innovative pastas.
All is not perfection at this storybook-sounding restaurant, although it should be noted that it is only a few weeks old. Service is shaky and some dishes are disappointments.
On a busy Saturday night, service was a study in smiling neglect. Our waiter was amiable, but we were left to pour our own wine. We also failed to receive bread. That was unfortunate, because the chewy focaccia strewn with onions and peppers, and the crusty country-style bread, both baked in the restaurant's wood oven, are too good to miss.
Additionally, the young people who delivered the meal were fuzzy about who ordered what and plunked dishes down at random. Even on a slower weeknight, when service was attentive, there was still a breakdown at delivery time.
Shortfalls from the kitchen included a watery pasta of penette with red beans and white-clam sauce. The dish arrived with no beans, no taste and no apologies. Less of a strikeout but garnering no accolades was the rib eye steak, which turned out to be a chewy shell steak look-alike.
These losers are not typical of North Street Grill. There is a nightly parade of winners, beginning with the herb- and garlic-flavored olives and the bouquet of two-foot-long crunchy breadsticks.
Do not miss the individual appetizer pizzas, with their crisp crusts pleasantly charred from the wood oven. My favorite had grilled eggplant, roasted peppers and a fillip of garlicky aioli.
Alluring seafood openers are house-smoked salmon, shrimp and sesame fritters paired with a creamy wasabi mustard and sea scallops skewered with a ribbon of pancetta and presented over crisp slices of marinated kohlrabi.
Three salads made fine beginings. A fall-away tender confit of duck accompanied by greens and a paper-thin homemade potato chip fan is the menu's most expensive appetizer at $9.50. More economical is the $4.50 market salad of impeccably fresh greens in a light balsamic vinaigrette. Also winning kudos was the wilted salad of julienned strips of endive crowned with walnuts and goat cheese.
A main-course choice with salad at its heart is lovely baby greens encircled with grilled vegetables. A splash of herb-infused olive oil was its delicious complement.
Fish fanciers will reel in a keeper with either the crusty pan-seared salmon resting on a bed of lentils or the wood oven-roasted channel bass ringed with ratatouille and annointed with black olive paste.
At the top of the list for meat lovers is a house-made chicken chorizo sausage served with white beans and bitter greens. A half chicken rubbed with herbs and perched atop a bread salad consisting of greens, toasted croutons and dried cranberries also scored.
Beef tenderloin, unlike the rib eye steak, was tender perfection. It was enhanced by a tomato-chili hollandaise and a nest of chopped asparagus.
Every entree has its own well-matched vegetable accompaniments. Nevertheless, there are $4 a la carte side dishes. The best is the array of crunchy baby vegetables. Potato pancakes were soggy, and sweet potato home fries were thick slices slathered with sauteed onions and peppers that did not fit the menu description.
Only an apple cobbler disappointed at dessert. Served piping hot rather than warm, its scoop of maple ice cream became an instant puddle. Ice creams are homemade, and the best is the fresh mint with its intense herb flavor.
Chocolate lovers swooned over a moist cupcake encircled with dollops of creamy chocolate pudding, as well as a rich slab of frozen chocolate mousse cake that melted on the tongue.
Wine and food are given equal billing at North Street Grill. More than 100 mostly American wines are available by the bottle, and 10 more can be ordered by the glass. Although a smattering of Italian, French and Long Island wines are on the list, its focus is on the small, high-quality, boutique wines of the West Coast.
Names seen only rarely on East Coast lists abound at North Street. They include Chappelet, Edna Valley, Chalk Hill, Arrowood, Dalla Valle, Page Mill and Frog's Leap. Wine can be ordered for as little as $15 a bottle and $3.75 a glass.
 
North Street Grill
Very Good
661 Northern Boulevard, Route 25A, one block east of Lakeville Road, Great Neck. 466-0200.

HEADLINE: Hispanic Doctors Form Network

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER

 BODY:
IN a move to meet the health needs of a rapidly growing segment of the county's population, Spanish-speaking doctors have formed the county's first Hispanic medical society.
Dr. Felix Davila, a White Plains internist, has spearheaded the drive among Westchester doctors to help Hispanic residents who -- because of a language barrier, financial need or a lack of understanding of a new culture -- may not have access to medical care. 
 The first Westchester Spanish Medical Conference, held in White Plains in November, drew nearly 150 county doctors. Dr. Davila, who emigrated to the United States in 1965 from Nicaragua, organized the meeting and said that in addition to yearly dinner conferences, he planned to continue sponsoring gatherings and workshops yearlong to expand the efforts begun in the fall.
"Many Hispanic people are poor, do not have medical insurance and are overwhelmed by the cultural differences," Dr. Davila said. "They represent special needs that we must begin to address."
 
An 89 Percent Increase in 10 Years
 Hispanic residents account for about 1 in 10 of Westchester's population, and the census shows that their numbers have increased in the county by 89 percent over the last decade and by 337 percent since 1970.
"As the Hispanic community at large grows, we need to begin to unify the Spanish medical community," Dr. Davila said. "We need to get to know each other, network among ourselves and make referrals so that patients and doctors can come together."
According to the census, of the county's 874,866 residents in 1990, 86,194 were Hispanic, compared with 45,566 in 1980 and 25,506 in 1970.
Although there are no official counts of Hispanic doctors working in the county, Dr. Davila said there were "too few doctors to serve this population."
 
Shortage of Bilingual Staff
 Olga Mackenrow, an advocate for Hispanic residents with the County Department of Health, said that in addition to a shortage of Spanish-speaking doctors, there were also too few bilingual health-care workers at county-run medical clinics and hospitals. She cited instances at the County Medical Center in Valhalla of cleaning people in the building being asked to translate for patients because doctors and nurses did not speak Spanish.
Mrs. Mackenrow and Dr. Davila are encouraging Hispanic doctors to treat, on a sliding-scale basis, low-income patients without insurance or those on Medicaid, because, she said, "Many other private physicians refuse to treat them."
The county's Department of Health, too, is taking a hard look at the health needs of the county's Hispanic population, Commissioner Mark S. Rapoport said. The problems of Spanish-speaking people, he said, "loom very large on the horizon."
Dr. Rapoport cited national statistics showing that in 1989, 36.2 percent of Hispanic children lived in poverty, compared with 14.8 percent of white children.
"Westchester," he said, "does tend to mirror that."
 
Emotional Problems Also Addressed
 Doctors who attended the November conference and are beginning to identify the special concerns of Westchester's Spanish-speaking residents said it was important to assess not only the health needs of their patients but also their emotional problems.
"When a patient comes looking for help, we need to treat not just the disease but all aspects of life," said Dr. Elena L. Pena, a Mamaroneck psychiatrist from Salamanca, Spain.
"Many times, when a person immigrates," she said, "they are convinced that the place they left is all good, and the place they have come to is all bad, because they do not understand the language and because they have lost their emotional and religious supports from the past."
The language barrier, she said, was "especially important with psychiatry, because you miss a lot when you have to translate, and you can lose trust between the patient and the doctor."
 
'It's Not the Rich'
 Dr. Pena cautioned against generalizing about Hispanic patients, saying that there have been waves of immigration from different Spanish-speaking countries, with an early group of professionals emigrating from Cuba and recent groups coming from Central and South America.
The newest Hispanic immigrants are the working-class poor, Mrs. Mackenrow said. "It's not the rich ones now," she said, "but those who have come to make a better life for their children."
Dr. Manuel Sanguily, who emigrated from Cuba in 1960 and now works as a family practitioner in Tarrytown, said that because of his early experiences in the United States, he wanted to help the new groups of Hispanic immigrants.
"I feel very aware of my roots again," he said. "Yes, I am an American now, and I vote, but I am also Hispanic. The Spanish-speaking population settling in Westchester and trying to be part of the mainstream needs doctors like me who understand firsthand what they are going through."
 
'It's Time to Be Vociferous'
 "They need that arm over their shoulder, the handshake, that abrazo," Dr. Sanguily said. "It means that I'm your friend, and I am here to take care of you, to show you the way."
As important as it is to be sympathetic health-care providers, Spanish-speaking doctors must also learn to be more assertive in taking a leadership role in the medical community, Dr. Sanguily said.
"It's time to be vociferous," he added, "not to feel shy or inferior, even if our English is not as good as theirs.
Dr. Sanford A. Kaplan, president of the 1,800-member Westchester County Medical Society, described the newly formed doctors' group as a "much-needed avenue for bonding" among the Spanish-speaking medical community.
"It is important that Hispanic physicians develop an independent identity so that they can strike out in the socio-economic area and become leaders," Dr. Kaplan said. "They shouldn't feel that their background or where they came from inhibits that ascension to leadership. We welcome them."

HEADLINE: Rules Forcing Towns to Pick Big New Dumps or Big Costs

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LUVERNE, Ala.

 BODY:
New Federal and state rules are forcing the closing of hundreds of old community garbage dumps and prompting the development of many fewer, but much larger landfills that only the biggest cities and the largest garbage companies can afford to build and operate.
And residents of thousands of small communities, like this one south of Montgomery, will be forced to choose the revenue and heavy truck traffic of a new nearby landfill or the huge increase in costs of transporting their garbage far away. What is definite, though, is that the new regulations are proving to be a bonanza to the nation's largest garbage companies. 
 "A little county like ours can't afford to build a new dump," said Dwight Faulk, the probate judge and chairman of the Crenshaw County Commission. "So we have to have a company do it for us. These laws were set up for big business to monopolize an industry."
 
Boon to Large Companies
 Industry executives agree. "There are only a handful of companies that will have the capabilities to provide the type of environmentally sound facilities that the public is demanding," said John C. Shirvinsky, vice president of public affairs for the Chambers Development Company, a Pittsburgh-based garbage company that operates 14 huge landfills around the country.
Rarely have environmental regulations produced as many political distractions for the communities they are written to protect, or meant as much to the bottom lines of the industry they are intended to regulate.
 
Upgrade or Close
 The intent of new Federal regulations, which were issued in October, was to eliminate toxic waste problems caused by community-owned dumps that leaked. The Government now requires new landfills to be built with plastic and clay liners, liquid collection and treatment systems, and other expensive environmental equipment that has raised the cost of opening a landfill to $10 million or more. Old town dumps that fail to meet the new requirements must close by 1993.
The new Federal rules, and a few older state laws including those established by New York and New Jersey, mean most of the 6,500 community dumps across the country will be forced to close within the next few years, the Environmental Protection Agency has said. In their place will be 1,000 or so immense modern landfills owned primarily by a dozen or so companies and intended to serve entire regions.
In effect, the Government may be helping to establish regional monopolies, and that worries some officials.
"It's not difficult to project a situation in the future where very few firms could have regional or statewide control on the management of public wastes," said Thomas C. Jorling, the Commissioner of Environmental Conservation in New York, which will have fewer than 100 landfills by 1995, down from 518 in 1983. "If that occurs, it might be necessary for some kind of public utility regulations so that the public is not ripped off."
Garbage industry executives insist, though, that there is enough competition to protect homeowners and businesses. "There will not be so few landfills that a city has only one option for disposal," said Philip S. Angell, the special assistant to the chairman of Browning-Ferris Industries, the nation's second-largest disposal company, in Houston. "There also will be a broader range of disposal options -- recycling, composting, incineration."
The big money in garbage, nevertheless, still remains in dumping it. Despite recycling and new incinerators that turn trash into steam, electricity and ash, the amount of garbage headed for landfills amounts to 130 million tons a year, according to the National Solid Wastes Management Association, the industry's trade group.
 
Battle in Alabama
 The nation's big garbage companies now earn $30 to more than $100 a ton to haul and dispose of the refuse. Managing garbage has grown into a $30-billion-a-year industry, and revenues are expected to double within five years, industry analysts say.
Industry executives warn potential investors that the path to a new landfill is strewn with political obstacles, and only 1 of 10 proposed landfills is actually built. But they also acknowledge that companies nimble enough to overcome local opponents and beat their competitors in building a new landfill can realize profits of 25 to 50 percent on revenues of more than $100,000 a day.
Thus, garbage companies are now battling for control of a region's garbage. And in few places is the fight more aggressive than in Alabama.
Only 10 or 12 of the state's 102 community and county landfills meet the new requirements of the Federal law and the rest will close by the end of 1993, according to state officials.
Garbage companies, led by Waste Management of Oak Brook, Ill., the nation's largest, and Browning-Ferris, are battling for their share of the nearly 13,000 tons of garbage dumped in landfills by Alabama every day. The two companies, and several smaller companies, have proposed replacing the state's community dumps with 15 large regional landfills.
The proposals have angered some residents who say they believe such large landfills are unnecessary to replace the unobtrusive small dumps. In Blount and Walker Counties, north of Birmingham, county leaders have been threatened with death for inviting Browning-Ferris to propose new regional landfills, residents and state officials said.
Environmental groups warned that the new dumps provide far more capacity than Alabama needs and aresituated to take advantage of Alabama's superior network of railways, waterways and highways to accept garbage from other states.
"We're being set up to become the garbage dumping ground of the nation," said Linda Guy, the president of the Alabama Environmental Coalition, a state environmental group. "If all these new dumps are built, we'll have capacity for 30,000 or 40,000 tons per day, three times what we produce."
 
Protecting Counties
 Executives from Waste Management and Browning-Ferris objected to Mrs. Guy's assertion. State law, they said, protects counties by requiring companies and communities to negotiate a contract that specifies the dozen or so counties that a new regional landfill would serve.
"It would be political and economic suicide for Waste Management or any other company here to import garbage from New York or New Jersey or any other state," said Steve Bradley, a Waste Management spokesman in Birmingham. "Alabama just won't tolerate it."
But Alabama is seeing garbage companies fiercely trying to derail another company's proposal for a new landfill. For decades, Crenshaw County's 14,000 residents used the garbage dump just north of Luverne. It cost Crenshaw County $80,000 a year to haul residents' garbage and operate the landfill, and families paid an average garbage fee of $10 a month, said Mr. Faulk, the probate judge.
About two years ago, Mr. Faulk said, county leaders recognized that the new Federal and state rules would require the county to either spend millions of dollars modernizing the old dump or build a new one at an even higher cost. Late in 1990, Crenshaw County's five commissioners signed a contract with a Florida company to close the old county dump at a cost of $100,000, and build a $10 million 200-acre landfill on the same land four miles north of town to serve residents from Crenshaw and nine neighboring counties.
The company, Three Rivers Construction of Marianna, Fla., was eager to gain a contract and promised benefits that have become common in Alabama and other states. Crenshaw County residents could dump their garbage free in the landfill and Three Rivers would pay the county $1.50 a ton for other garbage disposed there, a potential source of income to the county that eventually could be worth $300 to $800 a day. For the fiscal year 1991, the county's entire budget was $1.2 million.
The proposed landfill, which is awaiting state approval, stirred protests from residents who worried it was too big and would cause dangerous levels of truck traffic.
 
'People Wouldn't Stand for It'
 "If we just closed the dump and didn't build a new one, that meant we'd have to take our garbage out of the county to another dump where tip fees are going to be $20, $25, or $30 a ton," Mr. Faulk said. "Add the trucking costs and you can see that the cost of garbage disposal would go to $300,000 or $400,000 a year. People wouldn't stand for it."
But the project's biggest opponent has been Waste Away, a Montgomery-based garbage company and a business partner of Waste Management. Waste Away has a competing proposal to build its own $12 million landfill 35 miles east of here and wants the garbage from Crenshaw and surrounding counties to be dumped there to make the project more profitable. Crenshaw County would pay at least $24 a ton, plus hauling costs, to dump there.
At a public hearing last month in the Crenshaw County courthouse, Waste Away sent a team of lawyers and engineers to attack the Crenshaw landfill. One of Waste Away's engineers said the proposed Crenshaw County landfill site was unsuitable and could become a threat to the environment and public health. Charles Patterson, a lawyer for Waste Away, said a second landfill in the region would generate such competition for garbage that waste would come into the area from out of state. "We don't need another regional landfill," Mr. Patterson said.
Mr. Faulk and other commissioners were livid after the hearing. "What you are seeing here is raw power and greed," he said.
Sarah Clark, another commissioner, added: "The commissioners of Crenshaw County did what was best for Crenshaw County. If the people of Crenshaw County want to pay $30 a month for garbage pickup, it's up to them."

HEADLINE: Escape From Cuba: An Affair For Family and Friends, Too

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MIAMI, Jan. 5

 BODY:
Ten days ago, at a ceremony in Havana, German Pompa Gonzalez was awarded a medal for "exemplary service" to the Cuban Revolution for his performance as a helicopter pilot. This morning, he sat in the living room of his sister-in-law's modest house in a Miami suburb, a wanted man back in his homeland but a hero to thousands of Cuban exiles here.
Mr. Pompa's journey to freedom began on Friday at dawn, when he awoke, dressed quietly in the uniform of Cuba's national airline so as not to wake fellow crew members still asleep in a staff dormitory and boarded the Russian-made MI-8 helicopter in which he normally ferried tourists around Cuba. 
 Three hours later, after picking up his wife and 32 more relatives and friends in a pasture and flying 200 miles across the Florida Strait, he landed his craft at Tamiami Executive Airport south of here and kissed American soil.
"We were flying barely two yards above the water, and there was always the danger that Castro's radar would detect us and force us down," Mr. Pompa, a 27-year-old lieutenant in the Cuban Air Force with two years of combat service in Angola, said of his daring flight. "Nevertheless, I felt a tremendous sense of equilibrium and calm. I knew that one way or another, it would soon be over."
After requesting political asylum, Mr. Pompa and all but one passenger were released from an Immigration and Naturalization Service detention center Saturday to the custody of relatives. Cubans are treated differently from those of other nationalities, like Haitians, and are eligible for legal residency in the United States in a year. This morning, Mr. Pompa and 13 other relatives, including his brother Gustavo and various cousins, awoke in Opa Locka in the two-bedroom house of his wife's sister Mery Diaz, a former political prisoner who arrived in Florida two years ago.
There, he learned, to his distress, of news reports from Havana that the Cuban Government was demanding the return of both the helicopter and its pilot. In addition, there were new uncertainties. "We need to put a roof of our own over our heads," Mr. Pompa said. "How do we find jobs? Who's going to give us orientation on how you live here?"
Ms. Diaz's house, whose principal decorations are a few religious pictures and a pair of small television sets, is normally home to five people but was filled to overflowing this morning. Mr. Pompa's wife, Maria de la Caridad Carrazana, emphasized that neither her sister nor their parents, who remain in Cuba and whose house is now reported to be under surveillance, knew of the escape plan in advance.
 
Idea Came From His Wife
 Mr. Pompa said it was his wife, dissatisfied with life under Communist rule, who initiated the idea of a mass escape by helicopter, the first of its kind since Fidel Castro took power in Cuba in January 1959. "She was the planner, and I was the instrument," he said.
"I lived for many years cherishing the revolution," said the 44-year-old Ms. Carrazana, who has four children from an earlier marriage. "I loved it and worked for it and sacrificed for it, but the Cuban people have no rights any more, and nothing to eat or enjoy as diversions. Before too long, Cuba is going to be thrown back to the conditions it was in when Christopher Columbus discovered America."
As Mr. Pompa's brother and 20-year-old stepson Emilio, an automobile mechanic, examined a car parked in front of the house, another sister-in-law, who had not seen Ms. Carrazana since she left Cuba as a former political prisoner, entered and embraced Ms. Carrazana. "Girl, you look good, considering what you've just been through," she said.
"And why shouldn't I," Ms. Carrazana retorted. "Now we can begin to live. Now my grandchildren are going to know what it is like to say what they want, to celebrate Christmas and New Year's and the Three Kings' Day, to buy a soft drink or a bicycle when they want. In Cuba, there's no freedom, there's nothing."
Sustained for many years by billions of dollars of subsidies from the Soviet Union that have been gradually cut off over the last five years, the Cuban economy has gone into a tailspin. Food and fuel have long been rationed, but on Jan. 1, the Government imposed new restrictions on the consumption of gasoline and electricity, leading to cutbacks on bus routes, store hours, television programming and other aspects of daily life.
At the same time, Mr. Castro, alarmed by events in the Soviet Union, has vowed never to implement the policies of perestroika and glasnost that brought about the fall of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and the collapse of the Soviet Union, saying that Cuba would rather drown in a sea of blood than embrace capitalism.
Ms. Carrazana said that a personal turning point came with October's Communist Party Congress, which party officials and the state-controlled press had hinted might bring some political and economic change. But when Mr. Castro made it clear that he had no intention of instituting any such change and called for greater sacrifices and renewed revolutionary ardor, the populace felt a sense of betrayal and disgust, she said.
 
'Things Only Got Worse'
 "Everybody was waiting, waiting, waiting for the Congress, thinking they would put things in order," she said. "But things only got worse. When the new laws came down, they just tightened the system."
She said the family's plan to flee Cuba began about three months ago, when her 24-year-old daughter Inova Lara, a model, "came to me and said, 'Mommy, I can't stand it here any more. I'm going over in a raft, and I'm taking my child with me.' "
That prospect, Ms. Carrazana said, alarmed her. More than 2,000 Cubans successfuly crossed the Florida Straits to freedom aboard rafts, inner tubes and small boats last year, but many more are believed to have drowned, died of exposure, or been eaten by sharks as they drifted on the sea.
 
Plan for Mass Defection
 Ms. Carrazana said she made her daughter swear not to leave Cuba on a raft, promising to organize a mass defection that would take the entire family to the United States. But when it came time to approach her husband with the idea, she confessed, she felt some nervousness.
"He liked the system, and had always been what they call a revolutionary combatant," she said. "But I began to talk to him about conditions and planted the idea of leaving, and he did not oppose it."
Mr. Pompa, it turned out, had also grown disenchanted with the Castro government and wanted a new life. "The reservations I had about leaving were practical, because this was a difficult thing, after all," he explained this morning as Ms. Carrazana sat in his lap, her arms around him. "But I told her not to worry, that I would find a plane and get all of us out."
Friday's flight, he said, was actually the third attempt to fly the group out of Cuba. On Dec. 30, he said, the group rode a bus from Havana to the beach resort of Varadero, where he works, but the escape had to be canceled when Mr. Pompa discovered that a fuse had been removed from the helicopter, apparently to disable it.
Then, on New Year's Day, Mr. Pompa discovered that the helicopter he flew had been shifted to Havana for festivities associated with the anniversary of Mr. Castro's assumption of power. He worried then that his plan to escape had been uncovered, but said that the rest of the group remained optimistic.
d a lot of luck, and we are grateful to God for that," Ms. Carrazana said. "We were a large group, but there were no informers among us, and we were also fortunate to have the means to get out. I think 88 percent of the Cuban people would like to do the same, but it is not easy to escape."

They stood outside a relative's home in Opa Locka, Fla. (Susan Greenwood for The New York Times) (pg. B8)

HEADLINE: The Quandary in Japan;
Bush Will Be Given Concessions on Trade, But Not the Broad Changes the U.S. Wants

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Jan. 5

 BODY:
For weeks, Japanese newspapers have been filled with reports of trade concessions Japan will offer President Bush on his visit this week, most of them aimed at increasing Japanese imports of American autos.
But for all the expected promises, the measures are likely to create a troubling quandary for American officials: many of the steps have nothing to do with opening the Japanese market or freeing trade, the professed aim of the President's trade policies. Instead, they add up to Government orders simply to buy more American products to head off worsening trade tensions. 
 The difficulty this creates is that President Bush and his trade negotiators have long maintained that they do not want special favors so much as fundamental changes in the Japanese economic system to remove barriers against imports. The United States has said it wants tougher enforcement of Japan's antimonopoly laws, measures to open the tightly knit industrial groups that are said to discriminate against outsiders, and steps to stimulate the domestic economy so that Japanese companies can focus more on their home market than on exports.
 
2 Agreements Planned
 Japanese and American officials have said two documents will be completed during the President's stay, which starts Tuesday. One, the Tokyo Declaration, is intended to serve as a blueprint for relations between the two countries in the post-cold war era spanning political, security and economic issues. Officials on both sides said that document was essentially completed.
The other agreement, which was still being hammered out over the weekend, will be an "action plan," which is expected to include Japan's specific responses to American complaints about trade.
Among the measures that are expected from the Japanese are an easing of some testing standards and pollution-control regulations for imported cars; a tax break for buyers of imported autos, and Government pressure on Japanese auto companies to change their distribution policies to make it easier for dealers to sell imported autos.
In addition, under Government pressure, every major Japanese auto company has announced a campaign to buy more American autos and auto parts. For instance, the Nissan Motor Company, Japan's second-largest auto maker, last month announced a program that it said would increase its imports of foreign autos, auto parts and machinery to $1.23 billion annually by fiscal 1994, which ends March 31, 1995, a 150 percent increase from the current fiscal year's level. Nissan said it also planned a fourfold increase of its procurement of American-made parts for its United States plants, to $2.8 billion in fiscal 1994.
 
$1 Billion for Research
 Japanese and American officials have also said Japan is considering offering more than $1 billion in financing for an expensive research center with a supercollider to be built in Texas.
The trade tensions have been worsened by the American recession, election-year pressures in the United States and a new surge in Japan's trade surplus.
After declining for the last four years, Japan's trade surplus shot up last year and is expected to hit another record this year, to more than $100 billion. Adding to America's renewed irritation is the fact that about three-fourths of Japan's $45 billion trade surplus with the United States last year is made up of autos and auto parts.
But to hear the Japanese describe their responses to President Bush's anticipated demands, they are more like offerings of aid from the conquerors to the vanquished, a lifeline to save the United States from economic decline.
In a series of comments recently, Kiichi Miyazawa, the Prime Minister, emphasized that Japanese companies must lend a hand out of "compassion" for the ailing American economy and the auto makers. Nothing has been said by Mr. Miyazawa or others about lowering barriers.
"I would like to do whatever I can to help the United States recover from its economic and social ills with the cooperation of the Japanese people and industry," Mr. Miyazawa said Saturday.
Earlier he remarked, "It came as a considerable shock to the Americans that General Motors had been defeated by Japanese autos, though Japanese cars alone might not be responsible" for G.M.'s decline.
Japanese officials have also firmly rejected comments by President Bush and other officials in Washington suggesting the American recession resulted at least in part from the closed Japanese markets.
"We have very strong doubts about a correlation between U.S. unemployment and access to markets in Japan," a Foreign Ministry official said at a briefing for foreign reporters last week. "It is a bit too simplistic."
Similarly, the Japanese Government has already begun to mount a defense against expected American demands for new negotiations to tackle outstanding trade problems. American officials have said they plan to "reinvigorate" a three-year-old set of negotiations on what are believed to be structural aspects of the Japanese economy that discriminate against foreign companies and keep out imports.
One longstanding issue that the United States is expected to address is keiretsu, or groups of Japanese companies with interlocking ownerships and business relationships. The United States has long insisted that these tightly knit groups, which are said to exclude outsiders, should be forced open to eliminate the barriers they present to newcomers.
 
Degree of Openness
 The Foreign Ministry has just released a brochure that argues keiretsu are completely open, and that in some regards they make Japan more open to imports than the United States. The ministry even chose to describe how they work not by referring to the most well-known keiretsu, like Mitsubishi, Toyota and Sumitomo, but to American companies, including American Telephone and Telegraph, Sears and G.M., which have cooperative relationships with subsidiaries or other companies.
But in a contradictory afterthought, the brochure adds that Americans might benefit from studying the keiretsu system. That comment probably best captures the Japanese attitude toward these economic and trade matters as they prepare to play host at this meeting with President Bush.
More than ever, the Japanese look at the lingering American recession, the country's industrial ills and the President's need to come to Japan to press for concessions as a sign that the time has come for America to do more to emulate the Japanese system, rather than demand changes.

HEADLINE: New Interest in Missing Servicemen May Imperil Move Toward Hanoi Ties

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5

 BODY:
Expectations that the United States and Vietnam would soon establish diplomatic relations, more than 15 years after the end of the Indochina War, may be set back by a resurgence of interest in one piece of unfinished business that will not go away: the fate of missing Americans.
The revival of the issue has been spurred by a series of statements over the last six months -- from apparently bogus reports of sightings of live Americans to unsubstantiated information that Soviet officials interrogated Americans in Indochina after the time Vietnam said it had freed them. 
 While most American officials discount such reports, their persistence has led to the establishment of a committee in Congress that will begin to draw together new threads of the story in hearings over the next few weeks.
This week, State Department officials are expected to meet with Maj. Gen. Oleg D. Kalugin, the former Soviet intelligence official who reported the interrogations in October. The former K.G.B. official, who has been interviewed in Moscow by American Embassy officials, is expected to testify at a closed session of the Senate Select Committee on P.O.W.-M.I.A. Affairs.
 
To Interview Former Agents
 The panel will begin this week to interview former intelligence agents or servicemen who had access to secret information in the 1960's and 1970's and who have reportedly offered to testify that more was known about the fate of missing Americans than subsequent Administrations acknowledged.
Some members of Congress predict that the panel's findings will move the American-Vietnam relationship into domestic politics.
Representative Robert G. Toricelli, Democrat of New Jersey, said he would guarantee that the issue is brought up in this Presidential election year.
"The steady accumulation of information and persistent expressions of doubts about the fate of missing Americans has now shifted the burden of proof to the Vietnamese," said Mr. Toricelli, a member of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, who first discussed the issue with officials in Hanoi in 1984. "If George Bush persists in moving toward recognition now, he is putting himself at considerable political risk. I wouldn't have said that six months ago."
In October, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said the United States was prepared to begin talks with Hanoi to establish relations.
He said progress would depend on Vietnam's willingness to furnish information about 2,273 Americans who are listed in records as prisoners of war or missing in action.
On Friday, the State Department reiterated that lifting economic sanctions and opening diplomatic relations depended on Hanoi's cooperation in making a fuller accounting of the missing. It also said it had supplied a list of names of missing servicemen to officials of several former Soviet republics. Richard A. Boucher, the deputy spokesman, said Kazakhstan had offered to allow United States officials to visit a high-security military installation at Sary-Shagan, 150 miles northwest of Alma-Ata, the Kazakh capital, to investigate a report that Americans had been taken there from Vietnam.
Those who believe that missing Americans are still alive say progress on accounting for has them slowed in the last year.
"In fact, 1991 was the worst year in accounting for cases," said Ann Mills Griffiths, who heads the National League of Families of American Prisoners and Missing in Southeast Asia, the largest of many advocacy groups.
Referring to the Vietnamese, she said in an interview: "Did they in fact withhold Americans after the general release in 1973? We know there are glaring discrepancies they could resolve by giving us access to files. They could resolve these if they had the political will to do so."
Officials say that about half the Americans unaccounted for are assumed to have been killed. Of the rest, only a few dozen, at most, may have been left behind or seized on clandestine operations after the American withdrawal in January 1973.
But doubts persist among those who, according to opinion polls, think more were left behind and that some may have survived.
Most Americans close to investigations discount stories of live sightings, saying it is inconceivable that with all the Vietnamese defectors and refugees in the West, some incontrovertible evidence would not have been produced.
Hanoi, stung by the allegations that it held American prisoners after the 1973 withdrawal and the fall of Saigon in 1975, told a visiting American Congressman on Friday that investigators should come and see for themselves that the charges are not true.
"They flatly denied these, as expected," Representative Stephen J. Solarz, Democrat of Brooklyn and chairman of the House Foreign Affairs subcommittee on Asia, said in a telephone interview from Bangkok after leaving the Vietnamese capital. "They are still hopeful of better relations with the United States. But a lot depends on how convincing the Kalugin evidence is."
In October, General Kalugin, who said he sent interrogation teams to Vietnam from 1975 to 1978 but did not go himself, began telling Western reporters that he knew that Americans had been turned over to his teams for questioning before being returned to Hanoi's custody.
In a telephone interview from Moscow, General Kalugin expanded on his allegations that certain unidentified Americans known to possess advanced knowledge of high technology were interrogated by his teams. The Vietnamese, he said, lacked the expertise to interrogate these prisoners. He insisted that at least three Americans he knew of had subsequently been freed by Hanoi and then traced in the United States by the K.G.B in the hope that they would be useful in the future. There are no American reports of such returnees.
On Saturday, the press agency Tass quoted a spokeswoman for foreign intelligence, Tatyana Samolis, as saying the Russian authorities had made a thorough study of K.G.B. files and found only one contact with an American prisoner, in 1973. The Central Intelligence Agency on Friday also disputed General Kalugin's assertions, saying that two of its agents had been interrogated in Vietnam, but that one was released in 1973 and the other in 1975.
Nevertheless, General Kalugin's statements have been seized on by advocacy groups who believe that the United States knew about such cases but kept silent to avoid compromising intelligence.
Representative Solarz calls these accusations "wholesale McCarthyism."
"The notion that any Administration was aware that people were being held against their will and covered it up is a monstrous accusation, which if one thinks about it, has to be premised on the notion that there were traitors in key positions," he said. He says the story that Americans could have been slipped back into society, as General Kalugin says, is "extremely suspect."
The growth and influence of the advocacy groups alarm those who believe that the only way to resolve the issue is through closer relations with the Vietnamese, said John McAuliff, director of the U.S.-Indochina Reconciliation Project in New York. He called the lobby for the missing "a tiger that is now out of control."

HEADLINE: Irving B. Kravis, 75, Who Was Specialist In Comparing Prices

 BODY:
Irving B. Kravis, a noted economist and educator who specialized in international price comparisons, died Friday after becoming ill at the Philadelphia airport on his way to receive an award.
He was 75 years old and lived in Haverford, Pa. His family said he was suffering from lymphoma and Parkinson's disease. 
 He was chairman of the economics department at the University of Pennsylvania from 1955 to 1958 and from 1962 to 1967, and he was associate dean of the Wharton School of Finance and Commerce at the university from 1958 to 1960. Including those posts, he served a total of 37 years on the university's faculty. Mr. Kravis earned his bachelor's and doctorate degrees at the university.
Sponsored by the United Nations and the World Bank, he conducted pioneering studies comparing consumer prices in foreign countries and the average number of hours of work required to buy certain items.
In large part for this work, he was posthumously made a distinguished fellow of the American Economic Association on Saturday at a meeting in New Orleans to which he was traveling when he became ill.
He received a Ford Foundation fellowship and a Guggenheim fellowship and was a research associate at the National Bureau of Economic Research and a consultant to the Organization for European Common Development.
He was awarded a Bronze Star for service in World War II as a first lieutenant in China with the Flying Tigers.
Surviving are his wife, the former Lillian Panzer; a sister, Lillian Zingg of McLean, Va.; two sons, Robert, of Glenside, Pa., and Nathan, of Brooklyn; two daughters, Marcia, of Philadelphia and Ellen Hamberger of Silver Spring, Md., and six grandchidlren.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Repairing Battered Industries
Some leading American industries were left reeling last year, from autos and real estate to retailing and banking. As top managers seek to repair the damage, an informal survey of some hard-hit industries found little hope that managers could solve the problems in 1992. Rather, executives warned that business must hold on tight until the roller-coaster economy heads up. [Page D4.]
 
International
Japan is expected to offer President Bush trade concessions on his visit this week, most of them aimed at increasing Japanese imports of U.S. cars. But for all the expected promises, many of the measures have nothing to do with opening Japan's market. Instead, they add up to Government orders simply to buy more American products to reduce trade tensions. News Analysis. [A1.]
For years, the Big Three auto makers have been the most conspicuous case of what happens to companies that try to sell in Japan the products they sell in America, with few concessions to Japanese tastes, habits, and the width of Japanese roads. [A12.]
Leading American economists are advising Russia and other former Soviet republics to move more swiftly than Eastern Europe in tackling economic changes. [D1.]
 
Companies
Many real estate developers are cutting back, but Edward S. Gordon is aggressively expanding. The company is expected to announce the appointment of Stephen B. Siegel, a former Cushman & Wakefield chairman, as its president. [D1.]
In his first months at Tenneco, Michael H. Walsh has practically run a seminar on how to act swiftly to alter the course of an industrial giant in distress. [D1.]
A proposal by some Revco creditors to maintain the drugstore chain's independence appeared to win support of creditors. [D2.]
 
The Economy
A research group proposes tax incentives for Americans who buy U.S.-made cars, to help stimulate sales and save "a dying industry." The proposal by the Economic Strategy Institute come amid calls for Government intervention in auto making. [D2.]
The Media Business
General Cinema won a yearlong battle to acquire Harcourt, but salvaging the publishing company will not be easy. [D1.]
The magazine industry is beginning to look into the possibilities of audio cassettes as marketable spinoffs of magazines. [D8.]
Congress will begin a third effort to pass legislation that would allow most cities to regulate prices for basic cable television services, after lawmakers struck out twice in two years. [D8.]
Unconventional images, like tatoos and spiked hair, will be the focus of a tongue-in-cheek trade advertising campaign for Family Circle magazine. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D9.]
Many businesses and organizations nourished by the newspaper industry have gone on short rations since advertising went into a steep decline 18 months ago. Alex S. Jones: Press. [D8.]
 
Today's Columns
The recession has not brought hard times to all retailers. Dollar General, which sells inexpensive necessities to low-income consumers, is growing at a pace that is the envy of merchants with more affluent customers. Market Place. [D1.]
Winter is usually a bad time for the bond market, and some analysts expect this year to be no exception. Kenneth N. Gilpin: Credit Markets. [D7.]

HEADLINE: John Elliott, 95, a Correspondent Who Foresaw the Threat of Hitler

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT

 BODY:
John Elliott, a foreign correspondent whose prophetic criticisms of Hitler led him to join the Allied effort and become a postwar occupation official in Germany, died on Saturday at the Fernwood House nursing home in Washington. He was 95 years old.
He died of natural causes, but a specific diagnosis was not given, a nephew said. 
 Reporting for The New York Herald Tribune, Mr. Elliott wrote in 1931 that "the specter of dictatorship menaces the German republic." He described Hitler, then a rising dissident, as a "fiery crusader" and "magnetic" orator. But he also called the Austrian-born Nazi leader a demagogue who "aspires to be a dictator" and "is not even a citizen of the country whose fate he may someday hold in his hands."
 
Reported on Jews
 His predictions came true. In 1934 he wrote a chilling assessment of the new totalitarian regime that began "Germany today is a military state" and went on to detail the Nazis' rigid control over the country. In 1935 he reported extensively on the growing persecution of Jews, quoting one official who called for mass castration. Mr. Elliott labeled such proposals an "extermination policy."
The German police seized newsstand copies of his newspaper in 1935, angered by his denunciation of Nazi "butchers" for executions in a purge. Under pressure, he moved to Paris. He reported on the Spanish Civil War and the outbreak of war between Germany and France, filing dispatches that were sometimes heavily censored by foreign officials. Twice in 1941 the Vichy Government suspended him from reporting.
He left journalism to become a major in the United States Army's psychological warfare branch in London, where he edited propaganda leaflets that planes dropped on Germany. After the war he was appointed deputy director of the Civil Administration Division of the occupation government in 1947, chief of its political activities in 1948 and chairman of the official newspaper, Neue Zeitung, in 1949. In the 1950's he helped create Radio Free Europe.
 
Worked for U.S. Agency
 Returning to the United States, he worked briefly on The Herald Tribune's financial news staff in Washington, then joined the Agency for International Development for about a decade before retiring about 1967.
He was born in Morristown, N.J., and earned bachelor's degrees from Princeton and Columbia Universities. He also studied at the University of Montpellier in France.
His wife, the former Edna Muriel Law, died in 1984. He is survived by two sons, John of Bethesda, Md., and Robert of Ross, Calif., and three grandchildren.
