HEADLINE: Seattle Journal;
City Fights to Keep Its Losing Team

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SEATTLE, Jan. 5

 BODY:
For the first time in its inglorious history, the Seattle Mariners baseball team has a problem that has nothing to do with its performance on the field.
The club posted its first winning record last year after fielding an unmatched series of losers for 14 years in a row. In the process, it shattered all home attendance records, attracting more than two million fans -- close to what the pennant-winning Atlanta Braves drew. 
 But the economics of major league baseball are such that Jeff Smulyan, the Indianapolis broadcasting executive who purchased the team in 1989, says he cannot make a profit with gate receipts alone. This summer he asked Seattle to come up with more than $10 million a year to help cover the expense of operating the team -- or else.
The else, he hinted, might be moving the team to the Tampa Bay area in Florida, where the Suncoast Dome sits empty in St. Petersburg without a major tenant, and the area's leaders, hungry for baseball, have assured Mr. Smulyan that a move would be profitable. Another possibility was bankruptcy; Mr. Smulyan, who owns Emmis Broadcasting, was given until February to pay a $39.5 million bank loan on the team.
But even as Seattle civic leaders were seeking money, Mr. Smulyan abruptly threw in the towel. In early December, he announced that the team was for sale, at $100 million, and that if a local owner did not come forth by March 27, he would be free to move the team or sell it to an outside owner. Seattle officials say he cannot do this, though, because of contracts he signed with the city.
At least nine other cities, from Houston to Pittsburgh to Chicago, have gone through similar agony in the last five years, as player salaries have escalated and owners have held out the threat of moving in order to squeeze more money from civic coffers.
One simple statistic tells the story of modern baseball: the New York Mets recently signed Bobby Bonilla to a five-year contract that will pay him $29 million -- an amount equal to the entire payroll of numerous other teams, many winners among them.
Mr. Smulyan's deadline has forced on this city a question that will become more common throughout the country as professional baseball becomes the province of the very rich: What is a sport worth to a city? Beyond the economic benefit, to restaurants, T-shirt hawkers and hotels, is the sense of regional pride, Seattle officials say.
The Mariners may have been a pathetic bunch of losers for 14 of their 15 seasons, but they were losers whose every strikeout, wild pitch and managerial temper tantrum was followed by fans from the North Slope of Alaska to the Flathead Valley of Montana.
The most obvious potential buyer is William H. Gates 3d, the founder of Microsoft Inc., the world's largest software company, with headquarters in the Seattle suburb of Redmond, Wash. Based on his stock holdings alone, Mr. Gates has recently become perhaps the wealthiest man in America -- worth more than $6 billion.
On radio talk shows and in letters to newspapers, fans have all but begged Mr. Gates to save the team. But Mr. Gates is not interested. He doesn't like baseball, says Martin Taucher, a spokesman for Mr. Gates.
So, with the March 27 deadline looming, the group of Seattle leaders charged with trying to find a local owner recently approached the Japanese. Seattle and Japan have long shared Pacific Rim trading and cultural ties that have held strong even through the worst of recent criticism of Japan by American political leaders.
But the thought of foreign ownership of an American team might be too much for baseball, the national pastime, after all, to bear.
What will probably emerge, say the Seattle officials, is a combination of Japanese and Seattle investors, with the local investors controlling the franchise. But it is far from a done deal.
The alternative can be found in the other Washington, the nation's capital, which was the last city to lose its baseball team. In 1972, the Washington Senators moved to Texas. There are still enough mourners to fill a stadium.

SECTION: Section A; Page 12; Column 4; National Desk

LENGTH: 1603 words

HEADLINE: In Japan's View, U.S. Car Companies Should Be Blaming Only Themselves

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Jan. 4

 BODY:
When President Bush and the chairmen of General Motors, Ford and Chrysler arrive Tuesday to cite the dismal sales of American cars here as a symbol of what is wrong with Japan, they may meet a rude surprise: Tokyo is preparing to cite the same example to make its case about the shortsightedness of American business.
For years, the Big Three auto makers have been the most conspicuous case of what happens to companies that try to sell in Japan exactly the same products they sell in America, with few concessions to Japanese tastes, Japanese habits, or even the width of Japanese roads. 
 With few exceptions, the American car giants have failed to make the kinds of large investments and commitments to new products that have brought modest success here to some of Europe's leading car makers, as well as other American companies like I.B.M., Eastman Kodak and Motorola.
 
Wrong Traveling Companions?
 As a result, many Japanese -- and more than a few American executives with long experience in Japan -- are suggesting that Mr. Bush is coming with the wrong traveling companions, playing into Japan's argument that the problems facing the American auto industry emanate largely from Detroit and Washington, not Toyota City and Tokyo.
"The solution is straightforward," Yutaka Kume, the president of the Nissan Motor Company and the head of the leading trade group for Japanese auto makers, said several months ago. "If the Big Three are to expand in the Japanese market, they first and foremost have to offer a car that is the right size and the right feel for Japanese consumers. They have to improve their marketing."
Most important, he said, "they have to realize that no one else will help them sell while they are sitting on their hands."
Few question that numerous trade barriers remain in the automotive market, particularly in auto parts, where Mr. Bush can present a strong case that many American companies have been unfairly excluded from the market. But even those American business executives and diplomats who complain about the obstacles to doing business here say they have a hard time working up much sympathy for the Big Three, even if three-fourths of the trade deficit with Japan has its roots in automobiles.
"If the Japanese changed their whole system tommorrow morning, and if American companies, especially the car companies, pursued every opportunity that opened up, the trade deficit would go down about $10 billion," Earle H. Harbison Jr., the president of the Monsanto Corporation, said here recently. "And that would still leave you with $40 billion."
In 1990, American-made cars accounted for less than five-tenths of 1 percent of the 5.1 million cars sold in the Japanese market, the world's second-largest. Japan, in contrast, holds nearly a third of the American market. That discrepancy, combined with the recession and Mr. Bush's trip, has prompted renewed talk in Congress of market limits on Japanese cars.
While Administration officials say they want Mr. Bush's trip to generate major concessions from Japan, some say there is another agenda at work: To force American auto makers to focus on Japan and Asia, and to make up for underinvestment there.
"We think the market in Japan is not yet open," Michael Farren, the Under Secretary of Commerce for International Trade, said the other day. "At the same time," he acknowledged, "the Big Three probably should have been doing a trip like this 10 years ago, maybe 20."
Long ago, Detroit began designing cars for European buyers, yet none of the Big Three has its own design center in Japan. (G.M. has just opened a small one to design parts.) While virtually all of the Japanese auto companies have built car factories in the American Midwest and opened design centers on the West Coast, no American auto maker has seriously considered an assembly plant in Japan.
 
Moves by Ford
 Over the last two decades, all three Detroit auto makers have made big investments in Japanese car manufacturers, chiefly to produce parts or finished cars that could be sold under American badges in the United States. Yet only one, Ford, has arranged for its partner, the Mazda Motor Company, in which it owns a 25 percent stake, to manufacture cars at its plant in Hiroshima that Ford can sell here -- with the steering wheel on the right-hand side, for driving on the left side of the road. And only Ford has followed Mercedes-Benz and BMW, the most sucessful foreign car makers in Japan, in building their own dealerships.
What the American auto makers do not lack in Japan is experience. General Motors has been here for decades, and Ford opened a plant in Yokohama in 1922 to assemble Model T's. Ford became the best-selling car in Japan, but soon after the military Government came to power in the late 1930's, the company was forced to leave.
For years after the war, the American car makers were excluded from the Japanese market, as Japan tried to build its own auto industry. When they finally were let in during the 1960's, Japanese tax policy and a web of anti-import regulations still worked against them.
But the American makers failed to get back in during the 1970's and 1980's, as the formal restraints fell away. Rather than sell directly, the American makers turned to sales agents.
 
Outnumbered in Dealerships
 The result is that the American car makers are vastly outnumbered in dealerships, a critical disadvantage in a country where Toyota salesmen periodically ring virtually every doorbell, talk to owners about what they want in a car, and often send greeting cards when a member of a "Toyota family" is married and show up at funerals when a good customer dies.
In 1990, General Motors cars were sold at nearly 700 outlets in Japan, while Ford had roughly 300 showrooms. Chrylser had the smallest network, with roughly 50 outlets, which have sold less than a thousand cars a year. However, the Honda Motor Company, which has no utility vehicle of its own, has begun selling Jeeps made by Chrysler, which are increasingly popular among young Japanese.
But it is the bottom line that Mr. Bush is expected to discuss, and not surprisingly his focus on autos has unleashed a torrent of resentments.
Japanese industial leaders insist that they have already contributed to the American economy by complying with American demands that they move their plants to the United States -- something that the Big Three thought in the early 1980's would level the playing field.
"Someone should remind President Bush," a senior Nissan executive said the other day, "that while Detroit is laying people off, the Japanese makers are creating jobs, jobs, jobs." All told, experts say, more than 50,000 Americans have jobs related to Japanese auto production in the United States. Since 1986, car exports to the United States from Japan have declined by nearly 800,000 units, while production in the United States has soared by more than a million.
 
'Concessions' to Be Issued
 The Japanese are preparing to issue "concessions" on autos that they hope will put a good face on the visit -- dropping, for example, a minor regulation that requires brakes to be tested once cars reach Japanese shores, and easing some environmental and safety regulations. More important, American makers could soon have access to bigger sales networks: Nissan just dropped requirements that its dealers seek permission before carrying other maker's cars, a contractual arrangement that froze foreign products out of thousands of showrooms.
But the problem is not that Japanese will not buy foreign cars, it is that they will not buy American cars. Mercedes, BMW and Volkswagen each sold about 36,000 cars a year here in 1990 (sales were down about 15 percent last year) not an enormous number, but more than three times better than the most successful American producer, General Motors, which was hoping to hit 10,000 units in 1991.
Success did not come easily to the Germans: They had to retool their factories so that cars could be ordered with the steering wheel on either side -- a change that General Motors has resisted because of the cost. Other modifications for the Japanese market are also available -- like a button that brings in the side-view mirrors when the car is driven down a narrow Tokyo street. And the German makers spent tens of millions of dollars building their own dealer networks, with prime locations in Japan's biggest cities.
But the American car makers say it does not pay to design cars for the Japanese market, at least until they sell more of them. "Obviously, we want to do better," Richard Johnson, who heads General Motors' operations here, said during the Tokyo Motor Show several months ago. "But only as we increase volume can we afford to develop cars for this market."
But the reality is that the American auto companies are probably less financially prepared to expand their market here than at any time in the last decade. With plants across America being closed and capital budgets cut deeply, General Motors is unlikely to open new plants in Japan and hire Japanese workers.
At the Tokyo Motor Show last fall, General Motors seemed to deepen its problems here: It did not show the Saturn, the innovative small car designed to take on the Japanese in the United States. To save money, G.M. decided to forgo a system that would allow Saturn's steering wheel to be moved to the right side. It will be another two years before the Saturn comes to Japan, by which time, notes Shoichiro Irimajiri, one of Honda's top executives, "it will be a very, very old design."

HEADLINE: Muslim Guards: Security Unit Maintaining Pride

BYLINE: By MARY B. W. TABOR

 BODY:
Silent and stonefaced, they stand in their crisp suits and bow ties in some of the nation's toughest neighborhoods and assemblages, their hands folded neatly, their eyes scanning for the slightest sign of disruption. More often than not, they work without pay. They carry no arms.
Still, the guards from the Nation of Islam, who have been called to clean up crack-infested streets and protect black politicians and celebrities, wield a weapon that often eludes the police in black neighborhoods: respect. 
 "They are more effective than police," said Spike Lee, the film director, who has used members of the Nation of Islam to guard his sets for movies, including "Do the Right Thing," "Jungle Fever" and "Malcolm X."
"The police and black people have never gotten along," he said, "and the community just has great respect for the Nation of Islam."
But not everyone shares that respect, saying that the group often crosses the line between intimidation and violence. And some other groups have cashed in on it, mimicking the guards' distinctive style of dress -- a phenomenon that has added to the widespread confusion about security at a basketball game at City College where nine young people were fatally crushed when a crowd got out of hand.
At that game, a small cadre of guards from an agency known as X-Men Security Inc. were among those hired. A common impression among survivors of the stampede was that the X-Men were from the Nation of Islam and some of the guards may have been.
 
Crushed to Death
 But at a news conference last week, Minister Conrad Muhammad, the New York representative of the Nation of Islam, said that while some of its members worked for private security companies, the Nation itself was "not involved" with security at City College on Dec. 28, when nine people were fatally crushed as a crowd surged forward to enter the college gymnasium for the game that featured a roster including rap stars. Eight of the victims died that day, and the ninth died days later in a hospital.
He then repeated a refrain that many black politicians have echoed with increasing fervor in recent years. "It is the Nation of Islam that could play a major role in preventing such tragedies," Mr. Muhammad said.
Area residents who watched the ambulances arrive at City College said the same thing on the night of the tragedy.
"In this community, the only ones people listen to are from the Nation of Islam," said a man who looked blankly into the frenetic scene at the gym. "They are the only ones people respect."
And the director of the City College security office, Charles Delaney, told City University officials on Friday that he had been pleased when he thought the student government group that organized the basketball game had arranged for 20 Black Muslim guards to buttress his own Pinkerton guards.
Since its founding in the early 1930's, the Nation of Islam has gained influence in the black community because of its aura of power, discipline, pride and commitment to economic self-help. Providing protection to the community and its leaders through its official security arm -- the Fruit of Islam -- has been a tradition as well.
Louis Farrakhan, a leader of the Black Muslim sect, gave the guards broader visibility when he provided a retinue for the Rev. Jesse Jackson's campaign for the 1984 Democratic Presidential nomination.
Usually the patrols are free. But as the Nation of Islam has been deluged with pleas for help with security from neighborhood, civic, tenant and religious organizations, it has also agreed to accept what its calls donations.
Through the years, students and journalists have complained of rough treatment by the guards, who frisk people and enforce strict access rules at news conferences, concerts and other events. Some even say they have been beaten.
But members of the Nation of Islam and those who hire them insist that there is an emphasis on avoiding violence.
"They don't make threats; they talk to people," Mr. Lee said. "They understand black people. They say: 'Look, brother; look, sister. You don't need to do that.' "
The New York City Police Department declines to evaluate the Fruit of Islam guards' performance. "That is not something we would comment on, especially in light of recent events," a police spokeswoman, Sgt. Tina Mohrmann, said.
The group's prestige within the black community has spurred others -- private security agencies and individuals alike -- to copy the suit-and-bow-tie look to help their own enterprises.
Dapper guards who function independently of the Nation can be found flanking people ranging from the Rev. Al Sharpton to Queen Latifah, the rap star. As a result, people often confuse the other private agencies, like the X-Men, with the official Fruit of Islam guard.
"Our reputation has transcended our organization," Mr. Muhammad said in an interview on Friday. "We have been in the community for more than 60 years and have earned a reputation. Others know if they look the part, they stand to benefit from that."
Others point out that using the Fruit of Islam for security when they are not a state-licensed security agency can present problems.
"Without the licensing, you don't know what you are getting, and there is less accountability," said Norman Siegel, the executive director of the New York Civil Liberties Union. "That is a fact that people should be concerned about with all private security agencies, including the Nation of Islam."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Minister Conrad Muhammad, the New York representative of the Nation of Islam, said at a news conference last week that while some members work for private security companies, the Nation itself was "not involved" with security at City College when nine people were fatally crushed. (Budd Williams for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Democrats Call Bush's Health Proposal Inadequate

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5

 BODY:
Two Democratic candidates for President today criticized health-care proposals being developed by the Bush Administration, saying they would not do enough to control health costs or to protect the millions of Americans who lack health insurance.
One of the Democrats, Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, asserted that the Administration did not have "the guts to go after the wasteful health-insurance system we've got, the wasteful health-care system we've got." 
 The other Democrat, Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska, said the Republicans' idea of using tax credits to help people buy health insurance was "not a step in the right direction" because it did nothing to slow the rise in health costs. He said health costs were "growing at a fantastic rate."
 
Record Health Costs
 The Commerce Department and the Department of Health and Human Services estimate that spending on health care will account for a record 14 percent of the gross national product in 1992. They estimate that such spending will reach $817 billion this year, up from an estimated total of $738 billion last year.
In his State of the Union Message in January 1990, President Bush said he was "committed to bring the staggering costs of health care under control." But since then health care prices have risen about twice as fast as the Consumer Price Index for all items.
Administration officials say that Mr. Bush, as part of his budget request to Congress later this month, is likely to recommend tax credits and other tax benefits to help individuals, families and small businesses buy health insurance. Insurers say that health insurance premiums reflect the price of health care and have risen rapidly in recent years, so that fewer and fewer businesses can afford such insurance. Thirty-four million Americans have no health insurance.
Mr. Bush is also expected to propose new restrictions on various Government benefits for the most affluent people, Administration officials say.
Governor Clinton said that in the absence of a comprehensive plan to control health costs, he would oppose Mr. Bush's proposal to increase Medicare premiums for high-income people. The Administration would "charge the elderly more for the same old health care," without making fundamental changes in the health-care system, Mr. Clinton said on the NBC News program "Meet the Press."
 
Issue in Campaign
 "If this were part of a comprehensive plan to really take care of the health-care problems of this country and control health-care costs and get control of the deficit, I'd be for it, but it isn't," said Mr. Clinton.
In a separate interview on the CNN program "Newsmaker Sunday," Senator Kerrey showed how he intends to highlight health care as an issue in the Presidential campaign.
"I am angry with our health-care structure," Mr. Kerrey said. "I'm taking on the insurance industry. I'm taking on the American Medical Association. I'm saying it is time for national health insurance to create eligibility as a consequence of being an American." He said he would "break the link between employment and eligibility for health care and simply say if you're an American, you have health care."
Some small-business groups responded favorably to the idea of tax credits and tax deductions for health insurance, saying they were an efficient way to reduce the number of uninsured.
Aaron Trippler, executive director of a nonpartisan research group, Health Care Solutions for America, said that nearly 10 million more people would buy health insurance if they could take tax deductions for the full amount they spend on premiums.
"Current tax policy allows corporations to deduct the entire cost of health insurance for their employees, while individuals purchasing their own insurance are not allowed any deduction at all," Mr. Trippler said. "The net cost of providing individuals the same tax deduction that corporations get would be about $8 billion a year. If President Bush and Congress are looking for a reform that can be implemented quickly and efficiently, this is the answer."
Samuel K. Skinner, the new White House chief of staff, echoing other Administration officials, indicated today that Mr. Bush was likely to propose further cuts in military spending.
"There probably is some opportunity to reorder, on a logical basis, the defense priorities," he said on the CBS News program "Face the Nation."
Mr. Skinner said the President remains firmly committed to the overall limits set in the 1990 budget agreement. He said that Mr. Bush might try to shift money from the Pentagon to other purposes, but would prefer not to renegotiate the whole budget agreement, as many in Congress now want to do.

HEADLINE: As Society's Need Increases, So Does Volunteerism

BYLINE: By J. PEDER ZANE

 BODY:
Moved and frightened by social problems that seem as persistent as they are public, increasing numbers of Americans are volunteering to work with the poor and the sick, charities and volunteer organizations report.
In New York, the Mayor's Voluntary Action Center said 11,000 people inquired about volunteer opportunities last year, up 28 percent from 1990. In Kansas City, the Heart of America United Way Volunteer Center saw a 16 percent increase in 1991. And the Volunteer Center of the Texas Gulf Coast in Houston said 24,000 people inquired last year about volunteering, a 20 percent increase over 1990. 
 Those reports indicate that the rise in volunteerism found by a 1990 Gallup Poll, the most recent survey done on the subject, has continued. That year, 54 percent of the 2,727 American adults surveyed said they had done some volunteer work. That was a sharp increase from the 1988 survey, in which 45 percent of those surveyed said they had volunteered.
In the process, experts say, the image and purpose of volunteerism is being transformed. Instead of primarily being retirees providing supplementary services -- the "gray ladies" who push book carts through hospitals -- volunteers are now more likely to be people of any age performing direct and essential tasks: nursing AIDS babies, teaching illiterate adults to read or taking on the responsibilities of being a mentor to a juvenile offender.
The new breed of volunteers includes people like Dana Silver-Kathe, a 30-year-old costume designer from Tustin, Calif., who rises at dawn to help feed 200 homeless people; Gene Edwards, a 26-year-old hotel food-service manager who talks late into the night with people who call the Dallas Suicide Crisis Center; and Eveline M. Turner of the Bronx, a 67-year-old retired stenographer who hugs, talks and sings to babies whose parents have abandoned them at Lincoln Hospital in the Bronx.
"In the 60's people tried to make a better world through political change, outside the system," said Carol Stone, president and chief executive officer of the Volunteer Center of Greater Orange County in California. "Now they are working within the system and working hands-on, one-on-one with the people who need help."
 
Recession Is a Factor
 The heads of agencies that work with volunteers said that some of the recent increase can be attributed to the recession, which has led many newly unemployed people to offer their services while others who have been forced to reduce their monetary contributions have decided to give their time instead. And they credit the publicity surrounding President Bush's "Thousand Points of Lights" campaign.
But they said its deeper cause is the continued local, state and Federal budget cuts that began in the 1980's and reduced financing for many social programs, even as problems like homelessness, AIDS and child abuse were becoming more widespread. The cuts have forced many agencies to rely on volunteers to staff and even run some of their programs. Together, the result was an increase in both the supply of volunteers and the demand for them.
"Everywhere we looked, from our televisions to our streets, we saw people in need," said Janet Harrison of the Volunteer Center of Los Angeles. "With the recession, people feel especially vulnerable, that they're not so different from these people and they want to do something to help."
Walter Richard Black, recruitment director for the Volunteer Center of the Texas Gulf Coast in Houston, said that in the past two years the number of nonprofit agencies seeking volunteers from his agency has increased from 400 to 520. Richard Reid, executive director of the Volunteer Center of Northwest Chicago, said last year his group placed volunteers in 140 agencies, a increase of 40 percent over 1990.
Another change prompting the rise in volunteers, he said, is the new sense of openness about subjects that once had been taboo. "Just this year an agency was set up to help incest survivors," Mr. Reid said. "A few years ago society wouldn't even admit that went on. Now it's on Oprah and Donahue. People recognize a problem, see the need for a solution and try to help."
 
An Aggressive Search
 Agencies have not waited by the phone for an newly sensitive and enlightened public to call. They have attracted volunteers through an aggressive and sophisticated use of the news media, direct-mail techniques and television.
In June, the Points of Light Foundation began broadcasting public service announcements on network and local stations that provided an "800" number viewers could call to reach volunteer organizations in their towns. So far, 25,000 have called, said Barbara Lohman, a spokeswoman for the Washington nonprofit group that has public and private financing.
"Few people just volunteer -- they have to be asked," said Patricia Cundiff, director of the Heart of America United Way in Kansas City, Mo. "In this day and age, the way people are asked is through a newspaper articles, public service announcements and even made-for-TV movies. Every time one of those is on, our phone rings off the hook."
Organizations have also recruited volunteers by nurturing relationships with schools, many of which have community-service requirements for graduation, and corporations. Ms. Stone said that 12 years ago her volunteer center in Orange County was helping one company run a volunteer program. Now, it is helping 160.
The Corporate Volunteers of New York, a coalition of businesses that run volunteer programs in New York City, reported that the number of companies involved has increased 40 percent, from 35 companies to 49, in the last three years.
 
Young and Employed
 The role of businesses in encouraging people to volunteer has helped attract two groups that have not traditionally volunteered: the young and the employed. Mr. Black of the Texas Gulf Coast volunteer center said that in 1986, 48.9 percent of his volunteers said they were employed outside the home; last year, 60 percent did. During that same period the percentage of people who identified themselves as homemakers fell to 4 percent from 21 percent. "This is very encouraging because it means many people, especially women, are finding time to volunteer despite the added responsibilities of a job," Mr. Black said.
Young professionals have been attracted by programs at work and by organizations like New York Cares, which was founded in 1987 to recruit younger volunteers who want to work directly with people in need.
"We have been besieged with volunteers," said Kenneth Adams, the group's executive director. "The number of people who have become involved in projects is twice as much as it was last year."
The organization, which has 8,000 members, most of them between 25 and 35 years old, has served as a model for similar groups in 10 other cities, Mr. Adams said.
"Young professionals thought volunteering was something blue-haired ladies in candy-striped suits did," he said. "And a lot of traditional groups never reached to them because they thought they weren't interested. I think the desire has always been there but now groups like ours are providing the opportunities."
The volunteers help homeless children learn how to read, visit children dying of AIDS, rehabilitate abandoned buildings and feed the homeless, Mr. Adams said.
Kate Sanderson, a 33-year-old staff manager at New York Telephone, said she volunteered in October to serve as a big sister for a 12-year-old girl from the South Bronx because "I got tired of reading about problems; I wanted to do something about them."
"I thought my main role would be helping her with her school work," Ms. Sanderson said. "I've found that what she really needed was someone to give her respect, to listen to her. Like a lot of people, she needed a friend."

HEADLINE: Russians Urged to Act Fast

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 5

 BODY:
Leading American economists are advising Russia and the other former Soviet republics to move more swiftly than Eastern Europe has in tackling economic changes, especially as they attempt to sell off 45,000 state-owned factories to private owners. They are also recommending that the United States and international agencies help to finance the changes, at least for a while.
"Privatization in Eastern Europe has been a debacle," Jeffrey Sachs, a professor at Harvard University, said at the three-day annual meeting of the American Economics Association here, which concluded today. The topic of economic reform and aid to former Communist nations overshadowed discussions about the sluggish economy in the United States. 
 "This is one area where Russia can learn from Eastern Europe's mistake," said Mr. Sachs, who is an adviser to the Governments of Russia and Poland. "Every Eastern European country has failed, and failed significantly, to find new owners for state-owned enterprises." Trying to sell off one enterprise at a time, as in Britain or Mexico, has proved "achingly slow and completely unrealistic."
 
A Cold War Relief Effort
 The economists favored Western aid to help maintain living standards in the transition to a market economy.
"The cold war is the third war to end this century, " said Lawrence H. Summers, chief economist of the World Bank. "After World War I, major nations looked inward and there was no serious effort to reintegrate the vanquished powers into the world economy. After World War II, the opposite happened. The question now is which pattern is going to followed."
Few Westerners can appreciate the daunting scale or enormous difficulties of an undertaking that makes Britain's large-scale privatizations in the 1980's seem trivial by comparison. Britain took seven years to sell off 43 state-run companies; Poland has 3,000 such concerns and the former Soviet republics have nearly six times that many. The question now is how to privatize efficiently and equitably in countries with no stock or bond markets, no private banks and no accounting systems.
Despite the enormous political and economic dangers, the economists were surprisingly optimistic about the long-term economic prospects if the changes are carried out successfully.
"These are not economic basket cases," said Stanley Fisher, an economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and former chief economist at the World Bank. "Russia has the potential to be a powerful economy in 10 years with a strong trade balance."
The economists see rapid privatization as critical in establishing ownership control over enterprises now operating in a vacuum. Without privatization, the lifting of price controls is not likely to stimulate a broad industrial recovery, skilled workers might emigrate and much of the industrial base could be looted.
 
'A Race Against Time'
 "You really have a race against time," Mr. Sachs said. "Russia could very quickly find itself in a profound industrial crisis. Right now, there are no proper incentives anywhere in the economy, and it is a very, very dangerous situation."
Furthermore, if privatization is postponed, money-losing enterprises would continue to swell the huge Russian Government deficit. That deficit, already 25 percent of the gross national product, is the main reason for the current inflation.
"On most countries, I tend to be a gradualist -- but not Russia," said Mr. Fisher, a specialist on macroeconomic stabilization who was a key adviser to the Israeli Government in its battle against hyperinflation in the mid-1980's.
To get thousands of companies transferred to new owners, Mr. Sachs advocated that Moscow, in addition to giving away 25 percent stakes in publicly run companies to workers and managers, turn enterprises into private corporations quickly; permit workers, managers and local authorities to appoint the directors, and allow those boards to distribute more stock, perhaps giving majority control of the company to private hands.
The boards could swap shares for debt held by banks, trade shares with other enterprises or sell more shares to workers and managers. Thus, the privatization would proceed in a decentralized fashion.
Mr. Sachs also wants Moscow to set up pension funds and mutual funds that could buy shares and monitor the performance of the companies. A key advantage of the plan would be that some positive effects could be felt before the transfer of ownership from the Russian Treasury to the private sectors was completed. "You don't have to have 100 percent private ownership before enterprise can operate like private entities," said Mr. Summers, who endorsed much of Mr. Sachs's plan.
Mr. Summers added that implementing the plan would be more complicated than Mr. Sachs had suggested. Many money-losing enterprises have more debts than assets, for example, so even giving them away would not compensate their new owners for the cost of shutting them down.
 
Points of Agreement
 "It's a mistake," Mr. Summers added, "to overstate the effectiveness of newly created boards and mutual funds in providing oversight for the enterprises."
Still, the economists agreed on several points. To begin with, advice that argues in favor of restructuring before selling off enterprises is wrongheaded. "To believe that the Russian state, which cannot stop the money presses, could restructure thousands of companies is far-fetched," Mr. Summers said. The grossest error is to argue that an enterprise cannot be privatized if it is highly unprofitable.
Another key lesson from the privatization of Eastern Europe is that insiders, namely workers and managers, must be given their due. Comparing workers and managers in state-owned firms to rent-control tenants who get discounts during co-op conversions as the price of their support, Mr. Sachs said: "Ironically, free-market reformers in Eastern Europe have fought very hard against shares going to workers on a discounted basis. As a result, they are bereft of political allies."
Finally, shares must be salable, to give workers and managers an incentive to increase the value of a company as well as to create a secondary market for shares. "The fact that these stakes could be sold would be an incentive to maximize their value," Mr. Sachs said.
The second half of privatization, Mr. Summers stressed, would be to encourage new, small business by removing economic and legal obstacles.

GRAPHIC: Photo: "Privatization in Eastern Europe has been a debacle," said Prof. Jeffrey Sachs of Harvard University at a three-day annual meeting of the American Economics Association in New Orleans. Also at the meeting were Stanley Fischer of M.I.T., left, and Lawrence H. Summers of the World Bank. (Matt Anderson for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Tax Breaks Proposed for U.S. Autos

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5

 BODY:
Tax incentives for Americans who buy domestically made cars could help stimulate sales and save "a dying industry" in Detroit, a research organization has proposed.
Calling on the Government to intervene as an advocate for the Big Three auto makers, a report by the Economic Strategy Institute advocates diverting some money from military research and development into a low-interest loan for a cooperative research and development project. The report suggested that the project be sponsored by the auto makers. 
 The institute, a Washington-based group that conducts research on trade issues, is partly financed by the Chrysler Corporation and the Ford Motor Company. But the group's president, Clyde Prestowitz, said its report on the auto industry was not directly paid for by the auto makers.
The report comes as political and industry leaders are calling for the Government to intervene in the declining fortunes of the United States automobile industry.
Proposals for action by the Government include a personal income tax deduction for one year to consumers who buy American-made cars from the Big Three auto makers; negotiations with the Japanese Government to create projects to encourage American exports to the Japanese market, and requirements that Japanese plants operating in the United States, known as transplants, increase the amount of American labor and materials they use.
The report estimates that the plan would cost the Federal Government $22 billion over five years, including the income tax credit for purchases of domestic cars in 1992, an investment tax credit that would be available for five years to businesses that buy fleets of domestic cars, and a $10 billion loan for auto industry research and development.
The report said the spending would be offset by $24 billion in tax revenues generated by the Big Three's increased domestic share of the auto market and higher sales of domestic materials to the American factories operated by Japanese companies.
Gary C. Hufbauer, a visiting fellow at the Institute for International Economics in Washington and a free-trade advocate, called the report's proposals "a mixture of reasonable and outrageous." He said in an interview that a tax break for domestic automobile purchases would encourage consumption instead of investment and would represent a misspending of scarce tax money.
He disagreed with the report's warnings that the Japanese factories in the United States spell the demise of the domestic auto industry.
"Transplants," he said, "have been galvanizing the industry and providing jobs."

HEADLINE: Albany Legislators Face Tough Session With Combustible Mix

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 5

 BODY:
Although it never really seemed to leave town, the State Legislature returns to Albany this week to convene a session that many participants predict will be the most difficult in recent memory because of an uncommonly combustible mixture of political ingredients.
Not that the last few sessions have been love fests: the Legislature and Gov. Mario M. Cuomo set consecutive records for budget tardiness in each of the last two years, which also brought the downgrading of the state's credit rating in 1990. 
 But this year the increasingly polarized debate over how best to protect the state from the ravages of recession will be complicated by a host of new variables that include redistricting, election-year posturing, a leadership change in the Democratic-led Assembly and a political makeover in the Republican-controlled State Senate.
The lawmakers will arrive in Albany for Mr. Cuomo's 10th State of the State address on Wednesday following a monthlong special session that failed to produce an agreement on closing the state's twin budget gaps -- $875 million in this year's $30 billion budget and nearly $4 billion in the fiscal year that begins on April 1.
As a trial run for this year's session, the December negotiations served only to highlight the deep political and ideological divisions that have paralyzed the budget-making process here during a brutally deepening recession.
The conflict between the Democrats who control both the Assembly and the executive branch and the Republicans who control the Senate has corroded even the fleeting good will that usually attends a legislative session's opening. Dampened by Mr. Cuomo's decision not to run for President, the mood inside the Capitol's stone walls has been as gray as the weather outside.
"It's going to be one of the most bitter and exasperating sessions of my lifetime," said Edwin L. Crawford, executive director of the New York State Association of Counties. "If the gap is what the Governor says it is, and it's probably going to be larger, I can't imagine what torture is going to be involved in getting that thing resolved."
The main factor fueling such dire projections has been the decision by the Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino, Republican of Oyster Bay, L.I., to take a more muscular stance after three years of relative conciliation with the Democrats.
Threatened from the right by a rejuvenated conservative anti-tax movement, scared by the anti-incumbency sentiment registered by voters last November and encouraged by the new acceptability of welfare-bashing, the Republicans are finding it increasingly comfortable to play the role of the official opposition.
"I think you can expect a very aggressive Senate trying to impose its view on the entire legislative process," Mr. Marino said last Friday.
On the other side of the Capitol's third floor, a newly elected Assembly Speaker, Saul Weprin of Queens, has taken over after last month's conviction of Mel Miller on Federal fraud charges. The affable Mr. Weprin faces the challenge of making his own mark while holding together a diverse and fragile Democratic coalition that had been fused largely by Mr. Miller's forceful personality.
 
To Fill Leadership Posts
 Mr. Weprin's savvy will be tested quickly this week when he announces his choices for four or five leadership positions, including the powerful Ways and Means Committee chairmanship that he had held. He also must field candidates for special elections in January and February to fill six vacant Assembly seats, four of them in highly competitive districts.
In November, all 211 legislative seats will be up for grabs, meaning that action and compromise in the session may often be displaced by positioning and oratory. If the anxiety level is not already high enough, all legislators will be consumed with the distraction of a redistricting process that could change their constituencies almost overnight.
"People who thought they were safe will find themselves in marginal districts," Mr. Weprin said. "It's going to make everybody wary."
Then there is Mr. Cuomo. Freed of the political burdens of running for re-election or for President, the Governor has already threatened to hold the Legislature politically accountable for its actions and has made it clear that he will use his veto power over reapportionment as leverage.
Mr. Cuomo, whose third term does not expire until 1994, is also expected to recycle a tactic he used masterfully in 1987 by waging an all-out campaign for reforms in laws on legislative ethics, campaign finance, ballot access, open government, budget making and legislative initiative.
He plans to reinforce his call for a constitutional convention to be held in 1995 to carry out such changes. Such a session would require a legislative vote this spring enabling a public referendum in November.
If Mr. Cuomo follows past practice, the Legislature will be cast as the heathen foe of this crusade. That could deepen the tensions created by a budget impasse that Mr. Cuomo blamed for blocking his Presidential candidacy.
 
'To Push All the Buttons'
 "Now that he's not running for office and we are, he's going to push all the buttons that make us uncomfortable," said one legislative aide. "He's going to be Mr. Outside, Mr. Reform, Mr. Anti-incumbent who gets the Legislature for whatever he perceives we did. It will be payback time."
Mr. Cuomo has denied being motivated by vengefulness. But the gathering storm over legislative ethics and fiscal reform is only one of the battles that may widen the fault lines between him and the Legislature.
His most pressing concern is the state's credit rating, already the third lowest of all states, ahead of only Massachusetts and Louisiana.
He has accused the Senate Republicans of ignoring warnings from Wall Street rating agencies that the state's credit could be downgraded at any moment if the budget impasse is not broken. But the Republicans have been holding out for deep cuts in Medicaid and welfare programs.
If state officials are successful in wringing more than $1 billion in savings from Medicaid and welfare programs, attention will turn to Mr. Cuomo's proposal for the state to assume the share of Medicaid costs paid by local governments. That measure eventually would provide significant financial relief to New York City and other local governments.
 
Other Pressing Issues
 While Medicaid is the primary issue on the fiscal agenda, it is not the only one. The Legislature must consider how to finance a $10.5 billion request by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority for a new five-year capital plan to improve commuter rail and subway service. It must deal with a growing prison population that requires 6,000 new beds. And it must consider delays in opening community mental health and drug treatment programs it has already spent money to create.
As is often the case when budgets are being cut, such fiscal troubles raise the prospect that the state, in its desperation to save cash, will make penny-wise and pound-foolish decisions that generate added costs down the road.
In past years, Mr. Cuomo has used his State of the State speech to unveil ambitious proposals with big price tags. But this year, as last, the speech is expected to concentrate on low-cost initiatives, including the Governor's reform proposals and a series of economic development projects that would be jump-started with money and loan guarantees from the state and its public authorities.
"Right now, I wouldn't want to have to find a centerpiece," one Cuomo aide said late last week. "I'd be in real trouble if someone gave me a million dollars to find one."

HEADLINE: GARRISON JOURNAL;
At the Fish Library, a Chronicle of Death and Taxes

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GARRISON, N.Y., Jan. 3

 BODY:
When Alice Curtis Desmond died in 1990 leaving an $18 million estate and no heirs, the trustees of the library she founded and liberally supported in the decade before her death anticipated a settled future. So did her lawyer and her nurse.
But when the will was read, the trustees and many of the 6,500 residents in this bucolic Hudson River estate town were dismayed to learn that the millions the 93-year-old banking heiress had left to the library would be all but eaten up in paying taxes on the $2 million apiece she left to the nurse and lawyer. 
 By making those two bequests tax-free, Mrs. Desmond had effectively disinherited the community library she founded with her ex-husband, a four-term Congressman, Hamilton Fish Sr., using $2.8 million of the money she inherited from her parents and her first husband, Thomas C. Desmond, a former New York State Senator and financier to whom she was married for 49 years.
The library, a two-story Georgian structure, contains exhibits that reflect the unusual political and economic contributions both the Fish and Desmond families have made to the Hudson Valley region, including rooms devoted to the Fish family papers and first editions of Mrs. Desmond's 22 published books, primarily biographies and children's books. Mr. Fish died last year at the age of 102.
The library received the remainder of Mrs. Desmond's estate after a number of other bequests, but since Mrs. Desmond's gifts to her lawyer and her nurse and a $250,000 gift to her doctor were tax-free, the taxes on those gifts had to be paid by the estate. The estate was also liable for an estimated $5.7 million capital gains tax. The tax exemption provision doubled the size of the employee bequests and eliminated the money left in trust for the library.
This conflict of death and taxes inexorably led to court. The library trustees sued, contending that Mrs. Desmond's lawyer of 18 years, D. Clinton Dominick, who became her guardian, financial adviser, director of her personal holding company, a trustee of the library and the draftsman of her will, had unduly influenced her. They also said her nurse, Barbara Suchy, who handled all Mrs. Desmond's correspondence in her final years, had also exerted undue influence and isolated her from library board members and friends.
Her lawyer insists that Mrs. Desmond was a feisty and self-willed woman shaken by her unhappy relationship with Hamilton Fish and determined to keep her money from supporting Fish family endeavors. "But for Ham's marrying wealth, the idea for the library would not have become a reality," Mr. Dominick said in a statement to the court. "But for Ham's shabby treatment of Alice, her enthusiasm for the library might not have waned."
In a fitting climax to this melodrama, a judge issued his ruling in an unusual New Year's Eve session. Judge Joseph G. Owen of Orange County Surrogate Court ordered the lawyer and the nurse to pay their own estate taxes, restoring approximately $2 million dollars to the library. The judge also revoked Mr. Dominick's trusteeship and gave an additional $2.5 million in recent income to the estate be paid to the library.
"It's quite clear Mrs. Desmond didn't have a clue as to the effect this tax exoneration clause would have on the library," said Michael F. Teitler, a partner at Teitler & Teitler, the Manhattan law firm representing the library. "The judge didn't throw stones at anybody," Mr. Teitler. "He just looked at the record."
The parties in the dispute have 30 days to appeal the order, but only until Friday to file their estate tax returns with the Internal Revenue Service. If they do, his client will be satisfied, Mr. Teitler said, adding that "$4.5 million is well within the library's objectives."
Mr. Dominick refused to comment on specifics of the case, which he described as a "delicate matter." Ms. Suchy was unavailable for comment.
The library trustees were relieved. "We certainly knew her intent," said Patricia Adams, chairwoman of the library's executive committee. "This was a woman without any real heirs. The library was her baby."
In her last book, an autobiography titled "Yankees and Yorkers" published in 1985, Mrs. Desmond concluded: "I hope eventually to make the Alice and Hamilton Fish Library one of the finest public libraries in New York State, specializing in the history of the Hudson River Valley. I will die, but my library will live on."

HEADLINE: Market Place;
At Dollar General, What Recession?

BYLINE: By EBEN SHAPIRO

 BODY:
The recession has not brought hard times to all retailers. The Dollar General Corporation, which sells inexpensive necessities like toothpaste, bleach and paper towels to low-income consumers, is growing at a pace that is the envy of merchants with more affluent customers.
Last week, it reported "the best Christmas selling season in the history of the company," said Cal Turner Jr., the chairman and grandson of the Tennessee tobacco farmer who founded the company 52 years ago. Sales at stores open more than a year are up 10 percent through December. Last month, sales roared ahead 25.2 percent. 
 Analysts expect the planned opening of 100 new stores a year to lift the company's sales by about 13 percent this year. Net income is expected to grow by 20 percent.
 
A Rise in the Minimum Wage
 While purveyors of yachts, diamonds and fur coats complain that a luxury tax has hurt sales, Dollar General is focusing on the impact of a different federally mandated change. Many Dollar General shoppers earn rock-bottom wages, and the increase last spring in the minimum wage created a windfall for the company. "We believe our customers spent a good portion of that increase in our stores," said Bruce A. Quinnell, the chief financial officer of the Nashville-based company.
With 1,500 stores in 23 states, concentrated in the Southeast and parts of the Midwest, Dollar General is one of the few large chains to focus expressly on serving low-income people. "Dollar General has become one of the smartest retailers in how to provide retail services to people of modest incomes," said George Rosenbaum, chief executive of Leo J. Shapiro & Associates, a Chicago research firm. "It's a tough but underdeveloped market."
"I call it bottom-of-the-barrel retailing," said J. Gary Dennis, an analyst with J. C. Bradford & Company, a Nashville brokerage firm. "When the people that shop at Dollar General shop at Wal-Mart, that's kind of the top of the ladder for them."
Dollar General has prospered by using its intimate knowledge of the needs of its customers, about 80 percent of whom have incomes of less than $25,000 a year.
Credit cards are not accepted; most customers do not have them. Few even have checking accounts, Mr. Quinnell said. "They can't afford to pay the fees," he said.
What Dollar General customers want is low prices. As a result, the company's stores stock 1,500 items that cost $1 or less. In fact, for years, the stores sold only items that cost $1 or less.
"That's the best price point that the good Lord ever made -- $1," Mr. Turner said.
Now, knit shirts cost $5. Rustler blue jeans are $9. A $25 dollar pair of work boots is the most expensive item in stock. Work gloves are 75 cents.
 
The Basics for Less
 The stores do not stock large sizes of shampoo or multiple packs of razor blades. While bigger packages are usually cheaper in the long run, they cost more up front than many people are able to pay.
Paper towels, at two rolls for $1, are the company's top-selling product. Pine cleaner, at two bottles for $1 dollar, and motor oil, a can for 75 cents, are other big sellers.
The company has clearly benefited from the recession and a shift in values that is making mainstream shoppers more bargain-conscious and spurring sales at big discounters like Wal-Mart Stores Inc. and the K Mart Corporation. But Mr. Quinnell said Dollar General customers are bargain shoppers out of necessity, not choice.
To keep prices low, about 25 percent of the company's merchandise is seconds or is bought at close-out.
 
Sites in Small Towns
 The company also holds expenses to a minimum. When asked the average amount customers spend on each visit to Dollar General, a statistic most retailers can recite in their sleep, Mr. Quinnell dismissed the question. "That's a statistic that costs money to accumulate and has no value to us, so we don't spend the money to get it," he said.
Most of Dollar General's no-frills stores are in towns with less than 25,000 inhabitants. By opening about 100 stores a year, Dollar General plans to add 1,000 stores by the end of the decade. Net income is expected to grow 20 percent.
In geography and customer base, the company has much in common with Wal-Mart, a dangerous position for a retailer, given Wal-Mart's tendency to devour market share at the expense of weaker competitors. But even though both companies sell inexpensive merchandise, and have many customers in small towns, analysts say the companies have a different focus.
Thomas Tashjian, a retail analyst with the First Manhattan Company, said, "I don't think Wal-Mart is all that concerned about them." People drive long distances to stock up at a Wal-Mart, he said, but Dollar General shoppers may dart into the store to buy a tube of toothpaste.
Many Wal-Mart stores have more than 100,000 square feet of space and carry a wide range of products. A Dollar General store has an average of 5,600 square feet and carries only 5,000 items. "He's a mass marketer," Mr. Turner said of Sam Walton, Wal-Mart's founder, "we're a focused bargain store." Wal-Mart executives declined to comment on Dollar General.
"We perform very well in the shadow of Wal-Mart," Mr. Quinnell said. In fact, the company has moved dozens of stores closer to Wal-Mart's in recent years, after finding that sales suffered if Dollar General stores were more than a mile away from a Wal-Mart. By Mr. Turner's calculations, Dollar General's sales per square foot exceed those of neighboring Wal-Mart stores.
In the fiscal year that ended in January 1991, Dollar General earned $14.6 million, or 80 cents a share, on sales of $653 million.
 
Interest From Wall Street
 The company's growth has caught the attention of Wall Street. The stock closed Friday at $24.75, up 50 cents a share and up from a 52-week low of $7.625, in over-the-counter trading.
Analysts are divided on how the company's stock could still rise. In a recent report, Alice A. Ruth, an analyst with Montgomery Securities in San Francisco, said Dollar General stock should reach $25 to $27 in the next nine months.
But Wayne Hood of Prudential Securities said: "They have had their run for the year. It's fully priced."
Dollar General stumbled badly in the mid-1980's, when it went on an acquisition spree, increasing the number of stores to 1,300, from 800, in 15 months. A weak management team bungled the rapid expansion, and earnings plunged in 1986. "We weren't executing well on the basics," Mr. Turner said.
The company has been rebuilding since 1987. After a bitter family feud, Mr. Turner's brother, Steve, the president, left the company in 1988. Professional managers were brought in, and the company has improved its buying and focused on lowering distribution costs, closing one warehouse and automating others.
With traditional retailers facing poor sales and fierce competition, Mr. Rosenbaum, the Chicago market researcher, thinks more and more merchants may examine the market for low-income customers. "Here is a large population where service is underdeveloped," he said. "This certainly is an alternative that has to be considered."

HEADLINE: METRO MATTERS;
Breaking Welfare Dependency for Young Mothers

BYLINE: By Sam Roberts

 BODY:
WHEN Padora Vincent gave birth as a teen-ager three years ago, she personified a growing national problem. Today, she may exemplify one possible solution.
The Census Bureau reported last month that more and more new mothers, teen-agers in particular, are unwed. Among blacks, 9 of 10 teen-agers who had babies in 1990 were unmarried -- the highest rate of any major ethnic or racial group. Regardless of whether the social stigma of premarital pregnancy has declined, teen-age motherhood typically bodes badly for the children. Many grow up poor. Some get another chance later in life. Their mothers often don't. 
 Ms. Vincent, who lives in Harlem with her 3-year-old daughter, is enrolled in an experimental program designed by the nonprofit Manpower Demonstration Research Corporation. It is intended to help young mothers on welfare, most of them high school dropouts with one or two children.
The program is called New Chance. Its goals are ambitious: to advance educational, vocational and parenting skills, prepare participants for jobs with career opportunities, reduce welfare dependency, delay further childbearing and promote self-sufficiency. It is being tested at 16 sites, including Harlem and the South Bronx, in 10 states.
"I feel like this is a second chance for me," said Ms. Vincent, who joined the Harlem program last January, took her general equivalency diploma exam last month and hopes to find a job "helping people."
What distinguishes New Chance from many such programs is that regular attendance is required in its high school equivalency diploma classes, most services for mothers and their children are delivered at a single site, participants may receive those services for up to 18 months and 12 months of follow-up services are available.
Financed largely through state and local welfare and job training agencies and monitored with private grants, the program is expensive. It costs from $5,500 to $9,500 for each participant, including child care. But this does not take into consideration the public assistance the women and children would have received anyway or the cumulative costs of not having provided a new chance. Given new national welfare mandates, which define ends with greater confidence than they do means, the first progress report by the Manpower Demonstration Research Corporation seems promising.
"We have a consistent message: That you can succeed and we expect you to succeed," said Evette Williams, who runs the New Chance program at the New York City Board of Education's Mid-Manhattan Adult Learning Center on West 120th Street. Only about 1 in 10 of the participants was raised as a teen-ager by both parents. On average, the women were 17 years old when they had their first child.
Another New Chance model is run by the National Puerto Rican Forum in the South Bronx. Others are operating in, among other places, Pennsylvania, California, Florida and Illinois. Still another was started in Carle Place, L.I., but was closed because of financing, recruiting and other problems.
One problem common to many participants has been their lack of self-esteem. A New York City case manager said many of the women were "quite confident about their ability to handle themselves in the sometimes dangerous streets of the city's poverty areas; what creates anxiety for them is a plush Fifth Avenue office," where they might someday work.
Shawn McCalla, who is 22 years old and lives in Harlem with her 20-month-old son, enrolled last spring, earned her diploma in three months and plans to enter City College next month to study child psychology. "I know for sure I can do it," she said. "If it wasn't for New Chance, I never would have realized the opportunity I could have."
Rose Wallace, who adapted the New Chance model to the Mid-Manhattan Adult Learning Center, where she is now assistant principal, said the program's goal is to "take young people and move them from public assistance -- the crutch that they've been using -- to economic independence."
New Chance is not geared for everyone. Moreover, it may be difficult to replicate for groups bigger than the 100 or so initially served at each site. And, while New Chance is costly, an investment of that magnitude may prove to be required and even prudent.
"It has had a lasting impact just in terms of what some of our students have achieved," Mrs. Wallace said. "One got her G.E.D., learned typing and worked in our data center. She received a $1,000 scholarship and was accepted at City College. We have one at LaGuardia and another at Bronx Community College, some working, and one who completed a licensed practical nursing program.
"That," she said, "has to be considered long-term success."
Last Monday's Metro Matters column reported on Unity Park, a project of the New York City Outward Bound Center branch at South Bronx High School, and the despair of some students after one of three ash saplings they had planted was felled by vandals. Through Bronx Green-up, a program of the New York Botanical Garden, Planters Choice nursery in Newtown, Conn., donated a replacement so that three ashes can rise, like a phoenix, from the South Bronx.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Rise in Long-Term Rates Expected

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
The winter is usually a bad time for the bond market, with interest rates tending to rise, and some analysts expect this year to be no exception, even with the weak economy and low inflation.
"January and February has always been a tough time for the bond market," said James Kochan, fixed-income strategist for R. W. Baird & Company in Milwaukee. "I think between now and the quarterly refunding auctions in February, there will be a bit of a back-up in long-term interest rates, even though the fundamentals look very good." 
 Mitchell Held, chief financial economist at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company, said, "Rates are not going to rise significantly and are not going to stay up, but we think there is an upward bias to long-term rates for the first three months to six months of the year."
 
War-Related Pattern
 Early last year, bond yields rose along with tensions in the Middle East in January, fell sharply on the sudden success against Iraq in the fighting in early February, but turned higher again when it seemed likely that a quick victory would be followed by economic recovery.
This winter, Washington is on the market's mind. The fears that rose in November about what Congress and the Administration might do to stimulate the economy are coming back and are unlikely to abate until after the clear outline of a recovery package has been sketched.
"I can't see the market improving significantly until the questions in Washington are resolved," said Donald J. Fine, chief market analyst at the Chase Manhattan Corporation. "And it could be February or March before that happens."
 
Large Supply of Debt
 In addition, market participants will probably be forced to cope with a very large supply of new debt securities.
The Treasury is the largest. But the drop in rates in the last month has been big enough for states, municipalities and corporations to saturate the taxable and tax-exempt markets with billions of dollars in new issues.
This week, for example, the Treasury will sell $9.5 billion worth of new seven-year notes in addition to auctions of three-month, six-month and one-year bills. The municipal bond calendar is topped by the expected sale of $775 million worth of securities for the New Jersey Turnpike Authority. And in the corporate bond market, the World Bank has announced it will sell $1.5 billion worth of new 10-year securities. Investment bankers said other taxable issues were also likely to be priced.
"I don't think the market has really focused on the fact that there is a lot of supply," Mr. Held of Smith Barney said.
After rallying sharply for much of December, bond yields gave back a bit of ground last week, and by Friday stood at 7.47 percent on the 30-year Treasury bond.
 
Limited Upside
 The likelihood that news on inflation and the economy will remain favorable to the bond market means that any rise in long-term rates from current levels will be limited, analysts said.
Richard Berner, an economist at Salomon Brothers, said his firm projected that bond yields would ultimately fall to 7 percent, and that any backup in rates now should be viewed as a buying opportunity.
Mr. Kochan of R. W. Baird agreed: "If bond yields got back to around 7.60 percent, the market would look quite attractive," he said.
Fresh statistical evidence of just how weak conditions were as 1991 ended is likely to be provided this week, economists said.
Two key reports are expected Thursday and Friday, when the Government is scheduled to release producer-price and employment data for December.
Because of a sharp drop in energy prices, many analysts are projecting that producer prices actually declined during December, after a gain of two-tenths of 1 percent in November. But excluding food and energy prices, wholesale prices probably rose by one-tenth of 1 percent, analysts said.
 
Jobless Outlook
 Nobody is projecting the employment report will register as stunning a decline in non-farm payrolls as the 241,000 drop recorded for November. But analysts are looking for another drop, one that probably will be accompanied by a rise in the unemployment rate, currently at 6.8 percent.
Economists at the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company are forecasting that non-farm payroll employment fell by 90,000 last month.
The labor report, in conjunction with recent auto sales numbers and the slide in manufacturing activity suggested by the big drop in the Decmeber survey of purchasing managers, should reinforce the notion that the economy is in the second leg of a recession and not in a sluggish recovery.
"Currently, declines in demand and employment seem self-perpetuating," James F. O'Sullivan, a Morgan economist, wrote in the bank's weekly letter to clients, "making it highly unlikely that the slump in the economy will be limited to just one or two months."

HEADLINE: Bills and Notes This Week

 BODY:
The tentative schedule of Treasury financings this week includes the regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills today, followed on Wednesday by an auction of new seven-year notes. On Thursday, the Treasury plans to auction new one-year bills.
By late in the day on Friday, the outstanding three-month bill was bid at 3.85 percent and the six-month bill was bid at 3.88 percent; the one-year was at 3.94 percent. In when-issued trading -- between when a new security is announced and the time it is issued -- the seven-year note was offered at a price to yield 6.49 percent. 
 Among Government agency securities expected for pricing this week is a $500 million financing due today by the Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae. The securities are short-term floating-rate notes that mature on July 9, 1992.
Sallie Mae said the notes would be priced at a spread to the bond equivalent rate of the 91-day Treasury bill with the interest rate adjusted the day after each weekly bill auction.
Also, the Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, said it planned to price tomorrow a $1.3 billion debt offering.

HEADLINE: BATTERED INDUSTRIES
Picking Up the Pieces in Six Struggling Business Sectors;
Automobiles: What Detroit Car Makers Can Do While Waiting for the Recovery

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN

 BODY:
The huge cutbacks announced by the General Motors Corporation just before Christmas capped what had already been a grim year for the American auto makers, and 1992 does not look much brighter.
After layoffs, plant closings and other cost-cutting steps, most industry executives say they can do little now but wait for a stronger economy. Their 1992 models are already in production, and 1993 models are set as well. The hope is that growth picks up and consumers flock to the showrooms. 
 Of course, there are other matters to attend to.
The Big Three must continue to hold down costs. They must rebuild morale. They must continue to work on vehicle quality and to reduce the time it takes to bring new products to market.
But the longer the slump lasts, the more likely that new-model-development programs will be delayed months -- or even years -- to save money. General Motors, for example, has already postponed its compact light-truck replacement to 1995, from 1994.
G.M. is in a particular bind. Having announced the elimination of more than 70,000 jobs in the next few years, it must still choose which 21 plants to close. Even that, some say, may not make G.M. competitive with Toyota and Nissan.
"G.M. is working great as a financial institution; it needs desperately to get back in the car business," said Thomas O'Grady, a consultant with Integrated Automotive Resources Inc.
Industry analysts expect the Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation to be profitable this year, provided the economy improves. They say G.M.'s profitability hinges on the write-offs it takes to cover plant closings and employee buyouts, perhaps more than $2 billion.
Most economists do not expect a buying rebound until spring, at the earliest, and, even then it might not amount to much. The WEFA Group, a consulting firm, predicts a 9.6 percent gain in car sales in 1992 and a 9.8 percent gain in light-truck sales.
Total vehicle sales in North America will rise to about 13.6 million units, WEFA predicts, up about one million from this year but short of the robust levels of the late 1980's.
But WEFA warns that if lower interest rates fail to stimulate the economy, the expected 1991 sales of about 12.5 million cars and trucks "may look good."

HEADLINE: BATTERED INDUSTRIES
Picking Up the Pieces in Six Struggling Business Sectors;
Real Estate: The Developers Are Still Sifting Market's Rubble

BYLINE: By RICHARD D. HYLTON

 BODY:
Few industries in recent years have collapsed as completely and rapidly as commerical real estate. Property values are down across the board, vacancies are at all-time highs and with the national economy caught in the grips of recession, the prospect that the demand for space will grow much this year is only a pipe dream.
The commercial real estate industry is trapped in a depression marked by a virtual absence of lenders willing to take any risk. Even the usually optimistic developers and property market analysts are now admitting that things are likely to worsen over the next 18 months, especially for the staggeringly overbuilt office market. 
"One good thing about this downturn is that almost everyone in the real estate community, at least on the East Coast, realizes that we're in a downturn and is working like mad to get us out of it," said J. Philip Rosen, a lawyer with Weil, Gotshal & Manges.
The crisis is rooted in the vast overbuilding of the 1980's brought on by a flood of capital and favorable tax laws. Real estate executives will spend the 1990's trying to bring property values in line with other assets, to work off supply and to regain credit. Some investors are looking for bargains in the rubble, but most lenders are expected to remain cautious.
A recent survey of 100 real estate professionals by the Real Estate Research Corporation concluded that the value of office towers and hotels nationwide would not increase for four or five years.
Respondents said most office markets would worsen until at least 1995, but that the prospects for some -- like Seattle and San Francisco -- looked brighter than others. New York and Boston were among those seen as the worst prospects.
Apartment buildings, which have suffered less in the last two years, were expected to start regaining value this year. Industrial and retail shopping center properties were expected to show recovery in 1993. Land and hotels were expected to remain soft until the second half of the 1990's.
