HEADLINE: Review/Television;
Treating Education Ills As Courtroom Drama

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN

 BODY:
Format gets in the way of content on "Learning in America: Education on Trial," the three-part series that begins tonight at 10 on Channels 13 and 49. Each hour is set in a courtroom and features real lawyers and a real judge. Viewers are to serve as jurors, via a toll-free number, and their verdict will be revealed in the next morning's USA Today.
In tonight's program, "Do We Need a National Report Card?," the witnesses -- Dr. Saul Cooperman, who used to be the New Jersey Education Commissioner; Gov. Roy Romer of Colorado; David Smith, a teacher in an East Harlem secondary school, and Ann Lynch, a former president of the National Parent Teacher Association -- are examined and cross-examined in what turns out to be a fitfully informative hour. 
 The opposing lawyers, Prof. Christopher F. Edley Jr. of Harvard and Prof. John E. Coons of the University of California at Berkeley, seem to be auditioning for "L.A. Law" (from whose cast the host, Richard Dysart, is appropriately drawn) and Judge Connie L. Peterson of Denver's Second Judicial District is there as part of the scenery. The verdict: guilt by association. The adversarial nature of a trial encourages point-scoring, not analysis, and the courtroom play acting seems strained, not to say fake. The issues addressed tonight and in the next two programs -- whether America's public education system is fatally flawed, and how much money should be spent on schools and how it should be allocated -- deserve better. The odd aspect of this show is that it comes from MacNeil/Lehrer Productions, a name associated with rewarding discussions without gimmicks.
 
Learning in America
Education on Trial
A three-part documentary series; directed by Gary Halvorsan; produced by MacNeil/ Lehrer Productions; John O'Toole, executive producer; Richard Dysart, host. At 10 tonight on Channels 13 and 49.
 
'Florio Under Fire'
Channel 5
Tonight at 9
John Roland's interview with Gov. James J. Florio of New Jersey, at 9 tonight on Channel 5, resembles the traffic flow on the state's turnpike: Governor Florio is heading in one direction, Mr. Roland in another. In keeping with the title of the report, "Florio Under Fire," Mr. Roland keeps asking about the Governor's diminished popularity. Governor Florio, not unnaturally for a politician with a 23 percent approval rating, prefers to talk about the long-term problems that his state is suffering along with much of the rest of the country.
Actually seated before a fireplace, wearing a sweater over a tieless shirt, Governor Florio seems reasonably relaxed, all things considered. He remains articulate, if somewhat chastened, and it is unfortunate that Mr. Roland, having made the point repeatedly that the political condition of the Governor is parlous, did not give more attention to details of the programs, especially on education, that Governor Florio seemed eager to discuss. But then it never has been easy to make a U-turn on a turnpike.
 
'Innovation'
Channels 13 and 49
Tomorrow at 10 P.M.
Tomorrow night, at 10 P.M. on Channels 13 and 49, "Innovation" begins a three-part series called "The Future Is Now" that looks at the latest in computers, robotics and so forth around the globe. At a VCR factory in Yokohama, Japan, 70 robots do the job of 200 workers (unemployment is not Japan's problem). A house in Boulder, Colo., can be heated for 75 cents a winter. A Berkeley laboratory is developing a long-lived, inexpensive light bulb.
Jim Hartz makes a cheerful master of ceremonies. Financed by NEC, which describes itself as "a worldwide leader in computers and communications technology," the program is as upbeat as a trade fair.

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
Detroit Fans Cheer for the Quarterback Without the Union Label

BYLINE: By IRA BERKOW

DATELINE: PONTIAC, Mich.

 BODY:
THE last guy anyone in Detroit would have considered a football hero became an unabashed, unmitigated, unquestioned hero yesterday. In this town that wears the union label so proudly, he was considered a strikebreaker. In this town that has boasted such quarterback stars as Bobby Layne and Earl Morrall and Tobin Rote, the guy who came to camp this summer as the team's No. 3 quarterback, who has played in things like the Potato Bowl while attending a community college, who wasn't even drafted by the National Football League after his senior year in college, this guy is today's hero here.
And in this grizzled, battered town, this blue-collar, lunch-bucket town, the guy with the dark, tousled hair and the gentle eyes and the unprepossessing build of, say, a high school chemistry whiz, this guy was cheered wildly by the 78,290 football fans in the Silverdome. 
 What Erik Kramer did to deserve all this was lead the Detroit Lions to a spectacular 38-6 victory over the Dallas Cowboys in the divisional playoffs, placing them in the National Conference championship game Sunday against Washington and giving them a chance to go to the Super Bowl and win their first football championship in 35 years.
Kramer led Detroit simply by completing 29 passes in 38 attempts for 341 yards and three touchdowns. He did it after he was goaded and baited and derided by the Cowboys. The Cowboy defense stacked up on the line, virtually daring him to throw, and anticipating that he would give the Lions' ace runner, Barry Sanders, handoff after handoff.
Earlier in the week, a pair of Cowboy defensive players, Tony Casillas and Jack Del Rio, were outspoken about Kramer, calling him a scab for having crossed the picket lines to play for Atlanta during the strike-interrupted season in 1987.
Del Rio kept up the verbal barrage during the game, or part of it, anyway.
"I didn't hear him make any more remarks after the first quarter," said Kramer.
On the first series for the Lions in the first quarter, Kramer took the Lions 68 yards for a touchdown on five plays, all of them passes, concluding with a 31-yard toss to Willie Green.
"I took the remarks that were made about me as a challenge," said Kramer. "They didn't show me respect; they didn't show our team respect. When I woke up this morning I didn't even feel any jitters. I just wanted to get to the stadium to play."
When it was all over, Kramer said: "It's been a dream season, and this was a dream game. Now we gotta keep it going."
Kramer got his chance this season in the Lions' eighth game, also against the Cowboys. Their first-string quarterback, Rodney Peete, suffered a torn Achilles' tendon on the first series of plays and was lost for the rest of the season. The Lions called on Kramer, who had moved past Andre Ware on the depth chart. Kramer had played three games in the strike season right out of college, had then spent two seasons in the Canadian Football League, and at this time last year, after spending most of the season on the injured reserve list of the Lions, was out of a job. He had traveled a long way to get to this point, from Pierce Junior College in California to North Carolina State to disappointments in the pros.
But against Dallas in that first game, Kramer responded handsomely. He threw two touchdown passes and the Lions won, 34-10. He went on to play a large role as the Lions won six of their next eight games going into yesterday's playoffs. "He's won some games for us," Lions Coach Wayne Fontes said of Kramer. "He's made the big play."
In regard to his once having crossed the picket line, Kramer says: "I had to do it. It was probably the last opportunity I'd have to play in the N.F.L. It was a hard thing to do, but you have to do what's best for you."
Kramer, meanwhile, has demonstrated resilience and poise and skill this season -- his teammates call him "Brass" for his independence and coolness under pressure -- and in a curious way he seems to personify aspects of this city, the part, anyway, that consists of doggedness.
"Times are tough around here, as tough as most people can remember," said Ted Wagner, reduced to part-time work on the assembly line at the Ford Escort plant here. "So that's why a lot of us overlook it that Erik Kramer was a scab. He's our quarterback, and it's the Lions. We're rooting for him."
Motown, from "The Motor City," depends hugely, of course, on one particular industry, automobiles, which is reeling. In a depressed national economy, cars have been hit as hard as any product.
In this area, though, as in many others, sports has often been a great rallying point. And while the Lions have been down for a long time, they remain beloved. Then suddenly this season they began to win again, behind Kramer.
Nevertheless, nobody, even in Detroit, had thought of Kramer in the class of Elway or Marino or Kelly. Or Samuel Gompers.
Ted Wagner shrugged when asked about the non-union quarterback. "Right now," said the part-time assembly-line worker, "we're hoping for two things here. We want the Lions to win and for George Bush and the Big Three" -- representatives of General Motors, Ford and Chrysler -- "to come back from Japan with good news about trade barriers. If that happens, there will be such a warm glow around here you'll see flowers growing in February."
And, oddly enough in this union town, maybe echoes of cheers, too, for Erik Kramer, who once crossed a picket line.

HEADLINE: GOLF;
Season on the Links: More Prosperity Is Just Around the Next Dogleg

BYLINE: By JAIME DIAZ

 BODY:
After a season that gave us the most dramatic Ryder Cup ever played and the thrilling power of John Daly, 1992 will have to go some way to keep from being regarded as an anticlimactic year in golf.
Of course, the same could have been said last January about 1991, the year that followed the social upheaval of Shoal Creek. In fact, 1992 promises a great deal, including Daly's first encounter with the wide fairways and short par 5's of Augusta National, Phil Mickelson's professional debut, and the classic venues of Pebble Beach and Muirfield, where the United States and British Opens will be played. 
 Despite a recession that is pummeling corporate America, the year also promises continued prosperity for golf professionals, as the PGA Tour, the Senior PGA Tour and the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour will play for record purses. Indeed, if anything threatens the appeal of the game in the United States, it is too much prosperity.
 
Fairways Paved With Dollars
 After years of striving to improve conditions for its members, the PGA Tour in particular has evolved into a sleek series of $1 million-plus tournaments where a single victory in a year, or even a solid string of top 10 finishes, is enough to guarantee a free ride on the next year's road to riches.
Any Darwinian would agree that in such an environment, there is diminished motivation to win and keep winning. In fact, the 1980's brought a sharp decline in the number of tour players achieving multiple victories in one year. And without consistent winners, the PGA Tour, even as the general quality of its play gets better and better, is in danger of suffering from a shortage of stars.
The sport has been through other periods when it lacked compelling figures, most notably in the 1930's before the emergence of Sam Snead, and in the mid-1950's as Arnold Palmer was entering his prime. The problem is that despite unprecedented exposure and financial opportunities for players, the star-making machinery in American golf doesn't work as well as it used to.
First, potential stardom in any sport is diminished when circumstances conspire to keep the best from regularly competing against the best, which is the current situation in world golf. Given the fact that top players like Ian Woosnam, Nick Faldo, Seve Ballesteros and Jose Maria Olazabal play primarily on the European PGA Tour, most victories for Americans on the PGA Tour essentially carry an invisible asterisk.
At the same time, parity has undeniably found its way into the well-monied heart of the PGA Tour. In 1991, for only the second time in tour's history, no player won more than two tournaments. On a tightly bunched final money list that was led by Corey Pavin with $979,430, the players who finished 15th through 26th were jammed between winning totals of $597,438 and $546,984. Further evidence of the tight competition was the record number of first-time winners: 13 in 43 events.
 
Good, Bad and Boring
 There are unquestionably more good players than ever on the PGA Tour, which kicks off its 1992 season on Thursday with the Infiniti Tournament of Champions in Carlsbad, Calif. But because these players appear so close in ability, never have so many good golfers engendered so little excitement. To most observers, the PGA Tour lacks the aura of greatness it had when Jack Nicklaus, Lee Trevino, Johnny Miller and Tom Watson were playing their best golf.
"It's gotten very hard to separate yourself from the masses on the regular tour," said Nicklaus, who believes that technological advances in the golf ball and golf course setups that neutralize the shotmaking elements of power and creativity, have made it more difficult for the most talented players to assert their natural advantage. "I think we've got to allow young talent to develop and we've got to have some superstars. We've got to create some situations where Americans excel again."
Off their performance the last two years and by general consensus, the American players with the best chance to do just that are Fred Couples, Paul Azinger and Pavin, each 32 years old, and Payne Stewart, who is 34.
Of those four, Pavin has the most career tour victories with nine, while only Stewart, with the 1989 P.G.A. and last year's United States Open, has won major championships. On paper, these are substantially inferior records when compared with those of the superstars of yesteryear at comparable stages in their careers.
That alone does not preclude that one or more of the foursome won't achieve greatness -- or that Curtis Strange or Australian golfing expatriate Greg Norman won't rediscover the path of excellence they've strayed from. Or that a group of 30-and-under players led by Steve Pate, Davis Love 3d, Billy Andrade, Daly, Andrew Magee and Robert Gamez won't produce a player for the ages.
 
Quality is Eroding
 But the evidence seems to indicate that the current structure of the tour works against Nicklaus's concept of "separation." Some critics even see decadence outracing excellence.
"I think the quality of play in the U.S. has eroded because life is too easy on the American tour," said Mark McCormack, the founder and chairman of International Managment Group, which profits when the players it represents become stars. "Everybody is too pampered. The courses are too manicured. Players don't care about winning enough. They care about making a good check."
Officials of the PGA Tour take strong exception to McCormack's statements, particularly the idea that American players have become complacent with lucre and are less motivated to win.
"If that's so, why are scoring averages going down, cut scores going down, and winning scores going down," said Tim Finchem, the deputy commissioner of the PGA Tour. "The only reason is that everybody is trying to win."
Finchem also contends that the fact that the foreign tours have more multiple winners each year does not mean that their stars are better or more motivated than the Americans, but instead shows that those tours are easier for top players to win on.
"Essentially, the other tours are where the PGA Tour was 20 years ago, where a few people won a lot of golf tournaments," Finchem said. "To go back to that, we'd have to restrict competition, which we believe would be bad for the game. We simply have more guys who are capable of winning golf tournaments, which makes them harder to win."
Perhaps the PGA Tour regulars and their public will have to change their criteria for defining stars in order to continue to have some. But before things get to that point, perhaps an extremely talented and driven player will come along in the United States to remind us of what a star really is.
If that happens in 1992, it will be remembered as a very good year.

HEADLINE: Topics of The Times;
Naivete's Not the Problem

 BODY:
Older Americans are being bilked of their life savings, as documented in a recent report in The Times. The victims, most of them widows, tell, for example, of trusting "a nice young man" who ingratiated himself and then disappeared with most of their bank account. Even sadder were the tales of family thievery. Driven by drugs and the recession, children in soaring numbers prey on elderly parents.
The solution seems obvious: Wise up the gullible old folks. But older adults are no more naive than younger ones. What they lack is not savvy but support, the friendship and confidence they need to sound the alarm. One bilked widow in Asbury Park, N.J., told authorities that she was so lonely "she'd pay the devil to visit her." 
 Most seniors, no matter how isolated, have some contact with others -- the Meals-on-Wheels deliverer, a visiting relative, a neighbor. These people can often detect the first sign of troubles. When they do, they should blow the whistle, loud.

LENGTH: 577 words

HEADLINE: Don't Look for Jobs in Japan

 BODY:
Americans buy much more from the Japanese than the Japanese buy from the U.S. Everybody knows that these huge trade deficits force Americans out of work. That's why President Bush is leading an entourage of big-shot executives to pressure the Japanese to import more goods and thereby create "jobs, jobs, jobs."
But what everybody knows just isn't true. Trade deficits don't cause unemployment; indeed, the number of employed Americans is unrelated to the size of the trade deficit. If that statement seems to contradict common sense, just recall the 1980's, when the U.S. rang up $100 billion trade deficits yet operated near full employment. Bashing Japan might make good campaign rhetoric, but it's unlikely to lower the unemployment rate one tick. 
 Mr. Bush's promise to create jobs is based on the false premise that generating exports or cutting imports is an effective way to create demand for U.S. workers during the current recession. But the U.S. doesn't need the Japanese to create demand: the same economic kick could be delivered if the Federal Reserve Board were to further lower interest rates or Congress were to reduce taxes and raise Government spending.
Indeed, trying to create jobs by manipulating the trade deficit would be absurdly difficult, requiring the restructure of Japanese society before the recession runs its course in the next couple of months.
Besides timing, the attempt to drive down the trade deficit would likely be self-defeating. If Americans were to buy fewer Japanese cars -- which would, in turn, require selling fewer dollars to buy yen -- the value of the dollar would rise. That would make U.S. exports more expensive, cutting sales. Employment in Detroit auto factories would rise. But employment in the airplane, agriculture and computer software industries would plummet by comparable amounts. Mr. Bush wouldn't be creating jobs, he'd be swapping jobs between Detroit and Iowa.
There is a constructive spin Mr. Bush could put on his Asian mission, but it wouldn't pack much wallop. By blocking imports, Japan prevents its trading partners from selling what they make best. That forces them to produce more of what they make less well, lowering their living standards a bit. The biggest losers, however, are Japanese consumers -- who, for example, pay astoundingly high prices for domestically grown rice that can be produced far more cheaply by the United States.
So while Mr. Bush can't accurately promise that knocking down Japanese trade barriers will produce more jobs, he could rightly promise that it would raise U.S. living standards a tad. That's not an exciting message, but at least it's honest.
The unpleasant truth is that U.S. trade deficits are home-grown. They occur because Americans overconsume -- buying more goods than they produce. The excess consumption comes from foreign suppliers -- if not from Japan, then from Korea, Germany or Canada. As long as Americans persist in outspending their income, cutting the trade deficit with Japan to zero would solve nothing.
There is a serious consequence of insufficient saving, but it's not the trade deficit. A country that saves too little invariably invests too little in new machinery and technology. Over time that means slow productivity growth and stagnant incomes.
Mr. Bush chose the wrong problem and offered the wrong solution. The trade deficit isn't related to the number, or productivity, of American jobs.

HEADLINE: Essay;
Redskins' Revenge

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The Washington Redskins are winning; "Native Americans" are losing.
While the politically correct fret that the word "redskins" may be taken as an ethnic slur, they ignore a far more serious assault on the character and traditions of our aboriginal Americans. 
 With the cooperation of greedy tribal leaders and their fast-buck white lawyers, tribes from the Chippewa in Wisconsin to the Barona in California are being victimized and corrupted by promoters of organized gambling.
It began in seeming innocence a decade ago with bingo games on the reservations. Then half the states in the U.S., under the delusion that good ends could be achieved by bad means, legalized gambling. (It's called "gaming" or "off-track betting" or "casino promotion of tourism"; never use a dirty word like "gambling.")
Because Indian reservations retain a form of sovereignty that limits control by state governments, shrewd gambling operators saw a way to get around local restrictions and steal a march on the local casinos. The Supreme Court held in 1987 that states that permitted gambling could not deny its triumphs, glories and spoils to Indian reservations.
That opened the floodgates to those who wanted to exploit the special status of Indians. Today, gambling dens fronted by Indians are a billion-dollar-a-year business and mushrooming; tribal lands are illuminated by neon; tribes reaching out for more suckers are litigating with state officials about whether one-armed bandits are illegal slot machines or merely "technological aids" to bingo players.
The corruption of the original American ethnic group is taking place under the cover of a public relations campaign to show how gambling is good for impoverished Indians. Profits go to the tribes, goes the story, which then build schools and hospitals and lift the unemployed families off welfare.
Baloney; malarkey; oompah. The few facilities gambling built are Potemkin villages. Casino gambling will help the average Indian as much as the New York State Lottery has provided great new facilities for the average schoolchild. The great benefit of gambling profits to the public has always been a sham; it has proved itself to be the most regressive and shameful tax on any state's books. New Jersey and Nevada, those paragons of state virtue, have led the way.
With the notable exception of ABC News, investigative media have shied away from this national scandal. Many have been intimidated by immediate charges of racism by Indian "leaders" who benefit most from the deals like those being set up across the country by Grand Casinos Inc., a company whose over-the-counter stock is being promoted by non-Indians.
What a perversion of affirmative action; is this the proper answer to the massacre of innocent Indians at Wounded Knee?
In fact, the corruption of gambling is ripping many tribes apart. The Mohawk fighting along the U.S.-Canadian border last year was based largely on control of gambling money. The introduction of slot machines all but insures further mob penetration and moral degradation.
Big-time gambling is an organized vice deserving of no government promotion or identification with a single ethnic group. All lotteries are con games, manipulating our something- for-nothing lust. (I throw away any junk mail with a picture of Ed McMahon on it.)
Is there no tribal leader courageous enough to come forward to tell Indian children they come from the stock of Sitting Bull and Crazy Horse and that their role models need not be George Raft and Meyer Lansky?
Are there no genuine friends of a poverty-stricken group willing to put aside tut-tutting about misperceived slurs long enough to call attention to the real cultural and moral crisis facing the Indian nations today?
We cannot deny Indians their right to compete with states in attracting suckers of all races. The answer is to get both state governments and Indian tribes out of the gambling business. Public promotion of betting is wrong; it corrupts people and politicians; it should never be the goal of public policy.
If we fail to stop the casinoization of the reservations, we will surely change the name of the football team to honor the next generation of aboriginal Americans. We'll call them the Washington Croupiers.

HEADLINE: CHRONICLE

BYLINE: By NADINE BROZAN

 BODY:
For THOMAS P. WALSH, becoming director of public safety for the newly organized Times Square Business Improvement District, is a homecoming of sorts. A former New York City police officer who rose to become the department's highest-ranking officer for the southern half of Manhattan, he began his career 35 years ago on foot patrol on West 44th Street. Now he is back in the neighborhood, in charge of recruiting, training and supervising 40 public safety officers for the district, which went into operation last week.
"My first post was in 1957 on 44th Street between Broadway and Ninth Avenue," said Mr. Walsh, who retired in October as patrol borough commander for Manhattan South. " 'Little Abner' was playing then, so was Ethel Merman in 'Happy Hunting.' The biggest problems had to do with sex and prostitution and that has improved immeasurably. 
 "But the crack epidemic has knocked everyone around," he said. "Back then we didn't even have narcotics, then as time went by, we saw heroin and stuff but nothing that has affected conditions the way crack does."
Mr. Walsh, who was the principal planner and chief enforcement officer for the parades celebrating the end of the Persian Gulf war and the visit of Nelson Mandela, and who has overseen three New Year's Eve police operations in Times Square, said he has high hopes for his new job. "I am here to make the crossroads of the world more refined, helping to attract more tourists and citizens to the Great White Way, to make it the showplace it should be." And, he added, "I will be on the streets everyday."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: PRESS;
Industry's Turmoil Is Shaking Out Other Fields

BYLINE: By ALEX S. JONES

 BODY:
SINCE newspaper advertising began a steep decline about 18 months ago, many peripheral businesses and organizations that are nourished by the newspaper industry have gone on short rations.
For instance, as budgets have been tightened, newspapers have been cutting back sharply on sending employees to weeklong bouts of training. In December, The Philadelphia Inquirer eliminated all conventions, seminars, group meetings and outside training, except those related to the opening of a new printing plant. 
 "It is always unfortunately one of the obvious first costs upon which the publisher's eye falls," said Robert J. Haiman, president of the Poynter Institute for Media Studies in St. Petersburg, Fla.
A typical weeklong course on the finer points of reporting and writing at the Poynter Institute costs about $1,200, not including air fare.
The institute's programs are still oversubscribed, Mr. Haiman said, but instead of 80 applications for 16 available slots, there are now about 35. And he said that while those attending a writing seminar in the past would have been motivated by a desire for self-improvement, the current crop of journalists seemed to be driven by a more economic motive -- attracting readers to their papers.
The American Press Institute, a training center outside Washington that provides a wide array of programs aimed at middle and upper management, has seen its typical class shrink to 25 from 32.
William L. Winter, president of the institute, said publishers were still willing to spend scarce dollars for training, provided there appeared to be a payoff.
For instance, when a seminar for circulation managers drew few participants last year, the institute canceled that seminar and substituted one called "New Product Development" on ways to sell advertising.
"It was oversubscribed in two days," Mr. Winter said.
The advertising drought in the newspaper industry has only heightened the intense rivalry among the four big trade magazines: Editor & Publisher, News Inc., Newspapers & Technology and Presstime.
For decades, the weekly Editor & Publisher had the industry almost to itself, and it remains the dominant publication in total advertising.
Still, times are tough for E.& P., as it is known. Steven A. Townsley, E.& P.'s advertising manager, said advertising pages from industry vendors like press manufacturers and image advertising from newspapers had fallen about 30 percent in 1991.
E.& P.'s extensive classified pages have long been the industry's bazaar, with voluminous listings for services, used equipment and jobs.
But Mr. Townsley said classified volume was down about 30 percent, and the only category showing growth was "positions wanted."
The newspaper recession has hit E.& P. just as it has come under assault from two upstart monthly publications that emerged at the crest of the 1980's newspaper boom: Newspapers & Technology, which began publication in 1988, and News Inc., which started in 1989.
Newspapers & Technology focuses on the production and distribution of newspapers, and is sent free to about 21,000 newspaper executives who use -- and buy -- equipment.
News Inc., which -- like E.& P. -- is more broadly focused and covers journalistic issues -- has adopted a strategy of increasing advertising by offering packages in which, for instance, an advertiser buys four ads and gets two more for free.
Not surprisingly, both E.& P. and Newspapers & Technology sneer that News Inc. is padding its linage figures. Jack Berkowitz, publisher of News Inc., sneers back that his competitors are behind the times.
Just who is winning this race is not easy to determine.
While Mr. Berkowitz acknowledged that News Inc. was not yet profitable, he said that paid ad pages rose significantly last year and that it had supplanted Newspapers & Technology as the "No. 2 book" in ad pages.
"Oh, gimme a break; that's not true," said Mary L. Van Meter, Newspapers & Technology's publisher, who said that her ad pages were up by 20 percent for 1991 and that the magazine was well ahead of News Inc. for the year. She also said her magazine was profitable.
Presstime, a monthly underwritten by the American Newspaper Publishers Association, only began selling ads in 1984. James E. Donahue, the publisher, said sales were off about 20 percent last year, after declining in 1990 and 1989 as well.
Indeed, the publishers association and other trade and professional organizations are feeling the pinch.
Joe Lorfano, an association spokesman, said the number of member newspapers had declined to 1,324 from a peak of 1,430 during the 1980's. While membership declined by two papers in 1989, there has been a net loss of 94 papers since 1990, when the newspaper business began to turn sour. About a third of those papers either closed or merged, while the rest resigned from the association.
The association's annual convention, which is attended by vendors who pay stiff registration fees, is one of the group's principal sources of income.
But last year's convention in Vancouver, British Columbia, attracted about 1,400 people, compared with more than 3,000 in New York in 1987.
The American Society of Newspaper Editors is feeling an even tighter squeeze. Lee Stinnett, the executive director, said that membership was down about 10 percent since the peak in the late 80's and that attendance at last year's annual convention was off 50 percent from a year earlier.
"We've been burning up our modest reserves because we've taken the philosophy that we don't want to make drastic changes in our fee structure for fear of discouraging people from attending and joining," Mr. Stinnett said.
Indeed, the society has been operating at a deficit for the last three years and Mr. Stinnett said the reserves were almost exhausted.

HEADLINE: Taiwan Voted forStatus Quo, not One China;
A Stinging Defeat

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Contrary to your Dec. 24 editorial on the Dec. 21 Taiwan election, the ruling Kuomintang Party "victory" was not "a vote for one China." How could it be? The Kuomintang-dominated Government banned the opposition party's platform of an independent "Republic of Taiwan" even from election posters. The Government arrested a score of pro-independence leaders on election eve. 
 The Kuomintang spent millions of dollars buying votes throughout the island, as many election observers attested. The Government subdivided Taiwan into myriad tiny districts tailored for Kuomintang candidates.
The Kuomintang also controls the electronic media. The triumph of its propaganda can be seen in your acceptance of the Kuomintang line on the election outcome.
The election was a stinging defeat for the Kuomintang's policy of reunification with the mainland. In 1990, using the same districting tactics, the ruling party was able to garner more than 90 percent of the vote in elections for local officials. This time, despite control of the airwaves, vote buying, gerrymandering, crackdowns and propaganda, it came up with only 70 percent of the vote.
The 24 percent of the population that voted for the Democratic Progressive Party also gave the lie to the Government claim that only 6 percent of the people support independence. The figure is far higher. On an island where advocating "one China, one Taiwan" can bring charges of sedition and a stiff jail sentence, pollsters are unlikely to get the truth to questions about independence.
The "One China" policy is a fantasy the Kuomintang uses to justify its a grip on Taiwan maintained by a vast security network and the ever-present threat of detention and imprisonment. It is also the policy of the totalitarian government on the mainland, whose claim to Taiwan is dubious at best.
Forty-five years after the Nationalist Party massacred 20,000 people and a generation of the island's leaders in a 1947 revolt, the Taiwanese still hunger for compensation and justice. The delight with which the Taiwanese evade taxes and regulations, and the enormous underground economy are expressions of the contempt in which the Kuomintang is held across the island.
With a Government that permits the islanders little say in their national affairs, and the electoral cheating the Kuomintang uses to stay in power, it is only a matter of time until the ruling party itself brings about the result it is trying to forestall: Taiwan independence.
 
DAVID W. TSAI
President, Center for
Taiwan International Relations
Washington, Dec. 30, 1991

HEADLINE: Behind the Iron Hand at Tenneco

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOUSTON

 BODY:
In his first months at Tenneco, Michael H. Walsh has practically run a seminar on how to act swiftly to alter the course of an industrial giant in distress.
Even so, it will take a few years before anyone can applaud Mr. Walsh for administering at Tenneco Inc. his successful industrial shock therapy, which he most recently demonstrated at the Union Pacific Railroad. 
 Tenneco's troubles of too many plants and workers, huge debt payments, a bloated bureaucracy and fast gains by foreign rivals provide a classic profile of big American manufacturing and service companies hobbled by the managerial sins of the 1980's.
 
Follows G.E. Example
 Mr. Walsh's philosophy of urgent, tough actions to jolt businesses into keeping up with fast-moving markets has become fashionable with corporate directors. A new generation of chief executives has arisen, of which Mr. Walsh is at the forefront, that patterns itself after John F. Welch Jr., who revitalized the General Electric Company in the last decade.
"What we really did here was sit down and say, 'Look, here are the facts of life, here are the ranges of options we've got, and we've got to act quickly,' " Mr. Walsh said. "I don't think it's being tough or not tough. I think it's dealing with reality or not dealing with reality."
The drive and speed of Mr. Walsh's style is exemplified in his play as well as his work. He rides his stationary bicycle with such intensity in a half-hour drill most mornings that he recently developed back spasms.
For managers at Tenneco, which turns out products ranging from aircraft carriers and J. I. Case farm equipment to Walker mufflers and Monroe shock absorbers, Mr. Walsh's harsh medicine has forced them to search for ways to shed 6,000 of the company's 92,000 workers by the end of this year. They have already squeezed annual operating costs and capital budgets by a combined $500 million. Mr. Walsh, who is president and chief executive, preserved another $200 million by ordering the yearly dividend sliced in half.
 
Awaits the Payoff
 These moves, combined with sales of assets and preferred stock that raised more than $1 billion in cash, have put Tenneco's finances on firmer footing now than when he arrived Sept. 1. But to Mr. Walsh, a voluble one-time Federal prosecutor who sizes up events in blunt terms, the payoff for Tenneco must come in lower costs, higher profits and bigger market shares for each of its six operating companies.
If executives do not achieve specific targets, "they damn well better be able to demonstrate why they haven't, and what the corrective actions are going to be to get on track -- and in a hurry," he said evenly. "At Tenneco, we've been too understanding of excuses; that's why targets haven't been met."
Mr. Walsh is demanding improvements for 1992 regardless of what happens in the global and national economies. Last month, he gathered the dozen senior managers who head the six Tenneco companies and worked out specific goals for each company to pare costs and raise profits and sales.
He plans to convene the same group every month to review the results in close detail, such as how much less scrap Tenneco's Packaging Corporation of America is throwing out at its many box plants.
Tenneco executives have other symbols of Mr. Walsh's austerity. He closed the executive dining room at the company headquarters in downtown Houston and canceled a private Tenneco suite at the Helmsley Park Lane Hotel in New York.
 
Possible Loss of Over $1 Billion
 Tenneco's losses for 1991 might exceed $1 billion when they are announced late this month. The culprits were the high costs, weak sales and idled plant capacity at J. I. Case, the largest of the operating companies.
With dealer inventories bulging and Case's output down 34 percent in the third quarter, Mr. Walsh ordered plants shut and a winnowing of product lines that resulted in a $413 million write-down of assets in October. Case's operating losses for the first nine months of 1991 were $439 million, assuring the unit of its sixth -- and biggest -- loss in the last nine years.
Mr. Walsh would not comment about his profit goals for 1992, but analysts said Tenneco should earn a lackluster $300 million on revenues of $15 billion.
They added that the tough message to cut costs and bolster profits was sorely missing at Tenneco in recent years under James L. Ketelsen. Mr. Ketelsen, 60, had been Tenneco's leader since 1978 after a stint at running Case.
 
Forced to Cut Prices
 Analysts said his spending to revive Case with new products and his efforts to buoy Tenneco's share price with a $3.20 yearly dividend and the repurchase of 5.4 million shares for $300 million ignored a rising debt burden. Long-term debt exceeded 56 percent of capital at the end of 1990, before the debacle at Case unfolded.
"Tenneco was a company with severe financial problems that didn't realize it," said Eli S. Lustgarten, a machinery analyst at Paine Webber Inc. "The company is bleeding, losing a lot of money, and Walsh needs to get profits to a level that will satisfy both shareholders and lenders."
Mr. Ketelsen might have sealed his demise a year ago when he stoked production rates at Case in the face of flagging sales for tractors, combines and other farm machinery, Mr. Lustgarten said. Whether it was intended or not, the effect was to fatten 1990 profits at the expense of 1991 results.
Case was forced into huge price discounts last spring to find buyers for the equipment, and Mr. Ketelsen's backing among Tenneco directors splintered. They turned to Mr. Walsh, who had spurned their earlier offer to run Case, according to people familiar with the search. Mr. Walsh became president Sept. 10, chief executive on New Year's Day and will add the chairman's title when Mr. Ketelsen retires in May.
In addition to Case, the world's second-largest maker of farm equipment after John Deere, Tenneco owns a big natural gas pipeline, the world's largest shipyard, and three companies each with sales of more than $1 billion in auto parts, chemicals and packaging.
Mr. Walsh came to Tenneco with mostly glowing reviews from Wall Street for squeezing costs, gaining market share and bolstering profits in five years as head of the Union Pacific Railroad.
For example, one study showed that the only task for more than 200 clerks at the railroad was correcting errors committed in one of every five bills sent to customers, Mr. Walsh said. By reducing errors to fewer than one in every 20 bills, the railroad saved several million dollars in clerical salaries and benefits.
Mr. Walsh likes spicing his interviews and speeches about business problems with these kind of anecdotes as well as aphorisms borrowed from popular icons in business and sports.
Besides Mr. Welch at General Electric ("Either control your own destiny, or someone else will"), among Mr. Walsh's favorites are Vince Lombardi ("It's a game of inches") and Tom Peters, the management adviser and author ("Every company in America is trying harder, but only a few are actually getting better").
A star running back in his Oregon high school days, Mr. Walsh attended Stanford University on a football scholarship. Multiple shoulder separations and operations forced him to give up the sport.
 
Defender and Prosecutor
 After getting an economics degree at Stanford, Mr. Walsh worked in the Johnson Administration in the first class of White House Fellows. He attended Yale Law School, won an appellate court competition and later became a national director of Common Cause, the volunteer political action group.
He started his law career in San Diego in the company of rapists, murderers and drug dealers as a public defender, then rose to the post of United States Attorney for the Southern District of California at the age of 35. Mr. Walsh abandoned his law career three years later when the Cummins Engine Company persuaded him to manage part of its international manufacturing operations.
There he dealt for the first time with the cost and quality problems of a global American industry. "He never did anything brilliant at Cummins, it was just good blocking and tackling," said Mitchell Quain, an analyst at Wertheim Schroder & Company in New York. Mr. Walsh rose to head Cummins's global parts business and was an executive vice president before he departed for Union Pacific in 1986.
"You can make a pretty good case that you have to be an idiot to take this job, particularly with what I left at Union Pacific," he said about his move to Tenneco. "But you have to see the opportunity. Even given the difficulties at Case, there are significant strengths to build on in each and every business."
Details of Mr. Walsh's employment contract will not be made public until Tenneco mails proxy statements to stockholders this spring. He has only said that the rewards are linked to Tenneco's financial results. Union Pacific paid him $1 million in salary and bonuses in 1990.
Mr. Walsh's rush to avoid a financial crisis at Tenneco this fall preserved more than $2 billion, but his challenges are much broader. Before going to company directors and Wall Street with a long-term growth plan, he must grade the executives he inherited and calculate growth prospects for companies that compete in industries in which he has little experience.
At the same time, he must lead a global organization through a wrenching contraction that may go much farther than the cutbacks at Case. The shipyard in Newport News, Va., for instance, is likely to see fewer Pentagon orders. And some new projects that Mr. Ketelsen had bankrolled are already gone.
For now, Mr. Walsh is making few predictions of additional changes this year, except that he has no plans to sell any of the businesses.
"It will be a very difficult turnaround, but you have to give the board credit for bringing in somebody of the caliber of Mike Walsh," Mr. Lustgarten of Paine Webber said. "He's an executive with the capability and perseverance to do it."

Chart: Michael H. Walsh
Born: July 8, 1942
Hometown: Portland, Ore.
Education: B.A., Stanford University, 1964; L.L.B. Yale Law School, 1969.
Career highlights: White House fellow and special assistant to Agriculture Secretary Orville Freeman, 1965-66; lawyer, public defender, assistant U.S. Attorney forSouthern District of California, 1969-76; U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of California, 1977-80; vice president, Cummins Engine Company, 1980-84; executive vice president, operations and international, 1984-86; executive vice president and general manager for worldwide engine components, 1986; chairman and chief executive, Union Pacific Railroad, 1986-91; named president, Tenneco, Sept. 10, 1991; became chief executive on Jan. 1.
Hobbies: Skiing, horseback riding and jogging. (pg. D5)
 
Chart: "Michael Walsh's Fast Start at Tenneco"
 
1991
Aug. 7: Named to become president on Oct. 1, chief executive on Jan. 1, 1992, and chairman on May 17, 1992.
Sept. 1: Started work at Tenneco.
Sept. 10: Named president, effective immediately.
Sept. 11: Announced a $2 billion resturcturing plan in which he pledged to cut annual costs by $250 million, reduce capital spending in 1992 by $250 million, sell more than $500 million in assets, raise more than $500 million in equity and save $200 million by cutting in half the dividend on comon shares.
Oct. 22: Announced plans to trim the corporate staff by year-end by 230 people, or 36 percent, as part of the restructuring.
Oct. 29: Reported loss of $693 million for third quarter, including a $413 million charge for write-down at J.I. Case unit and a $169 million operating loss at Case.
Nov. 25: Agreed to sell its natural gas liquids unit to Enron Corporation for $632 million, including $523 million in cash.
Dec. 4:Announced plans to cut work force at J.I. Case by 4,000, to 21,000by the end of 1992.
Dec. 17: Sold 17 million preferred shares, raising $516 million.
 
1992
Jan. 1: Became chief executive.
Jan. 2: Completed the sale of natural gas liquids unit to Enron and sold three short-line railroads to other buyers for $54 million in cash. (pg. D5)
